review:
Finally!!! It seems as though this day would never come (seeing how the 'Infinity' name was spoken by Asus months and months ago). I had been pounding away on my TF101, holding out patiently & impatiently, until I could actually grasp the TF700T. Just ordered mine about 32 hours ago and selected one day shipping. I will say it lives up to the hype! Display of course it out of this universe. Extremely fast, even for ICS. I hear that Jelly Bean will be making its way to Asus in the next week or so, which should smooth out all transitions and swipes. Overall I am very impressed, and after a few minor updates (as usual) this tablet will officially be the beast of the block!
(FYI: for any tablet ever, there is no need to get 3G/4G service plan. Why? Cost too much, wifi is everywhere, tether, wifi access fees (if needed) will be cheap than a monthly bill,

This tablet is amazing, the screen is beautiful (its brightness will make you go "wow"). Works super fast. Im not gonna get into too much detail, Im sure if you are thinking about getting this tablet you already read all the good reviews on the tech sites so if you are still undecided on wether to get it or not let me just tell you this: YOU WILL LOVE IT!!! It's a beautiful piece of technology. I just got mine yesterday (July 18th)from Office Depot, and from the moment I saw it I fell in love with it, my wife loves it too so we are getting a second one for her.
Just stop reading and buy it, you won't regret it ;)

EDIT:
I TOTALLY REGRET getting this piece of crap for $500 when it was released, on paper this tablet was the dream tablet we all had been waiting for back in 2012, during the first days of use it was a work horse but as soon as I loaded some apps onto it the nightmare began, updating apps made me wanna kill myself, it would take hours to update a few apps so I stopped updating them altogether, wifi drains the battery like crazy, Asus did nothing to fix the issues. That was the first and last time I looked at a product from Asus. Now I have a $500 (which was the amount I paid) paper weight, which I occasionally grab to check Facebook. STAY AWAY!!! You have been warned.

Seriously, this is the single greatest product in the history of mankind! This is now the official benchmark that all other products should be placed against.

The first failure was 10 days out of the initial warranty, they said to send back at my expense, they would honor it.$18 to UPS, and they sent a bill for $205, to repair. I had a backup warranty with my credit card company, that bailed me out for a new one at about that price ( Now it appears to be $322. Good grief.)
I don't trust their products.

The first year of using the tablet was perfectly fine then, overtime it got slower...I mean really slow to use. I thought it was the software and rolled it back to its previous version and that didn't help. Tried everything that I could and the tablet was still slow in doing everything.

I believe that technology and the demand the software had on this tablet was too great and it just couldn't manage over time. it may be the processor or the type of storage that was used. I do not recommend getting this tab

This tablet can still be used however, I recommend getting something something more modern and is supported by the manufactured.

Keep your hands away. There is no client who bought this Tablet and is still happy after a couple of weeks. This tablet looks good on specs but has terrible problems with performance. Avoid these abominations like the plague.  Seriously these are simply digital disasters. My company purchased about 20 of these a couple years ago much to the chagrin of 90% of the sales staff.  Our IT manager has a serious and unfounded hatred of all things Apple (You are paying for the name)  and made a huge and very costly mistake not listening to input from the vast majority of folks that were going to use them.  The owner went all out and purchased the TF700 Transformer and Keyboard sparing no expensive so everyone was extremely excited and thankful for his gracious generosity and prepared to make the most of this new "tool" especially in front of clients.  Well that was the beginning of Asus Hell for the vast majority of recipients of this product. These have proven to be excruciatingly slow, buggy, and simply unreliable.  Mine has been back to IT 4 or 5 times and most sale people have simply surrendered and use their personal pad while in the field.  As of last week mine will not even turn on and I've been to every forum I can find and tried all the known tricks of the trade to no avail.  I've also noticed a tremendous amount of frustration exhibited by other Asus pad owners as well. I still appreciate our owners generosity as this was a tremendous spend for a small business products distribution company (100 or so workers)  and just wish he would have chosen another brand.  By the way I am not an Asus hater as I have used 2 of their high end routers for 2 or 3 years and they are beasts and work flawlessly...

*This is all my opinion based on my experience*

I purchased the  TF700T right when it came out in 2012. Specifically I wanted the quad core Tegra 3 and the 1920x1200 IPS screen.

Here is what I got - a tablet that doesn't work. 4 years later this tablet has never worked. Asus abandoned it shortly after releasing it, stopped updating it, because they knew the design was flawed.

The main issue with these is slowness. They will stop responding for 2-3 minutes at a time and when they do work, they are slow. Very, very slow. Painfully slow. 486dx66 slow. Unusably slow. You cannot predict the slowness either. Sometimes simply opening the settings menu might cause the tablet to go into a mini-coma for 3-4 minutes.

I have tried all kinds of custom firmware, official firmware, google stock firmware, nothing works. Asus support is worthless.

Cyanogen 11 works the best, but it's not great. The version of android this shipped with did not support TRIM, which is a major issue. This thing needs to have TRIM run DAILY for ANY kind of usability. The best thing to do is set the CPU to performance, set the minimum CPU to 600+ MHz, set background process limit to MAX 4, and you will have SOME KIND of experience - it will be a BAD EXPERIENCE, but you will at least be able to read an email.

Long story short - Asus screwed a lot of people with these devices. I'll never buy another Asus product. This design is JUNK. Avoid. They are cheap now - that's for a reason. AVOID.

This is the most expensive paper weight I have ever purchased. There is a youtube video with a couple other comments about how slow this table is and what a piece of junk Asus cranked out on this one. I trusted Asus as they make good motherboards and monitors but this is the most frustrating thing I have ever attempted to use. I always end up going to my computer because this tablet is soooooooooo slow! Every page takes forever to load it's like going back to dial up internet connection. There are so many glitches, the e-reader won't finish downloading books and I have to download them every time I want to read so if I am somewhere I don't have wifi I'm out of luck. I spend more time trying to solve problems than using it. Please do not buy this one and save yourself endless hours of frustration!

Slow like hell! I don't know how some of the people would praise this deadbeat unit, what I have experienced after I got it only made me speechless. I have another first generation EEE Transformer T100, but it seems that except the resolution is not as sharp as this TF700T, all the other functions are way better and faster than TF700T. When used T100 to read some ebooks, there's no lag, slow down or freeze up ever, yet this darn TF700T, even the simple text page of the ebook would be a heavy work for it, it would freeze up after just a few pages. It only showed that the meager 1GB memory on this unit is not enough even to handle several pages turning over of any ebook. The finished page would suddenly freeze up, a circular mark would appear in the middle of the page, it'd circle and circle and circle for so long and then, the whole screen would turn black, all the touching function on the screen would disappear, the only way to make it work again is to shut down and restart it again.

I think the TF700T got very serious problems all over it. When I tried to use the browser(s), the browser(s) would suddenly notify you the "XXXbroswer has stopped working, would you like to Wait or...." WTF?! Even using browser to surf the web would be a mission impossible?

Yes, TF700T is lighter than T100; yes, the pad feels lighter with more comfortable edges around to hold onto; yes, the resolution is sharper than the old model....But Asus, what else this TF700T is better than your orginal first generation T100? The keyboard still got the same problem when you try to type something, it jumps around like crazy blind mad guy, if you don't pay attention all the time during your typing, you would find what you have typed already messed up with what you've already typed, making the whole text become a unreadable garbled mess. In order to make TF700T lighter, Asus cut so many corners to get that result, yet at the same time, sacrificed all the important parts and functions to make it a better and newer device.

Three year ago, I purchased a TF700T tablet for the purpose of being able to read and respond to my emails while out of the contry. Since I travel only once or twice a year, I did not use the tablet much. About 6 months ago, I noticed that this Asus tablet could not boot properly. In a few weeks, the tablet could not boot at all. I contacted the Asus customer service for assistance. After several email exchanges I had become obvious that the tablet needed to be rerooted. Asus provided me with an internet site that allouded me to dowanload the required software. Fortunately I have a family member is are very skilled with this kind of process. Since, the tablet has functioned OK.

Major regret purchasing this thing. I got the detachable keyboard as well. My main complaint is performance. I power the device on and it takes a couple minutes (literally) to see the login screen. Most of the time the screen dims and the device goes to sleep within 5 seconds of the login screen appearing. Sometimes I am ready to start typing my password immediately; other times I have to push the power button again to revive the login screen (cue another short delay). I start typing my password, and... sluggish response. Is this thing registering my keystrokes? Oops, it thinks I typed the same character twice. Backspace... (wait...) ok, try again. Poking each key deliberately and slowly this time so I don't "overwhelm" the machine with input. You get the idea.
This sort of performance continues with apps, particularly Google apps (?!). Reducing the number of apps I had installed helped somewhat. I think I have about 34 apps installed, including the ones that came pre-installed and can't be uninstalled. Google Chrome comes pre-installed. Using it is like browsing the internet at 2400 baud (that's late 1980's tech level). Observing the device using the "System Monitor Lite" app showed the CPUs running at 465 MHz 38% of the time, and 1.5 GHz 42% of the time. Why is the My Library app using up 15% of my CPU? I haven't added any new documents. There aren't any updates. I didn't launch it. Why is it running?

When I use this device, I would say 75% of the time I give up in frustration. Is it Asus? Is it Android? My sense is that it's Android, but it could be the poorly written bloatware Asus installed and forces me to keep.

My advice would be: Look into the Apple iPad.
I own another ASUS  tablet  and this one is underpowered and overloaded.. Hangs up all the time, bought "USED"  and got screwed as far as I am concerned.. It sits in a drawer..

The tablet is practically unusable due to lagging performance issues.  I'm a fairly technical guy and have tried everything, including totally removing the firmware and replacing it with a ROM maximized for performance, and it still performs like absolute crap.  Do not buy this tablet for any reason, do not buy it if it's through a cheap 3rd party reseller, and don't ever buy it through Amazon.  I have older tablets that perform better than this POS and this tablet has gone down as one of my worst gadget buying decisions I've ever made.

For anyone interested: I've wiped the tablet repeatedly, tried killing backgrounds apps, tried various roms like Cyanogenmod, Crombi, etc.  The tablet lags sporadically and rarely the same place twice, in and out of menus, typing, and it's been that way straight out of the box.  Conferring with other tf700t users has confirmed the same problem.
Great looking tablet that runs well. Easy, no hassle set-up that can be done in minutes. Very pleased with the way the tablet moves. Awesome aluminum backing. Stylish and durable. Highly recommended!

Had this tablet for about six months, and I have a real love/hate relationship with it.

Works well for reading ebooks, watching Netflix, and sending email, etc. However, the processor is so underpowered that internet browsing is glacially slow and the whole thing grinds nearly to a halt if you try to use more than a couple of apps at the same time. For example, when I'm watching a movie, I like to be able to pause it, then jump online to look up something about the movie. Unfortunately, most of the time, when I do that, web pages take forever to load, or just hang up completely. Gets so frustrating, I just want to hurl it across the room.

Also has a really hard time with a lot of games, especially if they are graphics-intensive. Some newer games (Kill Shot Bravo, for example) won't run at all on this tablet. And, it won't update past Jellybean, so there's that.

There's a software glitch common to these tablets that causes a thin black line to flash on the screen occasionally. It's annoying, but fortunately does not do anything more serious than that.

Physically, it's a pretty rugged little machine. I dropped mine onto a tile floor from about 2.5 feet and it landed on one corner. Bent it a little, but (knock wood) caused no problems.

All in all, a good portable machine for movies and reading, or for light tasks (I use it to run Outlook, OneNote, etc). But not the machine for you if you need it to do a little more heavy-lifting.

I got mine refurbished for $150. For that price, I feel satisfied. But I would not recommend paying full price. It isn't worth it.

my problems are not with the tablet itself so much as ASUS. I bought the Tablet in  2012, adored the thing, used it all the time and a year later bought the keyboard for it and loved it even more. However shortly after I bought the keyboard ( 3-4 months) the tablet died..just a vibration inside but no lights/ no screen no sound. I sent it to ASUS (sadly just a few weeks out of warranty) and they wanted 250 to fix it (no damage, they said the motherboard was dead) I spent almost 500 on this tablet at the time ( not counting the keyboard) but when I wanted it fixed they wanted to charge me more to fix it than a new one would have cost me.
 At the time of purchase this was one of the most expensive tablets on the market. I expected it to last longer than under 2 years. I still have it, they returned it to me unrepaired. It's been sitting in the box they returned it in since (3 years ago) I've gone around and around with asus on their website, twitter and facebook and they refuse to do anything for me.

I just got this tablet back out to give it another try, after about a year of it sitting in the box on the shelf. I should have left it there. It was a frustrating reminder of why it ended up there, and just how disappointing this tablet has constantly been.

Even while I'm writing this, I'm wondering why I would bother to write a review for a product that's almost 4 years old, and that almost no one could possibly be even considering buying at this point. But I guess that is a testament to just how thoroughly, crushingly, and repeatedly disappointed I have been with it, while even so wanting to like it for that entire time...

Let me start off by saying that this is one of the most elegant hardware implementations (NOTE: the _visible_ part of the HW) that I've ever owned. This is a beautiful tablet, with what is still one of the most gorgeous screens I've ever seen. I've owned both the tablet and the keyboard dock for 3+ years, and it still looks and feels like it did out of the box - solid, weighty without being heavy or clunky, an absolutely perfect external package.

Unfortunately, that's where the beauty ends. I don't know what ASUS did wrong here - I've researched it up & down, I've tried every trick & suggested fix, I've even rooted it and replaced the ASUS stock Android with a custom ROM. The sad, unfortunate fact is, something in the guts of this thing is just wrong. Don't get me wrong, the tablet works - always has, since the day I got it. But it stutters, halts, takes forever to "catch up". The custom ROM took care of most of the random crashes that the ASUS firmware experienced (often), but nothing got rid of the sheer, unadulterated clunky-ness that was this tablet's user experience.

So sad, really - ASUS really had a potential home run here. I still have yet to see an Android hardware implementation that even comes close to being as elegant as this. But they had something wrong deep down in the tablet, and they released it anyway. And that's too bad, in that it's really soured me not just on this particular tablet model but on ASUS as a manufacturer & brand. It gives me pause, to think that they knew something was "off" here (and they had to have known, there've been way more than enough issues & reports about this thing since soon after its initial release) and the company still said "ship it". That's just not right, and it makes it doubtful that I'd ever trust them again.

In summary, to anyone out there that might still be thinking that this is a deal now that it's a fraction of the original price - it's not. Save yourself a lot of time & headaches. Spend the $150 or $200 or whatever this costs now, and get anything else. It won't feel as good in your hands, and it won't look as good to your eyes, but I guarantee you won't get worn down and ultimately completely disappointment either...

It's a lemon. Apps crash all the time, including Launcher and other system apps. No app is immune, and the same apps don't crash on my other Android device, so it's not the apps. I bought this tablet not long after it came out. Like many, I bought the hype and then bought the tablet. Even the tech guy at Best Buy recommended this over the *other* tablet. He was wrong.

Like many, the first month or so I had this thing it was amazing! But slowly and surely, it became the last thing I would use to read, surf or play with apps on. I tried all sorts of tricks to try and get it to work more quickly just shy of doing anything that would void the warranty. Even with only junk apps it came with, this thing was molasses in January.

So now I'm biding my time to swallow the $600+ mistake (yep, I went all in and bought the damn keyboard too!) and buy something new.

And the taste in my mouth is still so bad that as I'm looking for a new laptop, I won't even look at Asus.  It's really that bad.

So why the two stars instead of one? The screen is still pretty incredible three years later!

Moral of the story (which only took me three years to write) - buy their monitors, but steer clear of their other stuff!

Are you looking for a tablet with the freedom of Android, and all the functionality of the iPad? If so, the Asus Transformer Infinity is the right tablet for you.

Freedom

This tablet uses the Android operating system which gives you the freedom to customize your user experience, including what apps are used by default, your onscreen keyboard, and your app launcher.

The iPads iOS doesnt allow very many customizations. They lock you to using Apples apps by default, the default keyboard, and the default launcher.

Winner: Asus Transformer Infinity

Price

The Asus Transformer Infinity is priced at either $239.99(32gb) or $399.99(64gb). When compared to other tablets of similar capabilities, such as the Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1 ($259.99 for 16gb), this is a great deal. Meanwhile, the iPad is priced significantly higher at $449.99 (32gb) or $599.99 (64gb) even though it has less impressive specifications.

Winner: Asus Transformer Infinity

Specifications

The Asus Transformer Infinity has either 32gb or 64gb of flash memory built in. This can be expanded by an extra 128gb through the use of the built in MicroSD card slot or USB port. There is also a built in HDMI port that allows you to connect to HDMI TVs or other displays to easily share your screen. The available Asus keyboard has a built in battery that will keep the tablet going for much longer than the rated 9.5 hours. This extra boost in battery puts it ahead of all other tablets within its price range.

To this day, the iPad does not support the use of SD cards, USB, or external displays without the purchase of a clunky adapter. Also, there are no Apple accessories to extend the iPads otherwise average battery life.

Winner: Asus Transformer Infinity

Apps

Many people think that Android is lacking high quality apps compared to iOS. This belief couldn't be further from the truth. When I first bought Android, I was able to find nearly all of the exact same apps on the Google Play Store. As for those that I couldn't find, such as iBooks and Facetime, there were very good equivalents in Google Books and Google Hangouts.

Winner: Tie

Summary

Overall, you can be confident that the Asus Transformer Infinity will perform just as good as, if not better than the iPad in nearly every aspect. I definitely recommend it to anyone who is hesitant on making the switch from the iPad to Android. Hopefully I have helped you make your decision. Ill see you on Hangouts!

If you are looking for a high quality tablet I strongly recommend you consider a brand other than ASUS.  My tablet quit charging after 14 months and nothing I could do could fix it.  After returning it to ASUS I was informed that the motherboard was bad and that the charge to fix it would be $236 including parts, labor and shipping.  ASUS refused to give any consideration to the fact that it was only 14 months old and barely out of warranty.  A bad battery or plug might be reasonable, but not a bad motherboard.  It was a take it or leave it response from ASUS.  Since the same model can be purchased from Amazon for less than the repair charge it made no sense to get it repaired and only have a 90 day repair warranty.  My new tablet is a Samsung!

On the brighter side, because it was purchased new and fully paid for with a VISA card, VISA extended the warranty an additional year and reimbursed the repair amount after I provided them the necessary documentation.  This is a nice service that VISA provides.  I would recommend that your electronic purchase be registered with your card company when purchased to make the process go more quickly.

Pros: The finish is nice, and it has a smooth, thin feel to it.
Cons: The battery life is really poor. I have even reset to defaults and installed minimal apps, disabled GPS, etc., and it still doesn't last as long as many of my other devices. I was originally very excited about this tablet and had purchased it to use instead of a laptop while travelling. At home, the tablet mostly served as a media viewing device for watching movies and TV shows from files or via streaming services.

The keyboard dock was great as it also served as an additional battery supply, however, it was poorly engineered, and I wonder if it had been tested prior to release. If the keyboard was open more than 90 degrees on a flat surface, the tablet would fall on it's back if you lifted your hands from the keys due to the heavier weight of the tablet compared to the keyboard dock. A simple weight added to the keyboard dock would have fixed this issue.

The tablet performed very slowly over wireless networks. Although it did not have an issue with bandwidth, and could stream HD video over wifi very well, latency was an issue, particularly with very long connection times when trying to load webpages etc. I had read that this was an issue on Amazon reviews before purchasing but didn't think it would be too much of an issue, but it proved to be very frustrating. We have a number of other tablets, phones and laptops in the house and this tablet by far performed the worst over a wireless network.

The external micro HDMI port was a great addition, and I have been unable to find this on other tablets that I'm interested in purchasing as a replacement. This was extremely useful when travelling and you wanted to stream or play video from your tablet to a TV screen.

The main reason I have voted this 1 star and would advise people to steer clear of it is the overall reliability of the tablet. As a lot of other reviews have stated, this tablet suffers from a lot of random reboots and failures. Just after my one-year warranty expired the tablet completely failed and will not boot at all. Asus help center were not able to help and only suggested shipping the tablet off to an Asus service center at my cost. The cost of repair including labour and shipping is estimated to be more than purchasing a new tablet. Unfortunately since I purchased on Amazon, I am unable to have the tablet repaired or replaced under obligations by the retailer to comply with local consumer law in my country.

Pros:
Keyboard dock with extra battery
External micro HDMI port
Good picture quality and screen

Cons:
Poor wireless networking performance
Constant shut downs and failures
Died just after one-year warranty expired

In comparison, my partner's Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 out-performs this tablet in almost every way, with the exception of the keyboard and external micro HDMI port. If someone could make a tablet with the performance and reliability of a Samsung, but with the keyboard dock and HDMI port, that would be nice.

The first one was dead on arrival. I contacted Asus technical support (after all, a defective product is no fault of the seller), and they promptly arranged an RMA# and delivered a new unit to me.

Out of the box, it's operation is somewhat "laggy". It's easily fixed if you go through the settings and disable some of the pre-loaded apps you know you won't be using. Things such as "Google Korean Input", a multitude of ASUS apps, etc. Shutting down these unnecessary background applications can significantly improve the performance of the tablet.

The screen resolution is great but the sound quality is so-so given that it has only one speaker on the right side (when oriented in landscape).

As it stands now, I'm pleased with it. I use this mainly for internet browsing and e-books, And while it plays many games fine, some processor-heavy games will result in lag and screen stuttering. Rooting the device and loading a custom ROM would make a world of difference, but is also beyond the scope of this review and the skills of the average user.

Totally agree with EastSide's review on July 20, 2012. I too fell for the specs on paper and soon found out that I was duped .  This thing is such a lemon that my 8-year-old doesn't want to use it because it is too slow.  I too hoped for an update, but ASUS did not choose to do so.  Therefore, they can count me out on any future product purchases.  What a waste of my families money.  I rarely feel ashamed of a purchase as I research, and I too saw that there were many promising reviews.  I have included EastSide's review below.
"I just deleted my original 5-star, glowing review (I was one of the first early adopters who bought the TF700T when it first came out last Summer).. I was eagerly waiting almost a year for a full-HD tablet and on paper everything looks good and should be good. This was my first tablet and of course I didn't know better so everything seemed nice and "fast" at the beginning, just like the 70% of people giving 5-star reviews here right after purchasing this tablet. Well, what an expensive mistake it turned out to be!

After 8 months of daily use and having tried other TF700Ts (all with similar issues) and comparing it to other newer hi-res tablets, I'm *gladly* getting rid of it. Despite the quad-processor and all the nice on-paper-only-specs, what kills it is the slow NAND RAM memory (not the storage memory) and the ASUS GUI overlay on top of Jelly Bean. To make things worse and adding insult to injury, the RAM is limited to 1GB(!).. it's like having a PC with very slow non-upgradeable 512MB RAM after system overhead. It makes using the tablet feel "bloated", lagging and excruciatingly slow. Of course people who just bought it (including me then) are blinded by the shinny full-HD screen (pun intended) and excited by the on-paper-only potential but that wears off pretty soon once you put the tablet to heavy use and realize how other tablets handle the same load. Don't take me wrong, the tablet works relatively well doing passive stuff (like reading) and the screen is bright and nice but that's it. The first months I was hoping for a miraculous firmware update, many came but nothing really changed. This thing stutters while browsing or just using apps. Typing gets extremely annoying if you are used to fast computers, smartphones or newer tablets. It takes time for the tablet to catch up with you and sometimes freezes up or blanks out. No, not even cold re-booting or updating to the latest firmware will fix this (I just updated to ASUS's latest modified version of Android 4.2.1) and it's still slow and buggy. Yes, you could root the 700T (cleanrom, data2SD) but that misses the point. I should not be the one half-fixing a mediocre engineered tablet and on top of that losing my warranty doing it. Besides SD cards have limited read/write cycles."

I bought this TF700T as a gift for my boyfriend. He did enjoy it for about 1.5 year. The response to touch was a little sluggish, but overall not bad. And then when he was already used to having it around and reading his newspapers on it the nightmare started: the screen would not respond to touch, instead it got a mind of its own - as if a ghost were driving it. The "ghost clicks". After reading a lot on the web we bough a new digitizer screen and replaced it - no change at all. Finally, we realized that the loose contact of the digitizer ribbon cable was the cause of the screen malfunction. The most useful advise on "iFixIt" web site suggested to slip a piece of film into the same slot as digitizer cable to firm up the contact. It helped, but only temporarily. For the last half a year cracking the case open and reinserting these digitizer cables has become our biweekly exercise. Unfortunately, buying a cheaper tablet with less memory is not a good choice - these devices really do need these 64 Megs, otherwise mapping software and videos are sluggish or not at all functional. Shelling out more than $500 every year and a half is outside of reason for us. It would not have been so bad if parts were readily available, but that is not the case, parts are exceedingly hard to buy. The bottom line: it's a great tablet while that contact lasts. But  the luck ran out in 1.5 year.

Asus TF700T is a relatively dated model (released in 2012).

Its build quality is solid and on par with that of iPads.

Battery life is descent and the CPU performance is little bit lagging (because it was released 2 years ago).

The display resolution is true HD (1920x1080) and IPS monitor quality is outstanding (even not as high as that of iPad retina screens, which have even higher resolution).

It runs Android 4.2.2.

The only glitch I had was that, due to the fact it was released and probably made in 2012, I need download and apply a lot of updates from google store. For some reason, some google app updates always failed to update and caused the installation process of google store to hang. The symptom is that, you won't be able to install any new app and won't be able shut down or restart the tablet.

I had to restore the tablet to the factory condition to start over again. This was quite frustrating for non-tech savy customers. I tried several times and downloaded the app updates in various different orders. Eventually, I was able to complete the update and bring the whole system up-to-date.

Since then, no issue happened and it runs very reliably.

My family owns iPad mini 2 and iPad air. I prefer to experience some non-apple technology just to keep my eyes open.

Were it not for the fact that Google store installation process had glitches, I would have given this product 5 star-reivew.

Fool me once, shame on Asus.

Other than its relatively slow eMMC internal storage specification, the TF700 boasted a pretty spectacular set of specs on paper and was lauded as a groundbreaking design when introduced in mid-2012.  It's a tablet I have used for hours a day since buying late that year.  However, as numerous others have described in support forums and customer reviews:  with ongoing use it has become chronically laggy and slow (far slower than dial-up speed slow); yet under warranty terms, users may not unlock it to install required fixes.

When it takes 19 minutes to navigate four web pages and send an email link from each - an operation that should take 60 seconds in a skilled operator's hands - game is over.

Worse:  Asus stopped issuing needed software updates just one year after release, so buyers are still stuck on Jellybean 4.2.1 as of Dec 2014.  That's disappointing (and probably a little outrageous) for a tablet priced far higher than its competitors and hyped as a premium model at time of sale.

Ironically:  had Asus pushed a Kitkat update (instead of stagnate this model at v4.2.1), it probably would have gone a long way to correct many of the storage inefficiencies that drag this model into the toilet.  Quite a few individual owners have jailbroken their TF700s to force a Kitkat upgrade - and found their nearly-dead TF700s gain remarkable new life.

That manual upgrade, along with a few efficiency utilities, help overcome one of the prominent reasons for TF700's poor performance:  its use of eMMC storage.  (The HowToGeek site provides a smart explanation for how that becomes a performance bottleneck in "eMMC vs. SSD: Not All Solid-State Storage is Equal":  eMMC storage works well for data storage but provides slower access than SSD, so it's better suited for long-term storage than it is for, say, fast reads/writes required by an operating system.)

Another major TF700 performance drag:  bloatware.  I never grasped how significant that can be, till I owned a TF700.  I always thought bloatware meant:  a few extra unwanted apps that the consumer could ignore or uninstall.  But independent developers have identified TF700 bloatware modules which persistently communicate its device status back to Asus (current software version, GPS location, more).  When still supported by publisher, such utilities made some sense (after all, TF700 received a few pushed upgrades during its initial months) but once the publisher abandoned the model, these legacy apps, still aggressively chewing up resources, act more like an anchor.  After unlocking and learning how to use ADB (Android Data Bridge), I removed the associated CMClient, DMClient and Parental Lock - and experienced a remarkable performance gain as a result, in just one of my own experiments with the model.

So the solution is:  buy a replacement (better) tablet, or rescue this expensive model by repairing or replacing its software.  I prefer a repair, rather than tossing away this expensive model.

But applying a replacement custom ROM is skilled IT work requiring a self-study project to safely deploy - and as I learned, the vastly greater operating speed may also come with issues not fully debugged for bluetooth or DRM support:  I temporarily lost bluetooth remote speaker stereo pairing (since fixed) and permanently lost Tivo streaming because the Tivo publisher blocks that app if the tablet has been repaired by consumer (a publisher choice that robs consumers of fair use of an app for which they paid for supportive streaming hardware - poor choice by Tivo, and one that has rankled many owners).

Betrayed - tired of fighting it - and apparently resigned to having to buy a replacement tablet (since even good custom ROMs built by enthusiasts and freely offered, have their bugs that in my own case broke apps I use all the time):  sure, yeah, I concluded:  I'll buy another tablet.  But:  it won't be an Asus tablet.  Not after this experience.

Ironically, I still have an Asus desktop tower PC and Win 8 laptop, which continue to be well used and I really like - but they're not locked formats, so they will likely have a longer useful life.  I'll simply advise friends:  how can you trust that the next Asus tablet won't be similarly abandoned by its publisher support within just a year?

-
P.S. - Since publishing the above, I've gained some industry and market perspective - and found a custom ROM by one of the open source developers that reshaped my TF700 into a (nearly) new tablet, with stable, fast, highly functional performance.

Perspective.  Asus is hardly alone in marketing tablets with short lifecycles and premature planned obsolescence. Product research suggests the tablet category is premised on short useful lives, presumably to goad consumers into replacing their gear with the next model.

Tablet manufacturers should take a lesson from the music industry, which had to reprice and repackage its products when consumers recognized its price gouging for what it was - and simply stopped buying albums, en masse.

We may already be seeing such a reaction with tablet sales; the latest market projections declare a surprise downward trend, and actually attribute the drop to consumers seeking to extend useful lives of their expensive models.  Can't blame consumers - conditioned to buying cheap, powerful desktop PCs:  they compare value, and feel ripped off if a premium priced tablet has a useful life only 1/3 as long as a comparatively cheaper desktop PC, or comparably priced laptop.

My own moment of zen:  thanks to excellent work by some of the android custom ROM developers who publish in forums (though I may not link here, you'll find them):  I'm happily using a zippy fast "Vanir" Kitkat v. 4.4.4 custom ROM now on my TF700, and the sole shortcoming is that Tivo app whose publisher won't let it stream to a rooted tablet (but for now, I'll live with that single fail).  We're all learning, as we go.

Looks like I won't be buying a new tablet soon, after all.  But when I do, I'll seek out a Google Nexus: perhaps unique in the category, they tend to receive publisher upgrades well past their first year.

I was very impressed by my new purchase. I wasn't sure initially if I had made the correct choice in a product from some of the negative reviews I saw. However, for the limited use I need my tablet for (reading) its awesome. There is indeed a delay for the initial power on as is usual for most computer products, but once it starts the reactions are very fast. I will have to invest in more protection since this model is even thinner than the other older model I own.
We love it. I have noticed the back gets a little warm after an extended amount of time. But we also have a case on it which could contribute to this.

In my opinion this is the best Android tablet on the market, save for two things, both of which are pretty minor when you think about it. 1) It claims to be "gray," but honestly it looks purple. In certain light it can sometimes look like this odd bluish-gray color, but really it's purple. I knew this going in but I decided on "odd blue-purple-gray" over "ugly beige-gold-champagne." (Personally I call that second color "baby poop." If you've ever changed a diaper you understand why.) 2) For no apparent reason it will randomly reboot every now and then, even if I'm not even touching it. A sometimes-inconvenient oddity, but nothing major.

Don't let those two little weirdnesses turn you away, though. This is a great tablet. When it comes to phones, I'm pro-vanilla Android; but on tablets, I like a slightly more powerful interface that offers more functions with fewer touches/less navigation. Asus provides that here exactly the way it should be done (in my opinion): adding to the Android experience without getting in its way.

DO NOT BUY THIS TABLET.

I don't care how cheap it is. My wife bought it from OfficeMax because ASUS was a reputable brand and it was a 10.1" tablet for around 200.

The power button would not work. It would only turn on if you plugged in the cord, and it wouldn't turn off or reset. So within the return period, and I thought I just got a lemon, so I bought it here. I had to RMA it almost immediately. I got it back, and it would not turn on (the deep sleep issue that you will soon become familiar with if you ignore my warning and buy this. They told me to RMA it, but I couldn't get around to it for about a week or two. On a lark, I pulled it back out of the box, and sure enough it was working as expected. For a third time I re-set everything up on my tablet, and then the display randomly quit, and appears to be malfunctioning (as it is working via HDMI).

Supposedly there things you can do to deal with the deep sleep issue, but they are out of the norm for most tablets and most platforms I've had experience with. I'm pretty flexible normally, I've set up workarounds and happily stuck to them when the tradeoff was a little convenience for a lot of price. So when I say this is unreasonable, it's not coming from a place of laziness.

The lone bright spot has been dealing with the customer service. They are pretty prompt in replying and in a situation where bad CS would be the final straw, they have been pretty nice to work with.

Still, it is no wonder why these tablets are so inexpensive so soon after they first hit the market--and the hassle still isn't worth the price. It's really not.

Have had mine for over a year and previously had a TF101 and TF 300. Only reason for upgrades was for more features. OK...lets get to any negatives. Compared to the latest and greatest from companies like Samsung it is a bit slower. I have the docking keyboard and it no longer snaps on...after REALLY hard day to day use the little fingers it grabs have worn out or broken off. But it still works fine. The compass isn't dead on accurate...no Androids are thus far compare to Apples offerings.

Now to the pluses....expandability....you can use a micro SD card in the tablet and another full size one in the keyboard PLUS it takes USB so can plug in my flash drive or even better...the same HD I use for backups with my Windows computer..and I can read and write the files between Word, Excel, using included apps. Same for pictures and videos.  Long battery life that is even longer with the keyboard and its battery attached. Screen is excellent and has excellent color and resolution...maybe not the latest but still VERY good. HDMI output is great...camera for stills and video gives excellent large mp images and 1080 HD movies. While some of the competitors have newer offerings with of course newer specs...they have one major flaw...they don't support AdHoc wireless whichI need to connect and control my astronomy telescopes wirelessly. May not be an issue for others but it is a major one for me.

It's a real beauty and my wife was ecstatic Christmas when she opened it. Great size and fully functional like a full sized computer. We added a keyboard a month later and bought a cover for protection as well. It really is a nice little thing. We'd give it a 5 star If it didn't start having issues after only 4 months of gentle and normal use. I did a factory reset thinking it would solve the problem but it didn't. It will not even boot up anymore. I have to let the battery run empty for it to turn off. I will be contacting the manufacturer for repairs. Hoping it will be within the warranty and free of charge. I will add the continuation as things progress and hopefully have a smooth transaction with it all.

I have had the tf300t and now the 700t and I have to say that at first it was nice but ever since day one I have had slight issues growing to bigger issues. The 300t was good until I dropped it and of course after a failed repair attempt I figured I would upgrade to the latest and greatest. My biggest issue with them is while they have the gorilla glass 2 digitizer, it is still very fragile. I have gone through 2 of these tablets in less than a year because of the first screen cracking and the second one developed a very faint crack that I didn't notice at first because the screen would no work all the time until one day I tapped it in the right spot and effectively killed half the screen with the 2 inch crack that formed. ON the software side of things some things that never worked properly were asus bloatware like asus weather that crashed every time, on the 300 it never updated properly. The email widget only worked sometimes and overall the tablet ran slow. And now my problem is I bought a 60 dollar case to protect my $275 investment and now I am put off of buying another one because I know its going to just happen again most likely. This was a replacement for one I dropped and broke.  I looked at all the latest tablets, but since I still had the keyboard, I decided to stay with this one.  I searched extensively and finally found a great deal on it.

The tablet is very light, fast, and responsive, and with the keyboard, I am able to augment storage with combined 64Gb USB and SD drives. There are newer, more powerful tablets out there, but this one will meet my needs for years to come.

I had originally bought around two years ago and was absolutely in love with it for the first year.  Sure it ran slow at moments while using it to take notes, but I wasn't too overly irritated with that fact.  Going into the second year I used it mostly for my books in my classes so I could buy those cheaper.  This past year I had been having issues with it keeping charge and found myself needing to constantly charge it while using it.

Then one day while trying to use it to study for my final, the tablet decided not to turn on.  I looked up the issue and found that there are many users with this problem where the light is green while charging though it will not turn on.  I figured it to be a motherboard issue, and I could easily take it somewhere to fix, but why mess with a tablet I've been having issues with?  I do not want to put more money into this tablet than I already have since I already spent too much money on it in the first place, due to getting it around the time it was released.

I had issues where my apps will force close on me and I will loose recordings and notes from my classes.  Most items I have last five or more years, not two years.  I will join the many others in tossing this tablet aside and hope that my next one won't crap out after two years of gentle usage.

I expected the  menus to move to the top of the screen, and the navigation to move to the middle. They did not. It felt like using an old version of Android (4.0 or 4.1); that was frustrating. The tablet also lagged - BADLY. It felt like waiting forever, and half-expecting the tablet to restart itself often. It did sometimes. I thought I was buying a better tablet than the 300 I had before, and I was very disappointed.

Save up the money to get a new tablet with better memory and better processors. but if you're saving money by buying a $200 or less older Asus, go for the TF300T. Trust me. It is actually better in more ways than 1.

I have never been one to buy the bleeding edge of technology. Whether it be a desktop PC, Laptop, cell phone, or tablet, in thirty plus years of building, installing, using, and repairing computers of all shapes and sizes I have only bought the latest and greatest two times. Very rarely is there a need for me to to pay the premium price so it is my policy to let others buy at the top dollar level and bring the prices down for people like me (And also discover all of the bugs so the manufacturer can get them fixed before I buy).

All of that said I think this is a great tablet! I have been eyeing this model for well over a year. I purchased it's little brother an Asus TF300T at a bargain price about a 1-1/2 year ago and have truly loved it. But I kept watching for a great deal on this model. Finally gave up after about six months of searching.

Then recently, my wife's Kindle Fire HD started acting flakey (rebooting for no reason while she was reading), I began looking at possible replacements, seriously considering the Nexus 7.. She mentioned that she would like to have a larger screen because her eyesight is not the greatest. She enjoys playing several games, as well as reading her books. So I was going to buy her a TF300, but in my search ran across the TF700 brand new for $213. That was less than I paid for my TF300 over a year ago and far below the original price of $499.00! Also over $100.00 less than the Nexus 7-2013. I ordered it for her, along with a decent case. The day it arrived I set it up with her library and games. She hasn't stopped smiling since.

I am very impressed with it. The video is much sharper than my TF300. I have customized my TF300 with a custom ROM and kernel, OC'ed it to 1.8 Ghz and this tablet is just as fast out of the box with everything stock. I can only imagine how well it would perform if I customized it. But that is not to be until after it is out of warranty and maybe not even then. My wife is perfectly happy with it as is and when she is happy then I am happy. :-)

Be forewarned however, do not expect Nexus 7-2013 performance or performance as fast as the current generation tablets. This is three year old technology. Unless you are willing to customize this tablet which will void the warranty. But it is a decently performing tablet and suits my wife's need very well. An she hasn't seen any of the lag issues and freeze-ups described by others in their reviews. Not sure what the difference is, but she is running in performance mode at 1.5 Ghz and it is more than adequate. The bottom line - it blows any other tablet in the same class and generation out of the water.

And as far as people whining about it not having a USB port without the keyboard dock, DID YOU READ THE SPECS AND RESEARCH IT BEFORE YOU BOUGHT IT????

When you are looking in the tablet world, you are basically looking at an iPad, a Samsung Galaxy Tab, a Nexus, or an Asus Transformer (there are some notable other devices out there, but for the most part this is what the main options are).

If you want the best hardware, I believe the iPad 4 is the best thing walking.
The problem I have with the iPad is the lack of options. There is no side loading apps, no easy expansion, and lack of customization to my desires. This is an Apple thing, and it puts me off. I'm not starting a debate, but I fall into the category that I prefer non-Apple devices.

I have opted for an Android device because of this (for my phone as well) and then it came down to hardware.
At one point, the TF700T was the best hardware out there by far. Now it is not. But it is still really darn good.

Mind you, if you want to compare... apples to apples (I swear I didn't mean that pun) you would want to compare the Asus TF701 to the iPad 4 to make some comparisons. I would still opt for the Asus with the Tegra 4 processor and 2560x1600 display.

But of course, I opted for the TF700 instead. Why? Because it was $200. With my dock it totaled $300.
That's half the price of the best tablets out there and more than half the benefits.

So my reasoning for choosing this tablet follows this line of thought:
It's Android, and it is far less expensive (both as noted above)
This is a full 1920x1200 resolution screen, and looks darn good (not as good as a retina display, but far better than anything else out there)
The dock is a dock, not a mere keyboard (though having a physical keyboard is a big perk for me). It has a USB and SD slot for easy attachments of flash drives etc... and it contains it's own battery so it can actually charge the tablet if the tablet battery is low.
While I feel the best sizing for a tablet is 8" (not the 7" or 10" which are typical) I felt the 10" gave a vast difference compared to my phone (5")
and good screen real estate for working on "office" type documents and remote access to my desktop computers. (side note: the USB port on the dock actually comes in handy for a mouse connection for my remote desktop sessions, just plug in and it recognizes and works automatically)

Things I wish were better:
For the specs, the tablet seems laggy. When there are too many apps running in the background the whole thing starts to lag. Mind you, it is still usable, but slow. I tend to use a quick kill app to close background apps and fee up RAM.
Ice Cream Sandwich is a good version of the OS, but it is outdated now. Having Kit Kat would add Trim support (so your flash memory doesn't clutter giving you performance degradation over time).
There is no Delete key on the dock. Minor deal, but it's annoying. (and granted, this is more of a dock review item than for the tablet)

Some other thoughts:
Swiftkey works great on the tablet, but doesn't play well with TeamViewer and the dock. I've reverted to the stock Asus keyboard (which isn't bad)
Office 365 does not natively load on tablets (it is not supported). However, you can side load it (I exported the apk from my phone) and it loads and runs well. The hitch...is that it doesn't recognize the dock, so you can't use the keyboard which sort of defeats the purpose of it.
If you like to tinker and will root this (a friend of mine has rooted his) this thing won't ever lag like I have stated earlier. It will run smoothly and without issue.

Overall I am happy with my purchase. I have used this for about 2 months now and love it.
My primary uses have been media (netflix, various games, e-reader) and remote connecting to a PC (home and work).

The fact that it only had one back-facing speaker bugged me from the start, too.  Later, it started getting pop-up error messages and lagging in performance.  Even after killing all tasks or rebooting, it was slow.  Now, it gives me the boot screen and can't be restarted, even with the cold reboot.  It's a paper weight.

I got a lot of use and enjoyment out of it, but for the $700 (tablet, keyboard, accessories) I paid, it was not worth it.  I am shopping for a different brand now, and I'll probably try to keep the cost under $400 if this is the kind of life one should expect from a tablet.

UPDATE SEPTEMBER 8, 2014:

I bought this tablet on June 20, 2014. Within a few days I had to send it to ASUS for the previously mentioned performance issues (See original review below). Despite the fact that I was in regular contact with their customer service department the device got lost and had to be tracked down. It was tracked down and returned repaired about 10 weeks later. Upon receiving this I found that the screen had not been properly seated into the frame and was loose along the top edge. I contacted customer service again and was told to send it back again. Because so much time had passed and because my frustration with them so evident the customer service representative said that instead of sending this back to ASUS for repair, she would see that I would receive a replacement in its place. This took an additional two weeks.

I received my replacement just a few days ago. Over the last three days I have rebooted and restarted this thing probably 20 times because programs won't open, programs shut down, programs don't respond or the device won't open or the devise will shut down or the devise simply won't respond. I have had to return to the ridiculous dependability of my three- or four-year-old HTC Rezound as well as my nine-year-old Acer laptop because even with their ages and performance problems they perform better than this tablet. In that this tablet was to replace those items I am a angry to have to put them to continued use.

The only thing I can say about ASUS's tablets and level of technological competency at this point is that they are horrible. Clown-like. An embarrassment. I bought this tablet and a dedicated ASUS keyboard dock a full 12 weeks ago. I have had a tablet in hand to use for about two of those weeks. I have had zero usefulness out of three device opportunities--the original purchase, the repaired original, and now the replacement. ASUS should be incredibly embarrassed for their inept quality and their patent failure for getting me a device that works given that they had the better part of three months to get it right. Put it this way. In my original review I mention hurtling the tablet into the woods across the street from my house. It's been so long that the entire wooded parcel has been stripped of vegetation and now there are complete houses standing there. I'm serious.

I have decided to use this tablet only for writing. Let's hope that, at over $300 for the tablet and board that it can bear this heavy burden lest I have to go to the next step up in tablets which will require both a hammer and a chisel. Honestly, I won't even donate this thing because it's just ridiculous.

ORIGINAL REVIEW JUNE, 2014:

Well the first thing that you should know is that unlike every device I have ever had, this one requires an ASUS brand-specific USB cable and power plug. You cannot charge it without this. Nor can you charge it through any type of extension product such as a power strip or USB line extension cord. Unless you are a witch.

This thing is slow as molasses for even the most mundane things like typing up an angry and disparaging letter to ASUS to let them know just how bad you think this item is. It crashes more than a room full of toddlers after both lunch and outside play time on a hot day. The video, despite being "blazing, blistering, blastingly fast,"...well, that's really just a matter of perspective now, isn't it? Fast compared to what? To the annual growth rate of an elm? Discernably fast? Sorry, but no. Let us reference the letter again. Sort of like the Portlandia bit about sitting at the stop sign insisting that the other person go first.
"You go."
"No, you go."
"No, really. I insist."
I was able to both shave my dear Uncle Jeremy's backhair off and then watch it grow back up while waiting for this thing to accept my text. And that's a really bad hassle when I am dependent upon this for holding onto and regaling in every word that I feed it. "Please, for god's sake, the word is "the." I told you that 30 minutes ago. Didn't I? It's been so long I simply cannot remember."
Insofar as video quality and playback? Crash and crash again and then lag and then just burst into flames. Nothing stellar about this at all. It's actually hardly even worth using for video. Although, if you like epic movies and mini-series it will do well in playing back old Frasier episodes with those sorts of time frames. Why enjoy 22 minutes of fun when you can endure 3 1/2 hours spent playing that same program? I think that they consider this a value-added feature.

The beautiful side of this tablet is that still images are really gorgeous. Awesome colors and spectacular resolution are its hallmarks. It's fundamentally a tablet "trophy wife," but without the burden of being expensive. Great looking, but without a lick of sense where it matters most.

Battery life is exceptional. I've been running across the Internet, docs, and images for the last 3 1/2 hours and still have power. I optimistically bought a well-priced dock for it and both can probably last another few hours. Which is great because I'd really like to start that second Frasier episode.

Finally, like the trophy wife it is very slim and doesn't weigh a lot, so when I get finished with this review and hurl this into the woods across the street I'm sure it will go quite far, probably with a very gentle, avian arc to its flight trajectory. If YouTube will accept a live feed, then I'll set the camera to record the video upon launching. Wish me luck. And lament with me now that I have a great ASUS tablet dock to remember her by.

I bought this when it first came out, and like everyone else, I thought it was fabulous when I first got it. Then the problems started. First, within the first few weeks, the keyboard/docking station quit charging, so I called ASUS customer service and after a long conversation and some attempts to solve the problem, I was told I had to send it to ASUS for service. After about 3 weeks, I got it back. Right out of the box, the keyboard wouldn't work with my tablet, so I called ASUS again, and this time it was determined that I needed to send in the tablet for repair. Three weeks later, what looked to be a new tablet came back. Then the charger stopped working. It would heat up and I'd have to put it in the freezer for a few minutes to cool it down. I just ordered a new charger on Amazon, rather than call ASUS about that. The next thing that happened was that the little plastic "hooks" that kept the tablet and keyboard secured to each other broke, and the keyboard wouldn't stay attached to the tablet. Not long after that, the plastic piece that covers the mechanism where it attaches to the tablet broke off completely, which made it impossible for the tablet and keyboard to stay attached at all, especially when folded up. At that point, I decided I would only use the keyboard if it was crucial when I had a lot to type. Then I noticed that it started to slow way down and then started feeling hot in the upper left corner when I used it for more than an hour or two. Not long after that, it started just re-booting randomly when I had been on it for awhile. Then one night, it shut off and when it tried to re-boot, I just got the ASUS logo and the dots going in a circle. So I made another call to ASUS and after 2 hours with the guy on the phone, where he had me completely wipe it of all data back to the factory settings,  I was told he couldn't help me, and I could send it in to them, or because it was now out of warranty, it might be cheaper to just take in to someone locally. A few days later, when I took it to Micro Center service, the guy there confirmed what I was afraid of: it was "bricked", meaning it was now just an expensive paperweight (brick) because it would be at least $200-$300 to send it out to their repair people, and in his opinion I should just buy a new tablet. According to him, it was a hardware issue, most likely a faulty hard drive (factory defect). So, there it is. I spent $700 with tax and shipping about a year and half ago for the tablet and keyboard which are now useless pieces of hardware, only worthy of the "computer graveyard."  I recently purchased a new laptop/notebook computer, and there was no way I would even consider an ASUS computer after that experience. I bought a Lenovo Yoga, so I could just fold it back and use it as a tablet. The only problem with that is that there are Android apps that you just can't get for Windows 8. Will I buy another Droid tablet? Maybe. But if I do, it definitely won't be an ASUS!

Prior to purchasing the TF700 I had a tf300...  The tf300 failed twice during warranty due to touch screen issues.  Finally gave up the ghost when I removed it from the keyboard dock one handed and the screen cracked corner-to-corner.  The tf700 seems much more substantial with the metal rear shell and gorilla glass II screen.  I had been experiencing numerous crashes while playing high power usage games like Call of heroes and Knights & Dragons.  I attributed this to the much more ram hungry HD graphics processor.  The tablet would crash seemingly for no reason till I noticed that it was doing automatic updating just prior to the crash. Put all the apps in manual update mode and that problem has pretty much gone away.  Probably why Asus made the change to 2 gigs of RAM with the tf701.  Suspect that they knew there was a problem, but it was a cost issue...  Would have given a higher rating had there not been the initial crash issues.
Maybe I should have gone with the tf701, but for me it was a matter of money.  Just couldn't bring myself to spend the extra $100+ for the tf701.  Wish there was a simple upgrade for the RAM without buying a complete new model...  Interestingly enough I paid $50 less for the tf700 than I paid for the tf300 a year and a half before.
