Don't buy, there are other one star reviews that go into detail about this tablet. I am experiencing the same annoying slownes problem. This tablet is broken from the get go. I don't even feel like iiI can sell it to get rid of it because it would not be right. My original pur phase price was $599... What a waste of money.

I had this for two years then sold it to my step brother. When I had it I loved it, I sold it so I could get a smaller tablet. But it was fast had an amazing display great sound and very nice battery. But my step brother took it with him to work and it was ran over by a BOB CAT=( but the screen glass was intact and the body was fine but the inside of the screen was broken. This is incredible. Highly recommend but just don't Run it over with anything Like a Bob cat.

I've had the TF700T for over 6 months and it gave me almost nothing but grief.  The drivers for it were horrible and sometimes it would take up to 5 minutes or more for a webpage to load through Chrome.  I wrote to ASUS about the drivers, they recommended factory resetting it and seeing if that cleared the problem, but unfortunately, I broke the digitizer screen before I had a chance to try it, but it might have been Android 4.0 which is standard on that particular model (they haven't upgraded the OS yet).
I have had this for a little over a year now, no problems yet. I do hate the charging cord that comes with it. That part only lasted 6 mths, and it is to short.

I had and have phantom touches.  Namely, unlike other tablets, my TF700 triggered on at least two apps when nobody touched the screen.  This clearly seemed like a hardware problem, since the software worked properly on other tablets.

I sent it in for repair.
It was sent back to me saying it's OK and no call.
Somehow my 64 GB chip was missing and they couldn't "find" it.
I spoke with another person in the Caribbean and he gave me a FedEx mailer, but it went to Milpitas CA.  It took another week to get to their ASUS repair site in Texas.
They sent it back to me again, without any note or call, despite my detailed explanation and phone number requesting a call.  I had removed all apps and reset the TF700 leaving two apps that showed the problem.

My experience with ASUS repair was really awful.

I will not buy their products again.

This tablet has been a great replacement for my laptop on vacations.

My review isn't going to be too technical. I like to travel light and wanted a device to replace my laptop when traveling. This was the perfect find.

I'd been using Android phones for a few years and the tablet is basically the same so if you can use an Android phone you can use this.

I purchased an external SD card reader to use for transferring vacation photos from my camera to the tablet.

I love the concept of the "transforming" tablet with the physical keyboard dock! That part works so well! Very poor execution of a solid performing Android OS (JB) and high performing processors though. Extremely slow at everything (even compared to my 3 year old Samsung G 8" Tab running 4.0).

If I had the nerve (and dollars to risk), I would have kept the tablet and keyboard dock (separate purchase) and unlocked it to flash Chromi-X ROM. I read this ROM makes this tablet extremely powerful. I just couldn't risk scrapping the ASUS warranty to do it though. Nor should I have to for a device in this price range. I should have paid attention to the reviews before purchasing. Back it goes.

This is my second TF700t and it works great with exceptional wifi.  I bought my first and broke the gorilla glass screen.  ASUS warranty is HORRIBLE so be sure to buy the "break" 2 year insurance offered by Amazon.  I originally had a TF201 and it had a well published wifi problem but ASUS refused to step up to the plate to fix the issue even though they came out with the 300 series which fixed it and did not offer 201 customrs an upgrade or anything.  So why I am still using ASUS - only because the mini HDMI plug is excellent for Sling technology while traveling and the attachable keyboard is the best in the market.

When I first got this tablet I loved it and would easily give it 5 stars. But when ive been using this for a year I have noticed its terrible lag. That 1GB RAM kills its performance, it could be so much more with more RAM. I bought the tablet with the keyboard spending almost 750 - 800 dollars its not worth all that money. I plan on looking for a cheaper tablet like the nexus 7 which has more RAM than this overpriced paperweight.

I travel for speaking and writing. After a few months the keyboard latches within the tablet body failed and this no longer was good at "transforming" to a laptop-like device. So, this device gets left home.

To convince you that I'm serious about this sort of device: I replaced this with a Toughpad FG-Z1 and iKey Jumpseat magnesium keyboard. I didn't pay full list for either, but they still cost many times as much as the Transformer Infinity. And are bigger and heavier. But they survive the use that the Transformer would not.

I have been able to improve over the manufacturer's software by installing Cyanogenmod 11 - no more lag and no space wasted for the un-removable ASUS applications which are not as good as others you can download.

I hate that the manufacturer's DRM makes it easier to brick this tablet than other brands. If you even once render both the OS and the Recovery unbootable, there is no way to recover the device without sending it back for repair. Other devices have a protocol to rewrite the ROM and unbrick the device, but ASUS or nVidia encrypts theirs so that only they can use it.
Not sure why anyone would every by an apple anything. These are great. Better bigger screen. Great apps perfect for me

I am a college student, and this tablet should be more than enough for most of college students. I am not a tech-gig, so I don't know much about the spec of this tablet or any tablet, but I've used ipad and samsung galexy from friends and school rental. I honestly don't see the different between this tablet and the other twos that are way more expensive. The display is better than most of the tablet in the market at this price. A lot of you might say this isn't fast, but I don't expect computer speed with tablet. Ipad is not as fast as computer either. This tablet is compatible with ipad in terms of the speed, I believe.

I recommend this tablet for college student who needs it for school work. Reading pdf, powerpoint slides, not-too-big spreadsheet can be worked with this tablet very well. Checking emails, doing facebook and online shopping such as Amazon can be done without any problem.

I've play a few games and it ran smoothly and fast. If it is running slow, I closed out other windows, and it worked faster.

I didn't buy the keyboard dock, mainly because I read so much about the crack from the keyboard dock. Instead, I bought a wireless  tablet keyboard at $9.99 from Amazon, and this works great as well. (You have to pay more than 100 dollars from keyboard dock.) I am actually typing this review with wireless bluetooth keyboard.

Before I bought this, major concern was that many people say that Asus tablet is so fragile that the screen cracks very easily. I was a little worried about this, but I would say this tablet should be kept in its case all the time. I bought a case at about 13 dollars, and this case protects the screen. Most of times, I put this tablet with case in my backpack, and I've not noticed any risk of cracking the screen as long as I keep this in the case.

The tablet, bluetooth keyboard, and tablet case all together costed me less than a single ipad. I don't understand people spending more than 500 dollars for an ipad when there is a great substitute that is a lot cheaper.

The Asus TF700 is one of the best Android tablets on the market.  It has the best camera of any tablet, probably the best screen; and feels awesome in your hands.  The build quality is superior and it is aesthetically pleasing to the eye.  I still sometimes regret sending it back, but I had to because I couldn't live with the slow speed of the processor.  I'm quite sure the problem lies with the WiFi configuration, not the processor.  Asus apparently fixed the anemic WiFi problem with it next iteration, but the tablet devolved in other areas.  If you need a tablet that takes fantastic photos and can live with a slower load speed, do yourself a favor and check out the Asus TF700.
I hate this tablet. It is so slow I have to reboot often.  When I try to contact Asus, I am referred to the online forum.  I have reset to default and continue to experience the freezing.

I wish I had seen the negative reviews here. I would never have wasted my money on this total piece of garbage. Many is the time I have wanted to snap it over my knee. I advise you all to NOT invest in ASUS because I just cannot believe there will be many return buyers to support them in the future. I cannot really ad to the abundant negative reviews here. I can only reinforce that it is slow, laggy and buggy. When I first wake it up, it is not unusual to have to wait fifteen minutes before I can use it. They on screen keyboard is complete and total junk. I can't even type a sentence without multiple double and triple letters.

And I found out what I needed to find out. The same thing I discovered about previous iPad purchase - No matter how good the tablet is, it is still a different operating system than I am used to on my win8 computers - more akin to a smartphone without the phone AND just like iPad, most of the apps are watered down versions of their Windows counterpart.

I've had this tablet for about two years, and I still think it was one of the best electronics purchases I've ever made. Once you have the dock, this tablet can serve on just about any need you can think of. As expandable as any laptop, its equipped with an HDMI out, USB port, SD card slot, Micro SD card slot, 32GB of internal memory, PLUS stunning NVIDIA GPU and dual core CPU, there's not that much to complain about. When I travel, I take a 32GB SD card, 32GB Micro SD, and a 64GB flash drive for a total of 160GB of storage space, and can plug into any TV with an HDMI port.

The only real issue is the memory deficiency, with only 1GB (although the new tf701 has 2GB) of RAM, which is not ideal if you plan on keeping lots of apps or browser tabs open. A few other things to mention are that the weight and balance aren't quite right, so the tablet sits top-heavy when upright in the dock. Also, the keyboard is a bit smaller than what you'll be used to, but once you adjust you'll get the hang of it.

But overall, this is the best tablet on the market when I bought it, and if I were buying a tablet today I would make the same decision (but the newer model, tf701)
Definitely I'm an ASUS fan. It is so light, so bright, the screen looks clear, crisp and wonderful. This is my third ASUS tablet and surely won't be the last.

I'm so disappointed with this product. I bought the tablet together with the dock, paying a total of $550.

Here are the problems I have:

 The tablet restarts randomly out of the blue (no matter if I'm using it or if it's on standby) and crashes. I did a couple of factory resets but the problems were not solved. Lately the random restarts and crashes became so frequent that I decided to give up on using it.

 The internet browsing is very slow and kind a jerky/choppy.

 GPS sucks! Really, it sucks big time! Not reliable at all! It used to take normally more than 10 min (even 15-20 min) to lock on GPS satellites, even outdoor and standing. Then, out of the blue, it loses the signal.

 Very picky charger (gosh, now I hate the fact that I didn't get a tablet with a standard microUSB connector). The USB charging (from the PC) it didn't always work initially and now it doesn't work at all. Then again, the car charging was working initially, and then it didn't work at all. Eventually I noticed that even with the original charger the keyboard doesn't want to charge at all sometimes. That's irking me a lot!
I even bought a brand new USB charging/data cable and the tablet still doesn't charge at all from time to time.
Then there is a quality issue with the USB plug: the plug's jacket cover came out completely of the metallic part (and this only after 6 month of use, with no more than 4-5/months). Now, although I push the jacket back, it keeps coming out time every time I pull the connector out from the adapter or PC's USB port. Anyhow, I ordered a replacement cable from DX and I hope will solve the problem.

 As well, the battery charging status (the system one or the one showed by different apps/widgets) is not reliable at all - it stays at 100% for a long time, then is starts going down to 40-50% very fast, an then the tablet shuts down and need a full recharge.

 The keyboard dock, although appeared to work initially, turned out eventually to be affected by the fast battery drain problem; after about 7 months it stopped completely to charge and work and it ended up in the garbage.  

Well, this is my fourth ASUS product (fifth, if I count the keyboard dock separately) with a lot of issues. Firstly it was a WiFi USB stick, secondly I had major problems with a motherboard, then with a graphic card (plus it took ASUS more than 1 month to send me back the repaired card) and now this tablet. Well, wrapping it up, I'm pretty sure: NO MORE ASUS for me from now on (and not only because what happen to me, but as well because I read so many bad reviews about the Asus' quality issues and its bad support; reading the bad reviews about the quality issues and service problems for the TF701t make me think that ASUS it's going somehow downhill).

Another consequence of what I've been through is that I will never ever buy tablets or smartphones with proprietary connectors. So all the devices I'll buy from now on will have standard USB chargers/connectors, which besides being very convenient is as well Eco-friendly.

First off Amazon has been fantastic both with shipping the product out and handling the returns. I have nothing but praise for them.

The product, on the other hand, has been nothing but a nightmare, and I can't stress this enough, please research it before you buy.

First, and I knew this very well when I bought it the first time, Asus used horrible NAND memory (it's on board memory) on this tablet. It's guaranteed to slow down to a crawl within 8 months to a year. This can be fixed with an unofficial TRIM app that requires you to root the tablet. I'm fairly tech savvy so it wouldn't have been a problem for me, but for the average user you'd wind up with a nice looking brick within a year of use.

2nd, the tablet is known for having random battery, screen, and system board issues, which I wasn't completely aware of until I experienced it first hand. The first TF700T I bought charged and ran fine the day I got it to replace my Acer Iconia A200 (which I'm really upset I didn't keep). The next day it randomly powered off (even though it had 50% battery life remaining), would not turn back on, and would not charge. I tried everything I could find to try to solve the issue but the tablet would not turn or even charge.

I returned that tablet and as soon as I got my refund (which was very, very quick) I ordered a replacement. My gut instincts told me to buy something different, but I had already committed to the Asus by buying a dock, case, and screen protector. The 2nd Asus charged fine, but would not turn on. Again I tried everything I could possibly find by could not get the tablet to turn on. Again Amazon was very quick with processing the return and the refund, which will now be going to a Samsung Galaxy Tab Pro 8.4.

While researching the problems I had with the TF700T I found a laundry list of cases where the tablet would not charge, would not power on, or would not display anything. In most cases the tablets had to be sent to Texas for repair which took weeks between shipping out, getting fixed, and shipping back. If the only problem this tablet had was with the memory Asus used I'd at least recommend it to those who felt comfortable rooting the tablet and setting up a TRIM app, but with everything I've seen I wouldn't recommend this to anybody.

If you're looking for a good, basic Android tablet I'd recommend the Acer Iconia A200 (my previous tablet). It's not the fastest tablet out there but it has a full USB port (great for external drives and thumb drives), has good battery life, and a decent screen. If you're looking for a full featured Android tablet that will knock the socks off an iPad go for the Samsung Galaxy Tab Note 10.1 2014 edition or the Galaxy Tab Pro 8.4. They're expensive but you can't beat Samsung for their quality and full Android OS.

I ordered an off-brand Hannspree product after getting this, as this "top of the line" product was such a piece of junk.  It locked up, it ran super slow, it was full of bugs and glitches, etc.  Surprisingly, the Hannspree product which costs less than 1/2 the price, worked amazingly.  Dont buy!!!!!!!
The screen resolution is very good and the overall design of the tablet looks great. However, it tends to slow down and takes too long to process stuff too often.

This was very nice until the warranty expired. It started rapidly and randomly flashing all the programs on and off and was completely unresponsive to touch. FAIL. It was an expensive foray into tablets for me.

When I could use it, it was great for reading and web browsing. Good for email but really not good for serious work of any kind. Android just isn't up to the task of real spreadsheets and work processing. I replaced it with a Windows Ultralight -  get the portability, speed, and lightness and it still can run serious programs.

I do love this tablet. The clarity is great.  It is pretty fast. I really like it because you can use it like a laptop if you buy the keyboard.  I have had it crash a few times for no reason.  Other than that it is a great product.

I am enjoying yhis tablet.
When I was making the decision to purchase I read a comment about the spontaneous restart that sometimes occurs.....I have experienced that at least 3 times since my purchase in February 2014.  I am a bit annoyed with that.
I put a post it note to remind myself to not activate after I factory reset it and hide away
The system starts to be veeeery slow after 4 months. I restarted factory restore and after a while still very slow. Maybe i should try to root.
THIS TABLET IS JUST WHAT I EXPECTED AND HAS MORE FEATURES THAN NEEDED.  I WOULD BUY THIS UNIT AGAIN AND RECOMMEND IT TO MY FRIENDS.

I enjoyed the unboxing, every thing was down hill from there.  I would rather be forced to buy an apple product than have to deal with Asus again.  A black line went across the  screen shortly after using it. Had to pay to ship it back. After I got it back it did it again.  I had to pay to send it back again.  This tablet really soured me to all tablets.

I've lived with this tablet for 18 months, and at the end I seriously regret spending the $400.

The most egregious issue is the performance. There are two causes for the poor performance; memory and wi-fi. The memory is too limited at 1 GB, although one can chalk that up to trying to keep the costs lower. In addition, the transfer mechanisms used internally for memory access are poorly done, which is simply wretched engineering. Bad ASUS.

The Wi-Fi performance issues are curious. (I'm an engineer. I find really stupid things to be curiosities.) Various experiments have uncovered that there is either some inanely stupid coding in the driver, or that there are hardware issues present; but packets are dropped like popcorn in a movie theater. The browser (or email client, or RSS reader, or ... whatever) then falls back on the timeout to try again. Eventually a re-request is made and the data gets through. In the meantime you've given up on email and gone back to quill pen and snail mail because it offers higher throughput.

Next on the list of woe is stability. At least once a week, and occasionally multiple times a day, the tablet just restarts. Usually when switching apps, or starting a new app up. Everything will freeze, and then you will notice the dreaded "Black Line of Death"; a single row of black pixels at the top of the screen. That means that the system has committed seppuku and will soon be restarting. Whatever you were working on is gone. So sad ...

I still use the wretched thing, as I've too much Scotch blood to buy a different one yet. I can read e-Books on it, and mostly finish one before a restart. Email will work, after a fashion. Web browsing is out of the question. Eventually it will suffer an "accident" and get replaced by something that can actually be as useful as my phone.

I purchased this when it first came out. I thought that it would perform better than the lower end model, due to the increased specs, however, I found the opposite to be true. There is at times so much lag, i find the tablet to be nearly unusable. I wish I had waited and got a Nexus 10 instead. I have had Nexus phones and had no problems with them. I tried rooting the tablet and it still did nothing to improve performance.

I also found that the size was a little more than I thought I needed. The 10in screen is great for watching videos and reading magazines, but can be unwieldy if you don't have it laying down or on a stand. I plan on purchasing a Nexus 8 when it releases later this year.

I've had this unit for some time now and through several updates of the Android OS.  I bought it, in a starry-eyed daze of hardware specs, thinking I would make iPads look like dinosaurs, and it worked out exactly opposite. Unexplained lockups for 3 seconds to a minute, tap-tap-tap-TAP-TAP is now my mantra, as it is terrible on screen response; the exact opposite of the iPad that I purchased for my wife.  I thought the keyboard would be the real killer feature, but it is painful to type on ... with accidental brushes of the touchpad moving the cursor into the middle of the text. The touchpad can be locked, but that's a pain when you want to use it along with the keyboard.

First chance that I get, I'll be trying some custom ROMs instead of the factory ASUS version, but I see some reviewers of custom ROMs saying that they fix some issues, but others remain.  We'll see.

Can't win them all.
So I had this one for about 2 months, then it just died on me and wouldn't turn on.  I had to send it back to amazon for a refund. I love asus products, but i don't know what's up with this one

Even with it's relatively high specs processing power this device seems to lag quite a bit, even after a factory reset the user interface has a tendency to hiccup a lot, the device is also somewhat unstable as it restarts a lot.  It's updated to the latest software as of this writing.
Buggy, slow, and reboots all the time. So frustrating when in the middle of a movie or game. It was great at first but I've had it for 8 months now and will sell it for whatever.

I got this tablet at a very low price, knowing full well it was a year and a half old model. When I picked it up I only wanted to do a few things: read PDFs (for grad school), watch Youtube, browse the web/social networks, and check email. The tablet was essentially for very basic stuff, as my HTC One was considerably more powerful and I bought most games for it.

All I can say is that Jellybean must have broken this tablet, as it is the slowest thing I've ever encountered. I thought the original Kindle Fire was a bit clunky, but it seemed as smooth as butter compared to this thing.

Constant lag, even on just a UI level and from a clean boot. Even sliding the app drawer caused the tablet to slow down or even lock up at times. Any "modern" app (read: Gmail, Dropbox, even Chrome) would drag the entire system to a crawl. Multitasking was impossible. If I only had one program open and used Settings to disable nearly every other app, then SOMETIMES it would work. But most of the time? Complete lockup.

I feel bad because all I wanted was a simple table to do simple things, and I did extensive research on reviews (including here on amazon, but also all over the internet) and it made it sound good. From what it looks like, it's because it's 1 GB ram is lacking, but in addition it uses an outdated transfer method so the ram is much too slow for a modern mobile OS. As such, the tablet is sluggish from the ground up.

I even tried rooting it and putting a custom Rom on; still no dice, the tablet didn't move a muscle. The only thing I didn't do was attempt to downgrade back to ice cream sandwich, but at that point I'd already boxed it back up and sent it back.

Point being: I'm sure this tablet was awesome when it came out, but now (in 2014) it is a slow, cumbersome mess. Spend a few extra bucks and buy something like the MeMo Pad (or a lot more bucks and just get a Nexus 10 or an iPad Air) if you're looking for a 10 inch tablet. For a tablet in 2014, this thing hasn't aged well, and it's only going to get worse from here on out.
I absolutely love this tablet. The screen is very bright and clear.  I gaved it 4 stars because nothing is perfect but its a wonderful investment if you are a Android fan.
Horrible. Wait forever for any browser to work. Tried every trick on the net, including rooting it. Complete waste of $$. WILL NEVER PURCHASE AN ASUS PRODUCT AGAIN.

So disappointed. In certain situations about 1/4 of the screen is covered a black fog. This is from day one. Biggest drawback is that it does not use Adobe Flash, so may images do not show, but it displays "unsupported plug in". Its often unresponsive and hangs up repeatedly. Wish I had got a Chrome book.

Due to internal storage slowness (on this premium tablet) the entire user experience is ruined. Asus really blew it on this one. The screen is super HD and bright, the processor is solid, and the wifi and GPS issues are mostly resolved. But the internal storage causes everything to be slow.

Custom ROMs can help tweak and make it usable most of the time, but it still runs into issues. This is made worse by the 1 GB RAM limit which causes browsers to lag a lot with multiple tabs and apps running in the background.

Overall this was a step up over the previous version, but it wasn't fully executed and missed the mark. This leaves the price for the tablet and dock to be too high. I've heard good things about the new version of this tablet that came out recently, but most people are done with Asus after the many issues found in the TF201 series and the slow storage of the TF700.

Their budget tablets seem to be a much better bang for the buck. They just haven't really been able to pull off an all-around solid high end hybrid device yet.

I enjoyed my Infinity when I first got it, the clamshell keyboard design is fantastic.  I use it a lot, and performance was decent most of the time, but every once in a while it would slow down or have issue.  Then about 8 months after I bought it, it just stopped working, press the power button, nothing.  I sent it in for RMA and they repaired it (and put a huge white sticker on it that was near impossible to get off).  Now several months later I have the same problem, and it's out of warranty.  I currently have 4 ASUS products in my house, this will probably be the last one.
My Ipad broke and I really didn't want to get another one, so I wanted to try something different. I couldn't be more happy with the Asus!!!

I am not going to go "geek" on this but I love this tablet
it does exactly what I needed it to do, read PDF files I throw on my Micro SD memory card, surf the web, and play battlefield commander.

the display is very nice and bright, great control when "clicking" and the battery last for a long time.
I admit, I wanted the latest and greatest as soon as it came out. I should have waited and bought something so much cheaper. There are tablets out there that do just as much for so much less.
Awesome and loving my tablet..My 1st buy and so far i'm rather satisfied. Tablet came as promised in a sealed box with all accessories..

I am an android fan...my htc ph. has never given me an issue. Before that I had a samsung s3,again ran perfect. But since buying android tablets-specifically Asus...im seriously considering apple...sigh
I bought the memo pad smart...went thru 2 of those (both returned) before i got this infinity. The reviews say its the best android tablet at 10in...NOT...Same issues as with both the other asus tablets...constant freezing,reboots and white screens of death...many times per day!!
I do not install any crazy apps, I browse the web,with preinstalled browser, watch movies with play movies and you tube...just regular stuff..no gaming or anything this tablet shouldnt be able to handle half asleep!
Epic fail in my opinion
This ones going back as well...for the 650 plus dollars ive spent,i expect perfection from a commercial product claiming to be the best...just saying
I bought this mostly to play games and watch Netflix. It's great! I'm not tied to the desktop any more.

Nothing special about the tab.  You do not notice the higher processing speed or the better screen at all.  On top of it, my tab suddenly decides not to power on.  When this happens I need to send it in at my expense to repair the product which takes a month for Asus to receive, repair and send back, on top of one week of multiple phone calls to get the RMA details established.  I would not recommend this or any other Asus product to anyone, ever.  Not worth the poor quality and bad service that they provide for such expensive products.

Good news:
- Battery life is good and the dock extends it well
- Most apps work well, including Gmail, Drive, Kindle, and any of the games I've tried
- Video playback is good, either streaming (Netflix) or off the disk

Bad news:
- Web browsing is unbelievably slow, regardless of browser (I've tried Firefox, Opera, and Chrome). The contrast with my MacBook Pro or my wife's iPad 2 is pronounced.
- I was never able to set up the remote desktop services or cloud storage
- It's not an even approximately adequate desktop replacement, even with the keyboard dock. When my Mac was in the shop for a few days I tried using the tablet as a desktop replacement and gave up after a couple hours to use my Mint desktop.
- It crashes about once a week

I bought the TF700 at a premium right when it came out. The specs sounded great but the implementation was poor. This thing gets really bogged down, even when you're running something basic. Each time there was an update I was hoping it would improve but it never really did and in some respects it actually feels slower, especially the keyboard. At this point Asus is no longer releasing updates for it so it's pretty much a dead product.

My other major complaint is volume. I don't care about the volume from the speakers; I don't use them very often and I don't expect tablet speakers to be particularly loud. My problem is when using headphones; even with good quality noise cancelling headphones I can barely hear it when I'm on an airplane. The same headphones on my Galaxy S3 can go way louder than I need them to. Asus told me an update that came out last year would fix it but I don't think it got any louder.

This tablet looks but performance is poor than any other Tab I have owned before  it is too heavy, the screen becomes unresponsive sometimes, just one sided speaker HUHUH you must be kidding one sided speaker yes one and really annoying because you ain't got more choices to chose from.
I wish I was home when it arrived I would have sent it back and get myself SAMSUNG OR TOSHIBA but not this one.
on Wifi is so fast to catch up than other tabs I ahve seen before including toshiba because it can use weak wfi wher other devices have failed and for this reason I decided to keep it may be I will donate it later next year.

I just got to add my frustration. I check reviews so carefully on this. My TF700 got progressively worse quickly after adding apps and upgrades from Asus (especially the last one) since I bought in Nov 2012. It was painfully slow and quirky. I was stupid enough to buy the 64GB version, so I am really in the hole for some money and all the accessories. To make matters worse, I plugged in my TF700 to charge one night two weeks ago and got no reaction. Dead! It was on an expensive surge protector and Asus charger. Sent it to Asus, they just wrote back since it is out of warranty, it will cost $300 to repair. Motherboard needs to be replaced . Won't tell me what is wrong or how long the repair is guaranteed for. I am done with Asus. This was an over-hyped POS. Battery sucked too, even with keyboard. The problems are notorious in the forums. Buy something else!

The TF700tT has some nice features, but they're diminished by some flaws. First and foremost is the poorly designed latching pins for the keyboard. After a little better then a month one of the broke off in the course of normal use.  The keyboard latch pins are tiny plastic tabs, literally the size of a healthy grain of rice,  that hang off an internal plastic framework.  The connect points between the pin and internal framework are very thin and other wise unsupported, so eventually the pressure of being inserted into the keyboard, combined with any physical jostling, bumping, or god forbid dropping  (even cased) will cause the pins to snap off.  Unfortunately, as Asus customer support really doesn't want to see this defect as covered under warranty, they quoted me a $$$ repair cost and 2-4 weeks of away time.  So with the help of a magnify bench light, micro tweezers, and a good super glue, I got i back in and reinforced the unbroken side.  Asus should have made them metal, or at least screw/adhesived them to the casing.  I might have blames myself for tabs breaking,  but this the SECOND exact same model that i've had the latch tabs beak off of, an I really babied this one.

The other big problem is the amount of OEM bloat ware on the thing.  On a straight from the factory machine, it doesn't seem all that bad, but once you do all the firmware updates (official Asus stuff they push out) and bring it up to the latest version of Android, The tablet starts to get noticeably slugish.  Removing the OEM bloatware is a bit of a pain as it requires a bit of trial and error, but well worth is as the performance improves quite a bit.

I have used other Asus products and they have been very good. I was excited to see that Asus was updating their product line with the TF-700. However, this has been my experience in chronological order:
1. Christmas December 2012: TF 700 is opened and found to be dead on arrival (DOA). Hey it happens no big deal.

2. The day after Christmas: Went and exchanged it without any problems.

3. The subsequent days using the tablet I had it crash every hour at least once or twice with several cold boots to follow.

4. From January 2013 until February 2013 the product continues to drain the battery at an excessive rate; even when powered off. As well, the screen begins to develop a random black line across it no matter what application you have running.

5. Called Amazon and they told me to contact the manufacturer because it was under the one year warranty and I could not use my square trade warranty. I understand fair enough. After contacting Asus they had the audacity to inform me that I had to ship them their broken tablet at my own expense... Furthermore, they "fixed" the tablet. Yes, they did fix the excessive battery draining, but they did not fix the screen from flickering nor the multiple crashes.

6. The experience in using the tablet caused me not to use for most of 2013. Seriously this was a tablet I was supposed to use on a daily basis for school. Luckily for me I was given another tablet from my work.

7. January 2014 the screen has a hairline crack from the top of the tablet to the bottom. Seriously, I had not used it and kept it closed with the keyboard docking station; so WTF? I called Amazon and used my square trade policy to have the tablet returned to the manufacturer and I got a full refund plus a little extra because I wanted the refund on an Amazon gift card.

The bottom line is that I am disappointed with this product and even more so with the customer experience in dealing with Asus. Please do not buy this product.

First things first. I am a old customer of Asus products from the time they started manufacturing Motherboards. They are absolutely good at doing that (and Graphics cards perhaps). But this was a train-wreck in the making. I got into the hype and bought this with the 150$ (which I don't use much). If this is not a scam then what is? Absolutely slow even when doing normal tasks and bugs abound. Check "Eastside's" review for a detailed analysis of what is happening with buyers of this tablet all over the place. Same issues. Sad that Asus didn't man up to their mess and take back their tablets for a refund to the naive users. I am thinking of starting a change.org petition to at least make Asus realize that they could have made us look like fools but it ain't come cheap. DO NOT BUY TABLETS FROM ASUS!

Bought this tablet. Had to return due to screen delaminating. Second tablet wouldn't stay connected to dock. Third tablet had constant slow downs. Had to root and install custom rom. I though it was a construction problem, even after two replacement of the tablet (Thank you Asus support, they are really professional and understand the customers) the problem remain, that means it is design-related and it is not an isolated, manufacturing problem.

I ended up switching for an Ipad Mini and despite the fact that I am an open-source enthusiast, leaving this Android Tablet was the best choice I have made. Do not buy this Tablet.

I bought this tablet a while ago and am just now getting rid of it.  Figured I would add a review.

I was attracted to the docking capability and the relatively low bloatware compared to what other manufacturers put on their tablets.  Unfortunately, both of those were misfires.

I've reviewed the dock separately, but it was a disaster.  The dock would lose keyboard and touchpad connectivity with the tablet constantly, especially if the dock hinge was moved at all.  When that happened, I couldn't type anything until I disconnected and reseated the tablet - the on-screen keyboard won't come up if the dock is connected.

Furthermore, the tablet itself is excruciatingly slow, with a noticeable lag to everything it does.  Even something as simple as waking the tablet, opening the browser and starting a website regularly takes 30 seconds or more, even in "performance" mode, whereas I can do the same in 10 seconds on my Android phone.  I tried resetting the tablet to factory default, thinking that the apps I installed were causing issues, but that made no difference.

I've seen benchmarks showing that the TF700 performs much better when running with a stock version of Android.  While Asus doesn't put much bloatware on the tablet, apparently the little bit that is there causes a lot of the issues.  I didn't want to root my device, but I tried replacing some of the core features with better ones from the app store (e.g., SwiftKey and the Chrome browser), but that actually made performance significantly worse.

The tablet does have a nice screen, and works great for watching movies and such.  However, it's dreadfully slow on many other tasks, making it a pain to use.  I'm selling mine, and glad to be rid of it.

I got this as a Christmas present last year.  The ability to use external memory storage and the sharp screen were strong selling points.  I am an avid photographer and do a lot of landscape work so I liked the wide screen format compared to the IPad.  However, even with reduced photo file sizes to match the screen size the Asus handled the pictures poorly.
