I had high hopes for this device.  And, to be fair, it might be less the device and more the ASUS updates that have been pushed down--but, given ASUS is behind them both, I believe this review is still valid.  I spent about $800 for both the tablet and the dockable keyboard about a year ago.

1.)  The battery life is *terrible.* Especially after the past two updates, which is about the past 9-12 months.  I have both the battery in the tablet and the tablet dock, which has another battery, and from a full charge, it takes less than 18 hours to drain them both while in standby.  To state it another way:  From a full charge, and the WIFI setting set to turn off when unplugged (effectively disconnected from the internet), and the device in the "off" state (not shut down, but not active or in use) it drains both batteries in under 18 hours.  This is just not acceptable.

2.)  Loading applications after a reboot, starting a browser session, accessing settings, sliding across screens is laggy, horrendously slow, jumpy, and buggy (applications crashing--or needing to be shut down).

3.)  The system will randomly reboot.  (Akin to the blue screens of old WinOS days).  Once it crashes, it will try to reboot, but the OS will be quite buggy as though some remnant of the prior session is still active in memory.  SO, after a reboot, you need to go through the shutdown process all over again until you get a clean shut down.  This is problematic, because even though you choose "shut down" as the option to power off, the system will actually try to "restart" itself over and over again.  (This is why I think there is a remnant of something still active from the crashed session.)  Eventually, after at least three and as many as seven (based upon my experience) you'll get a clean shut down, and you can power up and be okay until the next crash.

NOW, the logical expectation for me and my experience is to say, why haven't you done a factory reset--it sounds like something serious is wrong.  In fact, I have done four since getting the device in 2012.  Four times I have gone through the arduous task of backing up my files to the cloud, resetting the device, starting with a clean system, re-establishing all of my accounts and settings, and putting my data back on the device (if I want it back on).  Each time is a few hours to do the actual reset and a several days to get everything configured and set up again.  This isn't acceptable.

To be fair, I like the concept.  I like Asus technology in general.  I very much enjoy having a physical keyboard, which makes using a tablet as a primary device a possibility.  I think the resolution is amazing.  I like the concept of having an extra battery and extended life.  When the device was new (pre ASUS updates) it worked beautifully.  But, the device as it sits now, with current ASUS updates is undependable and if I had an option for a tablet with a physical keyboard (non bluetooth because they are in fact laggy and ridiculous to use), I would switch in a minute.

I consider this a big miss for Asus, and I will definitely look at a different manufacturer when I'm ready to replace this one.
In less than a year the WiFi system failed.  Other than that, it was awesome!  However, WiFi is a must have with any system.

Biggest waist of money.  Surfing the web is god awfully slow.  If you're downloading an app or something you have to wait until it's done before you can do anything else.  What good is 2 processor cores if you can't multitask?  Sometime pressing the on button has a long delayed reaction time.

At this point I'm just going to install a ROM and hope that somebody was able to make it useful.  If that doesn't pan out then I guess I'll have to spend more money on a new tablet.

I expected more from ASUS.  Boy was I wrong.

I have certain things I need a tablet to do and this one does them all.  I use it to browse the Internet, get & send emails, read books, read and edit MS Office documents, take notes, keep track of my contacts and calendar, watch movies, listen to music, remotely control other computers, take pictures and videos, and a few other things.

Like most Android devices, it needed a few tweaks out of the box.  The stock browser was agonizingly slow: fixed by downloading a 3rd party free browser.  Had a few problems with the email app: downloaded AquaMail Pro (cost a couple of bucks).  K-9 Mail doesn't work well on the TF700T.  The speaker (one "stereo" speaker) is weak but works fine for everything but music & video, and I use speakers or headphones for both.

On the plus side, the TF700T is sleek, metal instead of plastic, and has a great looking screen.  The screen is made of Gorilla Glass so it should also be tough.  You can add a micro sd card and it has a micro HDMI port.  And, if you want a physical keyboard, the optional dock is excellent, with an additional battery, keyboard & touchpad, sd card reader, and usb port.

I've read reviews here about the TF700T being slow, locking up, stuttering, etc.  I haven't experienced these things except for the stock browser.  This is my third tablet (iPad 2, Blackberry PlayBook) and I have no complaints.  To paraphrase another reviewer here, don't be afraid to buy this tablet.

edit:  I changed my rating to 4 stars from 3.  I like this tablet and it occurred to me that a lot of people don't think 3 stars is a very good rating.

Update:.
I've had this tablet for a while now and use it every day, and I can see what what the negative reviewers are talking about.  It will occasionally slow down when checking for updates and has locked up a couple of times when on standby.  I'm an IT Consultant and working around these things is a minor inconvenience for me; I still like it.  If you're looking for your first tablet or aren't computer-savvy, get an iPad.  Less features and more expensive, but my wife (who fits in that category) loves hers.

First of all I've been an IPad user for ever.  Hard to change when the IPad has done such a good job, but, it was time for an upgrade, without having to spend the high dollars demanded by Apple.  Not bashing Apple, but just looking for the best deal for my dollars.  The TF700 Transformer Tablet took a good 10 days to get used to.  I even thought about going back to the IPad, but stuck it out.  Now, I'm very happy with my new tablet.  I've been able to get pretty much every app that I enjoyed on the IPad, including a few I didn't know about that was available in the Google Play Store.  The tablet loads very quickly and is so easy to work with.  I also purchased the keyboard as it has made it easier to make notes, emails, and even make up documents.  There's no shortage of options to customize it to make it your own tablet.  I was initially disappointed with the factory "play music" app, but soon learned about the dozen's of free options through the play store, including apps that can transfer my music wirelessly from my ITunes to my TF700.  Using "Shuttle" app, it even sets up the same playlists that I had on my IPad.  I'm able to use Firefox as my browser, and new emails to my GMail account briefly show up in one corner to let me know instantly of mail received.  Now after 3 weeks, I'm very happy to have made the change.  Using the keyboard which has a USB port, I can easily transfer info, music, pictures, documents, and have already watched movies on the tablet.  I really like the IPad, but love the  this TF700 Transformer Tablet.

Shame on you AS; I've been a big fan of your motherboards, laptops, and network equipment, but this tablet is horrible.  I was very excited last Christmas when I received this tablet as it had been reviewed so well and it seemed to have enough hardware to be able to compete with an iPad.  It seemed fairy snappy for a bit and then the problems started.

Basic tasks like typing into the address bar of the web browser lags horribly.  Launching the Kindle app literally takes up to 15 seconds at times.  Multitasking is a joke as it can take up to 30 seconds to switch apps and it sometimes crashes and you have to wait another 15 seconds or so for it to update.

I have done about five wipes of the device hoping that it speeds it up and there has been no difference.  Even when it comes factory reset it is only slightly faster than when you add your own apps.  The "performance" setting makes only a slight boost in speed.  The really frustrating thing is that this tablet flies when playing full screen games like Need For Speed but at the same time can't accept basic typing without choking.  My co-workers urged me to send it back to ASUS since it was still under warranty (which cost me $15 bucks with insurance) and they sent it back wiped and said the device didn't have any issues.

I have never been a fan of how much Apple locks down their devices and you have to pay extra for everything that comes standard on the Infinity like and HDMI output and Mini SD card slot.  I hate to say it, but nothing I have used so far comes even close to an iPad 2 which is now three generations back.  I work with iPads everyday at work and it pains me that nobody can come up with an Android tablet that can come even close to an iPad.  I have heard good things about the Kindle Fire HDX and Nexus 7, but we'll have to see.

If I had known how slow this tablet was, I would have paid a little extra and purchased an iPad.  The only reason I'm giving it two stars is because it has a great screen and nice feel.
Fantastic tablet!!  Does everything I could want it to do. And I got it at such a great price!  Who could go wrong with this?

I upgraded from a TF101 because I liked it so much. But I had rooted the TF101 and the ROM I used was speedy. The TF700 was fast and responsive until it started filling up, and three months out, it's so slow that it's turned into a svelte Amherst gray brick. When I do need to use the tablet, I have to wait about 10 minutes for the tablet to become usable. Whenever any app is updating in the background, the tablet is unusable. Whenever a background process is running (for instance, Gmail sync), the tablet is unusable. Whenever I type an email, the lag is so great that sometimes an entire sentence will appear several seconds after I typed it.

I'm still waiting for Asus to provide an official update to the TF700 with Android 4.3, but that hasn't happened and I've lost patience. To save on costs, Asus used the cheapest, slowest storage it could find on the market, which is a bottleneck for the rest of the otherwise top-of-the-line tablet (Tegra 3, bright HD LCD, premium finish, etc). Android 4.3 brings TRIM support. TRIM is a routine that runs in the background to track used blocks on your computer's storage, so the unused blocks can be rewritten efficiently. So I could root this device, void the warranty, and use a ROM that's much faster, or wait until Asus gets around to updating this tablet to a version of Android that's already 6 months old.

This product is virtually unusable. All media functionality on this device grinds to a halt after a few minutes of use. Other reviewers have stated that this is due to slow memory i/o speeds, and that this is partially fixable with a warranty-breaking, 3rd party firmware such as cyanogen or some kang. I don't have the energy to try this, as I believe recent Asus updates have locked down the bootloader pretty hard. Those same updates broke their bloatware weather widget, by the way. YouTube, web browsing with chrome or the android browser, and the tegra-3-optimized splashtop client all become unusably sluggish after minutes, or even seconds of use. The browser crashes entirely. YouTube can't play five minute videos without stopping to buffer. Guess what! We can watch the same videos flawlessly on my wife's six-year-old ultra-portable windows xp laptop. It has lower hardware specs all around, and it streams fine, at the same resolution! Splashtop is just a choppy mess. I don't understand why they say this is optimized. Optimized for what?

I ignored the warnings about this device. Maybe it's some kind of situation where you'll be pleased with the device 9 times out of 10, and I got a bad one... but I don't think I'll ever buy another Asus tablet again. This thing is such a disappointment. I wanted so badly to have a tablet with the form factor of a laptop, and this has exactly that when you buy the dock. That part of it is excellent. It's better than anything else I was able to find, but the lag turns this into virtually a brick with a nice keyboard. Asus, shame on you.

Tablet takes 10 minutes plus to 'warm' up and doesn't seem to be able to do anything until it is completely though with the start up phase.  I have never had an Android device that had this problem.  When you talk to Customer Service, they just brush you off.  Would not recommend nor would I ever purchase another Asus product.
Purchased this for my son to use as part of his specialized training after BCT. This is an excellent product! I wanted to keep it for myself!

Like a lot of people my screen cracked due to the loose screen design flaw. When it said geurilla glass, I bought it, after taking it apart it's clear that they made the digitizer 1mm thick which causes it to crack with the slightest amount of twist. I've purchased a replacement digitizer for several tablets now and the one for the tf700t is impossible to replace without also replacing the middle plastic housing, which I can't find anywhere online.

Don't buy unless you want a $600 paper weight.

The tablet is excellent. This our first time with an android product so it is taking some time to get use to the system. The screen quality and sound quality is excellent. We had some trouble connecting to the internet, and the guy at ASUS customer service was no help, but we finally figured it out ourselves. The 82 page online manual needs a revision. We don't know who the manual was talking to, but it wasn't talking to us.

I've only had this for a few days, but so far so good- THIS IS COOL!
I was about to return the one I had because there was an issue with the wifi connection- a quick search will find LOTS of issues.  As it turns out, it's one of those simple fixes IF you know what it is.... Change your router security from WEP encryption to WPA/WPA2.  That's it!  The Transformers do not work well (or not at all, with mine) with WEP encryption.  And definitely sign up for the forum- the "Transforum"- at transformerforums,com- lots of good tips there.

Great picture quality & usability. I also bought the case & the mobile docking station, which I've honestly never used.

I bought this so I could load my work email on it & not have to lug my laptop for work trips, especially since I occasionally travel internationally. Ideally, this tablet would come loaded with Microsoft, but I was able to download the free Polaris app so I can open Adobe PDF files.

I use my tablet all the time...love it!

Honestly, I couldn't see a difference between the IPS screen on this machine and the one on its little sister, the TF 300. Useless outdoors, in daylight, but terrific on the plane or at your desk. Lots of power for smooth video playback, and now that VLC is available for Android, I'm not sure why you would need anything else for entertainment. Just don't expect to use this tablet as a productivity machine. But who does?
I had a problem with the tablet and ASUS responded quickly.  I could not ask for better service.  I use the tablet more than my computer these days.

This is a FANTASTIC Tablet.  I had an Acer dual core before this and loved it, too, but it didn't have the power to play HD videos without stopping to buffer them every few seconds.  This one plays the HD videos just fine.  I bought a Sony 64GB SD card for the keyboard drive which really adds a LOT to the whole device.  The keyboard is nice at times, but makes it rather clumsy.  I still like just using the tablet by itself and they batter seems to REALISTICALLY last about 6 hours of steady use, not as much as it advertises.  It is currently the BEST of the BEST.  I would highly recommend the ASUS.

I purchased this as a replacement for the Xoom FE. I was excited to finally get rid of the slow xoom, but i found that this had a defective screen. Worried about quality control, I returned this tablet and purchased the Nexus 10 straight from Google. Haven't looked back since.
The speaker is not any good.  There is no way to make the speaker loud enough to hear except in a silent room.  It is okay if you want a tablet that you can only listen to with earphones.

I love my Transformer! Wish I hadn't waited so long to get it. I bought it at the recommendation of an IT colleague who had done a lot of research on tablets. My transformer stays charged for a long time and charges quickly when needed. It's easy to carry around and handy to have everywhere.

If it had a SIM card to connect to my Verizon data plan it would be perfect, but, I easily work around that by connecting it to my Note II.

Bought this tablet as its supposed to be super fast. Well super fast my arse... my Nexus 4 is faster... after optimising the settings etc I managed to get it running ok. However, I'm already thinking of replacing it and selling it... love android just not this tablet.. it was released to market too quickly..

I replaced my Kindle Fire 8.9 about a year ago with this tablet because the Asus tablet supports Adobe Flash Player, unlike the new Kindle which locked up at Flash websites; but I have to say that the Asus sound is horrible compared to other two speaker stereo tablets.  The ASUS tablet has one small speaker on the back (2"x1/4") facing out with about 100 micro holes for the sound to pass through.  The only way to hear anything, is to cup your hand around the speaker to bounce back the sound. However, the ASUS tablet has an adjustable equalizer for music (the new Kindles don't have a manual equalizer anymore since going Dolby)...but the ASUS only sounds good with earphones or bluetooth speakers.  Do not buy this tablet expecting to use it without an enhanced listening device. It might as well not have a speaker at all.  And ASUS describes the tablet as having superior sound.

Everything else about the tablet is good (for me) and performs well.  No lockups on websites that use Flash Player - and that's why I'm going to keep the ASUS tablet - it supports Adobe Flash Player. But Like I told a friend:  The ASUS tablet is like driving a choice sports car while listening to a transistor radio.

11/08/13:  I just purchased an RCA clip-on stereo speaker set from Amazon.  It came with good reviews, it's priced right, and I think will be sufficient to use with the ASUS. I hope so.
The tablet works good.  Sound volume is not very loud.  Very limited number of good apps for children 3-5 yrs old

I did the research and this model tablet came highly recommended. I was not disappointed. Not only is it a great tablet, it has a great screen,is very lightweight, and recharges in 30 minutes. The vendor had it delivered to my home in less than week.
After 5 months of very light use it just DIED. Will not power up. spent $21 to ship it back to ASUS for warranty repair.

A very fast tablet, compared it to my friend's Ipad 3. Even with the retina display, we both felt that the TF700 had the better screen of the two (with the brightness up). The wifi is worse than that of the TF300, as is the bluetooth. I also bought the dock too, and I would have to say that it really transforms it into a computer running android.

This tablet is very good for anyone new to the tablet world but the only thing that hinders it is that the 1gb ram can easily get close to max capacity (always use a task killer app for this problem), the google chrome app seems to be extremely slow at times but the stock browser works just fine, you can read books, view movies and all the works with this tablet.
Now heres the very bad part, the tablet screen, it seems like there is a small space in between the sreen and the bezel or back aluminum plate and sometimes itll make the tablet register "phantom" taps, to fix this you have to turn the screen of and on (as in black screen not power off) although its better to just get it sent in for a replacement.

If your tablet shuts down from the battery running out, it has to be sent back to ASUS for repair. Am now waiting on day 5 for a response from customer service.

DO NOT BUY THIS TABLET

(Review has been udpated - scroll down for the update)
-------------------------------------------------------

When I first got my ASUS tablet, I loved it.  Clear picture.  More flexibility than its iCompetitor.

That changed a few months later when I started having screen issues.  At times, the screen wouldn't respond to touch.  Or it would respond, but not the way I wanted it to.  I would touch a link on the bottom of the screen and a link elsewhere on the screen would be activated.  Or I'd be typing and get to a letter and the tablet wouldn't accept that letter (but would accept other letters I touched).  And then came the frequent rebooting.  If the tablet was in use and I would plug in the charger, the tablet would often reboot.

I tried hard booting it.  I returned it to factory settings.  Nothing helped.  So, since it still under warranty, I contacted ASUS.  I shipped my tablet to them (at my expense) with a detailed description of the problems I was having.  About a week later, they sent it back.

I opened up the package and turned my tablet on.  After it powered up, I started to re-enter my information - only to discover that the screen still had the same issues I sent it in to ASUS to have repaired.

I contacted ASUS support and was told basically that they changed out my charger, but couldn't get the problem I had to re-occur, so they just sent it back with the new cord.  I was told that I could send it back in again to be looked at.

I will be shipping it back, but I don't have my hopes up that anything will be different the second time.

Disappointed in ASUS's product and their "customer service."

------------------------------UPDATE----------------------------------

I sent it back a week ago and apparently, it was fixed.  I say apparently because no one there can give me a definitive answer as to where it is.  Apparently it was shipped two days ago, but no one can find a tracking number, so I have no way of knowing for sure that it was sent back or when it might arrive.

The number of people I've had to contact just to TRY and find out if it was repaired or shipped in unreal.  And even after a few different customer service folks and at least 2 different "supervisors" - I still don't know.

AAARRRRRRRGGGGGGHHHHHHHHH!!!

Nice tablet! very high quality feel and look. The first thing you have to do is unlock it (go to ASUS website), root it and put Cromi-x OS on it.  The ASUS OS is bloated and kinda slow but Cromi-x fixes ya right up! Don't do an update on it or you can't root it.

I bought the Asus TF700 a few months ago, and it is already broken, although I did not use it much, and only as a kind of e-reader. The tablet does not react to the switch-on button, and there is no green light despite being fully charged. The original charger was always a problem, the connection being loose, and stopped working while in Germany. There I managed to charge the tablet with a replacement charger from Easy Access. I tried the same product (with U.S. specifications) here, but the tablet does not acknowledge the charge.
We bought this tablet for our daughter for her birthday.  She loves it!  We also like the android phone app you can use to regulate time limits and what apps she can use.

I travel a lot, and 90% of the time, my iPad 3 with $40 Apple HDMI adapter (2nd generation) doesn't work on hotel TVs.
So I bought this before a three-week business trip, and it worked perfectly.

Like the title says...

I've owned this device for a little over one year now, and I have to say, it's been a constant, consistent source of frustration. This thing is the opposite of being an absolute pleasure to use. I almost dread picking it up at this point, because I know there's a high probability using it will lead to me wanting to smash it (which I have almost done several times now). I truly hate this thing and wish I'd never bought it.

There are so many problems with it, but here's a relatively concise list:

1. Terrible build quality: From day one, the screen cover was not well seated, the buttons feel soft and cheap (like they're going to stick), there's a strong amount of light bleed on the sides of the screen.

2. Absolutely atrocious performance: Again from day one, the lag on this thing has been a pain in the behind. Given its hardware specs, it should have no problems whatsoever running apps, opening documents, switching from screen to screen in the UI, etc (although, how could they have put only 1GB of RAM in it?!?). However, this is nowhere near the case. It started off being absolutely unbearable to use. After a few months of owning it, I finally decided I had nothing to lose, and went ahead and rooted it and installed a custom OS (CROMi). This made the tablet much more bearable to use; but it's still super frustrating to use on a constant basis. There are still massive lags when opening up PDF documents, for example, or if there are more than a couple apps open at the same time. It's mind blowing how much I've had to do to this thing in way of mods, and even after that, it's still not as good as an iPad is out of the box (and trust me, I'm no Apple fanboy - I just like to use what works well and doesn't give me excessive headaches).

3. Poor peripherals and design: The built in speaker is near useless, since it's so quiet you need to be in a totally quiet room to hear it. It doesn't help that it's in the back, so most of the sound is projected AWAY from the listener! The headphones jack is in the worst possible spot, such that it blocks your hand from resting comfortably on the device while holding it. I was able to get used to this eventually, but still. The proprietary charging/data transfer connection is poorly designed. The plug fits very loosely in it, and is easy to pull out. The same goes for the USB adapter, which rests very insecurely in it. And why not have a USB port built directly into it, instead of having to use an adaptor???

4. Terrible battery life: The battery life in this things is a joke. Can't get through more than about 6 hours of normal use - maybe 10 with the keyboard dock.

There's only one positive thing I have to say about this device: The screen is very nice. It's nice and sharp and produces nice levels of saturation. However, even there, it's not ideal, since the color accuracy of the screen in not very good, and it tends to crush the blacks.

This has been my first experience with Android, and I have to say, I'm unimpressed so far. I'm about to give Android another try with a Galaxy Note 3, so we'll see how that goes...

Overall, I would never recommend this tablet to ANYONE. Terrible product.
Also have the older version and it's done me well. I love this one just the same, quick delivery and great price.

This is an awesome tablet. I am not an Apple fan, so I look at other products. The Samsung is a good tablet, but for business - that is my primary use, this is great. Together with Evernote and other business tools I can't ask for anything more. The graphics are very goo and the sound is also very good.
Upgraded from Asus TF300 to the 700 due to higher screen resolution.  Screen is excellent, and though purely subjective tablet seems to function somewhat better that the 300.

The major issue that I have with the thing is that the device is incredibly slow and unresponsive, especially when you have multiple apps running.  But just taking a rebooted device and opening a browser can be quite slow as well.  I have looked all over for tweaks to improve performance, and while I have found some things that help somewhat, at the end of the day the tablet is still a pain to use.

I have seen people suggest that the major problem with the thing is that it only has 1G of RAM, and that might well be the underlying problem. Unfortunately it isn't fixable - your only option is to discard the tablet and get a different one and hope that it performs well.

The problem for people trying the thing out in the store is that you are most likely only playing with a browser.  You won't have the facebook app running, and you won't have many other apps running.  Thus on the surface it might appear to be performing well.

Fantastic! Every thing about it. Havent found anything negative yet. I hardly watch my TV any more because the vidio on this is so crisp and bright.  I watch "online tv" a lot now, (like Gaither TV especially is incredable on this).  Love it, love it, love it.

I chose this product, becauase it had the best reviews.  It does everything it said it would, and more.  I love this tablet.  It allows me to connect to my home computer through mycloud.  I can be productive even from the road.  I am very happy with the awesome notepad app.  I can take a photo of a document, and keep it right in line with hand written notes.  This is one computing device I am glad I own, and I have recommended it to my friends!

Update: about a year after purchasing this tablet, the WiFi stopped functioning. It tries to connect, and then says connection failed. I searched the internet for a solution, and apparently it is a known issue with this product. there is no way to fix this issue. I even tried resetting to factory settings, but that just made things worse. I can't update the software, nor find a workaround to this problem. It is now a giant paperweight on my desk.

Saw this when I signed on to amazon, and figured "shoot, why not put in a good word. I love this thing. ASUS makes good products to begin with , and this is nothing short of great. I love the portability of tablets, and the camera on this is wonderful too. I'm an avid android user, and so the interface was familiar to me. The display is great, and the battery last a long time. I've even found a few graphics apps that I use on a regular basis for photo editing ... from bed... the downfall of this is nothing to do with the product... the downfall is:  It made me productively LAZY. Now, Time to get on a diet.
I can recomend this produt it's the best vs the Price, You can review the pc magazine in the section tablets and been with me in the choice

I bought this product through a some re-seller here on amazon. early July(2013), I love it, used it for pretty much everything, as I have no laptop and desktop recently died. responsive, screen image quality I really enjoyed, camera fabulous. I could not say enough good about it.

Last week a most lovely family member of mine was using my tablet, somehow during this time the infinity fell off(first time ever dropped to my knowlage) the couch(roughly 2.5ft) screen is wonderfully creaked, mainly in the top left corner, but stretching out across the screen like branches of a tree. It is still usable touch works fine, just have to careful of splinters of glass when sliding...
I contacted Asus right away they said(screen damage is always the fault of user therefore no warranty est cost to repair would be $305(half the price of the tablet at the time.) Yes I realize it is the fault of the user. so I can not be to upset with Asus about the warranty. But, I would like to worn you that the "tough gorilla glass 2" is not so tough. maybe they will fix this in the next modal they turn out.

I wish they or somebody sold parts so I could do the repair myself.(if anyone has found out where to find parts please inform me!)

I love this tablet - it is quick, the screen quality is amazing, comes with very helpful programs. My only issue is that the speaker is not very loud when playing certain movies or songs - but that can easily be fixed by buying small speakers. This is better than ipad!
An awesome tablet! Great screen resolution. These are the extra words required. Stupid requirement to have! One two three four

The ASUS 10incher met my expectations. I liked it so much I got an ASUS 7incher. However, I wouldnt recommend the 7incherget because the tablet powers off by itself frequently and battery life is half of what the 10incher is.
Slow on line.  My wife's iPad 2 is faster. But it works better than a laptop. And screen looks good. Great camera too.

I did a lot of research before I bought my ASUS Transformer Infinity tablet.  It has been rated up there with the Applie iPad but at half the price so since I am on social security, I opted for the one that cost the least.  I LOVE the tablet; HOWEVER, it is coming apart at the top next to the on/off switch and it causes the screen to freeze so that I can't do anything, not even turn it off.  I sent it to ASUS for repair three weeks ago and I have called customer support twice and had a 30  minute "live chat".  They all say they cannot let me talk to the warranty/repair department; they only communicate through email and they said they have tried to contact me through email but I haven't responded.  I have not received an email and I've checked it every day repeatedly, including spam.  All I've managed to get out of the "support" department is they were letting me know how much it will cost ME to repair it.  Since the case is cracked; they automatically assume it has been dropped and it is therefore considered "CID", customer induced damage.

I keep my tablet in a leather case and carry it in a laptop bag and I have NEVER dropped it. Of course everyone will say that, so they won't believe me.  It is less than one year old. I am on social security and my tablet is my lifeline to the outside world. I can't afford to repair the tablet, let alone buy a new one.

So, I am very frustrated that you cannot TALK to the people in the warranty/repair department and that the "support" department does not have access to the analysis from the repair department or the email they supposedly sent me. So, the support person said they would "escalate" the repair and make sure they contact me ASAP. I said that is what they told me last week. So, who knows when I will get the phantom email, let alone get my tablet back unrepaired because I can't afford to fix it.

I can't believe you cannot talk to someone in the warranty/repair department. That is absolutely ridiculous.

Everything is laggy.  Really laggy, to the extent that you can't play games.  Also, Netflix doesn't work.  I waited patiently for over a year for it to be patched up, and then it turned out to be a hardware issue. Apparently, they have some kind of I/O bottleneck.that slows everything down.  It looks like ASUS was just trying to be the first "IPad killer" and they rushed the Prime to market.  I spent over $600 on the tablet and dock, and I'd have to say that it was money wasted.  Should have waited for the Google Nexus to come out.  Poo poo on you, ASUS.

I have had this thing for two monnths and now all it does is crash and freeze up about every 5 minutes. What a ridiculous waste of money for this stupid toy. I should have stayed with my laptop and smart phone, both of which work a lot better than this piece of junk

This is our family's first tablet.  I got it about 5 months ago for my dad's birthday and while he liked it the first couple times he used it, it didn't take long for the input lag to get so bad he refuses to even try it anymore.  The most serious issue I've found with it is that if you aren't using it every day, each time you go to use it you have to wait 20-40 minutes for it to download updates until it's done being bogged down.  It's just not usable during this time, which is not something I would expect with a quad-core or even dual-core processor.  If you've got plenty of time and patience on your hands, it works quite well once it's gotten through all of that.  Overall it's just really disappointing and given all the glowing reviews this thing had, it makes me wonder how tablets could be so popular in general if this is supposed to be one of the best.

Bought this tablet because I thought I would be getting the best tablet in the market. I was wrong. It appears that have cut corners on parts and the manufacturing process because I have had nothing but trouble from this product and ASUS support. Made ASUS aware of my issues of ghost touches in late April, sent it to a service center at the beginning of May, got it back, did not look like it had been touched! Received another RMA with "apologies" and promise that I will be reimbursed for shipping. When I received the unit back in late June/early July, not only was the problem worse right out of the box (touchscreen did not work at all!) they had scratched up the screen pretty good. It then took about a month of phone calls and phone calls not being returned like promised to get another RMA to send it in again. They replaced it this time, however the replacement has a faulty power switch (screen keeps coming on randomly and frequently, draining the battery quite well); and getting any wifi signal on it is quite the trick. So save yourself the time and money and go with another tablet.

I bought this tablet, looking for a high resolution, and an SD card slot. I also bought its keyboard dock.

Don't get me wrong, it's a beautiful device. And when it works, it's vastly superior to just about any other tablet I've ever seen. The problem? If you don't use it for a while, and the battery discharges (which it does even if you shut it down, by the way), then kiss it goodbye. Leave it for a week or two, and go back to it, and it'll be dead. You'll plug it in to charge it, you'll see the charging indicator go from orange to green...and it won't power on.

When this happened to me the first time, I sent it back - I needed to get an RMA, and pay for shipping there (I overnighted it). They replaced the motherboard, and shipped it back (ground, of course, and signature required, which is oh-so-convenient for those of us who work 9-5). After I drove out to the "local" FedEx depot to pick it up, it worked great.

Until I let it go dead again. And so I charged it up again, last night. And yes, it doesn't power on. Again.

The $350 for the tablet, and then $150 for the keyboard dock is just money gone, never to return.

Do not buy this tablet. Get a Nexus. Get a Kindle Fire. Get an iPad, if you have to. But avoid this thing like the plague.

With the TF701 with Tegra 4 coming in the next few months, why buy this now?

The bottleneck with this device is like the Nook HD+ in that the ram is too low and gpu too weak to support the 1080p display- not to mention the I/O memory bottleneck.  You can wait for a little while longer and get a better display with 2GB ram, and MUCH better chipset for either the same price, or $100 lower (ASUS still has not picked a price).

If you can not wait, better to buy a Nook HD+ since also a great display, same bottlenecks to performance, but less than half the price of the TF700.
I  bought this model in July, it functions fine, but the battery is no good at all, easily get hot and only last for about 4 hours.

This is  a great paper weight , It`s slower then my sons Kindle , I call Asus they were like I don't know, send it in , I said I just got it , You can not usb the device to charge , So stay near an outlet , Keyboard respond`s when It want to , Sound sucks and for a Quad core It`s a joke...DONT BUY PLEASE DONT BUY unless you want a  450 dollar paper weight , I am sending it back fast as hell Dont Buy!!!!!!!
This tablet will shut off by itself and won't accept no charge, Asus service wil call it Physical damage and will not honor a warranty.

This tablet is still pretty fast even though it's not the newest hardware anymore. Screen is not retina but very high resolution (1920x1200) and as far as I can tell pretty good as far as viewing angle, colors, brightness go.

Major selling point is the keyboard that attaches to form sort of laptop.

I waited to get one of the units over other similar tablets. I have been very disappointed in the performance and quality. It lasted 3 months and then just stopped working. I sent it in for repairs and it took ASUS about 4 weeks to process it and then they sent me a refurbished unit instead of a new one. It hasn't failed yet, but I doubt it will last long.

Battery life is dismal. You really have to purchase the keyboard unit so you have another battery. By dismal, I mean several hours of use, and its time to recharge. With the keyboard attached, the batteries are good for 3-4 hours. The worst feature is that it runs hot. You have to use it in a case, because it gets very hot while it is being used for playing simple games (like Solitare and Ruzzle).

Reading e-books is challenging. The brightness of the display does not auto adjust as advertised and it basically is one level of bright which is like a beacon in the night.

It is not easy to learn the functions and settings compared to an Android phone, which puts it to shame.

Upgrades are supposed to be automated but my camera firmware upgrade fails every time. Not clear on how to download and install a major upgrade and ASUS instructions online don't help.

I would not purchase an ASUS again for any product. I would go with IPAD or Samsung. I should have waited and read all the performance reviews. Had I done that, I would have purchased another brand.

If you are looking for a "pretty" screen, then this is for you.  If you are looking for performance, STAY FAR AWAY FROM THIS TABLET!  It is not built for performance and can be frustratingly slow, even trying to catch up with what is typed in.  I gave up my Windows set up for Android and I have to say that I am sorely disappointed in Android.  Their UI is just buggy and slow.  Their apps crash a lot and they have virtually NO productivity apps that are useful and can handle the load that Microsoft Excel can.  I have just ordered a Microsoft Windows 8 tablet because I can no longer deal with the inconsistencies/lack of good apps/slow performance of Android.  Such a shame as I thought Android was the answer.

I fell for the hype. And this was the newest, fastest, greatest. And then three weeks later...it wasn't.

But honestly, maybe I just got a poop copy or something, but it was slow and has to be restarted all the time. Constant hiccups
and stalls.

So, ASUS, feel free to send me another one. That'd be totally cool. I'll be waiting.

OK so I've been living under a rock out somewhere for the past 6 years.  I am not a progammer, but just a user. My phone still has a slide out keyboard.

I looked at different tablets with 2 goals in mind. First to replace a dead HP laptop.  Second to have a tablet for use as a mobile computer / e-reader / game playing / movie watching device.  Not having any Apple products, and not liking their "new product every 30 days" hype, I wanted an Android device to be able to pair it with a new phone when I got around to it.  Surface was just coming out and I never buy the first edition of anything but would rather give them time to get the bugs worked out.

I like it.  It's heavier than an "Air" but that gives me a little more substance  which I find somewhat reassuring.  I like that I can slip it into a bag without the keyboard and use it as a tablet or add the keyboard and use it like a notebook.  I can use it  as an e-reader when stuck in some mentally terminal place like a Dr's office or on a trip.  Or use it for some mental and finger stimulation with offline games.  (I have never played Call of Duty or any of the other high action games so I don't know how it handles them.)

The word processing stinks.  It's functional but not something that I would use for serious "office work" and I have to extend that to the entire office suite preloaded.  Because it has Jelly Bean I cannot use Adobe.  But have found a reader that works well for pdfs (UB reader)

Having to manually reduce the running tasks to free up cpu is a pain.  If I'm not online why do I need YouTube and other internet tasks running in the background.  In time I will figure out how to keep them off until I WANT them.

The tablet keyboard has a big wide space bar but does not always register unless it is touched in or very near the center requiring that I go back and add spaces to "runonwords."  It also is missing the "up down left right" arrows that make simple word adjustments in the body of a document easier.

I LOVE  the clarity of the screen.  In anything but full sun that is.  The glass is too shiny and reflective then.

It does get warm as the battery both charges and while in use.  But not hot, just warm.

Yes, I bought an expensive "starter" tablet.  It reviewed well and I'm quite happy with my purchase.  I would recommend it to someone as a great crossover.  Tablet when you want it.  Decent sized notebook when you want that.

And yes, I've found that being able to carry just the tablet or the tablet / docking station around is so much nicer than lugging the 17 inch laptop around.

Tablet, & Docking Station / Keyboard & Poetic case.

I love the idea of a hybrid tablet/keyboard combination, the capability to use micro-SD card on the tablet and the standard SD cards in the dock!

However the downside is the pure tablet performance, my out-of-the-box experience has not been good. There is a lag on performance doing anything, no matter how simple. Compared to Galaxy S3, this feels like a 5 year old device.
Perhaps I might change my review once I get on installing a custom ROM to see any improvement.

Besides these issues the other problems might be just my bad luck, since a friend brought it over from US to Korea, and the damage might have been happened during travel, or maybe not. A narrow spot on the bezel flexes, nothing very obvious. The other is that the dock wobbles when tablet is standing vertically, but no issues when it's just the keyboard, so I do not what the problem is, uneven tablet edge ?! I've had 4 weeks on the device, so it's not wear and tear.

Great tablet for a great price. I purchased the tablet to replace an older one I had. This one has great battery life, a super screen, and is pretty fast. I also purchased the keyboard and it turns it into a great little pc.

I have one already and got this as a gift for my father. He loves it. I think it is a well built 10.1 tablet and Asus has awesome support. First one ordered was damaged and they replaced it no questions. Amazon was a pain to get them to replace so Asus stepped up.

I like this tablet because I can read my books on it but I can't stand the fact that even when I'm sitting in the same room as my WiFi router I have a tiny triangle of signal. The worst part, ASUS was apparently sued over this and the result? A free Dongle and $17.  Would definitely not recommend.

I'm not going to donate it. It would be cruel to whoever bought it. I'm just going to put it in the hard drive shredder and count it as a lesson learned; never buy another asus product again. Too much money spent on their "awesome" products.

I didn't want to give it any stars. It dashed my expectations that badly.
It's a good tablet but there are others better in the market now, it's not as responsive as an ipad but for an android tablet it's very good

I love android and I love Asus, but this tablet just made me mad time and time again to the point where I just bought an iPad. Not to mention, you need a 3rd party app to raise the volume loud enough to even hear it clearly through a headset. I just did not like this tablet at all.

The tablet is so slow that the browsers often time out with an error message while the tablet lags out. There are times I want to put it through a wall. when i first bought it i was siked.  it looks really cool and sleek.  decently fast too. but after a while internet slowed a little and come to find out there has been a problem with the gorilla glass screens.  they seem to crack on there own and if u don't have ins, the manufacturer will not cover a replacement, so you will be screwed.

the product is fine, but documentation and support is sorely lacking. As a first-time tablet user, I had no idea where to start. There was virtually no documentation that came with this table. But somewhere along the line - with the various OS updates - it has become ridiculously slow. I reset my system multiple times and disabled all my apps - to no avail. I am using the 64 GB version of the tablet, with a 64 GB microSDXC card.  I have the keyboard dock and the Caseen folio case, which it is always in & connected to the dock.  I was happy to see that the microSD card slot supported SDXC cards, as I could not find that information online (eventually, I plan on putting a 128 GB SDXC card in the dock & this thing will be a monster!).  The screen is adequately bright, even at medium brightness, day & night.  I have not tried using it in direct sunlight, but inside my car all summer on break at work, or out on the patio during the middle of the day, I have had no problems reading the screen.  The colors & pictures are amazing.  The touchscreen is highly responsive & accurate.  It scores just a bit lower on the AnTuTu benchmark than my Samsung Galaxy Note II, which uses the same Tegra 3 processor, but I have seen reports that suggest that larger screens typically score lower, and it is not by a wide margin.  The Samsung seems a bit more responsive under heavy load - for example running app updates through Google Play store while also browsing on the web, or checking email, or even reading an ebook, there is occasionally a bit of lag, especially when switching from one task to another, but overall not too bad.  It is great that it is absolutely silent, and does not heat up appreciably.  I love being able to open the folio & have the screen turn on automatically & instantly and be able to resume exactly where I was.  The battery life is excellent - I used the tablet & dock for about 13 hours almost continuously on WiFi before it was completely drained.  I have not tried the bluetooth yet, not have I really tested the audio with music playback, but the few movie clips & webpages I have viewed looked/sounded great.  I turned the camera on once (just to make sure it worked), and the resolution on both cameras is what I would expect.  I find myself using this over my Netbook occasionally, although I do like the keyboard on my Netbook slightly better when typing long text blocks (like writing papers).  If I wasn't doing a graduate IT program, where I need access to Windows programs sometimes for classes, I might even use the docked tablet more often than the Netbook.  I am waiting for a microHDMI to regular HDMI adapter, and I will see how well the tablet interfaces with my Samsung tv.  I am planning on getting a USB OTG adapter as well, so I can connect the tablet directly to my external hard drive.  Maybe I will update in a month or so, after I have had a chance to put the tablet through its paces a bit more, and test some of the other features and connections.

I purchased this product after careful consideration and research.  I spent over 800.00 bought the 64 gig and keyboard docking station.  I have sent it back twice for repairs.  The Asus support Rep each time was helpful but in the end it resulted in me shipping back my beloved (at least initially).  In fact I loved it so much I spent the same amount and bought my husband the exact same table with keyboard.  My sister who is a die hard Apple user bought the same setup.  She wanted it for business and planned to use her Ipad3 for everything else.  Now I feel bad for strongly supporting this product so quickly.  Over time the memory leak problems have occurred to all of us.  The screen light leakage and dead pixels have also happened.  But so far I am the only one who has had it literally stop working.

I am very disappointed and will not be keeping it this time.  I don't want to take another chance on it.

I have been a 'tolerant' fan of Asus's line of Transformer tablets.  I have had the TF101, TF201, and the TF700.  Of the 3, I really liked the TF201.  Now, the only drawback of the TF201 (aka: Transformer Prime) is that the Wifi issues were definitely apparent.  Unless you were literally 10 to 15 feet from the router, your Wifi experience would be sluggish.  Hence, I got the TF700.  Definitely a huge improvement.  In fact, once you get another tablet/computer with a higher resolution, it's almost unthinkable to go back.  Switching back and forth to my TF201 and TF700 was like switching from a standard definition TV (TF201)to a high definition TV (TF700).  The problem with the TF700, is Asus didn't bother to implement enough RAM to make up for the screen's demands as well as the user's potential to multitask.  Despite the TF700's superior screen to its predecessors, it was the most sluggish in regards to performance.  I even rooted and flashed the TF700 with a ROM that would "fix all that".  And the result was the same. My beautiful screen wielding TF700 went from a sluggishly performing tablet with all looks and no strength to back it up (again, perhaps more RAM would've helped in this matter). After so many cold boots, factory resets, mixing and matching with this ROM or that ROM, I noticed that Amazon was featuring a 2012 Nexus 10 (new, not refurbished) for the SAME PRICE as a new TF700.  After getting a Nexus 10 with none of the bloatware and straight untouched Jellybean, woah, what a difference.  And the screen resolution is top notch (for now) out of any 10+ inch tablet.  I sold my TF700 but kept my TF201 (despite the Wifi issues, it was the most reliable overall).  If you shop around Amazon, you'll notice that a Nexus 10 (2012 and new, 32gb version) costs just as much as a new Asus TF700. Why not avoid the bloatware and waiting game (yes, you'll be waiting on the next Android OTA update while Nexus devices such as the Nexus 4, 7, and 10 get it first)? If you want a superior screen without the lag and performance issues, I would avoid the TF700.  It's just too bad that something this great (a nice sized tablet with a dockable keyboard) would have so many issues in regards to performance.  My best description of the TF700 is that it's a 2012 Chevy Corvette with a 4-cylinder engine under the hood.  Meaning, it looks good, but the horsepower isn't enough to prevent the performance issues from being so obvious.

Performance wise, this is an awesome tablet. It runs all of my development applications (and games) quickly and easily. The screen is clear and responds well to touch. I like that Asus has been so quick to update the software as needed, although sometimes the constant updates can be a bit of a hassle. (I went through a couple of updates while I was connected to airplane WIFI - not fun.) The cameras are high enough quality, although I don't take many pictures with this device. The battery life has been very good - approximately 4 to 5 hours depending on my use.

My favorite thing about this tablet is the connection to the full keyboard that is available separately. Used together, I have a complete mini laptop that will fit in my bag and is easy enough to carry around with me. When I use this and my remote desktop application, I have the freedom to use my home computer from anywhere I go.

If you are looking for a great tablet, this definitely should make your list. I'd also recommend the Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1, with a bluetooth keyboard. Although neither of these tablets is "budget" priced, if you are a working professional, you won't find a better value.

If anybody doesn't believe I will provide (to private address) all RMA numbers and correspondence even they put a note that it's illegal to publish and parts/information's from e-mails.

It was very slow to begin with; then totally stopped functioning with no external reason (BAD hardware; no damage occurred).

The client has to pay the bill...
I do not trusut Amazon any more.  Won't buy Asus again.

I'm a big android fan and was pretty excited to get my hands on this device. Unfortunately, my excitement was short lived once I actually started using it.

The tablet is nearly incapable of any kind of multitasking. If you happen to be surfing the web when an update for one of your apps comes through your browsing will slow to a complete crawl and there is a good chance of having the tablet freeze and/or crash on you completely. Apps will also 'hang' when launched so when you press a app you can expect to wait for a while till it decides to open the app (your device will freeze during this time) and even when launched it will just go to a black or white screen for even longer while the application loads. Sometimes the app will load, some times it will freeze and force you to do a hard restart...it's a complete crap shoot every time you decide to use the device.

While the screen resolution is nice, you really aren't going to make use of it unless you are watching videos that have been completely downloaded onto an SD card or the internal hard drive. Video quality while streaming Netflix or Hulu is horrible and on par with my first generation Nook and it still runs into serious frame rate issues at less than 480p resolution. This isn't an Internet issue on my side as I have multiple devices in my house and ALL of them outperform this device for streaming video; even ones old enough that you can't buy them off the shelf anymore.

I know not everyone who owns the TF700 has these issues, but Asus's QA is spotty at best so you are taking a complete gamble as to how well it will perform once you open the box. On a separate but related issue, the dock/keyboard for the tf700 also suffers from some serious QA issues. Hitting backspace will, 50% of the time, force close all programs and take you to the home screen or shut the device down completely. Simply writing a simple email can become the ultimate test in patience as you are going to need to start over at least twice trying to write more than a few paragraphs.

I have to admit that the device looks gorgeous but as I'm not in the market for overpriced paper weights I can't really weigh this as a positive.

I seriously considered benchmarking this device to see what was really going on as I am fairly sure the factory they have putting these together in China is supplementing the parts it's suppose to have with cheaper, outdated parts that cause it to perform so poorly. Ultimately I decided it was better to just package it up and return it to Amazon and warn other potential buyers what they may be up against.

My wife loves this tablet. She had the previous model and had camera issues but this display and camera seem much better. I like the versatility of this tablet with  MINI HDMI OUT and MICRO SD CARD SLOT to expand with.  Seems much better then its predecessor. I highly recommend!!
I did a lot of research before purchasing the Asus Tablet. I was not disappointed. Now my co-worker wants one
Last really long time when charged fully. Love it, I love it more than I loved my iPad when I got it.

This tablet is awesome. It has great battery life, especially if you buy the ASUS Transformer Infinity TF700 Mobile Dock to go with it. It's fast, has great video quality, and is lightweight. I've had it for a few months now and haven't had any issues. I wish the charger had a longer cord, but that's about it.

I originally bought this Tablet and Keyboard dock last November (2012), and then bought my wife an identical setup 1 month later.  The TF700 boasts great specs on paper, but using it will eventually make you want to drink drain-o.

PROs: Pretty HD screen.  RMAs get sent/returned very fast.

CONs:  Everything else.  You ever had one of those bad dreams where you're running away from a bad guy and it feels like you can barely move; like you're running in slow motion?  That's what using the TF700 is like.  Everything is laggy.  The tablet is constantly trying to catch up with your inputs.  That includes when typing, especially when web browsing(I've tried Chrome, Opera, Firefox, and the default browser).  Some of them suck slightly less on this thing than others, but it is always a frustrating slow experience.  Like many of the others on here, I prayed and prayed that the JB firmware updates would liberate this thing's performance.  That hasn't happened yet, so either Asus' programmers really suck at buidling their version of the Android updates or this thing just doesn't have the speed.

No joke, it is actually slightly faster for me to do the same tasks, games and web browsing on my first-generation Kindle Fire than using the TF700.  My wife's Samsung Galaxy S3 blows the doors off this thing, and its a PHONE.

My TF700 also suffers from chronic lock-ups and reboots out of the blue. I just got it back from RMA yesterday (not rebooting anymore) but the touch interface is now screwed up.  My understanding is the NAND memory in these things is really slow, and that's what causes the problem.  The solution I'm told is to root your device (voids the warranty) to bypass that memory

I've had to RMA BOTH my TF700 and my wife's in the last 5 months; and mine's going back again tomorrow.  My wife's is the same amount of laggy, but it also stopped charging after about 2 months of use.  They replaced the MOBO and its back to its normal laggy self.

Mine (for several months) rebooted and crashed constantly even after factory resets.  The keyboard then stopped charging and working, so I RMA'd both.  The keyboard now works, but the TF700 touch screen action is all glitchy.  I have to tap on the same icon 4-5 times to get it to do anything.  Its almost like the system is locking up very briefly every few seconds as I'm using the touch screen.

I don't know what's wrong with it now... I just know I'll NEVER EVER EVER buy another Asus Tablet again.  I wish I'd gone with the Galaxy Note 2 or something else.  This thing SUCKS and is expensive for something that's slower than Amazon's first generation KF.
This tablet is plauged with input delay. It freezes non stop, heavy, and it makes my hands smell like pennies if i hold the tablet for too  long. Stay away and buy a different tablet.

I bought this product based on the specs and could not be more disappointed in both the tablet and in Asus. My unit is complete junk. Touchscreen is totally non-responsive and had to send back to Asus at my expense only to have the touchscreen come back even less responsive after their "repair". However, after spending forty minutes on the phone with them, they said I would have to send it in again and they would "take another look at it".

I've received two Tranformer Tablets form Amazon Warehouse deals, not one of their sellers. The first one had a cracked screen so I returned it.
