I don't know if its the HW or the OS, but this little steamer...the Infinity TF700T...is 100Xworse than the first ASUS Eeepad Transformer (which was pretty awesome before support for security patches and the rest was dropped).

Whoever decided that this was ready for release and that the charging of premium prices for this turd should commence immediately versus ASUS as a company embracing the targeting of product quality, should be fired immediatly. Its so unreliable as to be unacceptable. I can't even in good conscience...resell this thing. What the hell do I do with this? For battery life and reliability, I give it an "F".

Also, it is not an improvement over its predessessors overall. Not AT ALL. Even the extra ram over its that which its previous version had is unnoticable. It does seem to restart somewhat faster. But, that is little comfort when you just lost the last hour of original thought. You will not get that back.

Can I have my money back?

The Asus TF700 is exactly what a premium tablet should look and feel like.  When you hold it in your hand it just screams quality.  The lines are clean and there is no flex in the tablet at all.  The screen is bright and colors are true to life with very little saturation or contrast issues.  While it doesn't have as high a DPI as the Nexus 10, I much prefer the display on the TF700.  I love how bright it gets and if you watch a lot of movies/tv shows on it - like I do - then you'll appreciate how beautiful this screen is.

Other Pro's are the keyboard dock which adds battery life and a bunch of extra functionality.  It really feels like a potential laptop replacement (though you'll want to use a regular laptop for heavy lifting of course).  Throw in not one but TWO SD card slots (one micro-sd on the tablet and regular SD on the dock) and you have the potential for a ton of extra storage. If you have a lot of multimedia content there really is no better set up than this.  With the micro-hdmi port you can pipe beautiful HD video to your big screen TV without a problem. I've done this countless times and have been pretty pleased.

With so much to love why would I give this tablet 2 stars?  Simple: usability.  While the tablet is a year old it should not have the lag problems that it does.  It has a Tegra 3 with 1 GB RAM.  More than enough to run multiple apps without a problem.  On Paper!  If you're like me you get frustrated when your phone or computer just sits there seemingly doing nothing while you wait for it to load an app.  Well, get ready to feel that way a lot!  Want to use your tablet while apps are updating in the background?  Good luck!  I was away from wifi for a few days and went to use my tablet today.  10 apps were updating and the tablet was unusable.  At one point I just put it down and Instead reached for my laptop and smartphone.

At this point I'm going back to the Nexus 10.  While I will miss the keyboard dock, better build quality, and nicer HD screen  I will not miss that feeling of utter frustration I feel using the TF700.

You have been warned.

The tablet screams premium when you open the box.  Mated with the optional keyboard and you have the makings of a nice little ultraportable looking device. The OS is smooth and as of this writing is on Jelly Bean 4.2.1. Hopefully Asus will keep this on the update wagon. The extra port for the microSD is a plus.  And if  you purchase the optional keyboard you have access to USB drives as well.  Battery has been good at about 8 hrs 51 minutes for the tablet. GPS is awesome and I've been able to consistently see 6-9 satellites in doors. The aluminum clamshell is rugged, but not impervious to all scratches, so I would recommend a case of some type.
This one works.... Though oddly enough, I think my galaxy s3 is a bit faster. Shrugs. Can't beat it though

This has been an excellent device for me.  It is super lightweight, has an outstanding display, and very good battery life with battery saving options.  I keep it up-to-date with the latest Android Jelly Bean updates, which ASUS is very good about providing updates for.  The version I have has the 32GB internal, and I use a Sandisk 64GB Class 10 microSDXC card with complete success.

The wireless signal reception is very good, the GPS is very responsive (on par with my Garmin eTrex Vista HCX unit), and the docking station option works perfect for this unit.

After a year's use, I still HIGHLY RECOMMEND this tablet.  It doesn't have a built-in cell radio for 3G internet, but it wirelessly tethers flawlessly with home network and public wireless hotspots to accommodate web browsing, Netflix video viewing (which is outstanding on this device), and Skype video communications.  I also purchased a wireless OBD2 code reader to read and reset the fault codes in my vehicle, and use this to read/reset the check engine fault codes in my vehicles.

My ONLY complaint with this unit is the sound level is terrible.  If you do get this to listen to music and/or watch movies/video, then I would highly recommend a set of either wired or Bluetooth headphones to use with this.  Oh yes, and the Bluetooth does work excellent for both headphones AND a mouse.  I have found using a Bluetooth mouse actually works very well to augment the docking station when web browsing.

I originally bought and tried the ACER A700 before this unit and had overheat issues with that unit.  Having tried both, my recommendation is this ASUS unit.  Other than the totally weak speaker sound, this unit has been outstanding.

Got my tablet 2 moths ago and now i have to send it for warranty
The screen is not responding if there is pressure aplied by the dock or hand on the bottom part. THE SCREEN IS SLIGHLTY RAISED IN THAT AREEA. It executes commands by it self because of this , not happy with ASUS...
the dock is great do..

The tablet is great, the ASUS flavor of Android is not. Using the tablet for 30 min plus would result in numerous apps running in the background. Out of the box they add a process killer widget (bad sign). I like this tablet for the optional keyboard (have not purchased it yet). About a month in I unlocked the bootloader, rooted and installed CM 10.1 on the device. I feel like it is a whole new tablet.

First, the bad: it will randomly shut off once or twice a week. It does collect finger smears on the screen (we don't use a screen protector because of the Gorilla Glass 2). The ASUS weather widget doesn't auto-refresh.

Now, the good: ASUS continues to push out firmware and Android updates that improve an already strong performing tablet. Great screen. If you need to be able to see the screen in sunlight, the IPS+ setting works great. Great battery life.

Since purchasing this tablet, we find ourselves using our desktop computer less and less. The apps that come with this tablet work well, and there are some stellar free ones in the Google Play store.

Although without previous experience on tablets, this one seems bratifully designed, and as far as now is fulfilling my expectations.

I miss a printed manual. Shouldn't it be included in the package?

If I knew it in advance, I had better bought the 3G model, but I didn't realized mine wasn't from the specifications.
The tablet is slow slow slow . We also have ipads 2 at home and they perform faster than my tf700. I do not have many apps uploaded. I do not understand why only I have a slow tf700

I love the tablet, everything works as expected except the headphone jack. Something is wrong with the input because I'm unable to plug any headphones into it. Fortunately this hasn't been too terrible of an issue yet, but for most I'm sure it would be.
the best product and i hope to contact another time to buy i new a product from asus co ltd

Pros: Great screen, great battery life, fast charging, up to 64GB sd cards work, keyboard dock option (which has a usb port) adds to the value, sturdy build, hdmi out, good volume

Cons: Kind of laggy at times, volume buttons feel cheap, camera is okay, only one speaker and it is not centered on the device

WARNING: THE THINGS I MENTION BELOW WILL VOID YOUR WARRANTY.

Side note: If you unlock it and load a custom recovery and custom ROM like Cromi-x, then this is a 5 star product. The custom ROM fixes all the lag issues.

I'm typing on it now.  We use it all day long for a wide range of things.  The 8mp camera takes great pictures and video.  The display is really quality, we watch Netflix on it often.  My eight year old practices math on it without being told to.  I compared several brands and for our needs this was the clear choice.  Get the Bobjgear heavy-duty case to go with it for superior grip as well as protection

This is a decent tablet with two major exceptions:

1 - The speaker royally sucks. You'll barely be able to hear youtube videos. I mean WTF? How do you screw that up?

2 - There is no connect as USB mass storage device like every other Android device I've used; only media device and camera. Without connect as mass storage device, this means when you connect it to your PC you will not get a logical drive letter assigned to the device. Without this you can not perform any drive operations like using personal synchronization software. The included sync software only syncs your contacts and calendar as if there is any utility in that... So if you have a large music/video library where you are constantly adding/deleting song/videos; you'll be manually doing it by dragging and dropping individual files.

Every other aspect of the tablet are pretty decent but these two are deal killers for me.
Love it.  Have not found anything that it won't do.  My kids enjoy it too.  It has all the abilities for as many apps and games as you would like.

I've owned this tablet for about 10 months now and have had few problems with it.
One or two major things detract from its value, though:
1) The first one I received froze up after only a few hours.  Amazon quickly replaced it. But it makes me worry about QC on the tablet.
2) The manufacturer claims it is wireless compatible on 802.11 B, G, and N networks.  N is the fastest and most reliable of these protocols.  In several tests, I have determined that my tablet works fine on B and G networks but will not access the internet at all on an N network.  This is a very serious shortcoming.  The operating system has been updated  to the latest (ICS) so there can be no criticism about that.  Its just an obvious over-sell of the specifications.
3) Good hard cases are hard to find for this model.  The folding simulated leather proliferated in the market offer little or no protection and are a pain to handle in the lap.  There are no Otterboxes or similar cases made as of April 2013 for this model.  I did finally find a GumDrop case which is great but it took a lot of digging to find it.
4) Slow to start-up.

Pros:
1) Crisp clear display
2) Responsive touch controls, even with screen skin
3) Useful outlets
4) Good camera resolution and placement

If I had not had an issue, could get an Otterbox, and it would work on 802.11N, It would give it a resounding 5.  As is, only a little above average tablet, with a very high price.

Bought this a couple months back.  It gets warm when being charged.  Runs Android, so the coverage of apps isn't great.  Recently, there are some lags and freezing while running a couple applications at the same time.  Wish I had gotten a VivoTab with digitizer.  Like all other capacitive screens, this tablet isn't good for small writing of notes for classes.

I like the ease of using a tablet over a bulky laptop. The screen is amazingly clear and lovely to look at. At times it can be kind of slow. I haven't fully put it through it's paces yet but so far I really like it for the price of it.

I purchased the 64gig tft700 asus transformer tablet about 8 months ago. Initially I loved it. It was blazing fast with a beautiful screen and all the memory in the world. Since then I have had to factory reset it twice and am now going to have to do so again. Gradually it starts locking up once every day or two, then every day and then every few hours, Then it will boot but lock up within a couple seconds of starting. Cold booting it helps for a while but then no longer works. At that point it is a paper weight waiting to happen unless you factory wipe it. I have applied all the over the air updates that Asus has pushed out and it just hasn't changed the behaviour. I actually don't really push this thing at all, I just use it daily as an e-reader using the kindle app. I had thought that maybe it was a problem with the kindle app but even if you don't start that app it will lock up. I am seriously regretting purchasing this thing over a sumsung. I like the idea of the docking station keyboard with extra battery power and that does work well when the unit is working. However it has let me down time after time after time till I want to throw it through a wall. Other than it won't run stably it is all that they crack it up to be. Oh one other warning.. the latching mechanism on the keyboard breaks really easily. You can still put the tablet in the keyboard but it won't lock, this happened in the first week of owning it. Keyboard still functions fine after 8 months when the unit is working.

I am an IT professional and have used many other android devices (tablets and phones) over the last few years and never had this many issues with one. I have even hacked a nook color to put standard android on it and have not had this much trouble. At this point, as I am stuck with this thing, I have thought about wiping and putting linux or a stock android flavor on it rather than asus's version on it and see if it will do better.

I do not recommend that anyone purchase this. I have not contacted asus to trouble shoot it as I have followed a lot of the forums for people that have, and I have already done all that they recommended those people do. Maybe if I feel like going through hours and days of asus support agony one day I will but I am in such a foul temper over this thing that I don't think I could not bite the head off of the first person that told me to factory reset the unit to continue the support process, after I told them I had done so twice and had the same symptoms show up both times in the past.

So after spending 800 dollars on this and the keyboard and 8 months of frustration take my warning and run far and fast.

Scott

It's a very nice product although it runs slower than I would like...the keyboard that pops up is probably the best thing about it...it's very easy to use and has the most intuitive word suggestions I've seen!

I love, love, love this tablet, my wife says I'm obsessed with it, well I do take it with me where ever I go, but it is so compact and light weight that I have no problem with it, the recharge time is much faster than the Kindle Fire HD the screen is, of course, much bigger but resolution is much better in my opinion, the only thing that it does not match up to the HD is the sound quality, I found the Kindle Fire HD had a better set of speakers I presume, also the Kindle hard case was nice, I hope that Asus or someone out there manufactures something equivalent. Unfortunately I cannot take advantage of some of my Prime membership benefits, such as, being able to borrow books, or watching some of my bought and owned HD movies on it, hopefully Amazon will rectify some of these problems. All and all I am very happy with my purchase, well worth the price.

I've bought this tablet 8 months ago with greaTablett expectations. Screen is doing what is promised, really very nice wiev. But speed of the tablet is far away from satisfaction. Running apps, browsing internet is very very slow. Even my 2 year old Samsung Galaxy S2 is faster than this device in all aspects. Really big disappointment.
And one final recommendation, if you still want to buy this tablet, DO NOT BUY KEYBOARD! It is definitely useless. I've never used it for 8 months. Just waist of money.

02/09/2013 Update: As now, I ve new problems.
Tablet does not connect to some wifi networks. When I googled the issue I found many people complaining the same issue. But unfortunately there was none having a solution. Connection to wifi with this tablet is a bit of luck. If it connects, it connects, but if it doesn't, there is nothing you can do to sort out the issue. Bad but this is the case for this tablet.
Secondly, last week this tablet burned my 32 GB SanDisk Ultra SD Card!... If but this tablet, better not to put any sd card. Because, your data and your sd card is not safe when in this tablet.

This is rediculously slow. I bought it because I thought it was the most powerful tablet on the market. It takes forever to load apps. Don't buy it.

Update!
After ASUS left a comment about resetting the device, I did this and it immediately sped it up. I noticed while I was resetting it, that the reason it may have been so slow is because I may have set it to encrypt the device. I could be wrong, but either way I did not enable encryption and it's faster now. The reason I gave it 4 and not 5 stars is because it does not have a slot to allow for LTE chip so I can use it without WIFI.

This tablet is he greatest.
For people, like me who want to ditch the laptop, think through what you do!
The tablet can do most things, but often you must do them another way.
Somethings your can't do -like print a  web page - but that's a browser problem, not the tablet
Eat your heart out Apple!
Item received within 5 days of ordering. Item was a Birthday gift for my sister. She has been using it ever since and love it. No issue ever occurred.

I love this tablet! I use it for work and pleasure and it's truly more user friendly than the apple products. I can easily edit documents from email attachments and save immediately. I can move around files in my File Manager and save/send quickly. I also own the Ipad 2 and can't do any of these tasks swiftly. There is only one flaw that others mentioned as well, occasionally i see the flicker/line that runs through the screen. It's not bad enough to return but it definitely is not a pleasure to see.

There is nothing wrong with the unit. The brightness and colors are not as good as an Ipad3 or Ipad4. This is a disappointment.
I bought these tablets for my family. The tablets were using the same apps with the brightness set to max on all of the tablets.
The Ipads just look better. I do not own an Apple product but I'll buy an Ipad5 when they are available.

The sails pitch for this product is a bit misleading to say the least. Yes you do have access to USB port and several others with the unit... But be up front and tell any customer that the USB is of no use to you at all, other then for purpose of adding a satalite drive or memory stick...  You can not use it for any other purpose.. Not bluetuth... not wireless mouse... USB micraphone..  Not for any input device whats so ever... Was very disapointed, when I thought I was buying into portable computer that I would use for years to come...  Ones hands are tied with this tech. reck...

I've had a iPad 3 now for over a Year and wanted something with expandable storage. This fits the bill! With 64GB internal, a 64GB microSD and a 32GBSD (in the dock) I've got more than enough storage for my needs.
I'd seen a lot of reviews on this model pertaining to the glass not fitting right, odd clicking sounds and quality of components and the one I received is in perfect condition with no blemishes of any kind. I'm extremely pleased with my purchase and look forward to years of use.

I have a seldom used desktop and until recently a laptop. When the laptop died I bought the Asus tablet to replace it. The  desktop was reserved for the occasional word processing and the annual tax return agony.
I used the laptop for the usual; email, web surfing, purchasing from etailers and banking/bill paying. I do all that with the Asus and faster.
I am far from being a techie but I do have a few comments on performance.
It's fast enough for me and patience is not my strong suit.
In about 6 weeks of daily use it has never once locked up and needed resetting or rebooting (unlike any laptop or desktop I have ever owned).
The tablet connects wirelessly to my verizon router, about 50 feet away on another level. It's flawless, never fails.
One concern for potential buyers is the lack of flash player because Adobe no longer supports it for android devices. Out of the box you'll find some videos won't play.
But you can install it and it works perfectly. I found it when visiting the google playstore. If you select Movies and TV you'll be told you need flashplayer to proceed and you'll be given a link and instructions to install. It must be easy cuz I
did it.
Finally I find I get about 6 hours from the battery, not great but it recharges quickly
It is not easy to find out how to sync things. I thought it would be like a net book.

I am not an Apple hater the whole Apple thing just doesn't appeal to me for a number of reasons that don't need to be discussed. Android does work for me. Variety, control, flexibility of OS. I want to interact with and be able to change what's going on with my tablet as opposed to just turning it on and using what's set up or me by someone somewhere else  Enter the Asus TF201 and Android . Issues with wifi, GPS,video player support, lagging ram. In spite of those issues, still a nice tablet, great looking display,functional, great keyboard, all in all, a good tablet once you get done with the hard resetting,cold booting, and figuring out the work arounds. Which I didn't mind doing because it became a challenge, and I like challenges. And I am not a technical person.

Now comes the TF700. Outstanding display,good wifi, good gps, TF 201 keyboard works with it. Bought it refurbished from Amazon for 379.00. A good deal by any standard. I love this tablet. It is actually hard to put down. the display is better than or equal to the ipad display and you can actually do multiple tasks at the same time(Not so with ipad). The keyboard attached makes it look like a small laptop. Insert a 32GB sd card and you have a small laptop with more space than most people are going to use this for. Posts on Transformer forums state that they are running the TF700 with 64 and 128GB sd cards. I will try that later.

So what's the point? This tablet is a lot of fun, great display, multi functional, Looks great but has some performance issues that require continued involvement on your part.  I have had this TF700 for over a month now. No epic fails as yet. However, it requires regular cold boots after app installs, frequent cache clean outs, assessments after app installs to see if the app is a problem, and resets for smooth running. You are going to need a support community to help with issues(trust me). But, this is a nice tablet if you are willing to put in the work. The rewards are worth it(I think). It does more than play chopsticks(Ipod analogy). I'm not sure about the stars. You figure it out on your own.

Harley Davidson(Asus TF700) vs Suzuki(Ipod analogy). Two bikers are talking about their motorcycles. The Harley guy is talking about fixing this and that on his bike. The Suzuki guy says I would rather ride my bike than fix it. The TF700 is a great bike and does things that a Suzuki(ipod) can't do but requires routine maint. You decide what works for you.

I've had my Asus TF700 for 2 weeks now and am very pleased with my purrchase.  I'm a novice with using my tablet but am findig I can manuver around  very.  easily.  I have a friend with an IPad who was very impressed with my android and wisded they had. an Asus.  Next step is a docking keyboard.

Asus really impresses me with this tablet. It is built from sturdy materials and does not feel cheap. The brushed metal feels like you're holding something valuable.

I bought this to replace an Acer 500 that had a broken power button. (I'll fix it one day...) This is light years ahead in terms of specs and construction.

I've thrown everything at this tablet, games, movies, apps all run smoothly and without missing a step. The rear camera take great pictures and the flash makes them even better.

Upgrading it from the stock image was easy and after a factory reset, it worked even faster than before!

It's such a good tablet, I am not going to take away a star because the front-camera is a little sub-par in low light but in well lit areas seems to be fine. It does not take away from the experience.

Overall this is one of the higher quality Android tablets out there. I prefer this over an iPad simply because you can do so much more with an Android.

This is a must have for anyone looking for a new Android tablet!
This tablet is all that I needed. I wish the battery life was longer, but I did buy the keyboard too which is suppose to add 8 or 9 more hours.

This tablet is great!  I highly recommend purchasing the docking station which turns this into a laptop-like device.  Battery life is outstanding and resolution is jaw-dropping.  Skip out on the iPad and get this Android beast!
I have not had a tablet before.  Think I will like it.  Good way to connect to web and do work without need for a notebook when a phone is too small
I looked at many Windows options, read the reviews--my daughter convinced me--ASUS + Android OS.  Has been great replacement for my HP iPAQ 211--though I mourn the loss still

I was headed off to class and I needed my tablet/doc/case so I unplugged it and put in in my bag. Got to school and it wouldn't turn on. Tried the hard boot/cold boot and still no luck. Held the reset pin down and sit still refused to boot. Put it back on the charger figuring it might not have charged, got the orange light, that evening it was green and it still refused to boot. Now I'm trying to let it go completely dead to try to get it to come back on. I tried plugging into the HDMI and it won't come up. I don't want to send it in as I got information on there I don't want to lose.

Pretty sad. I had to "void" their warranty because the tablet was too laggy for me(read other reviews) and I hated how asus wasted so much screen space in Jelly Bean.so I unlocked and loaded cleanrom. Cleanrom allowed me to remove that huge border Asus felt I needed and increased responsiveness. To be honest once I loaded cleanrom it work fantastic. Battery life was great, sound quality was pretty good. I could play any movies I had on my network. I could access my home PC do almost anything I wanted to do on my home computer. I bought a mount for my truck and took it on trips using the GPS and it took pretty good photos in a pinch. I loved being able to pull my memory card from my dslr to get quick previews using the memory slot, a rare find on tablets now. But alas 3 months and 21 days later it refuses to work.

I since I voided my warranty they are going to charge me for repair and I'm hearing about $200 on a $430 tablet. FM

UPDATE: After 8 months post RMA repairs the tablet again died. It's not covered under any warranty as ASUS only extends the warranty 90 days after they fix a device. This is sad. Also after I received the tablet back from RMA the GPS wouldn't work.

Asus, as always, made a good job here. The tablet is light, the finishing is very good. The overall performance is very good and with combination with the keyboard dock, it has killing battery power and can pose as a netbook. But we have some little issues. The system is ok, Android 4.2 is fantastic and the Asus intrusion in the looks is minimal, although we have a bunch of crapware that are unnecessary, but can be useful. The only thing that annoyed me is the fact that the tablet takes some minutes to get a good  performance after waking up from the stand by. In this time, it responds irritantly slow. I don't know if the fault is of the Asus Android version or the Nvidia Tegra Processor. After this, the performance is very good! The screen is very good, indoor or outdoor. I like to watch some series or movies on Netflix in bed, before sleeping, and the quality is superb. The sound is ok, but it could be better. Battery life is ok, I can take around 9 hours of intense use; with the dock attached, this jumps to 13 hours. Resuming, it is a very good choice for a Android tablet, but there are some room for improvement. I definetely will consider the next Infinity when the time for a new one comes.

Beautiful tablet loaded with versatility especially when paired with the optional keyboard dock. There are many exceptional features to this tablet, but unfortunately there is one BIG drawback. It is quite noticieably slow overall. My cell phone is much smoother and faster with nearly all tasks. Just browsing is usually a slow jerky/jumpy experience. I was drawn to this tablet by it's versatility and seemingly impressive specs. If there were a way to remove the bloat, increase the RAM, or whatever to stop or remove what is killing a potentially great tablet. Pretty disappointed.......

A gift for graduation for my daughter.  She has a laptop, but wanted something a little easier to carry from class to class.  There are a few hickups, occasionally freezing and rebooting radomly, but that is to be expected with new technology.

hello that such I am writing to express my disappointment, since the infinity pad tablet came damaged. people told me that only costs vibrated in effect that's what makes once remove all security seals that brings the tablet and turn it on q is not light. I put it to charge until it reaches the light turns true either. I feel robbed anyway with this product .. from Venezuela. cotacto very bad seller, nor care to know what had happened by the tablet that sold, not knowing whether EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION infinity pad asus equipment could be faulty as mine. if other countries do not buy with this seller, and I did buy a tablet pad neck infinity and never worked I could use my time and lost money on something that never worked, and now less when its price increases
It's my multimedia walk around device, it does require minor tweaking but performs very nice. It upgrades to Jellybean 4.2.2

This is my first tablet and it does not disappoint. Very smooth and quite fast. No stuttering except for a few apps I downloaded.

Like the screen; sharp and bright except in bright daylight, but that's no surprise as this is the case with all tablets.

Fist the good, the screen is absolutely gorgeous, the available ports (sd, hdmi, etc.) are a must have, the optional keyboard is a huge feature to have.

Now the unacceptable. Out of the box, this is the slowest tablet I have ever used. The lag and stuttering are huge obstacles in basic usability. Simple swiping, lag. Bringing up the keyboard, lag. Launching apps, lag. Using any browser, huge lag. My rooted HP Touchpad blows this thing out of the water as far as speed. I know I can get better performance if I root this tablet, but I should't have to root a product just to get it to a usable state. Asus really needs to look at how they are implementing the android os, because on paper, this table should run like butter. Maybe I got a bad unit, all I know this baby is going back.

Just an fyi, I'm running the current OTA 4.2 version of Jelly Bean from Asus.

This is an amazing tablet. I own the TF300T and decided to upgrade.  Best decision ever! Amazing resolution, camera flash, microSD slot, microHDMI port.  That right there just eliminate any thoughts of getting an IPAD. Best bang for your buck.  Anyone that buy it won't regret their purchase. I love this product.

The device worked great for first 5 months. Then the power cord quit working. I am now in day 2 of trying to get assistance getting a new cord. The vendor that sold it no longer carries it.  I was on hold with ASUS for over 2 HOURS last night and am writing this now as I have now been on hold for over 20 minutes.  I can't get the cord at any local office supply store.  DON'T GET THIS IF YOU ARE WORRIED AT ALL THAT YOU COULD HAVE PROBLEMS!

Bought it as refurbed unit. The tablet itself was fine, minimal scratches and wear, however this unit was clearly dropped. The power button was damaged and barely worked. Returned it and Amazon would not give me a replacement.
Well built. Android 4.2 works seamlessly on this device.  If you don't want to wait for the next iteration that was announced this year at CITA, then get this on sale.

So far, I'm loving this tablet.  Its screen is outstanding.  The processor is plenty fast for the tasks I've thrown at it.  the fact that it takes an SD memory card (which fits flush when installed) affords it plenty of memory capacity.  The audio is pretty faint but using either headphones or an X-mini external speaker rectifies that in situations where I need more volume.

Scrolling is smooth, all apps I've loaded work well with the system.  Upgrade to the OS have been effortless.  Some of the functions are just different enough from my Android phone (LG Nitro) to take a bit of getting used to but they're not illogical, just different.

This is a constantly moving and improving market, of course.  But at the time of purchase, this was about as nice a tablet as you could get and now, a few months later, it continues to meet my needs very nicely.  I use it primarily for music-related activities, displaying lyrics and chords for guitar, playing back music, etc.  None of those activities are video intensive.  But when I've used it to view videos in high def, it performs like a champ and looks really good.  I'm very pleased.

Perhaps the best thing I can say about the tablet is that it's largely "transparent."  By that, I mean that I just do what I want to do with it and don't have to struggle with a clumsy interface.  I'm aware of the tasks but not of the device as an intermediary between me and the task.  that's the way a tablet should work, in my judgment, and this one does.

I bought this to travel with.  I am relishing the super long battery life, especially with the keyboard combined.  And it works pretty much as advertised.  The graphics are not as smooth as the Ipad but I am free of the big brother policies of Apple.

This tablet looks great, feels very well made, and runs apps quickly.  The WiFi, however, is terrible. I regularly use this tablet in three locations where I get rock solid and fast connections with my PC, my android phone, and my Playbook, but the Asus tablet NEVER connects solidly.  The WiFi connection burps every three or four minutes, when using the browser it stops almost every time I try to access a new page or new YouTube video and I get a "problem with the network" message and then have to click on "retry," after which it will connect.  Not good.  I haven't tried contacting Asus about it yet; I'll update this review when I do.  Tablets, unlike laptops or desktops, ought to work right out of the box, no tech support needed.  Isn't that the point?

The HD screen is crystal clear and there are plenty of apps available to do everything that I need to do.  Couldn't seem to get it to join my network, but picked up the Wifi with no problem.  My wife and I both love it and we got the keyboard dock to go with it.  Looking for more of a bag type carry case for it.

This is my first tablet.  First, why I bought this.  I wanted a tablet to use ad hoc around the house.  Especially when watching TV something would come up that I would like to get more information about.  For the first time I don't have to get up and walk to my desktop PC and I'm not limited by the tiny browser screen on my smartphone.  Using that tiny screen was really irking me.  Now after 3 months I'm very happy that the tablet has exactly met my objectives.  I use the tablet on many occasions while watching TV or just sitting around drinking coffee or sharing some information while sitting in the living room with friends.

I narrowed my choices to the Samsung Galaxy TAB, Nexus and ASUS.  So why this particular tablet?  First I decided I wanted a 10" screen.  After several trips to retailers comparing the 7" & 10" I decided the 10" was the more usable screen size.  I am completely happy with that decision.  I think the size is a sweet spot for displaying enough information on the screen without needing to scroll while also displaying text and graphical content in a size that doesn't cause eye strain.  The tie breaker for choosing this tablet was the wide screen format to accommodate wide screen HD video plus the favorable reviews about the color quality, clarity and brilliance.  This tablet met or exceeded all my expectations for these features.

My second choice was the Nexus because of the very positive image and color quality reviews but it was much more expensive than the ASUS.  The Galaxy TAB seemed most comparable in price and features but the wide screen format of the ASUS was the tie breaker for me - even though I deliberated on the final choice because of negative comments about the speakers.  (More comments about this follow.)

Another reason for choosing this tablet over others was the keyboard dock and particularly the ability to close it up like a laptop.  I also like others' favorable reviews about USB ports and keyboard feel.  I haven't bought the keyboard yet.

I don't have any issues about performance.  But I'm not a power user and I'm not using any apps that are processor intensive.

Now for the one feature I'm really disappointed and annoyed about.  The speaker.  Its placement at the back of the tablet and the inability to raise the volume enough makes some content almost impossible to hear.  I was fully aware of negative reviews about this but I decided to buy it anyway because 1) many positives outweighed this one negative and 2) I didn't feel I would be listening to audio so frequently to become a major issue.  My feeling after 3 months of use is I can live with it, reluctantly.  As others have said, I frequently cup my hand around the speaker to project the sound.  On other occasions I have used a speaker dock that I originally bought for my smartphone.  But I would still like to say to the ASUS engineers, "You did such a great job on the rest of the tablet, couldn't you figure out a way to make the sound better??".

This is my first tablet.  The wife and I got this in order to read books, stream movies and surf the web in front of the TV.  The screen is bright and the tablet is pretty easy to use.  The wife loves playing her games on this.  We got the keyboard and we really like that feature too.  Great battery life!

I really like the tablet, but it is by no means a laptop replacement. The web browsing is horrificly slow in most cases, especially on the stock browser. I use Chrome now and it works well enough. I also have the dock and it is nice but I don't think it will hold up very well. It doesn't seem to hold the tablet in place well any more and the casing pops like it is coming apart. The tablet however is very solid and the screen does not scratch easy. The screen is phenomenal and very bright! Works great for watching HD videos, streaming or on my micro SD card. Now that I have a GS4 I hardly use this unless I am using the Wi Fi Go app from my desktop PC which works very very well on this tablet.

My favorite part is the battery life. I leave it on constantly so it's always ready and only use it here and there, but I only have to charge it about every couple of weeks. Even when I do use it for some serious gaming, it still lasts 6-8 hours with just the tablet and easily 10-12 with the dock!

Now that it has gone down in price for a refurb and the software is better I would recommend this to anyone looking for an android tablet. However it is not a windows laptop replacement, and it does not support FLASH AT ALL!!! That goes for all jelly bean and later android devices, but is still disappointing.  I would recommend this if you are looking for a tablet to travel with, as it has long battery life and easily connects to hot spots and works well in airports. Any new high end android phone is faster and more useful though so up to you I suppose!

I research for along time for what tablet I wanted. I am not anti-Ipad but that tablet was not what I needed. I wanted something I could still do work on and play games on at the same time. I am currently awaiting the return of my tablet from the service center as it has a power issue. I was playing a game and the tablet shut off and would not turn back on. Other than that this tablet has been exactly what I wanted. It has Polaris Office so you can read and edit office documents. First, let me qualify by saying that I have been a customer and supporter of Asus since the early 90s.

I received my TF700T in December and was very happy with it until May.  That is when I had my first issue.  This is referring to the keyboard, which is a separate product, but it highlights the issue with their customer support.  The rubber feet began randomly falling off of the keyboard.  I contacted customer support and they wanted me to actually send the keyboard into the service department to deal with this.  That's right they wanted to spend $20-$30 in combined shipping to take care of a few $.10 rubber feet.  I eventually got to someone reasonable who said they would send replacement feet.  Fortunately, I found the missing feet in my bag, but their solution to the problem was "glue them back on".

Not long after that, I started having issues with the system itself.  The touch capabilities started failing and the system began acting erratically.  I went through all of the usual Android steps... updates... factory reset... and finally needed to send it in for repair.  When I sent it in, the techs "tested" it, decided there was nothing wrong, and sent it back with another factory reset.  I got it, reloaded everything, proceeded to use it and the problems were still there.  Now they are making me send it back AGAIN.

It gets 2-stars, because, when it works, it's a great system, but only 2-stars because their customer and technical support is AWFUL.

Very crisp display, light weight and feels sturdy in your hands. Experienced some slight lag but overall very responsive and quick. Excellent battery life with moderate to frequent use. Sound is adequate, but could be greatly improved, although I mostly use external speakers or Bluetooth headphones.

I was looking forward to this device, and was heartily disappointed by it.  I sold my iPad 1 for it, then sold this to a co-worker and replaced it with an ipad 3...which I traded in for my Surface Pro (and now I've never been happier now that I have the Surface Pro).  After I give some background, I'll bullet my concerns, just to save you voluminous reading.

  I'm a tech guy, so I have a fairly regular 18 month refresh cycle on my laptop and 2.5 rolling part-at-a-time refresh for my desktop.  I swap phones on a whim to try out new capabilities.  My tech goal though, is optimizing for travel:  I fly ouvr 50,000 miles a year.  With the amount of time that I spend on planes and in hotel rooms, I'm constantly looking for the 'best solution for the road'.  This wasn't it.  Some of the reasons why surprised me, and I wouldn't have expected them until I faced them.

*  The removable keyboard is a pain in the butt on the fly.  If you are flying, you need to find somewhere to stash the keyboard if you remove it, and in a place that you can access it without bugging your neighbor.  It usually ended up jammed between the cushion and the armrest.

*Removing the keyboard was generally a 'pull it off at an angle' endeavor, which is a little awkward with limited arm room, such as in a plane.

*The screen...holy fingerprint magnet!  I have never owned a device before or since that attracted so many fingerprints.

*HD-out:  I'm not sure why, but it didn't work quite right all the time.

*Interface lag:  there was noticible input lag when swiping and scrolling.  This is not an issue with either the ipad or the Surface Pro.

*Crashing:  I have crashed every device I have owned I think, so I guess I shouldn't have been surprised.

*Movies overseas:  I purchased and downloaded three movies before going overseas.  In the course of trying to watch them, something in the viewer 'phoned home' and told my machine that I could no longer watch them because I was overseas.  I spent 15 minutes on hold at $2.50 a minute to find out that it's an implementation issue with Google Play, and that I could have my $4 back.  This is not an issue with the iPad or Surface Pro.

*Device support:  It "sort of" supported some of the peripherals, such as common game controllers, that could be hooked up to it.  I could hack around it, but that was sub-optimal.

*The media player functionality didn't always work.  It wasn't always broken either, which was almost more frustrating.

*Almost too small and slippery.  Because it was thin and stainless steel, I was constantly worried about it flying out of my hand if toted vertically.

*Office productivity suite was disappointing.  This is a personal preference issue, but the iWork suite was much better suited to tablets, and the Office experience on the Surface Pro just kicks everything else to the curb.

*My timecard with my company didn't render right in the browser.  Ever.  Not being able to do my timecard on the road was the final straw.  The ipad couldn't either, but I dug my old laptop out for a while.  The Surface Pro renders just fine, so it (and my cell phone) are my only electronic travel companions now.

  Finally, if you're an Android fan, you're probably so used to the little software and OS nits that bug the crap out of me about Android.  I know people love it...but it reminds me of Linux:  "It works awesome, as long as you just do this, and this, and this, and this..."  Apple products on the other hand, offer a polished experience with a limited productivity experience.  The Surface Pro offers a good travel-productivity experience, with a battery life that is on par with the comparably sized Macbook Air (only about 4-5 hours)--but it offers full PC capabilities in addition to tablet capabilities...which is why I stayed with that.

So let me begin by saying I have owned 1 (Count 'em ONE) Apple device apart from iPods in my entire life. That was an iPhone 3GS and I returned it after a week. I bought an Android phone right afterwards and haven't looked back.

I am on my 6th Android smartphone now. I have a Galaxy S4. I also owned a Nexus 7 (Also made by ASUS) right before this. That was my first Android tablet, and I was very happy with it. I just wanted a bigger screen.

BUT THIS TABLET IS NOT WHAT ANDROID IS MEANT TO BE.

Don't get me wrong, the hardware is phenomenal. It's extremely thin, Micro SD card slot is a major plus (so is 32GB of storage though) The tablet itself is beautiful. As well as the screen. The cameras on the front and back are great and I didn't expect anything more  or less from them.

But the fact that it only has 1GB of RAM is this thing's downfall. It's downright pathetic that a QUAD CORE 1.6GHz TEGRA 3 PROCESSOR can't handle the ANDROID HOME SCREEN!!

I installed CleanROM which is 100% de-bloated from all the crapware ASUS installs and it even overclocks the damn thing to 1.9GHz. YET IT STILL LAGS.

I don't understand how a manufacturer can sell something like this when all it does is slow down and freeze after opening 3 apps. I've always trusted ASUS, but after this issue, and the fact that both this tablet and the Nexus 7 both had screen separation problems until I returned them the first time; I'm not as convinced as I used to be.

Sorry ASUS, but if I spent $430 on a tablet, I expect a flawless device, and if not a flawless device, then at least a slightly diminished hardware experience in exchange for a flawless software experience.

RETURNED.

After liking our Android phones decided to toss my wife's windows laptop and replace with the tablet. While for use almost exclusively networked to the home pc, I really liked the improvement in features the tablet represented: smaller, lighter, touch screen, cool apps, etc. I also liked the idea of taking it on the road when traveling, just a lot more portable. And while I really liked the tablet itself, when it came to Android and home networking, I decided this platform simply wasn't for me.

Tablet Pros:
 Touch screen - very bright and clear, smudges when screen off are completely invisible when on. Responsiveness is incredible.
 Battery - unbelievable standby time, very good use time. We didn't use that much, but left on all the time only had to charge every few days or so, maybe every other day with moderate use.
 Keyboard Dock - I also got the keyboard dock, worked really well, love the convertibility of it - the Android keyboard works amazingly well, but for more robust typing, the keyboard is obviously your best choice
 I really didn't use any other features but liked the idea of having both the forward and rear facing cameras, as well as the mini-HDMI port among others

Tablet Cons (only one):
 WiFi Speed - while at times I experienced speeds comparable to my laptop, at other times, this thing was incredibly slow, especially when watching video such as Youtube or a product video on a company website.

Android Home Networking Cons - The Deal Killer in my book
 File Sharing - requires an app, such as the most popular, ES-File Explorer, all of which function essentially as FTP, meaning that you don't edit the file in place but instead open it, edit it, save it to the tablet, then transfer it back to the PC. Call me Goldilocks but I want to open it, edit it, save it, done. Okay, so "duh," we're talking two completely different O/S's, so I should expect that, but I seriously thought the apps would handle it differently.
 Printer Sharing - again, requires an app. No, you don't just print directly from an Office type of software, or directly from a web page, but instead you save your file to the tablet, then open your downloaded printer app, then open the file, then print it. What a pain.

Conclusion:
So again, if you're looking for a mobile tablet or are all about cloud file storage, not considering it for networking with a pc, and are also only an occasional printer, then I would highly recommend this tablet. Otherwise, stick with Windows.

The rest of our school staff got Ipads and I'm not jelous at all, allthough I don't think I would buy this particular tablet again, especially at the price point of the tablet and the keyboard. That said, I'm pretty content with what I have

The Asus Tf700 is so awesome,  I have the nexus 7 inch and was debating on the ASUS and the nexus 10 so I decided ASUS, it is so fast, the display is beautiful.  I have been waiting to get this one for a while when the price dropped on jumped on it.

This tablet has exceeded all of my expectations.  Battery life is amazing, after adjusting several settings I regularly get about a day and a half of battery time.  The graphic potential is amazing as well and with the Tegea quad-core processor I have no problem doing multiple things at once.  I was going to get an iPad like my fiace has but changed my mind when my friend showed me his transformer.  I am glad I went with what I did and will never reget thus decision.

I have been using this tablet for about a month. The resolution is amazing. It makes reading on it fantastic, even in night mode. It is nice and quick. Games run really well. The touch sensitivity is right on the mark. The 32GB of built in memory with an SD slot gives you all the memory you need at a faction of the cost of most 64GB tablets. Even though it doesn't use a standard USB charging system, the proprietary one charges really quickly.

The downside is that the battery life will get you over 9 hours of watching movies, but if you are just using it switching back between apps and games, you see a big drop off. (Although the docking station would resolve this.) Also because of the higher resolution, there are a fair number of apps that aren't available in the app store because it doesn't support this resolution.

All in all, this is a fantastic tablet and would highly recommend it. Just make sure your favorite apps are supported on it.
Great product for work or play.  I take it with me everywhere.  If you're worried you won't have enough memory, buy a micro SD.  Add the dock and you've got a great travel companion.
Loving my Asus tablet.  So glad I did not go with an IPad!  Everyone said I'd be happier with the TF700.

I have an android phone so this tablet is like having an extension to my phone. I can do so much with it I never imagined, I also bought the keyboard so my co-workers who have other more expensive tablet (Ipad) are jealous of my tablet. great investment!!!

I didn't find much difference between my new TF700 and the TF300. My personal benchmark which I found most effective in representing true daily use speed is the Play Store application updates. The sequence of download/install gives a good idea of how fast the device can be. My Nexus 4 is much faster (but it has phone issues which can be solved mostly by leaving it in 2G). Yet, about the only difference in specs is that the Nexus has 2GB of RAM and the tablet only 1GB.

So, the performance between the two is about the same. No significant improvement. However the TF700 has an improved GPS (it works as it should) and improved Wi-Fi. As for the higher resolution screen, well, if you have great vision, maybe you can tell the difference between 240dpi and 150dpi, but if your screen is full of finger marks, or if you had to put a non-glare screen protector on it, then I bet you can't tell the difference anymore. So there is much hype placed on screen resolution, none of which makes any difference really.

If it wasn't for the keyboard, I would have bought the: CUBE U30GT2 II Quad Core 10.1 inch Retina Screen Android 4.1 Tablet PC RK3188 2GB/32GB for $290

[...]

In my view, it deserved a try. Unfortunately, it seems stores don't have it in stock so you can't try it. But it certainly appealed to me.

You just have to be very diligent in searching for android versions of the apps and accept that some will not be available.  Also you notepad works more like a mobile phone than a laptop.  It's been a good learning experience. Not cheap...but most are not.  :))

I got this, and checked if I had the latest updates on it. It did.
So I tested it out.

Web browsing is painfully slow and the ui lags frequently.
Most other apps were the same way though not quite as bad.
So I started reading forums about it.
Almost everyone who owns one of these and keeps it has to first unlock it, then root it, and finally flash a 3rd party ROM on it to make it perform at all reasonably.
The step of unlocking it voids your warranty. I don't know if there is anyways to relock it so that ASUS won't be able to tell that it was unlocked either.

So basically if you buy this, plan of giving up any warranty support almost immediately if you want it to be very useful.

I'm returning mine rather than messing with flashing it. It's not hard to do, but it just doesn't seem worth keeping a product that manufacturer isn't willing to make work properly. Also from what I've read ASUS support is horrible.

I gave it 2 stars rather than 1 because if you take the time to adjust it and fix what asus is too lazy or cheap to fix, it's actually a pretty decent device.

Don't bother reading this unless you're willing to lose your warranty and possibly brick your Asus (which is a brick anyway unless you take matters into your own hands).  Do not use this review as the instructions to do the unlock/rom install, there are better instructions.

If you're not willing to do this then I can't recommend it. Get the Note 10.1 or Nexus 10, even if they are a little bit more money.  Or, buy it and be prepared to return it within a short time if your browser thinks it's from 1997.

This thing was decent when I first got it.  Then the first update came and slowed down the browser to a very frustrating pace.  Like the worst computer you've ever used. Like an Ipad 1 which is what I had bought this to replace. The second update came and it was no better, maybe slightly worse.  There is something wrong with either the latest versions of Android or the lack of ram in this machine or Asus' ability to create their own ROM.  My 2GB Samsung Note 2 blows it out of the water in wifi or LTE. Samsung knows how to fix stock Android.

I was really about to chalk this purchase up to a bad decision and just retire it after less than 2 months.  I couldn't in good conscience sell it to someone else.  If it was a horse I'd have to have shot it!  Then I figured I'm going to stop using it anyway, might as well try one of the "mods" that are all over the internet, especially xda developers site.  So I spent an evening reading about how to do it and the next day spent an hour doing it.  There is simple software available where you just choose some options and it magically does it.

First I "unlocked" the bootloader, did not select root though it may have done that anyway, then did a backup, then installed the ROM (Cleanrom Inheritance) which is a slimmed down version of the actual Asus ROM.  I got to pick and choose default apps as well as the ability to add some additional ones during the install.  The additional ones are things like different home screens like Nova, ADW, etc, as well as different file managers, etc. Make sure you download browser2ram also and run it after install.  Quite a bit of good stuff.  Then I pressed install. I also chose to clear cache.  I recommend clearing ALL cache options because...

Then came time to reboot. Then I waited.  And waited. And started freaking out that I may have "bricked" it.  It wouldn't get past the Asus spinning wheel.  Give it 15 mins. Googled it and found out that if I got this far, it wasn't bricked. Yippee.  If it doesn't work, hold the power button down until it shuts down, go back into the bootloader (hold volume down and power until the 3 icons come back up). Then clear ALL cache (3 buttons I think) and reboot normally again. Seems like after a time or two doing this it came up just fine as if it was a new tablet asking me to log into my Google account.

Guess what?  It was a completely different tablet.  Now it works like it should.  The browser is fast, maybe not quite as fast as my Note 2 but then again my Note 2 has 2GB ram. I never get close to 1gb of ram used (sits about 6-700mb), so not sure if the Samsung is just faster or better. Could also be the lower resolution and screen size of the Note 2 vs the 1080p screen.  It's just fine now though, not the frustrating machine that gave me the worst post-purchase dissonance I've had in quite some time.

In the future if desired, I'll no longer get over the air updates (fact of life if you unlock the bootloader).  Thank GOD (and Asus) for that! I'll take these xda updates or simply leave it as it is forever (3 years it will probably be long in the tooth anyway).

Luck..

**EDIT** 26 December 2013:
Installed Cyanogenmod 11 (Android 4.4.2 KitKat) successfully. It still lags a lot and feels really sluggish, but it is perfectly usable for most tasks. Lowering one extra star because of the lag. Yet I feel it is aging well, KitKat's Memory optimizations and Jellybean's TRIM have helped the NAND performance. It should be enough to last me rest of this device's productive life. But I look at my old iPad 2 and I lament the wasted chance this product entails.
Please ASUS, if you are reading this: never again cripple a product with such subpar components. For the next generation I WILL NOT be an early adopter for you.

***Review Start - Minor modifications on 26/12/2013/***
If you are still waiting for the Android Tablet Messiah, this is not it.

I bought this tablet back in October 2012, just after it finally went on sale, and immediately had buyer's remorse. The OS felt jerky and unresponsive, even with the Performance settings on. Turns out this tablet's flash memory is so sluggish that it drags down all the crazy performance of the Tegra 3 processor. So angry I was with this turn of events I installed Cyanogenmod 10.1 and slowly saw as performance improved. Now, in April, Asus has released a new update which appears to finally have optimized the OS and gave it the performance it lacked at first. I have tested the new Cyanogenmod version which includes the new optimizations Asus made and the difference is surprising. ***EDIT: Turns out the performance degraded after a while. It it perfectly usable, but not best-in-class***

Now for the good: The rest of the hardware. The screen is a gorgeous slab of Gorilla Glass, amazing resolution and great colors. Love the aluminum body, and the dock keyboard is useful. The best feature, however, is it's unlockable bootloader, thanks to whom you can install any number of Android distributions. I installed Cyanogenmod 10.1 and haven't ever looked back. Asus' version of android is however very workable by itself, compared to Samsung's Touchwiz UI. It is very vanilla, has several minor improvements and comes preloaded with several good apps, specially the Polaris Office.

The Good:
* Gorgeous screen
* MicroSD slot
* Asus's OS is vanilla android with several (good) optimizations and preloaded apps. Samsung take note!
* Quick official updates. Asus has a great track record with the updates.
* Unlocked bootloader.
* Keyboard dock is far more useful than it looks.
* Cyanogenmod 10.1 works great here, has all the features of the Stock OS. ***EDIT: Cyanogenmod 11 works great as well, but as of this date not all keyboard functions are available. Still it is an improvement.***

The Bad:
* The first versions were very laggy. It has improved greatly since then, specially with Cyanogenmod. ***EDIT: But the updates make no miracles, the lag persists.***
* No 5Ghz Wireless-N Wi-Fi, limited to 2.5Ghz.
* Inferior performance to similarly priced devices. This NAND truly sucks.
* Expensive

The Ugly:
* Propietary power connector. WHY, ASUS, WHY????? Make sure to buy spares.

I am a university student and mainly wanted a tablet for reading eBooks, as well as the occasional light computing. I got tired of buying actual books (Costly), and didn't like to have my laptop on those small classroom desks. With my laptop on the desk, I am forced to put my notebook on my thighs when taking notes.

I read tons and tons of reviews, watch tons and tons of videos online to choose between the TF700T and the Note 10.1... Ended up getting the ASUS. I honestly regret that decision. The device began freezing up, and slowing down about 1 week after receiving it. Then at times the screen would flicker and present some lines going across the screen temporarily. I would either need to turn the screen off and back on to get rid of it, or it sometimes went away after a second or two.

*****My BIGGEST issue with the ASUS tf700T is the slow response to interaction. I would sometimes try to open a PDF and it literally takes about 10+ seconds to open. That same PDF would open on my Galaxy S2 with no problems at all, so I know its the device and not the file. To sum it up, the TF700T that I got is way, way slower than my phone, and for a Tegra 3 device I find that unacceptable. The device also came with some light bleeds, which they rectified with the RMA.

  I sent it into ASUS (At shipping cost to me) with the expectation of the problems being rectified. Apparently all I got back was a "Hard reset" device. After about another 3 or so days, the issues were all there again. The sluggish response, screen flickering, and occasion restarts. The device is in no way as fast or smooth as it was expected to be.

  Now, I am not saying that the ASUS TF700T is not a good device. I have friends who own them, and lower models and they are quite pleased with them. With any product there are always a few bad ones in the batch. If only ASUS would realize that and replace my with a different one.

Its an "Ok" device, but nothing that I consider worth $500.

I wanted to use this tablet for awhile before writting a review. For me the biggest negative aspect of this tablet is the Android operating system. While the Android system does do some things pretty well it has a long way to go before it catches up with the competition in my opinion.

Pros: Screen resolution is very good, processor is fast, battery life is good especially when docked to the keyboard. the ability to turn it into a mini laptop with the keyboard, ability to use other storage devices like memory sticks with the optional external USB adapter or keyboard, expandable memory with SD cards, Bluetooth, good WiFi reception, robust case and price.

Cons: Does not have 4G capibility unless tethered nor does it have the drivers to run a USB wireless adapter, does not have the drivers to print to a bluetooth or USB printer, has difficulty or inability to open some web pages and/or drop down boxes and web based files, limited apps although this is improving, no easy way, that I have found, to return to your web home page and the sound volume is poor from the speakers. It handles Word and PDF documents pretty well however, it doesn't have any good shortcuts other then the search function to navigate around a PDF document which requires a lot of finger scrolling.

Switching from Microsoft to Android was a terrible mistake. I purchased this tablet knowing ASUS was a decent manufacturer, but Android as the operating system, leaves out a lot to be desired. Starting out: At first, the interface seemed pretty neat with all the apps available. The functionality and user friendly factor is unfortunately not present. If you want to disable certain apps from operating such as email, it poorly effects other applications. You wouldn't expect an email app to degrade your "Play Music" app, but it does. Also, it seems like you can never rid any program on the tablet. It sneakingly finds it's way back on your tablet even though you don't want it. The 100 usless apps constantly update causing the user to manually select that you don't want these apps to update automatically and most apps of which you cannot uninstall. Switching between different apps is also upsetting. When I press the back key, expecting to re-visit the last page I was on, it goes to the home screen causing the user to now finger through your recent apps. I find that this sleek, thin, attractive ASUS tablet is not at all complemented and dragged down by the poor Android software. I also believe Android/Google does not make this "Your" tablet. It will always manipulate the apps and software to do what it wants to do, rather than the user. I find it more annoying to operate this tablet, than it's worth. It will definitely be replaced by a Microsoft tablet in the near future.

On sleep it lasts about 2 days. It has good battery life, enough that you don't have to worry all day about it running out.

Note: if you turn it off completely be prepared to wait some 2-3 minutes for it to boot up. Your best bet is to turn it on before you're ready to lay/sit down with it and go brush your teeth or use the restroom. It will be ready when you get back.

Also, don't turn on automatic updates for your apps otherwise when you go use it will start downloading all your app updates and if you're going online it will obviously not be as fast as it could be due to the extra processes and installations running. I spent a great deal of time researching tablets and debating new smartphone, new laptop or tablet.  Because I loved my rather inadequately and would never recommend Smartphone from T-mobile (a Samsung Gravity Smart filled with bloatware and incapable of expanding even with a larger storage card), I finally decided on the Asus tablet because it struck me as the perfect hybrid between a true laptop and a tablet.  I found a great deal on a 64 gig open-box unit and they price-matched me on the keyboard (J&R in New York) and was sooooooooo excited I purchased over $150 in accessories before I even got the darn thing!  I will say this, I have NEVER experienced such awesome visuals in my life (and yesterday was my 50+++ birthday).  Truly amazing, crisp, beautiful -- I can't say enough.  That being said, for the price, it just wasn't worth it.  The sound quality is a joke as in, why the hell do you put 1 speaker in the rear only?  Yesterday (I did say it was my birthday, didn't I?) I caved and bought an iPad mini and the sound on it is 1,000x better than the Asus.  Also, my brand new (not opened box) keyboard had a "T" that kept sticking.  I type over 80 wpm, so when I key doesn't work, It screws up my rhythm big time.  It also made be wonder about Asus quality control.  I will acknowledge that I thought the tablet will be more like a laptop, i.e., able to have multiple "windows" open at once, etc., etc., so I have to bear some of the blame with respect to expectations.  Also, I had no idea 10" could be so unwieldy.  I had seen and caressed the iPad when it first came out but it just didn't look that portable to me.  I think I had forgotten, and the Asus I believe is heavier than the iPad.  I carry a big pocketbook always but still, plopping it out at a restaurant was a bit unwieldy.  I'm currently "in transition," (i.e., desperately seeking employment)so the cost was a huge issue.  So, as much as I didn't want to give Apple any money, for half the cost of the TF700T, I got an iPad mini which is more portable, gets more podcasts (which I will be able to hear without earphones) and has less accessories on which to waste money -- although I did order a keyboard for that, as well.  Unless the visuals are a real requirement for you, I, unfortunately, can't recommend this product.

I finally decided this was the tablet for me.

My deciding factors:
HD Display

Expandable memory (MicroSD card slot)
Android OS (Jelly Bean Update)
SuperNote (preinstalled note taking app)
Polaris Office (preinstalled)

The HD on this tablet is very good.  The battery charged very quickly, I did notice the back of the tablet got very hot when charging.  But you cant feel it through the case I have it in.  The tablet automatically updated to Jelly Bean, which made the tablets web browser drag and crash like crazy.  I downloaded Boat Browser and have used that as the main browser ever since, it hasn't crashed on me yet (it also supports flash, BONUS!!).

Overall I love this tablet, it is customizable (Hello its Android), lightweight, stylish and extremely easy to use.  I would definitely recommend this to any college student.  The price is a little steep compared to other tablets but the options for this tablet trump the competition.

I've been reading some of the flaming reviews ... and some retractions ... for the TF700T. You know, if I wanted a full amped-out gaming machine, I would have stuck with a desktop on steroids. What I got was a solid functioning, usable platform. Add the keyboard/dock, and it met all my needs. I'm not expecting a tablet to be a full-fledged publishing platform - but the Polaris App makes working with Word/Excel/PowerPoint viable when I have to be mobile. I was torn between the Nexus 10 and the Transformer, but the 32G limitation with no SD expandability of the Nexus pretty much threw me to the Transformer. In addition, the amazing work that AstonSoft is doing on adapting their Essential PIM App to the Transformer has endeared me to it as a replacement for my Palm T/X, which HP obviously intends to let die on the vine since acquiring Palm. So all-in-all, from purely a personal needs and expectations viewpoint, I'm supremely pleased with my TF700T purchase.

The 1080p screen with Super IPS mode is absolutely beautiful, and I love having a physical keyboard. The tablet has replaced my laptop as a media consumption device. I had in mind to buy a second, but I will probably buy a Nexus 10 instead because the TF700 is so excruciatingly slow. Browsing web sites is a chore. It's difficult to type because the device is so slow that it often drops keystrokes. The problem is that it doesn't have enough RAM (1GiB vs. 2GiB on Nexus 10 and others). I was so frustrated with the sluggishness that the other day I went to see what things I could uninstall to make it faster. As it turns out, most of the memory is used by pre-installed Asus services which cannot be uninstalled. One such service (@vibe) has been spamming me.

For light usage the TF700 is okay, but it's overpriced and underperforms.

Update (06/08/2012):
The recent push of Android 4.2.1 improves the memory usage quite a bit, but the tablet still feels generally sluggish compared to other Android devices. It is particularly evident when typing in the omnibox in Chrome, but even typing this review I have noticed stuttering.

Nothing is perfect but this Asus tablet comes darned close.  After opening the box and charging the battery it took about 10 minutes for this beauty to upgrade itself to JellyBean 4.1.1. I am very satisfied and hope to get several years of use from this sweetheart of a tablet.

Best purchase I've made in a long time. I've almost stopped using my laptop even at home. This is so easy to use. The display is wonderful even with my eye problems, reading has become easy again.

I've noticed a lot of tablet reviews are written as if they're submittals for an engineering journal. I am an avionics and software engineer but will try to write something helpful for the majority of folks who buy tablets and are not engineers or hard core gamers. I just returned the TF700 to Amazon and bought a Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 and I'll explain why. So here we go.

After a lot of on line looking I decided to go with the ASUS TF700. Many times this model is rated at the top of the heap for all Android tablets. After getting one I'm not exactly sure how it gets rated that highly. Is it a bad tablet? No. That said, there's no real benefit here for the average to even slightly advanced tablet user so the value story isn't the best and it has a couple of issues which is why I gave 3 stars.

One major thing to know before you buy this model is that it can not effectively be recharged using anything but it's own power adapter. That may not sound like a big deal, but it is if you're highly mobile, don't want to carry extra stuff everywhere, or are prone to misplacing things. The last thing I want to do is have to carry separate adapters for all my electronics so I rely on charging via USB. This goes for my Android phone, my Ipod Touch, and everything else. The ASUS TF700 owner's manual says it will charge from a PC USB port but this is very misleading, if not an outright fib of sorts. Most USB ports, PC or otherwise do not have the voltage level this tablet requires. Hence, some ports/charger adapters will do a "trickle charge" while others will not work at all. Also, it's very important to note that if you find a USB port that works, it really is a trickle charge and the tablet screen can not be on or the tablet in use or it will stop charging altogether. The tablet will re-charge at a rate about 3% or so of the rate using the adapter....so be prepared to wait a very long time.

The TF700 is put together fairly well but it does have some parts that seem kind of cheap for a tablet in this price range.

Here's a real kicker. It has the latest Tegra Quad Core processor, a fair amount of RAM (memory), and yet it's slow. Boot up time is twice as long as the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 and there are delays when working with your favorite software applications. Very little to none of this happens on the Samsung which is why this is a kicker because the Samsung only has the Dual Core "slower" processor. Without getting too technical, if the engineering isn't good a better processor can be offset by other lower quality parts or design and the result is the computer/tablet runs slower than an older or supposedly less capable one, and I think that's what happened with the TF700.

The TF700 has a very high resolution screen (think similar to the iPad Retina display). The problem is it actually doesn't render (display the picture to keep it simple) many things as well as some less capable lower cost tablets out there. As time goes by I'm sure new software apps and some updates from ASUS would probably make better use of the display.

Lastly, the TF700 uses battery power at a pretty good clip. Honestly, it was this issue combined with the inability to charge properly/efficiently from USB ports that caused me to return it. While I use a tablet for fun things, it is really a tool and like any other tool, it needs to be there when you need it.

So what are the benefits? If you're reeaaallllyy into games then this tablet may be for you. If you just play some games sometimes and you're kind of an Angry BIrds level type, you can do better with your money. For you gamers, the TF700 does have a lot of chops, but for some reason there are issues with the RAM even though it's the latest DDR technology. Again it's either an engineering or part quality issue so you may not get the performance you might think you'd be getting. The other benefit is the optional ASUS keyboard. If you still like to use a real keyboard at times, no one does this better than ASUS with a tablet. Clicking it on the keyboard makes the tablet look like a netbook. It stays petty lightweight but the keyboard has a built in battery that also powers the tablet for extra up time. It also has additional ports and a full size SD card slot.

The summary here is that unless you're a serious gamer and you like Android, save your money and go with one of the many other capable tablets out there. The Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 10.1 is on Amazon for about $120 less than the TF700, and if you're a Costco member they have it right now for $279. Impossible to go wrong at that price and the quality/performance of the Samsung. That said, there's also a few others out there as well. The bottom line is that super horsepower is not needed on a tablet for most users, and if it is needed for heavy work then you'd want to go with a Windows Pro tablet or Ultrabook anyway.

Hope this helps someone out there! Take care.

After six months, the pins on the connection to the keyboard broke, which caused the tablet to shut down when you plugged it in. I sent it to ASUS for repair. After 2 weeks they sent me an email saying that it was not covered by the warranty and would cost $200 to fix. After another work without a reply, they told me I had two options: pay and they'll fix it, and don't pay and they'll send me back the broken unit. The worst customer service ever! They've created yet another Apple customer. I'll never buy another ASUS.

The built quailty and keyoboard are great though. Camera could be better , and the Ipads camera far surpass though. The bezzle on the tablet feels very clicky also which is a bad thing.
