Even better tan what I've expected, I ser no need to buy an iPad, for what I need is just the perfect match.

Full HD (technically more - 1920x1200), Tegra3, all-day battery life, super-slim, what more could you ask for?

It's easy to use for reading and browsing, but I wish it had some soft-touch surfaces or rubber surfaces for better grip (like the Nexus 7).  I have both, and each have their pros/cons.

The IPS display is gorgeous with great viewing angles and even an extra-bright mode for using the tablet outside. Depending on the reading app, two full pages can be displayed.
The Tegra3 processor/GPU can chew through any game/app individually though sometimes the tablet can feel slower than it should. Make sure that you're on the appropriate power profile since there's also a battery-saving mode and a balanced mode.
The tablet comes with a charger and USB cable (the end that connects to the tablet is a proprietary connector to charge the tablet more rapidly than just USB).
I highly recommend getting the keyboard dock since it has a built-in battery that can charge the tablet, add extra battery life (15+ hours, real-world) and of course provide a usable keyboard.

It's a great companion for running between meetings where you might need to use Evernote, email/browsing, chat/IM, etc.

Asus has been keeping up with updates fairly regularly and "Scrosler" on XDA-Developers has a custom "Clean ROM" to run as an optimized, bloat-free option.

Update - Asus has released a 4.2.1 upgrade! They are doing a good job of keeping this tablet updated!

This item replace my 3-year-old Motorola Xoom and I've had it for about a week now.  Let's start with the bad:

1.  There is no message notification light.  I sort of got used to seeing the light blink when I had an email.  Not a big deal but something worth mentioning.
2.  The tablet is so thin that I find the edges a bit sharp when reading a book.  Again, not a big deal since I can always change my grip or put it in some sort of case.
3.  The built-in speaker is a bit tinny and doesn't put out a lot of volume. It does the job but not much more.  To be fair, the Xoom is my reference point and had some pretty good built-in speakers.
4.  The speaker is on the back.  I much prefer the speakers on the front because that's where I am.

That's it for the bad.  Not so bad though is it?

Now the good.

This tablet absolutely screams.  It is incredibly fast.  The display is awesome and easily handles even the highest resolution videos I can throw at it.  It's got a micro-SD card for extra expansion and a micro HDMI connector for connecting directly to a TV or monitor.  I believe the audio through the HDMI port (I haven't tried a headset yet) is much "bigger" than the Xoom.  The basses sound quite full and the high frequencies "snap (that's good).

Battery life is good but I wouldn't say it's exceptional.  I'm using the keyboard dock which has an extra battery.  I charge both devices every other day.  I'd say I'm a tablet power user so that's not too bad.  All in all, I'm happy with the battery life.

The Infinity is very light (compared to my Xoom) and seems to have a comparable feel to my wife's iPad Retina.  It is very stylish and I find the controls to be intuitively placed on the device.

With the exception of Scrabble Free (come on EA) all of my apps work very well on the Infinity.  The screen scrolls smoothly and I have not witnessed any slowness or jerky motion using the touch screen.  I'm not a gamer so I can't comment on game performance.  The automatic display brightness seems to work well in all levels of ambient light.

Asus doesn't add much in the way of "bloatware" and what they do add seems to be useful (or can be disabled in most cases).

I've got the keyboard dock (reviewed separately) which, IMO is a must if you're going to do much typing.  But, that would be the case with any tablet.  It's just that the Transformer line gives you a pretty good option.

Short story:  I'm very happy with this purchase and might just become a long-term Transformer customer.
I have an iPad 2 and a Transformer 101 and this easily blows them away.  Better processor, beautiful screen resolution and Android 4.1!

Did find out that it is completely dead and have to ship back at MY cost for possible warranty work that THEY get to decide if it was my fault.  They don't even have a local USA service center for this -- as near as I can tell from the website.

My recommendation - don't buy one.  Get a tablet that is about as good but with great service support.  This is a near commodity device that is supposed to be a $500+ throwaway device after 2-3 years? I got the TF700T and the dock for it a few weeks ago, used it for about 10 days and exchanged it for a Samsung Note 10.1. I don't regret the switch one bit!

Here's the somewhat lengthy bottom line:

1) The TF700T has a fantastic screen with truly impressive resolution! It's essentially the same resolution as the iPad Retina. However, I believe this extra resolution results in...

2) It is REALLY slow! Just switching screens and starting apps, etc. is truly painfully slow. It feels as if the tablet is virused or bogged with bloatware. But it's not. It appears that having double the resolution of other 10" tablets is really taxing the system resources. Therefore, bouncing from app to app to crank out tasks takes many times longer than it should. I found that I was just going back to my Samsung Note II phone to do the tasks I got the TF700T for.

3) Battery life is horribly poor. Because the TF700T is so slow, it must always remain in the high performance mode (fire symbol on the taskbar menu). I hardly ever even used the device but by the end of the day, the dock would be at 0% charge and the tablet at 50% or less charge.

4) The dock's touchpad is SO sensitive that it was nearly impossible to type without constantly accidentally bouncing to unintentional areas of the page and/or highlighting entire sections and accidentally deleting them. Typing with the keyboard resulted in so much error that remedying those errors took FAR FAR longer than just typing with the on-screen keyboard. Also, despite only having the keyboard for about 10 days and literally only typing on it for about an actual hour, either the "T" or "7" key (sorry, forget which one) came off. It's only held on by adhesive so I just stuck it back on and it looked fine. When I returned it to BestBuy, I did mention the key to the guy at the counter and he told me that returned Asus stuff just goes back to the distributor and they get credited back so no loss to them. Good. Because this quality is simply atrocious.

SUMMARY: If you have a Samsung smartphone, your transition to the Note 10.1 will be seamless. Samsung's user interface is MUCH better than the TF700T's. Yes, they're both running Ice Cream Sandwich, but each company has its tweaks and Samsung's though rather subtle on the surface make a truly material difference in practice. Particularly the "Samsung Keyboard" feature vs. the "Asus Keyboard." The Samsung "Continuous Input" (sliding fingers across keys like Swype) feature is LIGHT YEARS better than Asus' version. The Asus sliding keystroke feature thing, like its dock's keyboard, is only good in theory but in practice works so poorly that it's actually a negative and therefore useless.

All in all, I have to admit that though I wanted to love the TF700T+dock combo, I wound up disgusted with everything about it except the beautiful screen. The Samsung Note 10.1 is SO SO much better at EVERYTHING except resolution that this is a no-brainer decision. Plus, the Note 10.1 has front-facing stereo speakers and the Asus a rear-facing mono speaker that's poorly placed. The Note's battery life is FAR superior. I never even think about battery life with it and I use it way more than I did my Asus.

This is a really really easy decision, folks. If you're going high-end Android tablet, there is a clear winner and that is the Samsung Note 10.1. For now at least. Who knows what will pop up next week? ;)

After reading tons of reviews on every possible android tablet out there I finally settled on the ASUS Infinity TF700 thinking it would be the ultimate smooth, lightweight take-everywhere productivity machine.  Of course I have a full blown desktop, and full sized laptop, but I wanted something that could do it all for general and business production, and still be small and portable.  I also bought the docking keyboard in order to use it as a stripped down, small laptop.  I was replacing a 3 year old Toshiba Netbook that I absolutely loved and used when I traveled or ran to meetings but it was time to upgrade.  I've been using the Android OS on my phones for years so I was already up to speed on how to operate the tablet.  Right out of the box it was the same and a snap to set-up.  I love all the Android applications, OS, widgets etc much better than the Apple OS, by far.  So I was super excited to receive this.

The look, feel and build quality of the Transformer it is second to none.  I got the 64GB version that comes in a cool champagne (goldish-silver) polished metal case. It is truly one sleek, sexy light machine.  Everywhere I went people asked "wow, what is that?".  The screen resolution was amazing, with crisp graphics and rich deep colors.  Glare on the screen was non-existent.  Hard buttons on the tablet are positioned in just the right place, and the snap-in connection of the docking keyboard is easy, tight, and seamless.  Once connected, the keyboard "takes over" and functions pretty much like a regular laptop keyboard, while still allowing you to use all the touch functionality of a the tablet.  Pretty cool.  Over all the hardware is amazing.

Unfortunately I cannot say the same thing for the performance of this tablet, which ultimately led me (reluctantly) to return it.  At first I thought maybe something was wrong with the software on this unit and not the hardware, but l am an Android power user so I know how to cold-boot, root, install custom ROMs etc in order to eliminate software conflicts etc.  After tweaking with this incessantly, the performance was just not smooth at all.  I am convinced it is a hardware problem.  Screens took too long to load, widgets didn't refresh quickly, and swiping across multiple home screens was jerky and slow.  And don't even get me started on the Browser problems.  Terrible!  Google it, its a known problem.  Constant slowdowns, crashing ("browser has stopped responding, Wait or Cancel"? ) Arg!  I installed every browser available and they were all slow.

I know all these minor issues may sound nit-picky, because the tablet does work, but considering a small portable computer like this should be lighting fast, gets used on-the-fly , and constantly to surf the internet, the performance slowdowns were a big problem for me.  Also, you should know that Adobe has stopped support for the Flash Player plug-in for Android so you won't find it in the PlayStore.  This is not a problem for most mobile-webpages but can be for some full-blown flash enabled desktop-webpages (ie pandora.com).  Fortunately you can find it online elsewhere (look at xda-developers) and side-load it.  This isn't a huge problem and certainly is not the fault of the hardware, but it just contributed to my overall frustration.

I should note that I am comparing speed to my Android phone running the exact same OS (Jelly Bean) so that was my expectations for this tablet.  The result is my phone is much faster, much smoother in side-by-side comparisons.  Also my daughters iPad 2 is much smoother, and way faster loading pages, swapping sites etc.  Im not a big fan of the Apple OS which is why I wanted an Android tablet, but the Apple hardware performance on tablets is the best, period.  I hate saying that.  Darn.  I was really hoping this sexy piece of hardware would be as good as that, without the annoying Apple OS, but I was wrong.  Darn again.

Ultimately this is a very well built machine that is just not up to par in performance.  If you are patient and don't mind the herky-jery motion, long browser load times, the annoying crashes, and you want the sexiest piece of hardware out there to set on the conference table, this is the machine for you.  If you want more than just good looks, I would suggest you look elsewhere.

When I decided I wanted to buy a new tablet I did a lot of research first.  Here are some of the reasons I chose this one over the others on the market:

App Selection
Prior to the Infinity I owned the Blackberry Playbook and it was a great tablet for its time except for the app selection.  Although Android doesn't have quite as much selection as Apple's App store it has plenty for my needs.  I have never wanted an App that I couldn't find in the Android Play Store.

GPS and Google Maps
The great thing about Google Maps on Android is that you can download maps for offline use.  I currently own an Iphone 5 and my wife has an iPad 2 but neither of those can download maps for offline use even when using Google Maps.  The Infinity also has built in unassisted GPS.  That means I can take it with me camping in the mountains and still view my offline maps and use GPS even without cell phone signal.

Storage Capacity
When I bought my Infinity it was $500 for the 32 gb version, whereas the current iPad was only 16 gb for the same price.  I was not willing to pay more than $500 for a tablet so the extra storage capacity was a big plus.  Furthermore, the Infinity comes with a nice mini SD card expansion slot which allows you to double the storage capacity with another 32 gb sd card.

Smoothness of Operating System
I tested many of the other hot Android tablets but none of them were as smooth and fluid as the Infinity.  Even the Galaxy Note seemed to get gummed up by ordinary day-to-day operations.  The Infinity feels like it's actually running a robust operating system that doesn't leave you hanging for extended moments of time after trying to swap apps in a bout of multi-tasking.

Asus Makes it Great
Asus has done a great job at restraining themselves from the tempting urge of over modifying the Android system.  They have left it clean without adding too much bloatware.  They also shipped it with one really nice app though, SuperNote.  I use SuperNote for all types of note taking activities because it allows me to write in normal handwriting without typing on the awkward tablet keyboard.  Although it is not without a few glitches I'm sure it will only get better with updates, and it already works great.  If you want a tablet for the note taking abilities, just buy a $5 stylus on Amazon and use the SuperNote app.  Another nice app is the video editing app.  Although it's a little glitchy, I'm amazed that I can actually edit my home videos right on my tablet.  Apps aside, Asus has also done a great job with the design.  The build quality is excellent.  Maybe not quite as solid as an iPad, but it feels like quality when you're holding it.  The Super IPS+ screen sure is bright too.  The resolution and brightness certainly exceed the large majority of other Android tablets out there.

The Bad
Yes, there are disappointments to every tablet, but the Infinity only has a few of them.  The number one is battery life.  The iPad definitely has a longer battery life, but compared to other Androids the Infinity still has great battery life.  I use it heavily for about two days before charging and it charges pretty fast.  The second bad point is that the Android OS is not as fluid as iOS.  No matter how hard they try, the fact of the matter is Android is not as robust of an operating system.  On the other hand the Android system is more user modifiable which was a big plus to me.  (Please don't argue about the definition of "robust" in the comments, the fact is you have to trade one for the other.)  The third point is that the Android Play Store does not offer a large selection of tablet optimized apps.  All the apps still work on the Infinity but non-optimized apps just don't look as beautiful.  So there you have it.

The Skinny
I chose this tablet over other Android tablets because it has great build quality and runs smoother than comparable tablets.  I chose it over the iPad because you get more storage, unassisted GPS, offline maps, and the SuperNote app.  I've owned it for about a month and a half and I would definitely buy it again.

(Another disclaimer: yes I did compare the Infinity to the iPad, in addition to comparing it to other Android tablets.  The reality is they are marketed in the same category and I myself had to choose between them.  Sorry to you anti-Apple die-hards but I like to feel like I am giving an unbiased review.)

For the past few years when tablets were just starting to become the new "it" thing to have, I shunned them quite a bit.  To me, they were nothing more than really expensive toys with very limited functionality.  Well, tablets have grown up quite a bit over the years, so my inner hypocrite shined and I decided to go out and get one.  The Asus Infinity TF700 was not my first choice actually.  Originally I wanted to get the Asus Vivo Tab Smart, which I did end up getting at Best Buy for a pretty good price.  The Vivo Tab Smart runs full Windows 8, and only runs for around $499 which isn't that bad at all.  Everything about it is pretty solid, except one thing... If you have never owned or used a Windows 8 tablet before, please keep reading.  Windows 8 in itself is not a bad OS, it is an OS I believe is strictly made for tablet devices, but that's just me.  The problem is this, when navigating your Start Screen it is a great device, but problems lurk the further you dive in.  For instance, when you are navigating through your main desktop on a Windows tablet it is freaking nightmare.  The main problem is you are in the end navigating your way through an OS that is meant for use with a classic mouse and keyboard.  The Start Screen = Great.  The Desktop = No Bueno.  And there is really no way around not using your desktop at least most of the time you're on your Windows tablet.  So that is what did it, just using your fingers to navigate outside the Start Screen is more aggravating than anything.  Even on a screen with a res of 1366x768 everything is STILL to small to try and touch. You go to click on something and you have to zoom in A LOT to hit the right button or link.  And you can't do that everywhere.  I even had a stylus I was using and it didn't always work the way I wanted it to.  I think Windows 8 needs A LOT of work.  The Desktop screen should have been optimized more in tablets especially, and the Windows Store needs to expand very fast and maintain functionality if it has any hopes at competing with the Google Play and Apple Store markets.

So, after I returned my Asus Vivo Tab Smart, I went on to my fallback.  The Asus TF700 Infinity Tab.  I was less than excited about getting a tablet that only ran Android OS, but I was open minded about it.  And all I can say in the end is, WOW!! This is an experience 10x better than I had with the Windows 8 Tablet.  EVERYTHING is touch optimized, because well...Android is a mobile based OS, so it kinda has to be :D  The Full HD Screen is absolutely stunning, the build quality is strong and solid, the OS is incredibly easy to navigate through, even for a first time Android user like myself.  The cons on this thing are, well...there are really only two as far as I'm concerned right now.  One is the battery, Wi-Fi eats up A LOT of juice, even on power-saver settings.  So I can at best stretch the battery life to 8-10 hours.  Second is the volume/power buttons.  The edges on this tablet (like most tablets) are beveled, or rounded.  I wish that tablets were made more squared on the edges with very sharp slightly rounded edges.  This would make button issues go away, by placing the buttons on a flatter as opposed to rounded corner surface.  But because the buttons are positioned on a beveled edge, they are a lot more cumbersome.  They are difficult to press at times, and feel slightly loose on occasion.  That is it though in way of issues, for me anyway.

In all, this is a GREAT tablet, Asus makes wonderful products and this one doesn't disappoint.  This tablet is great for photographers, graphic artists looking to showcase their artwork, light gamers, the e-book enthusiast, and social network guru.  One of the best tablets on the market right now.

After doing some research and trying various tablets at stores, I bought This TF700.  It features a very slick screen, and great performance from wifi, bluetooth, and GPS connectivity.  The included software is ok, not great.  As a book reader the screen is fantastic.  Being a long time Windows user I find Android to be somewhat awkward.  I am putting effort into acclimating to this tablet, but general browsing is clunky and when it comes to watching videos the YouTube app does not always work.  Some USB ports would be nice. And the proprietary charge port seems silly when so many devices are using micro-USB.  The battery life does not seem to be exceptional, indeed it isn't much more than my laptop.  I bought a stylus, which has made my using experience MUCH BETTER.  All of these devices should come with a stylus.  While this is a better device to me than a relatives iPad, for the money I think a traditional laptop is far more usable.

I ordered the Trasnformer thinking I would be getting an android based laptop.
My Mistake.

As an Android tablet the thing runs fairly well, but leaves much to be desired.  Keep in mind that all of the comments below are factors which occur when the tablet is running on 'High Performance Mode' (the UI in this Andoid build allows you to choose between Power Saving, Balanced, and High Performance modes) :

The Great Factors:
- Amazing standby life
- Brightest tablet display I've ever seen, quick UI
- Great Memory Capacity
- Extreme Battery Life when attached to keyboard

The Mediocre:
- After 6 months of use it has been slowing down significantly.
- All Email apps are slow to load 50% of the time
- WiFi/Wireless can be spotty/slow 50% of the time
- ALL Browsers (stock-browser, Chrome, and Dolphin are what I've used) are extremely slow. This includes starting up, opening new tabs,  and bringing up the keyboard (when you press on the address bar).

The AWFUL:
- The "Audio" is a godawful single speak with hardly ANY 'Umph' / Volume.  Great for SongPop. Terrible for anything else, especially video chatting or playing music. Your phone has better audio....
- Keyboard does NOT act like a typical Android keyboard, let alone a Windows/MacOS one. Highlighting, Copy-pasting, and other functions either have differing keyboard input commands from program to program or have no keyboard input comands available at all.  The 'stock' word processing programs are terrible, and the keyboard works horrendously with Gmail/stock email apps.
- Word processing programs have terrible save functions, and often lose data when using the keyboard and switching between programs.  Essentially, you can save your file, switch to a browser to research, and then return to the word processor only to have lost your data.  Additionally, of the 5 processing programs I've tried, all have saved earlier versions of documents over current ones causing significant loss of work.
-All Video players function as intended 50% of the time - this includes playing files on the tablet's internal memory.  Often they will get choppy, freeze screens, or just fail and shut down

Overall:If I was looking for a tablet to work as a tablet only, I'd still consider the Transformer for the Screen Size, Battery Length, Brightness, and Memory.  Still, if I could find something which performed better and had enhanced audio, I'd jump on that IMMEDIATELY!

This tablet is incredible and I don't even know where to start. It does everything as advertised and fulfills its specs. It's very fast and responsive, although rarely it does lag and freeze up for a few secs. Once I did receive it, the battery was dead. Upon reading the manual it says charge it up to 8 hours before use, which I did. After turning it on, a few minutes later you will be prompted to update to the latest firmware. After updating you will receive all the latest update for it and the latest version of ice cream sandwich. Unfortunately at the moment jelly bean isn't available yet, but Asus has declared that the do plan to bring jelly bean to the tablet. The new version of Android doesn't include flash player since Adobe has discontinued it. You can still install flash player by downloading the latest apk file and installing it using the file manager on the tablet. It does come with a few bloatware that can't be uninstalled unless you root the tablet, but some of it is useful. For those who are looking to game, the Tegra 3 processor is for you. You can play games like Grand theft auto 3, Max payne, and even emulators from the market place. As for the hardware, the display is very nice and delivers true HD. It does come with a cleaning cloth for the screen and cleans it very well. The rear camera records and takes pictures in a very high quality while the front is good quality, but much noticeable than the rear. It does read and accept a 64GB micro sd card. Many people have complained about the speaker placement. It does affect the sound since it's going away from you and will sound muffled if your hand is in the way. However, it does deliver great and precise volume. The battery lasts a very long time, but will drain faster if you have the tablet in performance mode rather than power saving mode. An option of a docking station is available to you which I got and I'm very glad I did. It turns the tablet into a netbook. The dock give the tablet another 5-6 hours of battery and works by when the tablet's battery falls around 70%, it will start to be charged by the dock. The dock is just like a laptop's keyboard. It includes an sd card reader (not micro), a USB 2.0 slot, and a charging slot. The price the tablet sells for is definitely worth it. I highly recommend this to anyone who is interested in an android tablet.

The extra battery make long international trips bearable as I can take my own etertainment and know that the device will still be working for the whole trip. They keyboard does add quite a bit of extra weight but that is outweighed by the extra battery and usefulness of being able to type easily.

I'm quite tall and even in the cramped space of economy class the size of this device makes it easy to use.

Would recommend this to anyone wanting to buy an Android based tablet. Will be even better when Android 4.2 is available. Good thing is that Asus are reasonably quick in providing the updates.

This might not be the best way to start this review, but here it is: I hate Apple. I really wanted a tablet, and most reviews rank the iPad as one of the best tablets out there. Whether or not this is true, I know I didn't want to get an iPad (I'm a very petty person). After doing some more research, I came across this tablet and found it ranked right up there with the iPad. It's an awesome, user-friendly, and intuitive tablet. The Android OS makes it familiar and comfortable, and it's lightening fast. I'd recommend this tablet to anyone.

Its a good tablet. Screen is sharp, and its quick when on performance mode. Honestly, the only complaint I could make is the power button placement. It is a pain when I have my tablet in a case, but its still a great tablet.

Let me start by saying I have been working on and building computers for about 20 years. Although I hadn't bought a tablet up to this point, the ASUS was my choice after much research for the following reasons: 1. This tablet has the best HD screen on the market second only to the current iPad 4.  2. The quad core cpu and 10.1 inch screen is comparable to if not better than the iPad 4.  3. For what I needed the tablet to do and the apps that are available for it (this is where some people may need to do their own research for apps vs needs as the iPad still has quite a few more apps available to the consumer), this product has (sold separately and I bought) the available keyboard which also has a battery that will charge the tablet (until the battery on the keyboard runs out) while they are connected together. Then when I disconnect them, the tablet is still charged once I am done using the keyboard.  4. Also unlike the iPad, this has a micro SD card slot for extra storage space up to 32GB as well as a micro HDMI slot for connecting to a TV.  5. The keyboard, when attached, also has an available full sized SD card slot as well as a USB port (which is what I use the most to transfer files from my computer).
As you can see, there are quite a few more features externally on this ASUS tablet that I use that must be paid for separately if you buy an iPad.  Oh and let me mention that this has 32GB of internal memory when you buy it for the same or less price than the 16GB iPad. So far it has worked extremely well for my needs and runs very well. As almost every computer that has an operating system (Android on this), I have had a few "lockups" or "freezes" that require a reboot of the system. This doesn't appear to be out of the normal range.  I highly recommend this product to anyone needing a tablet and will buy from ASUS again in the future should my needs again require their products.

I have been waiting awhile to get this device. I originally bought a Nexus 7 and while I love that device it has a few caveats that make it a less than ideal device. Storage space, and HDMI out being the too major reasons I wanted a tablet with expandable storage. My wife is the apple enthusiasts so I am not going to get into any apple versus discussions.

The tf700 is greatly expandable. With the on board micro-sd card slot and the keyboard dock's full size SD slot you can add 2x64gb more space to your tablets base memory. I went with 64gb model as I learned a long time ago that I need to future proof as much as possible as I may not have the funds later to get more. Altogether with base memory that's 192gb of minus whatever is used by the system. Not to mention with the full size USB port on the dock means flashdrives and portable hd's can also be used.

Why would I need all that space you might wonder. For emulation mainly. While a lot of the early arcade emulators use very small ROM files, when you get into later post street fighter II era a lot of games used CDROM drives or other high capacity storage devices because games became larger. Mame4droid requires chd files which eat up space fast. Not to mention ps1 emulation where games get up to 1gb or more in size so I will need a lot of room if I want to have a larger later game variety.

You can find a ton of info on this device's tech specs but ultimately it is use that determines value for me and this has all my wants covered. Its versatility is amazing and being able to play all those old retro games from just about every console up to ps1 (Dreamcast has an emulator in the works) with controllers is a dream come true.

I have introduced all my kids to the wonders of neo-geo, the PC-engine, and all of Sega's and Nintendo's early consoles/handheld's. I am already planning on getting them some nabi 2s so they can play these games on their own devices. These android tablets, to me, blow away any gaming handhelds on the market now with a few exceptions IMHO.

The best resource for info on how to get the most from the tf700 is to just go do a YouTube search. They have a ton of tutorials and reviews. Oh and the icing on the cake is I can also use it for movies/music/reading. I had to get another android device because I am always draining my N7 and the extra battery dock on the tf700 means the N7 will finally get a rest from usage.

One last thing while on my window's PCs I use ATI cards I love nvidias tegra chip set as it seems to get better support on android devices versus other manufacturer's chip sets. Implementation seems better to me after trying out other devices. Once I get my HTC one x plus my tegra 3 triumvirate will be complete. A tegra 3 triforce if you will.

I noticed a scratch on the tablet when I took it out of the box. I contacted their customer service and sent them pictures, they offered to discount it but I asked for a new one andb they agreed. I love my tablet!

Review updated: March 1, 2013

In a nutshell: The Asus Transformer TF700 tablet and mobile dock have a few problems likely to frustrate all users.  Also, users interested in purchasing them for productivity purposes (i.e. as a netbook/laptop substitute) are likely to find them inadequately mature.  However, they're better now than before.

--------

While the several comments my original post received have helped me realize that none of my concerns are related to Asus hardware problems proper, but rather to Android/app problems, I'm afraid I cannot yet raise my rating if I am to be fair to potential buyers.  Although I realize Asus is not to blame for either Android OS or Android app limitations, unfortunately, in actual user experience, hardware, OS, and app experience are merged. That is, while the helpful comments below have clarified that my Transformer's inability to display two windows side by side is an Android OS problem and that inconsistent keyboard shortcut support is due to the inconsistent implementation of standard shortcuts across Android apps, rather than to Asus Transformer hardware problems, my net result is unchanged: I can still view only one window at a time, and keyboard shortcuts are still only sparsely available. I must therefore rate the Transformer accordingly because the capabilities (or lack thereof) of OSes and apps DO affect potential buyers' decisions (e.g. One reason I bought the Transformer, with its Android OS, rather than an iPad is because everything I'd read about the Android app, Kingsoft Office, indicated it would meet the specifics of my word processing needs whereas Apple's Pages and other iPad office software would not).

I recently upgraded my system to Android Jelly Bean (which has completely resolved my previously-mentioned non-display problem for several symbol characters typed using the mobile dock) and because of that as well as the comments my original post received,  I decided to extensively retest my Transformer today. Unfortunately, I still have to conclude that Android--and therefore the Asus Transformer Infinity--is not yet ready for "big-time" in terms of productivity and actually has significant problems likely to prove a frustration for all users.

I've done my retesting of the TF700'S capabilities with the five productivity apps I care about most as a teacher and grad student(i.e. the default Browser, Chrome, Kingsoft Office, Google Drive, and RepliGo Reader). I outline my results below:

--------

First of all, although I hate to add concerns not mentioned in my previous review, several problems likely to affect even non-productivity users came up during retesting, namely:

a) Both Chrome and the default browser load Web pages--and therefore scroll much more slowly--than either my (dying) Asus netbook or Mac desktop do (I assume this is because of the Transformer's high-definition screen resolution?--i.e., it takes a long time to display all those pixels?)

b) Both Chrome and the default browser FREQUENTLY freeze so I get messages like "Browser isn't responding.  Do you want to close it?"  (Probably because I get impatient with the slow loading/scrolling of Web pages as described in "a" above!)

c) Sometimes the Transformer screen fails to respond to my touch, so I have to play around with it to get it to recognize I've touched it at all, or that I want to select text rather than merely insert something at a particular point.

--------

Productivity users are likely also to have a problem with the following:

1) Keyboard shortcuts: I wrote in my original post that "Android keyboard shortcut support in connection with the mobile dock is spotty, most importantly with "Ctrl + X," "Ctrl + C" and "Ctrl + V."  Now, however, "Ctrl + X," "Ctrl + C" and "Ctrl + V" do function in Chrome (though it would be nice if Chrome also responded to "Ctrl + Z" because I discovered during my retesting that I was unable to UNDO my copy-and-paste retesting experiments in any other way other than reselecting/copying the text I'd experimented with and then re-pasting it back where it was before!)  However, keyboard shortcuts like cut, copy, paste, undo, and redo do not work in the default Asus browser (with either browser-accessed Google docs or Facebook) nor in  RepliGo Reader (which I use instead of Adobe Reader because Android Adobe Reader opens Google Drive-stored pdfs in a protected--i.e. non-annnotatable--format). However Kingsoft Office has excellent keyboard shortcut support per my limited test (cut, copy, paste, undo, redo).

Continued concern: Keyboard shortcuts are sooooooooooo important to productivity!!! Android, please encourage your app-producers to implement ALL of the common ones and as many others as possible.  I think using tablets for productivity purposes will only be viable if (at least the most common) keyboard shortcuts users are used to from desktops/laptops/netbooks function equally well on Android.

--------

2) Apps display full-screen only (i.e. It's impossible to multi-task via two windows side by side): As far as I can tell, none of my top five productivity apps--i.e. Chrome, the default browser, Kingsoft Office, RepliGo Reader, or Google Drive--allow for display of two app windows or same app/multiple documents to display side by side (i.e. These apps aren't available as "floating apps.")

Continued concern: While most users may not think Android's inability to handle side-by-side window display is a big deal as long as they view content via the Transformer's tablet screen only, I assume I'm not alone as a productivity user in being used to connecting a netbook/laptop to an external monitor and to easy side-by-side window viewing and copying and pasting.  (In fact, because my responsibilities as a teacher frequently involve back-and-forth interactions with multiple documents connected to student writing--e.g. our course website where my grading guide and gradebook are located and a student's paper in a word processor--any OS without this feature, in my mind, is not at all viable for productivity purposes.)

--------

On the positive side, I do want to report that the text-selection concerns I mentioned in my original post have been almost entirely resolved. I received a tip in the Transformer forums that text can be selected using "shift + arrows" in editable text areas and my testing has demonstrated that the tip works in all five apps included in my retesting. In addition, I discovered "shift + arrows" also works to extend already-selected (via long-press) text in NON-EDITABLE text areas in all the above apps except RepliGo Reader!  (And "shift + arrows" is MUCH easier to control than dragging the text selection grips--I think it's quite as good as the mouse-click-and-drag functionality so many of us are used to from desktop/laptop/netbook systems!)  However, unfortunately the text in Chrome-accessed Word documents stored in Google Drive is not selectable by any means and the same is true when it comes the hyper-link spiderweb text of TED Talk transcripts that I like to use in my teaching of English language learners (though, admittedly, even on Windows or Mac, the hyperlinked nature of TED Talk transcript text means it can only easily be selected from the bottom up).  I assume few users will care about these concerns, however. What they are more likely to have problems with in terms of text-selection are 1) The tablet screen sometimes fails to recognize a user's touch, with the result that text selection is significantly slowed down or stopped, and 2)while mobile dock text selection DOES work well in editable text areas, the long-press step built into Android's text selection process for NON-EDITABLE text areas still makes text selection for these areas a relatively slow process (compared to that in editable areas and in any kind of Windows/Mac OS text area.)

I do expect Asus and Android will ultimately resolve the above remaining problems.  The dying netbook I mentioned in my previous post is an Asus netbook that has served me extremely well until my exceptionally demanding use of it finally caught up.  My previous outstanding experience with Asus in relation to my netbook HAS convinced me of the company's interest in making top-quality, user-centered products and my less-than-positive Transformer experience has not yet altered my opinion (especially given the very helpful post by Tien, Asus Customer Loyalty representative!).  I have no doubt that Asus will communicate to Android its users' concerns and as much as possible, "pressure" Android to put effort into developing its OS to enable it to meet the needs of its less productivity-oriented users as well as (the potentially large population of) users who have substantial productivity needs they want their tablet to meet. And I assume Android will be responsive, not only in continuing to develop its OS, but also in continuing to encourage app developers to take advantage of its increasing OS capabilities as they're developed.

--------

In conclusion, because I would not have purchased the Asus Transformer TF700 tablet and mobile dock if I had known the above listed concerns were a problem, I do unfortunately still have to conclude: The Asus Transformer TF700 tablet and mobile dock are not (yet) mature enough to be used for productivity purposes (i.e. as a netbook/laptop substitute), and I need to add, they also have weaknesses likely to trouble even non-productivity users.

Monica R

P.S. I'm very sorry that it's taken me more than a week to respond to the helpful comments my original post received.  I've barely touched my Transformer since writing that post because, as both a teacher and grad student, I've been drowning in work and therefore have been opting to use my office desktop because it allows me to avoid the above-listed concerns as well as allows me to work with maximum efficiency because its OS is familiar.

P.P.S.  Although one commenter felt my "On the positive side, a touchscreen is addicting!!!" postscript on my original post only displayed my smartphone/tablet naivety, I will freely admit I am touchscreen-naive, and for the sake of other new-to-touchscreen-technology potential buyers, say again that touchscreens ARE addicting (i.e Once you've had one, you automatically try to touch other screens to make them scroll or whatever, even though, if you were thinking about it, you know they're not touchscreen-enabled!)

I came to this tablet from the Transformer Prime, which was poorly designed and terrible all around. (I went to the Prime from the Motorola XOOM because I wanted the latest and the greatest.). I thought I'd give ASUS another try and bought this tablet, thinking that with the second generation Transformer they would get things right.

For all the hype this tablet has, and the reviews, I'd give it a C-.  For all the money I paid for the thing, performance it average.  It is laggy.  I/O performance is poor. I see no difference between normal mode, power-saving mode, and performance mode. Sometimes the touch screen is not accurate; at times the touches seem "off" as to where I am trying to touch; not by much, but it's there.  No matter what program I use, I get frustrated just trying to type something because the tablet is unresponsive. I had better responsiveness on my old XOOM. Using the dock is better, but it makes the tablet a little awkward to use (I would get out my notebook, then.).

How many times I reformatted, cold-booted, and did the other suggestions out there on the web...well, nothing worked. Am I the only one? Go over to XDA Forums and read. It was suggested that the more programs you put on the tablet, the slower it becomes. That's why I bought the tablet with all that memory; so I could put all my programs on it.  Why would I buy a tablet with all the memory and not use that memory because it degrades performance?

When I first called them, Asus tech support was good; they responded promptly, and I received the unit back in no time. However, I still have lag and poor I/O performance. Because of the lag, I was willing to unlock the device, void the warranty, and install a custom rom that supposedly makes the tablet run better, but I keep getting the network error response.  I called tech support again, but after the initial response, I have heard nothing, although I did receive the email to rate the service.

On the physical side, I usually hold the tablet in my palms. Depending how you hold it, the tablet may dig into them. I also cradle the tablet between my thumb and forefinger. The bottom of the tablet digs into my flesh.

On the whole it is not a bad tablet. Tech Support was pretty good. It just isn't worth the high price. It's an average tablet with an over-average price. If you want to use it for the Internet (and it doesn't even have 5Ghz!) or play an occasional game, get something cheaper, or wait for the new technology to come out. I bought it for the dock, but I really don't use it that much; I'll end up going to my desktop with the better keyboard. People swear by the thing; others bitterly complain. There's no consistency. You may get a good unit, or you may get a bad one (not the occasional bad one either; there's too many people complaining). I got a bad one. Too much hastle for the money.

Don't buy this product based just on the specs. Do your homework before you buy. This tablet has better graphics than my old XOOM, but I'd rather have a tablet that works when I want it to rather than having to wait.

I'm a dyed-in-the-wool Android fan, and decided a tablet would be nice for informal browsing.  I didn't want to join the "I" fad thing.

I'm not disappointed with the unit; it's handy and useful.  It does not replace a laptop in any regard (typing this would be murder), but it's perfect for use like browsing or checking e-mail in bed, while watching TV, and other similar uses.

The compass does not work....no big deal; I don't plan a jungle trek depending upon my new tablet to guide me home.  But, nevertheless, it doesn't work.

ASUS support?  Forget about it.  You have to go online first, create a 'ticket', then call and wait in line for a live person.  The live person's advice?  Do a factory reset and see if that helps.....

....so, you blow out all your customization, downloaded apps, and the like on a 'maybe'?

Battery life is excellent, charger / power supply is unique to this unit, so you might want some spares.  Audio without external speakers or headphones is good, but I like using a bluetooth external speaker for long listening to movies or the like.

It has an overall quality feel.  Processor can be a little slow at times when the unit is 'busy'.

I'll live without the compass, I guess.  It would have been nice for Google Sky; the app won't work without the compass though.

Otherwise, I'm happy.  Just hope you don't need ASUS support.

For a $600 tablet I was expecting this thing to operate a lot smoother and faster than it does. It LAGS bad. I've had it for a month now and it just seems to get worse as time goes by.

I stalked this tablet for months before purchasing. I went to stores and tried it out. And finally I found one day on Amazon for $429!...That was the best price I have seen anywhere. I am enjoying my tablet but at times the internet seems slow to me but movies games everything else runs seamlessly.
bought this for my wife,  we have not really had much time to learn to use it yet,  but what we have done with it we love.

I purchased the tablet in July of 2012, and have had the time to become very well acquainted with it over the period of many months.

In summary: it is a great tablet, by comparison to many others.

What I use it for:
------------------
1. reading books (a lot). It replaced my Kindle, since it is has a backlit display (my old Kindle does not), and because the display area is so much larger that it feels like a real book.

2. Watching movies. Speakers are a bit weak if you have to fill the room with sound or if there is any background noise. If, however, you are using headphones or have a portable rechargeable speaker (many are in the $10-20 range), you will do just fine.

3. Browsing the web. Stock browser seemed slow to me, so did Chrome. I switched over to Dolphin for a happy medium of performance and feature set (use the same for my Android phone).

4. Emails.

What I like:
--------------
Sharp looking tablet.
I have a dock, which makes typing emails a breeze.
I downloaded remote desktop equivalent for Android, so now it doubles as a small laptop (Ultrabook-like), which allows me to use Windows when I need to.

What I don't like:
------------------
I had an issue with it latching properly to the dock, and I had to send the dock first, and, subsequently, the dock and the tablet to ASUS for repair. They replaced the latching mechanism in the dock itself, and did something in the tablet (all mechanical), so now it is all good.

I think the battery life is a bit shorter than what is claimed (I have not done the "marketing test" of watching the streaming movie at X brightness) but overall it is quite acceptable, and the dock does do miracles at ensuring the tablet's battery does not drop below 80% until the dock is completely exhausted.

Tips:
------------------
1. If you load up a new app, do a cold boot (not just a reboot).
It will prevent many of the white/black screen freezes that some people have reported. Most installed apps are fine the way they are, but it does not hurt to do a clean boot to be sure.

2. Given that the battery has a fixed lifetime and a fixed number of recharges, charge it when it is close to being completely drained.

3. Enjoy. 7 months later it is still one of the coolest tablets :)
