I bought this tablet to replace the TF300 that I got to replace the TF201...I'll make that story make sense first, haha

I got the 201 to try out the whole thing at Best Buy and returned it due to the crappy WiFi signal it's notorious for. I loved the experience and knew I'd be replacing it soon after. I read about the TF700 and had my heart set on it, but got tired of waiting and got a TF300...around the time the TF700 release date was announced. So the TF300 went on the auction block and I bought this and a dock.

Backstory out of the way, I can give a review that compares all three of Asus' best tablet offerings, where they apply:

How I use it: I use my tablet mostly for music, movies/Netflix, games, taking notes at school, and reading when I can find the time. The tablet comes out of the box with plenty of apps to satisfy almost all of these. The Polaris Office, My Library, and MyNet app are the only two "bloatware" apps I find worth having, as they are full of great features and free from Asus. I did replace Polaris Office with Kingsoft Office, as it has a word count feature that all college students need, but Polaris is great for those that don't need such things.

Display: What can really be said here? 1920x1200 is enough resolution for anyone in this world on a 10" tablet. Yes, I've played with the iPad with Retina Display my girlfriend has, and it's sharp, but the difference is hardly noticeable, and, if anything, mine has better picture simply because it's a 16:10 aspect ratio. The brightness goes to the same level of the TF201 (readable with the sun beaming on it), which leaves the TF300 in the dust because it isn't Super IPS+.

Performance: This is where things go South for our hero, a bit. I had the smoothest performance out of the TF201 and TF300 tablets (zero lag between screens with widgets and live wallpapers), while the TF700 has stutters here and there using the stock Asus Day Scene live wallpaper. I'm going to blame this on two things: one, the resolution is ridiculous, causing it to strain the processor momentarily from idle; and two, the flash memory in the entire TF line is SLOW! This fact is well documented at XDA Developers, if you'd like to read up on it. The slowest documented is 0.2 MB/s (that's 200 KB/s). The tablet also hangs when rotating on a home screen. The length varies by wallpaper type and number of widgets. Luckily, the hangs only seem to happen to me on home screens, because graphically heavy apps like GTA III/Vice City run smoothly in Balanced mode and with only slight stutters in Power Saver mode (running the thing entirely in performance mode ALMOST gets rid of all the hiccups).

Battery Life: If you put the TF700 and iPad 3/4 in a "staring contest", the TF700 will win. I've easily gotten 10 hours out of this thing with the screen brightness at about 40% and heavy app usage. The TF201 and TF300 will obviously get a little better than this, due to the slower processor speeds and screen resolutions, but 10 hours on an HD display is killer! It only gets better with the dock, as others have mentioned.

The Look: Typically, I won't review how a piece of technology looks, because I like practicality over style seven days a week, but this tablet is d*** slick! The "gray", yes, it looks purple, but it's not a tacky look like the colors of the new iPod Touches. It fits the tablet well. The thinness of the tablet is worth mentioning too; while slightly thicker than the TF201 (and I mean BARELY) it's the same thickness as my Galaxy SIII, which is one of the thinnest smartphones on the market. Also, there are those that say the TF201 dock and TF500/700 dock is a slightly different shade of "gray", but I don't notice this looking at them both side by side. So if you're looking for a dock, get the TF201 dock as it has a bigger battery inside.

Overall: After six months, I rate the Infinity Pad a 4.25/5 (can't do parts of stars, boo Amazon). The .75 is lost in the performance category alone, which is something I'm sure Asus will be working on with a potential TF800 tablet.
love the ease of use, display and camera of this unit.  I  Would recommend to anyone looking for a tablet.

I have absolutely 0 complaints about the tablet itself. Only concerns are some of the software that comes with it. I have used almost every function and head 0 issues or problems. I am actually writing this reviewfrom the Google voice to text app on the tablet
In 21 century and for this kind of money you would expect to see something more. It's plastic body was cracked, the screen leaked and whats even worse there were vertical lines on the screen as well.

The Asus Transformer Infinity... I like it.

The Asus TF700 offers a robust tablet that has style and substance. There are some things, hardware wise, that a prospective buyer should be aware of however. Nevertheless the TF700 is a very good device even though some of the draw backs may leave some users wanting.

There is no doubt that it is fast with its Tegra 3 processor. Applications open fast and you are sure that you can run the latest and greatest games without a hint of performance issues. There are only a few app that are optimized for the caliber of the Tegra 3 processor though.

The screen is beautiful with its HD display. High-res movies are a pleasure to watch and the cranked up Super IPS plus display enables that experience to be taken outdoors. The coating on the Gorilla Glass display enables your finger to glide across the screen but as always, you will leave finger prints that you would have to wipe off from time to time.

The TF700 is also very light and doesn't cause hand fatigue when holding it for long periods.

The sound the Infinity produces is `ok' at best. You are not going to be rocking to loud audio with this device. You're going to hear what you need to hear but don't expect much from its speakers.

Using the front camera for chatting is a standard experience. The rear 8MP camera can give nice HD videos but still images are not as good. Images can appear cloudy and grainy when zoomed in.

It would have been good to see newer technology like NFC included with the TF700. But the absence is not a deal breaker.

*BUYERS BEWARE*
It seems that the tablet version of Android is a completely different OS. Android on Phones now matches IOS with its buttery smoothness but the same cannot be said for the Tablet versions of Android. Without adding widgets you may get that smooth transition as you would get on an android phone. But after filling the screens with widgets, performance can become choppy. Lags become very noticeable and mainly because of Asus' decision to have only 1Gb of RAM onboard. When opening the settings>apps>running you will see that the device already uses about 80% of the memory without opening any apps. Any PC builder knows that more memory equals better performance. With the Asus TF700, you may have to compromise.

Overall the Asus Transformer Infinity is a good device that has only one major short coming which is its 1Gb of RAM. Anyone considering a purchase of this may want to consider alternatives before making a decision. But if you think that this is a great buy then make the purchase, you will be getting a top quality tablet that may meet or exceed your needs.

Boyfriend loved product.  Though he wanted the product to use as a small portable laptop so he could work from his home computer anywhere.  Took a while to get it to work the way he wanted as the product operates with Android, but he ended up loving the product.

The Transformer Pad is a brilliant device.  Great screen resolution, great storage expansion options, the optional keyboard, quad core processor, and modern Android OS made it an easy choice for me, even over the Nexus 10.

I wish it had more RAM.  1GB is my bottleneck when trying to run large apps, edit large documents, or task switch quickly between multiple apps.  In fact, the lack of RAM makes this tablet utterly useless when trying to do normal tasks with something running in the background.  Android's biggest advantage over IOS is its multi-tasking, but this tablet can't handle it.

Speaking of which, the Android OS is still not mature enough for me to consider it for long-term productivity work.  Problems with the built-in google chat client have caused me to nearly abandon IMing on the tablet completely [edit: after owning this for 9 months, I can say I haven't IMed from it in the last 6 months].  Switching tasks will sometimes crash the tablet and force a hard reboot, and during software updates (especially with only 1GB of RAM to work with) the tablet is unusable.

The memory is where Asus dropped the ball, but I can't fault them for Android being kind of crappy sometimes.  3/5 because of the issues with the lack of RAM making it more frustrating than helpful.

I was thinking about getting an iPad, but I already have an iPod Touch and was drawn to Android more. Great tablet though, nice size, decent battery, good graphics (not mixing apps that aren't made for tablet, that's not ASUS's fault), decent sound, pretty easy to use.

Tablet was a gift for our son.  He loves it and uses it more than his laptop.  Great tablet for social networking and email.  Nice apps and features at a fair price.  Graphics and screen layout easy to use.

I bought this tablet for several reasons
1) the screen / graphics adapter are full HD.  For the money I was going to spend on a tablet, I wanted the highest resolution available on an Android (iPads have better resolution, but I am not an iOS fan)
2) The processor was state of the art
3) I like the ASUS name
4) I wanted to be able to add the keyboard
The pros
The graphics are incredible
ASUS has made it a point to update the operating system.  It came with ICS and was promptly updated to Jelly Bean
The cons
The battery life, even with the optional keyboard, is less than fantastic
the 10" format isn't as friendly as the 7" units I have had before
The performance isn't what I would consider acceptable, even though the processor is top drawer

It IS my fault for changing to a 10" tablet, the rest is on ASUS

Before we begin, I just want to make it clear that the 1-Star rating for this product is directed more towards the manufacturer (ASUS), and not so much towards the product itself. If ever I receive a replacement device that does not exhibit the issues that the last two did, I'll update this rating / review accordingly. However, considering the fact that I have little to no confidence in ASUS's QA, I'm not holding my breath..

I'm not going to go into a ton of detail here, much as already been written here concerning specs and such. Suffice it to say, Transformer Pad Infinity TF700T is packing some serious hardware, and continues to be a force to be reckoned with.

Pro's
The Tegra-3 processor is a beast, and the inclusion of DDR3 RAM helps to improve overall speed. The HD display, while not as dense as those found on the newest iPads and Nexus 10, is incredibly bright (IPS+ Mode) with good color reproduction and contrast. Sitting side by side with an iPad 4, it's difficult to see any difference in display resolution. The addition of HDMI and Micro SD memory expansion ports on the tablet itself is a great touch. Additional memory expansion can be found on the keyboard dock which is sold separately. The build of the device is also top notch - "mostly" metal and Gorilla Glass 2. It's incredibly thin and relatively light, although the edges are probably a little too sharp for my liking. Battery life is also very good, especially when connected to the keyboard dock.

Cons
Unfortunately, even a fast quad-core processor, DDR3 RAM, and Jelly Bean can't seem to remedy the frequent bouts of sluggishness this tablet suffers from. I'm assuming that the hardware is having a tough time keeping up with the high resolution display. I mean, that's a ton of pixels to push around, but still I would have expected better performance. While the DDR3 RAM is fast, there's simply not enough of it. 1GB is simply not cutting it. The Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 seems to benefit greatly from the inclusion of 2GB of RAM, and that tablet uses a significantly lower resolution display. Hopefully, ASUS will include 2GB of DDR3 RAM in the next iteration of this line of tablets. Other than the sluggishness, there's really not much this thing can't do.

Quality
Ugh. Just, ugh. There seems to be a serious lack of quality control when it comes to ASUS products, and it certainly shows here. I've gone through two of these units from a big-box retailer, and a third one from Amazon. All three have suffered from a hideous amount of light bleed and dead pixels. To make matters worse, they've all come out of the box (brand new) with nicks, scuffs, and scratches all over the metal body of the tablet. I can handle a tiny scuff here and there, but deep nicks are just completely unacceptable. Honestly, is it asking for too much to get a unit that doesn't look like it sat in a room for an hour with a toddler and a fork? Also, the light bleed! While it may be too subtle to notice when browsing the web, they look like spotlights when watching a dark movie, or reading an eBook in night mode. Honestly, it's enough to drive someone up the wall after a while. ASUS needs to double-down on its quality control, because it absolutely sucks..
fast shipment, great tablet, meet all my expectations, should have got the 4G version for the future but i'll just get a new one.

Screen resolution is great. Tablet quality is fine. Battery life is fine, but I'm still learning to switch off apps etc. Now after a few months of ownership I really appreciate the high res screen. It makes reading text extremely easy, even on long articles. Video is superb too.

I love this thing. It came loaded with Jelly Bean and all kinds of Asus stuff.
Jelly Bean is a wonderful improvement to ICS. I still have ICS on my Sprint EVO 3D and I still love it, but Jelly Bean is smoother (also because the TF700 is way faster) and more intuitive.
The tablet came with a bunch of ASUS bloatware, but that is easily disabled via the application info screens. The internet browser it comes with was OK at first, but for some reason it started getting REALLY slow. I suppose the cache fills up pretty quickly. I just disabled it and got Firefox with Ad Block Plus (no ads! best add on ever!).
The TF700 screen is incredible. SUPER bright. Readable in broad daylight, unlike a lot of LCD/LED screens. This is thanks to the Super IPS+ option. It does use a lot of battery, but it really helps in daylight like walking around campus or sitting in the quad.
Battery...I have to charge it at the end of everyday, but I use it a lot. There are some days I don't use it at all and pick it up and it's dead..but then I realize I left the WiFi on (which is easily disabled when the screen is off) and it drained the battery. NBD, mostly my fault. The cool thing about this tablet is the ASUS options for power saving and performance mode. Power saving options like turning of GPS (oh yeah, it has GPS. Freakin' sweet!) and other things to save on power is crucial.
Be wary though. I'm a total Android Fanboy and I HATE apple products. Than being said, this is probably the coolest piece of hardware I've owned...and I build gaming PCs. lawl.
I'm not really hip on what other tablets have to offer, but I know (from reading other reviews and tech sites) that this is probably the best Android Tablet on the market as of 2/5/13 and if that interests you, then get it already!

Initially I was torn between going with the iPad and the Transformer Infinity. I had the 1st generation iPad and I remember not really being all that impressed with it, because in so many ways it reminded me of an over-sized iPod Touch.  So skip two years and I'm back looking at tablets.  What really sold me on the Infinity was the fact that it "Transforms" easily into a sleek netbook with a touch screen.  Sure most tablets allow you to use an often cheep looking keyboard, via bluetooth with them, that really aren't worth the money you pay for them. However with the Infinity, the tablet attaches nicely to the keyboard dock. Oh and let's not forget the additional battery power that comes along with the keyboard dock. Where else can you go and get an average of 16 hours of constant use on a tablet? As cheesy as this may sound... it's pretty awesome, because I don't find myself running to the charger every few hours, let along daily.  I will admit that I am a droid phone user, so the familiarity with the Android Platform was definitely a plus.

The tablet itself is very nice. Great display, relatively light, sturdy. But the performance is terrible. Even on high performance mode the tablet is sluggish, freezes quite a bit. I don't have any weird apps installed, just basic Facebook, Twitter, Etc. I tried Cold booting it, seemed to help at first but then sluggish again. The Wifi is not very good. Brought it to work to compare with other tablets and the infinity consistently couldn't get A good signal while the Nexus and iPad could.

Coupled with the Mobile Docking Keyboard, in my humble opinion, this tablet blows the iPad out of the water! I like the fact that it has so much flexibility compared to the iPad. If you're looking for an iPad alternative; this is it! To me, Apple products are 'vanity/status' devices and they're over priced. Prediction: Apple will start discounting their products heavily because of products like this and the Galaxy S III mobile phone in the very near future...

I was really excited to get this as I had the transformer prime and liked it, except for the wifi issue.  After using this for a couple days I charged the device as normal and when I went to unplug it, the device was extremely hot to the touch, uncomfortably so.  I let it cool down and then tried to turn it on.  After several attempts of pressing the on button it finally booted up.  This time with a horizontal white line running across the screen (in landscape mode).  This line never disappeared after restarting it several times.  I also noticed that where the sd card slot is the screen depresses noticeably and makes a little creek sound.  I am chalking all this up to this being a defective unit and did return it.  I have tried the kindle fire hd and the transformer prime, both of which had major glitches.  The prime had serious wifi issues and the kindle had serious touchscreen responsiveness issues.  I will now try the nexus 10 and hope for a more complete tablet.

I like this tablet but it is slower than I would prefer.  Asus is great about updating Android versions and generally I am pleased with the unit.  I wanted a tablet with GPS and this has it.  I put a new version of Android on a Nook and it seemed faster.  I prefer the smaller form factor of the 7" after using both.  Camera on this is great and apps work well.

TABLET IS AWESOME SO GLAD I GOT IT VERY HAPPY WITH THE ASUS TF700. I HAVE HAD OTHER TABLETS BEFORE BUT THIS IS THE BEST ONE. SELLER WAS GREAT WOULD BUY FROM THEM AGAIN.  THIS TABLET DOSE IT ALL ONE OF THE  BEST TABLET ON THE MARKET.
I love my Tablet. It has given me the flexibility to do writing where ever and when ever I want.  It is very user friendly.

I bought the ASUS TF700 as soon as it came out. I had done a lot of research on which tablet  to buy and settled on the tf700 because of a very good price-to-value point. I was looking for something which is good for everyday consumption (for family, I don't get a chance on it :) ), and won't break the bank. This left out the ipad (among other things, no extra ports, very high price etc). As such, I limited myself to an android os and compared a lot between the acer, toshiba as well as the tf300. After reading a lot of reviews, I settled on the tf700 primarily for its nice screen (one could go for the tf300 also but back-to-back, this just looked nicer :), thin case and low heat : we run it continuously and barely notice any warmth)  It has a nice brilliant hd screen, very good battery life and is very responsive. We primarily use it for netflix, youtube, browsing, skype  and a few games and it works very smoothly.  The wi-fi speed is excellent and so is gps lock.

As a BIG bonus, the tablet comes with an hdmi out which allows me to stream netflix, and other web-content to our HD tv,  We haven't used too much content other than this, so can't comment on that, but in general the android environment seems to have a very reasonable set of applications that we use.  On the hardware side, we use the front facing camera for video calls but haven't used the actual camera.

Overall, highly satisfied with the purchase.

Before I get to the product review - ASUS (contrary to their advertisement on this product) will not provide one year accidental damage support like their advertisement states.  They say they offer no coverage on this unit for that.  Why do they then advertise it that way you ask??? Good question, I reply.  I purchased this tablet influenced in large part because of the fraudulent advertisement for this guarantee thinking AH HAH, protection from my little mayhem generating monsters!  Not so much...  When my then 8 year old managed to find a way to try to use the tablet as a shot-put and finally cracked the screen (surprised? nah, not here...), I said, AH HAH, thank God, I have that protection (see advertisement under "Reliability Matters", Paragraph 2, Sentence 3 which states "In addition, ASUS also offers the industry's best-in-class warranty and free 1-year accidental damage protection so you sleep worry-free knowing ASUS' got your back."  "Uh-huh, yes-sir , whats that?  Oh, you don't???, but that's what the ad says, yes, please read it, right here. Im sorry there IS no supervisor???.."  Apparently the sentence was supposed to read "In addition, ASUS also offers someone else the industry's best-in-class warranty and free 1-year accidental damage protection so you sleep worry-free not knowing ASUS' will stab you in the back."  And please ASUS if you are reading this don't try to tell me that this was just one person because I tried on several occasions over a few weeks with different individuals and got the same line each time.  You have put out a sickeningly deceitful advertisement for this product and you should be taken to task for this.  BIG KUDOS TO AMAZON THOUGH- THEY AGREED WITH ME WHEN I CALLED THEM AND THEY RETURNED THE PRODUCT THEMSELVES FOR A FULL REFUND.

Now, on to my brief and succinct product review.  Product is generally okay, although it generally cant be substituted successfully for a shot-put and reused.  I have actually repurchased this unit because its the closest thing to what I am looking for that I can find on the market.  Graphics are nice, OS is greatly improved with firmware improvements since the original version shipped.  Still buggy at times.  Two biggest complaints?  1.  Battery life - nine hours...on which planet would that be? Its not here at least in the southeastern portion of North America.  Now that I have two of them, I can say neither of them really approach half of that at best, with all recommendations on battery life followed.  Maybe they meant when its not in use.  2.  Product support - plain and simple, what was once a respectable company for many years now just sucks.  I have been purchasing motherboards exclusively from them for over 10 years now I think.  Its hard to even find a phone number any more for support on their products.  Their support is now in some very difficult to understand grammatical dialect of English that reminds me reminiscently of many of my engineering school professors from College.  Hello....Remember us??? The Customer???  We put you where you are today???  You are working hard to make Apple more appealing to me, but I digress.  Yes, I know, shame on me for purchasing another product from a company that I believe has a sense of ethical morality on par with Bill Clinton.  Long story short?  If you can in general overlook those two items, its an okay tablet.

Many of my friends have the iPad but I am not an Apple lover so went with this one.  Since it was my first tablet I did some research before picking the ASUS.  Right after starting it up the updates were applied.  Since I have many apps on my Droid Razr it was easy to send them all to the tablet, I was very happy to see I did not have to buy them all over again.  The two things that I do not like and was not aware of is one the cable connector is not a mini usb and two it takes a 15 volt charger.  Do not expect to use all those USB wall chargers laying around the house, they do not work.  Well they work but very very slowly and the battery icon will not show it is being charged.  Also bought the USB adapter which is great to connect a portable harddrive to.

One annoying quirk is when the charging sometimes the charge icon will keep popping up then going away, over and over.  It seems to be related to getting a notification causes it.

I love very much using this tablet especially that this is my first time to use an android operating system. But I am still studying how to print files in wireless network and also I am looking for gadget that would let me connect my tablet to the LCD projector. I only bought the tablet without the dock.

Very fast, quick response; HD screen is very sharp. 720p movies are displayed flawlessly.
Being Android, it synced all my contacts from Google. Also synced all the the Wi-Fi connections (including passwords) from the phone.
Would definitely recommend it to anyone who looks for an 10" tablet.
Battery life is quite good.

What's interesting to me is that I like most everything about this tablet, although it seems like sometimes it slows down for no reason. The one thing that I like from the iPad over the Transformer is that the iPad seems to have a more consistent, smooth feel. However, I like almost everything else more about the Transformer and love the addition of the keyboard dock that extends battery life to the point where I never have to worry about it. This tablet is also much more battery efficient than my previous tablet (a Sony S) which would run out of battery incredibly quickly. This tablet has now gone many days without charging with the keyboard dock attached and I carry it around for email constantly.

This has amazing display, I use it daily. I love it, it is fast well constructed and a nice thing to use. The screen is large and I have had no complaints with it. I use it mainly for browsing the internet and reading. Has a lot of adjustments to make it your own. I love that you can customize the droids over the Apple products.

I bought this tablet for all of the reason you would want a quality tablet, but I got it because of the bluetooth tethering option while away from wi-fi.  I first got it for Christmas and the tethering worked fine until an update in January.  Asus service tried everything and couldn't get it to work again so I received an RMA for service.  I sent it in for repair like a good boy and just got it back today and guess what??  The bluetooth does not work! It reboots every time it pairs to any bluetooth device.  I am on the phone with Asus as I type this and they are telling me I need to send it back so they can not fix it for a second time.  I asked for a replacement, but it seems that the person I am talking to can't understand why I'm upset after spending 500 dollars for a tablet that they have had more that I have.  If you are on the fence..... get the Ipad... their service is far better and they would have already replaced the tablet to keep the customer happy.  After this experience I will never buy another Asus product again.

Really glad I held out for the 700 with the hard shell and gorilla glass. Already proven durable- don't ask. My friend and i were sitting next to one another in an airport, he and his I-pad and me on the transformer - two hours later he wanted to steal my transformer.

The speaker won't work right after the latest firmware update. It was working fine before the update. Now I have to always use the audio jack to listen to anything from the tab.

Called the tech support and they straight away asked me to factory restore the tab. I had to ask multiple questions to know that this would also delete the music, photos, etc that I have in the internal storage. I was glad I asked those questions. Otherwise it would be gone forever. It would be better if the rep. would warn the consequence to everyone and not only for the ones who ask too many questions.

After the factory restore, the speaker still wouldnt work. Now I am sending them the tab for them to look at. If the speaker doesnt work for hardware reasons, this is indicative of issues with durability and quality of ASUS products. This tab is just 6 months old. When you pay big bucks to get this tab, it ought to last several years before running into such issues.

It seems there is no extra warranty that will make all of shipping free. Currently I have to pay out of pocket to send it to them. Return shipping is supposed to be free. It would be good to have a warranty plan that can be bought where the customer doesnt have to pay a dime to service/repair.

Until this happened, I was pretty happy with the tab. The display is gorgeous and the quad-core tegra makes it zippy. I really started liking it when this happened and threw a wrench on the ASUS brand.

I am now sending the tab for servicing. Lets see how it turns out. Will update the post based on my service experiences.

Update: I got the tablet back. The speaker is working now. Pretty sleek customer service. Paid to send it and free shipping back. However, I do have another problem. The micro SD card I used to have is no longer detected. And when it detects, it doesnt show up in the file manager. This used to work. I am still on warranty. Contemplating whether to send or not. Looking at the pain of backup and restore, I might just live with it.

Reducing one star for this.

I have been looking at tablets for a long time. I wanted something powerful enough to do my work on but that I could also easily get apps for when I am stuck in airports. This tablet fills that perfectly.

Best Tablet So Far. The only competitor is Surface which is struggling with issues right now.
If you are considering between iPad and TF700, you are wasting time by even taking iPad seriously. However if you are in between TF700 and Surface, I suggest you wait a little bit until Surface's future becomes clear.

I was in a doubt to buy an Ipad Retina or TF700,I am glad I choose the later one. The Screen is awesome and product just works as best. The Amazon Service is the best and help resolve customer issues quickly.

I wish ASUS would improve its customer service. 1 Star lost due to that.

Got this for Chrismas, Can't believe the picture quality, how easy it is to use. Tablet seems to be of great quality materials. I use this for work and home. Has some great apps already loaded and I'm adding more everyday. Love the fact that you can add the sd cars to expand your capacity. We added a 32 gb ultra class 10 and it works just great. We also purchased the docking station and love that also. Very easy to carry around as it's very light. Would highly recomend to any one looking for a tablet.

The tablet seemed to work fine until I tried to use the micro SD slot to transfer pictures.  I could not write to the micro SD card.  I had to send it back to Asus in Texas to repair the tablet.  This I feel should not have happened.  I believe that the item should have been checked thoroughly before it went out the door.  Also on the tablet their is a file called Manual but the folder is empty.  I would assume that this file, if it were their, would have information about the tablet and how to operate it.

I use my tablet as a substitute for my old laptop. While there are a few things I can't do on a tablet that I do on a PC, I can do all most everything I need to do right on this tablet. The only negative is the tablets battery by it self is terrible and can't even make it close to one day. But, if you purchase the ASUS keyboard that goes to this tablet, the combined battery life is more than sufficient to make it through a day. Plus the keyboard makes it easier to type and gives you some handy shortcut keys.

After months of comparison shopping and test driving all of the best Tabs on the market (thanks to Best Buy) I'm extremely happy with my TF700 and dock from Amazon. I now get to enjoy my TV episodes, movies, games, and yes, even my Excel and Word files I bring home from work. My previous Tablets were the Ipad2 & the ASUS TF101 which I also loved, but I wanted the Quad core and Hi-Res of the TF700. WOW! I'm in love all over again!

For storage I'm using a 64gb microSDXC card for the Tab and a 64gb SDXC 133x card for the dock. It's not necessary to go that high or that fast for some users out there, but I find that it makes for quick access & response times when saving files to the removable SD cards and provides zero lag when playing back Hi-Res video as often as I do. To each his own.

I have not experienced any crashes, reboots, black lines on the screen, or missing pixels, and only the rarest of force closures. By the way, I am rooted, which was super easy to do (less than 15min), but it's not unlocked. This is not an endorsement for rooting, nor does rooting violate the Mfr warranty when rooting can be easily reversed & restored via the Voodoo OTA RootKeeper app avail thru the play store. However, unlocking does violate the warranty & blocks you from receiving OTA updates.  I have still received three OTA updates from ASUS in the last 5 wks since I have had this, all while being rooted. The latest was JB10.4.4.25. Thank you to ASUS for their continuous support & improvement of their products.

The Wifi & GPS reception is full & strong from a distance of more than 50ft away from my ATT router when I'm outside lounging on the back patio.  The battery drains & recharges differently on the TF700 when docked than it did with my TF101, which took a little getting used to for me, I admit. But it still recharges quickly. The TF700 has awesome features and settings for prolonging battery life between charges. When combined with Juice Defender it's even better. The battery life is at about 7-9hr undocked and an additional 5-6hr when docked depending on continuous use vs sporadic use and a prior clean full AC charge. And also depending upon your power saving settings. Explore the many options avail in the system settings to see what best suits your needs and usage. Because I use the Tab daily I recharge overnite. I program in the settings not to push email, app updates, or any notifications between the hrs of 11pm & 6am. But once 6am rolls around the Tab comes to life and starts sounding off like a happy R2D2 with all sorts of email downloads & app update notifications. It's like having my very own alarm clock, only better. So far I have never not made it thru a full day without plenty of charge left on the Tab. But then I keep it docked most of the time, where it recharges itself whenever it needs to. However, I did need to fully drain & recharge the Tab & dock 3x over the first few days, before experiencing the long battery life from each, like the user manual suggests.

I also get great Blue Tooth reception for my hands-free BT device, & my DBEST PS4003 BT stereo speakers for extra volume when I'm watching videos, movies, or even games. And great tether reception and Internet connection thru my Inspire 4g phone for on-the-road Internet access. I just turn on both the Mobile network & Wifi Hotspot connections on the phone, I turn on the Tablets Wifi connection in settings, more, Tethering & portable hotspot, and you should see your phones device name there. Click on it, wait a few seconds till they sync with each other, enter the security access code into the Tablet that is displayed on the phone screen, hit OK on the phone to accept the connection, and you've got instant Internet access thru the Tablet via the phone. This only has to be done once, for the very first time. After that, anytime I need Internet access thru the Tablet when away from home, I just click on the phones Mobile network & Wifi Hotspot from the quick access Taskbar,  the Tablets Wifi connection from the Tablets quick access taskbar, and they automatically pair up every time. Quick & easy.

I transferred my 258 apps from the TF101 to the TF700 and all ported over flawlessly except 1 game, which was the app Mfr fault, not the Tablet. I wrote to the app Mfr and they said they are already in the process of updating the app to take advantage of the TF700's Higher Res. The app still works...it's just that it doesn't expand to the full screen size of the Tablet. (about 1/4" shy of the Lft & Rt edge) That is the only prob I've had with any app not running or displaying correctly. There were 4 games with large data files that I attempted to restore but would force close on me. The problem was that the data was originally downloaded from the Mfr website after the play store installed the app. I had to delete the app & data, then allow the play store to re-install the app, and allow the app to re-download the data from the Mfr website. Then I used Titanium Backup to restore only the data for that app, in order to get my saved history back. Voila! I only had to do that for the 4 games where the data exceeded 100mb. I think it is because the play store & the Mfr website can place the app & the data in diff storage locations on your device, which can be specific to the make & model of your device. Your backup software can't always get it right when backing up your apps & data from one device then restoring it to another device. That was of no fault of the TF700.

I experienced the same prob when porting my phone apps over to my TF101. Some apps had to be re-installed directly from the app store because there was a diff ver avail for the Tab than for the phone. Same when porting apps & data from one Tab to another because of the diff make, model, & storage locations of each device. It happened to me when restoring apps from my TF101 to the TF700 because of the Quad core capabilities of the TF700. The app store has diff vers of some apps that specifically take advantage of Quad core devices capabilities. (Riptide, ShadowGun, FieldRunners, Anomaly Warzone, Sentinel3 for example) Just a heads up for those who already have an android phone or Tab and are wondering if their old files will work on the TF700. They will. But for those apps that were enhanced to take advantage of the Quad core, you WILL have to download the enhanced ver of the app from the app store, then download the additional Mfr data from the Mfr website. Then you can try restoring only the data from your backup software for that app to get back your saved progress. I've been lucky with Titanium & My Backup Pro so far. And I have not lost any data progress in the transfer. And wait until you see the stunning graphic details of these enhanced apps on the TF700. AMAZING! Even many of the apps that have not been enhanced look sharper & more detailed thru the 1080p Res.

I've read other user reviews where they speak of the proprietary USB cable, the weak sound output, the lack of 5g network access, the slow response from ASUS tech support personnel, etc. But in my experience the USB cable was never an issue for me even with my TF101 other than its length, which I easily remedied by ordering two 6FT 3.0 USB aftermarket Transformer cables thru Amazon. Or the sound volume, which is a vast improvement over the TF101 & the 201 series in my opinion. The standard vol is sufficient for most of my needs. But when I need more, I use my DBEST PS4003 mini rechargeable duo Blue Tooth speaker pair that puts out Loud vol & deep Bass for such small & easily portable speakers. I take them with me whenever I'm out & about. I've never had bad or slow Wifi reception at home even tho I do have a 5ghz connection and the Tab defaults to the 2.4ghz it's still fast for my needs. I'm not downloading huge files or P2P data thru my Tab even if it was capable of faster speeds. But that's just me. Luckily I have not had to contact ASUS for support via phone or online for any problems across my two ASUS Tabs in the past two yrs, so I cannot attest to their response time or lack there of.

I know this is a bit long winded for a review, but there are a lot of people out there who may be put off about getting this Tab. After all of my research on the TF700 I wanted to share what I've learned from others in hopes that it saves them from having to surf the web for this info like I had to. There is a lot of mis-information about this Tablet. Everything I've learned about this Tablet is thru my own daily use of the TF700, the user reviews like mine here, and much thanks to the many user forums and expert reviewers out there that I read thru before I purchased my TF700. Definitely check for yourself to see what others have to say. It took some time for me to type all of this out but I thought it was worth it if it helps anyone out there who may be on the fence about the TF700. I hope I've touched on the main points that may be of concern to most readers. If I've left out something important or got something wrong I apologize in advance.

I highly recommend this device to anyone interested in taking advantage of not only todays apps, but also the future apps that are sure to take advantage of the TF700s superior speed and Hi-Res capabilities in the months & years to come. With its strong Wifi & GPS connections, HiRes screen output for videos & games, the Quad core speed, the awesome battery life, and ease of tethering Internet access I have no complaints with this device. It is an absolute joy to take back & forth to work, or to play with, and all around fun. I get loads of compliments from friends who at first assume it's an Ipad. My old Ipad2 was no match for this. Not even close.

Update as of 6-22-2013
It's been 6 months now and I love this Tablet even more than I did at first glance. After re-reading everything here in my initial review, the only correction is that I have now unlocked the Tablet and installed a Custom ROM (CROMI-Xenogenesis) from xda developers website which adds customize-ability to the Tablet as well as many other bells & whistles for ease-of-use. My initial concern was about the Tablets output volume. I was able to increase it significantly with an app called Bass Booster. I still use my DBEST BT speakers alot because of the awesome sound quality and output. But with regular use the Bass Booster app is enuf for my needs. I also upgraded the SD card from 64gb to a Lexar 128gb 400x card for more video storage and backup space. I have not dropped it because it doesn't slip from my hand. I have not experienced any bad pixels or light bleeds or the glass pulling away or separating near the corners. Nothing of that sort at all. I have zero complaints. The compliments never end as my friends & acquaintances see the Tablet docked and think that it's a Netbook until I separate them. Battery life is still amazing with no need to ever recharge before the day is over. When they see the Hi-Res display and the snappy response moving from app to app or surfing the Net they are always impressed. I absolutely love this Tablet with no regrets.

Bought it at a brick store for $499 and it came with the keyboard dock for free. My thoughts on this device. Love it, I tried the 300 and the iPad 4. Had to return them for this. I didn't go with the nexus 10, because I needed the keyboard dock. Anyways, you won't regret buying this.
Picked this up for my wife.  She loves it.  Can read her Nook books on this as well as on her Nook and keeps her place regardless of which one she uses.

Okay people I've had this tablet for about 4 months now.  The tablet itself is great, does everything I want it do.  But guess what... if you can't turn it on... it's USELESS!! I honestly don't understand how they could build such a great tablet, but provide such a god awful charger with it.  I mean seriously?!? what were the thinking?!? mine stopped working the second time I tried to use it.  I went online and found some trick to move the pins forward to get it working again, now pretty much every few days I sit there for an hour trying to get it working again.  You know why? because they charge $40 for a new charger, and it's the exact same piece of crap one that they give you with the tablet.  My recommendation is to stay away from this product until they redesign the charger, no joke it has ruined the majority of my experience with this tablet.  If you think this won't happen to you, just google it and see how many other people have had this problem.  It's definitely not just me; I wish I new about it before I wasted my money on this piece of junk.  Now I'm forced to drop another $40 on a new charger and hope I only have to fix it once every month instead of once a week.  If the second one breaks, I'm selling this tablet.  I'll follow-up on this review some time in the future and let you know how it turns out.  For now, take my advice and stay away from this one unless you have time to become a charger fixing expert.
Exceeded my husbands expectations, would recommend to others.  Quick shipping, loved the color (champagne). Price in good range for most people.
Fast Shipping, just as described!, new condition. is a great part for the tablet, really need it!!!! can buy again.

The tablet has performed well so far and the battery life has been excellent.  I haven't time the battery too carefully, but with moderate usage and without using the most stringent battery-saving settings (it was driving me nuts when it was going to sleep after only 30 seconds of non-use), I think the tablet lasts 8 to 9 hours and then I get another 8 to 9 hours from the (optional) keyboard.

The main criticism I have of this tablet is the lack of support for flash video and therefore its incompatibility with a lot of online video resources (YouTube works fine, but other video sites and video on many websites is problematic).  This can be remedied for the most part with the Skyfire browser app available from Google Play, but there are still some compatibility issues with video on some websites.

Other than that, it is a nice tablet - sturdy-feeling metal case, nice screen resolution, front and rear camera, and good battery life.

Seems like the Android OS does not play many of the movies I have collected over the years.  Other that that it is a great little machine.  I would like to have a attached stylus for navigation.  Here in AFG cleaning products are in short supply.
Since I got this thing to watch movies and read on it; is a bit disappointing when I WILL NOT DO THAT.  It plays some movies, just not most of mine.

Great tablet; for PDF files on the go, and WI-fi web, yea... that's not really available here.
This was a gift and it was a hit!  He told me to give it the 5 star rating.  No cons on this one.

This is my second ASUS transformer and I love it.  Most of my colleagues have ipads but there are several features of the transformer that make it a better choice for me: 1. Good battery life that is greatly extended when using the docking keyboard; 2. Nice memory that can be enhanced with micro SD cards (tablet) or by SD card and usb ports (keyboard); 3. good options for free and inexpensive android apps; 4. mini-HDmi port; 5. most importantly, the docking keyboard really makes this useful for detailed tasks - it is sturdy and fully functional, adds battery time, memory and usb ports.  Typing on the tablet screen is very easy, but the keyboard is SO much easier for long documents or for remote accessing your office computer.

The Transformer screen is a very nice size and quite durable. The tablet itself is thin and light and you can use it separately from the keyboard for most tasks.  I have had to deal with customer service twice and they have been extraordinarily helpful and quick to take care of my concerns.

I bought the Asus Transfomer Pad Infinity after reading all the positive reviews about this tablet on many "tech" websites and feeling a compelling need to get a tablet that would also function as a laptop (sort of). I expected nothing but the best when I read about all the ramblings about how this is a worthy competitor to the latest iPad. Unfortunately, the Infinity couldn't even beat my iPad 2 when it
came to performance. True, it has a fabulous display, it's loaded with irresistible features and the keyboard dock even adds a USB port and an SD card slot, but think of it like this- what's the point of a fully equipped luxury car that drives like a truck?
  The performance of the Asus is abysmal. More often than not, I had to close down the browser because it wouldn't respond. I have to constantly make use of the Task Killer and the Fast Reboot Apps to keep the performance optimal. The tablet cannot handle more than 2 apps in the background without becoming choppy. With the keyboard connected, it's not possible to watch YouTube videos in fullscreen. That might be an app glitch and soon be resolved but there's no forgiving the dismal battery life when using the tablet by itself.
  If you open more than 2 tabs on the browser, or run more than 2 apps in the background, or try to browse the web while updating your apps, the tablet runs out of breath.
If you really want a tablet-netbook, I suggest you wait until they launch one with atleast a 2GB RAM and a quad-core processor.

today im going to write a review on the ASUS TF700t infinity tablet. It is pretty amazing, and the android 4.1 jellybean upgrade was free. This tablet is really fast even on power saver mode, this tablet uses nvidia tegra 3 which is super fast and uses little battery, the screen resolution is great with 1920 by 1200 pixels, and typing is a breeze with the android keyboard, im typing this review this tablet. its worth every penny.

I wanted to write a review after using this product for about four months to ensure that I have a fair review of it.

Pros
-Good price compared to iPad.
-The screen's quality is excellent.

Cons
-The speed at which the web page loads is noticeably slower than the iPad 4 (my child owns an iPad 4).
-After every update, there are new problems. For example, the tablet has a slower response to touch input when trying to open an app or its own settings menu.
-My other child has a Nexus 7, also made by Asus. Everything, such as web page loading speed and responsitivty to touch input, is much better and comparable to the iPad 4's performance.
-The tablet restarts automatically sometimes when playing the Google Play Music app with a bluetooth device.

I wanted to really love this tablet. However, it makes no sense that this same tablet, made by Asus, is worse than the Nexus 7, which is also made by Asus. Why can't the developers fix the firmware for the ASUS TF700T so that its performance, such as web page loading speed, is just as excellent as the Nexus 7's?

I am disappointed in the overall quality of this product.
Best Android device yet, especially with mobile dock!  The CNET review was spot on, be sure to check it out.
I recommend 100%, because i wait few  days for my tablet, and is all that i want! The box in perfect conditions, all in perfect state.

For the price at Amazon this tablet has so much more for the money then Apple has. Also this tablet  is so very easy to use and I have not had any problems with it. I believe if this company spent as much money that Apple spends on adverting they would be number one.

Asus listened and learned.  I love the custom asus rom, Asus quick settings and ability to disable almost everything.  It did not come preloaded with a bunch of bloat, instead it came with preinstalled apps that are useful and selected wisely like, polaris office and supernote. Kinda reminds me of Wackrosoft early years when they gave you all the good software free with the computer. Speed is super fast for a tab, display is so bright I keep it at 20%. perfect size for traveling full, but light. You must get the keyboard dock to turn this into a very nice fun little laptop and also extend batt life AND! also give you mouse friendly USB and SD that can read 64gb, addition of keyboard will keep you youtubing all day. I think apples Ipiad is in trouble.

I've had a TF101 for years now and have really liked it. After a huge disappointment with the Adam Tablet, I found the TF101, with base, and fell in love! It was about perfect! I got a great deal of use out of it as an all round reader, movie watcher, music, internet device. I used it all the time. Many versions later, I decided it was time to upgrade, and there was the TF700. I figured it would be the same, but better. I was wrong.

What I had forgotten was all those months of instability with the TF101. It has been a long time since those days of random crashes, reboots, incompatibilities. With the TF700, it has far less of those issues than the TF101 had when it was first released, however, it has an order of magnitude (loads) more than the current TF101.

The most damning aspect of this "updated" device is the reduced form factor. First, and foremost to me, is this newer Transformer only has ONE SPEAKER! And it's a weak bugger! It's very noticeable, and makes watching videos pretty useless. Where the TF101 had stereo sound and louder much nicer sounding (more base perhaps?) speakers. I gave purchased a set of self-powered speakers to compliment this product, however, it is far too incontinent to carry them around with me. Perhaps, if they really needed to, they should have moved them into the optional base. Either way, I'd prefer the device had stayed the same size as the 101, if it meant better audio.

The buttons are the other major new form factor failure. They have moved them from the top of the tablet, in portrait mode, to the top in landscape mode. Typically I only really use this device, in hand, when using it as a reader (book or internet), which is in portrait mode. The buttons then are at the very top, and bottom, so, depending upon your orientation, your hand is on the power button, or on the volume buttons, and you WILL accidentally press them. I had never had this problem with the TF101.

Where they have reduced the size of the form factor over the TF101, and substantially improved the processing power, if only in number of cores, and improved resolution, they have lost the slick form factor, and years of improved driver and product support. In the end, the processor power and resolution improvement is unnoticeable, as few applications take advantage of this (preferring to targeting lower end tablet and phones). Some times I -think- I can see the improved performance, and resolution (like when zooming), though the performance stalls a lot (like when browsing with the native browser), however, I can most definitely hear the changes, and feel them when my volume suddenly drops, or the power goes off, from coincidentally pressing those buttons. In the end I don't mind lack of application utilization of the new advantages of this TF700, what I do mind is the reduced form factor, making me regret this purchase and wish to even return to my TF101, which I had sold too soon (immediately upon buying this TF700).
Shiping not so fast, but then it was the Christmas. It was a great gift idea; great quality and she uses it everyday and loves it

I have only had my transformer for a few days now, but I already carry it everywhere. My friend who has an iPad is rethinking her purchase after playing with mine, and Cnet named it the best Android tablet on the market. It does everything and more than I expected.

The Transformer Infinity is very nearly perfect in most ways. It's super-light and thin, while having the power and flexibility to (with the keyboard attachment) entirely displace any ultraportable-type laptop.

The screen is very clear and extremely bright. The keyboard attachment is comfortable to type on, and holds it upright on a table just fine, without any tendency to tip back like older Transformer models were prone to do. The ports are convenient-- I especially like that I can plug in an external USB mouse and it just works. The OS and system software are very nice, running close-to-stock Android with only a few modifications that actually make the interface better, but can still be turned off if you want a VERY stock-like experience. ASUS doesn't lard up their system with shovelware the way the phone manufacturers tend to.

There are a few flaws, though. The top buttons feel a bit cheap and press very easily, occasionally leading to accidental locks when I bump the train seat in front of me. The screen glass is very glossy. It shows reflections enough to sometimes make it hard to work in bright lit areas, despite how bright the screen itself is. Finally, the Tegra graphics drivers seem to be a bit unstable, producing the occasional crash (maybe once or twice a day under heavy usage) when rotating the screen or launching an accelerated game.

Flaws notwithstanding, I heartily recommend this product.

I'm very pleased with the ASUS tablet.  It was advertised as a used item, but appeared new.  I've had no issues with it.  Graphics are very clear, touch screen responds quickly, most downloaded apps funtion properly (ones that don't are usually due to poor software development).

This is a great tablet for the price.  Eventually, I'll have a chance to use it on a regular basis once the family gets tired of it.

I had no trouble with mine, works great with or without the dock. I would recommend the dock for many reasons but this may very well replace my laptop especially for travel! Everything is as described and better as far as im concerned! This is the only one to get!
I bought this tablet in July 2012.  In December 2012, it would no longer charge.  I sent it in to ASUS to be repaired.  Today I got it back.  It still has exactly the same problem.

I will rewrite this as a 5 star if the following problem is fixed.  Power cord is defective.  Will not charge the tablet.  It seems to be in the main unit, not the cord connecting to the tablet. Jiggling the main unit in various outlets will sporadically make contact.  At this time, it is not working at all.

This is my first tablet and I've been using it now for over a month. Really the tablet has met all of my expectations. My wife has the iPad which is where I got interested in buying a tablet so that was my comparison. This tablet is fast easy to use, camera is fine, the wi-fi works great, no complaints!

Everything about this tablet is sensational.  It is fast, very high definition, and does eveything well, including playing movies.  It is terrific.  Also, 2 days ago, Asus automatically upgraded from Ice Cream Sandwich to Jelly Bean, which is smoother and faster yet!
I am having a ball with this and have used it so much my laptop and desktop had to be dusted off before I went back to them. I'm very pleased.

I purchased ASUS because of the researched reviews.  I am glad I did.  I wanted to try the tablet experience and the price that Amazon was offering this tablet for was just about right.  Lower than the competition.  Tablets are a bit different than the PCs and laptops I am used to, but it is not too abrupt a change to turn me off.  Now I am enjoying the different apps and such.  Not totally away from PCs, but this is a welcome change; especially when traveling.  I can even use this tablet as an alternative to my Kindle (yes there is a reading app!)

**BUYERS BEWARE****BUYERS BEWARE****BUYERS BEWARE****BUYERS BEWARE**

In the end I will win, because they will refund me completely and have to pay for shipping both ways >8]. Talk about a stupid business model. It would be way more profitable to just send out working devices.

The display is outstanding!  The touchscreen response is fantastic. The fact that it has a very nice rear camera as well as the usual front camera is a big plus. Another MAJOR plus is that it has micro SD storage unlike the iPad and many other tablets.  A little expensive but not over priced considering the extras and compared to the iPad.

I've been using the ASUS Transformer Infinity for about a month now, and I have to say I really like it. I haven't had a chance to thoroughly use all the features - such as camera and video recording but I have a pretty good sense of the device. The reason I did not give it a five star review is because sometimes there is lag - for example after unlocking - but other than that it is indeed very, very fast, has good hardware materials, and excellent battery life.

Pros:
- Excellent screen resolution - text is very sharp
- Durable hardware materials - aluminum chassis is great, and the champagne color looks awesome
- Upgradeable to Jelly Bean out of the box
- Great amount of storage, and expandable by 32gb micro sd card
- Good price point considering all its features
- Excellent battery life - I tend to lower the brightness significantly due to personal preference
- Watching HD netflix movies on the 10" screen is great - the size is just right
- This depends on personal preference, but I find reading ebooks on it very comfortable. I thought it would be too big and heavy compared to a kindle, but it really works just fine for this function

Cons:
- Sometimes lags after unlocking - probably because it's updating widgets (certainly not a deal breaker)
- On mine the top two corners of glass must not be set completely or completely adhered to the unibody chassis because when I push on them I can feel the glass move a little and here a noise - probably a quality issue. Annoying, but not so much for me to return it (my hands aren't in those areas enough for me to care too much)

Overall - very much worth the money and I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a top of the line general purpose Android tablet

The first one I received had lines going across the screen, Thank fully I sent it right back for a replacement ( Actully I wish now that I would have just returned it and moved on) So the second one worked for 90 days ( I used it maybe 60 times in that period ) Well when the OTA Jelly Bean update installed , I tried my bluetooth a couple of days later and it would not work. I called Asus and tried what they said and it did not work so I sent in for RMA on 12/01/12. for 14 days no updates on what was going on and on the 15th day the RMA screen "Waiting" was still the status but also showed repair complete and shipping out. The only thing was the serial number changed ? Why. So I called and they said my tablet could not be fixed so sending another tablet. OMG now I was going to get another broke and fixed tablet that someone else owned ?  ( remember only 90 days old ) I paid $500 + for this Fun. Anyway I received the tablet a week later and started it up , as soon as I got the setup down I noticed that the tablet was working by itself , starting apps etc.  So I set it down and tried to use it and this did not happen, I picked it up and as I held it it started opening apps again by itself. So I had been using this on 30 seconds and it's jacked up. So I called right away and they said " I am Sorry" send it in for service ! Really $500+ for this and all this fun. I hung up . The next day I called back and asked for a supervisor and got the same. So I guess you really do not get a different person, just the same joker type comands into their PC to talk to you.
