The world of Android tablets, or just tablets in general, is a very confusing one. I'm not one to make a big purchase like this without doing my homework first. I don't want to spend my money on something that I'm going to end up regretting. So, I did a lot of research and a lot of back and forth between different brands and features, but in the end I really felt like this was the tablet that could suit all of my needs. So far, I've been correct. I'll make this review fairly simple and to the point- PROS- -Android 4.2- I just love Android first of all. I toyed with the idea of an iPad but the Apple iOS is just so limited and it was very important for me to be have the OS that gave me the most versatility and could be ultra customized to my liking. (It's worth noting that this tablet came with Ice Cream Sandwich out of the box, but a Jelly Bean firmware update was available as soon as I got everything powered up!) -The Color! I love the Amethyst Grey color... even though I do have it tucked inside of a case (Poetic Slimbook Leather Case for the ASUS Transformer Pad Infinity TF700), so the color didn't matter much after all, haha. I would say that the color is neutral enough though for either a guy or a girl to carry around without shame :) My husband loves it...but then again, it's in the case! :) -Very sturdy feel- This tablet just feels well made to me. I love the fact that the screen has the Gorilla Glass and the metal backing- it makes me feel more comfortable taking it out of the case; I don't feel like it's going to get all scratched and dinged up. I have three young boys, all under the age of five and they are extremely interested in playing with this, so it was very important for me to have something that would hold up to any potential torture they might put it through. So far though, I've kept it out of reach, but I do like knowing that if they do get a hold of it at any point, it will be safe! -Thin!- I love the sleek design of the tablet- it's comfortable to hold in or out of a case, and is a reasonable enough size to be able to slip it right into my purse or diaper bag along with everything else and it fits right in without any added bulk. -The Camera!!- This is an extremely important feature. I didn't actually think that I would take too many pictures with the tablet because I always have my phone with me and I always felt like taking pictures with something of this size was just clumsy and foreign. That was until I used the camera on it!! Oh man does it take some nice pictures! I dare say it takes clearer, crisper pictures than my Galaxy S II and it takes them faster too! My kids are quick so it's hard to get a picture of them that isn't just a blurry streak, but the shutter time on this camera is almost non existent and it makes it MUCH easier to snap a pic and have it come out nice. Since I want this to be a very honest review, I do have to say that I have noticed a couple little things about it that are worth noting. They aren't worthy of a list like the pros, but here they are anyway... There have been a couple of times when randomly the screen has gone white and everything froze up, then restarted. But it has only happened MAYBE three times in the three weeks that I've owned it. The other thing is that there is a line across the screen that blinks every now and again- it's very brief and doesn't affect anything else. That is all that I've noticed that could be considered negatives. So ultimately I have to say that the pros of this tablet certainly outweigh the cons! If you're looking for a tablet, look no further- get this tablet!! You won't be disappointed!

I ordered this product on a Monday and received it the next day. I've had the tablet for almost 2 weeks now and feel compelled to write this review in light of the more nit-picky negative reviews (read unfair) over the past couple of days. This is my first tablet ever and purchased it after watching the tablet wars for some time and made my purchase decision after extensive comparisons to the iPads, Surface and Samsungs. Even considered the Sony version with keypad and the Fire Kindles. Overall, the TF700T beats them all hands down - no question. When one balances price (paid $428 for new), features for the occasional road warrior (mini SD and HDMI ports), long battery life, outstanding resolution for the price (1920 x 1200 wow!), the ability to turn itself into an ultrabook when it is docked with the keyboard when one needs to do serious work and the really nice Android 4.1 OS - it is the best value for money there is given the current market right now.

Where the ASUS TF700T really shines is the amazing industrial design of how the tablet and external keyboard come together to make a very compact Ultrabook with even more battery power in the keyboard and THEN full size SD and USB ports that complement the mini ports on the tablet. Done with the serious work? Just detach the tablet and leave the keyboard dock behind. ASUS really had their thinking caps on when they designed this and beat the hell out of the competition. You can be sure Apple and MS are kicking themselves for not having thought of this design configuration first. Apple is dependent on Logitech for their external keyboard. The Surface has to have it's kickstand open to access the SD port and if you're typing on your lap, well, have fun ....

iPad is fun but a toy because it lacks the practicalities like mini-SD and/or mini-HDMI and an external keyboard when extensive typing is needed or a built-in mouse when more accurate pointing is needed. If you want GPS, tough, you have to pay for the WiFi-Cellular option whether you want the cellular option or not. WiFi alone means no GPS. The TF700T currently only comes with WiFi and Bluetooth and GPS - awesome deal. It's all I need because high-speed cellular data connections are too expensive and can be choppy depending on where you are.

The Surface is clean and .... boring. Really Microsoft boring. Windows is great for my desktop where it belongs. I refused to pay for the lower screen resolution of 13xx by whatever .. it just seemed ridiculous when most of the other tablets were offering much higher HD level resolutions. The Surface tablets also need 2GB of RAM to accommodate the OS, so one would be paying for additional memory to run what seems like an inefficient (read bloated) OS. The TF700T only needs 1GB of RAM with plenty leftover - kudos to Android designers.

Galaxy - not bad but felt big and heavy, almost clunky. Some nice features, but not enough to make me buy it when I had the TF700T available.

I've seen reviews recently that are unhappy about flash players not being supported. The tablet comes installed with a video player and I've played videos on Chrome from Netflix, etc, etc. No problems with speed or quality whatsoever. What is the big deal about flash? Is there a shortage of apps for playing videos on Android platforms? Why the loyalty to flash players? And so because of this ONE feature for which there many perfectly good alternatives, reviewers ding the product heavily. Come on .....

I've not had any need for direct ASUS support so I can't comment that. But not having to call the manufacturer is probably a good thing, I think. The tablet even knows when to update itself. For example, I received it out of the box running Android 4.0. Within a couple of days, it automatically updated itself to 4.1.x and rebooted itself. Smart. And all the apps continue to update themselves.

The negatives - only 2.4GHz WiFi, no 5.0GHz, no MIMO (multiple antennas) and the automatic switch between landscape and portrait formats can be a little oversensitive and sometimes slow to switch but it's not a big irritant for me. If you are impatient and expect INSTANT switching then you will be unhappy, I suppose ....

If you are still reading this review then I suggest you read the negative reviews carefully and you'll realize most them are about one or two issues that really aren't that big a deal after all (unless it's basic product functionality like something not working at all which is product quality) and may not even be a concern for your purchase decision.

P.S. Get the ArmorSuit MilitaryShield as a screen protector, works great.
P.P.S. Forgot to mention the TF700T comes with Corningware Gorilla Glass so the display looks really nice and the ArmorSuit doesn't spoil it at all. Competing tablets don't all come with Gorilla Glass, think about that one.

I wish i never bought this. It does have good graphics for games, but you cant stream movies or watch videos that require flashplayer. It tells you that you need to download it but when you try, it says there is no version of flashplayer for this os. Then when you try to contact suppoet from asus, it is nearly impossible. When you finally get a response, it has nothing to do with your question. I should have bought a samsung.

There is a 9 page thread on xda developers about the wifi dropping.  I have tried 2 asus transformer infinity tablets so far and both of them experience the issue.  The issue is that anytime you do something thats very packet heavy for example using Splashtop remote desktop at high resolution it will drop the wifi connection.  Some people say its an incompatibility with several routers.  I am using an ASUS RT-N16 with Tomato firmware.  I have several other android devices and laptops and these 2 asus transformer infinity tablets are the only devices that lose connection.

For the typical user you may never experience this but for those that are doing something like constantly using splashtop remote desktop and connecting via wireless-n then you may experience disconnects.  Changing the router to Wireless-G only resolves the issue but of course my speed is brought down.

I think everything else about the tablet has been pretty much covered in other reviews.  Oh I want to remind everyone that if they plan to Root or Unlock then do so before doing any firmware updates.  Use Rootkeeper to keep root between firmware updates.

I bought it just to try it out, but I ended up keeping it because there is nothing better out there. Among all kinds of tablets I've owned in recent years, I also owned Toshiba Excite 10, and loved it for it's built, shape, weight, and full size SD slot.  But it doesn't have accessories easily available and does not have updates that come out as frequently as Asus TF700.  Even buying an extra charger cable is a big hassle and expensive for Excite 10.

I thought TF700 would be crushed by Windows 8 Surface, but now the price even went up after the Surface entered the market.  So TF700 has stood the test of time and competition.

This tablet has become my everyday tool and it is very stable after the recent updates.

As a geek, I am also hungry for a better tablet, but for now, I can't find a better one considering the overall built, functionality and stability of TF700.

A month after buying the Asus from Amazon (who were awesome as usual), six horizontal pixel lines appeared on the screen. Just try to get customer service support from Asus. It's almost impossible, frustrating and disappointing. Just for this, I would probably not buy a tablet from Asus again, and maybe, in the future, I'd buy tablets in the electronics store where I can return them in person.

I give this tablet 2 stars simply because while a good tablet, it just didn't mesh with me while using it.

As an avid Android user I am very used to the android environment in general, so it was pleasant to be able to use android 4.1 on this tablet. I liked how with a quick tap you can pull up all your active apps and switch to any of them that you want or after pulling up the active apps, with a quick swipe, close them to free up memory. I liked how the clock and notifications were displayed down in the lower right and you could get to the settings quickly by pulling up the notification pane and tapping the settings icon. I liked the screen resolution and brightness. I liked the finish on the back of the tablet, it sort of looks like brushed aluminum, and mine was a little darker than I expected from the pictures, but I actually liked that better. The back also resists fingerprints pretty easily, however felt a bit slippery at times, especially if you have sweaty hands.

Now for the dislikes. I did not like the feel of the tablet in my hands. The way it is put together, there is a sharp edge all the way around the tablet that feels like it digs into your hands. I read a few reviews that complained about the screen being loose around the edges and found the model that I received to have the same issue, especially near the corners. If you press down lightly, you can feel the glass move downward and then when you let go it pops back into place with an audible click. The weight of the tablet is also odd. It did not weigh so much that I could not hold it with one hand, but it felt like the balance was off because holding it in one hand was very awkward, even for me and my hands are not even close to small. All in all with the sharp edges and the odd balance it just wasn't comfortable to hold for extended periods and since I intended to use it for movie watching and reading quite a bit, this is an issue.

Before purchasing the Transformer Infinity, I was considering the 8.9" Fire HD since I previously owned the original Fire and really liked it. I decided to go with the Infinity though because I was looking for something with a little more of the vanilla Android flavor. Now I'm thinking that once I get the money back from returning the Infinity I will get the 8.9" Fire HD since it has the same screen resolution and looks to have a more comfortable form factor. It will also have the ability to watch Amazon Instant Videos, which disappointingly, the Infinity cannot since you are unable to install Adobe Flash on the Infinity. If I want a tablet with the vanilla Android experience after I get the 8.9" Fire, I think i will go with the Nexus 7 since that is still considered to be pretty much the best 7" Android tablet on the market.

All in all I would have been much more satisfied with the Transformer Infinity if it had just been comfortable to hold. Plus the inability to install Flash was very disappointing considering how prevalent Flash still is on the internet. I'm hoping that I will be much more satisfied with the 8.9" Fire HD and I expect to be since it has pretty much all the features that I wished I'd had on my original Fire.

Not working smoothly as antispated. Reboots itself often. Some apps are giterring on screen.... very disapointing. Spekers are actually a Speker...a mono one. Language change is slow. The asus cover (sleeve) tends to set appart too easy

I sell tablets at Best Buy so I know the in's and out's of each. I have owned the Ipad 1 and Toshiba Thrive. Both were nice but the Asus tf700 have been by far the best. Keep it with me all the time. Use the camera all the time also. Great pictures

I had done my research and finally decided to get this instead of an iPad. It is so much better with the keyboard. It has the functionality of a laptop, but the processor(for games) of a tablet. It's display is beautiful, and the speaker is very clear. It is very fast and functional. I love it. If you are getting a tablet, this is the one to get.

I have owned an iPad, a Nexus 7, Acer, and a Galaxy Tab 7.0. As you can imagine I am a little picky.  The Nexus 7 was far and away my favorite tablet.  Only drawback: It's 7".  Don't get me wrong, it's FANTASTIC on the road and trips in the car, bus or plane.  I just needed a larger screen.  Enter the T700.  I bought mine at Best Buy because deliveries in my area are difficult.  I tore open the box and started charging it.  Ok...one hour down and I decided to turn it on.  I pushed the rather small and set to far in power button.  Hmmm...no power just a blinking amber light and a little vibration.  Ok, maybe more charging time.  3 hours pass and I try again.  This time success.  Seems kinda odd that Asus decided not to pre-charge unit, but, ok I get it.  I enter my Google account info and the basic set up tweaks.  I remember the CNET reviews saying this tablet is "EDITOR CHOICE" and "TOP PRODUCT" noting speed and screen quality.  Really????  Seems rather slow and oh look it, the battery indicator shows 4%!!! So 4% for 4 hour charge for $500?  I kept the unit plugged and charging for another 7 hours and finally I'm at 100%!  I decided to play a few clips on YouTube and noticed that 1) the wifi signal was only "good" even though I was 7 feet from router and 2) the picture quality while smooth was kinda blah.  For having a high res screen I really expected more.  Colors were off and noticed on 1080p videos that there would be less detail.  I tried games and all I would get is force close and crashes.  If you think I didn't update you are wrong.  Did all that.  Item is heading back to BB and will decide on if I should get Nexus 10 or Galaxy Note 10.1.  Save your pennies and avoid this "EDITOR CHOICE" item at all costs.

Also, look up ASUS under BBB.  Not good.  Seems if you're lucky, you get a good unit.  Unlucky, you end up with garbage.

The ASUS Infinity is just the best tablet by far. I am a retired computer programmer. I have been using hand held computers for over 20 years, from the days of PDA's. I have used and programed Nook Color, Toshiba Excite, PanDigital, Archos Media Tablet, Kindle, Kindle Fire and IPad 2. The IPad 2 is the only one that comes close to the ASUS Infinity, but the display on the ASUS leaves the IPad 2 in the dust. The wide screen on the ASUS is the best for watching video, movies or music videos. I do not play games so I cannot critique. My main interest was movies, the ASUS is excellent at streaming video. I use 32 gb microSD cards to copy DVD (vob) files for play back on the ASUS, the picture and sound is perfect. I use MX Player for video play back, it will play .VOB files as well as most other formats, avi, flv, mov, mp4,3gp, wmv and maybe more. Battery life is good not great for watching movies, I can get through one full length dvd but not two without recharging or using the power adapter. I was prepared to unlock the OS and add a custom ROM, as I usually do with new tablets, but I have not needed to. The ASUS arrived with ICS installed and two days later JB 4.1 was downloaded OTA. Hope this helps I am extremely pleased with this tablet have been using it for a 6 weeks.

Wow. This tablet is great. I did a lot of research and went with this tablet as the best non-Ipad tablet. I just like the freedom of Android, and I was not disappointed.

The display on this thing is incredible. Really standout. My girl has the latest generation IPAD, and my tablet looks just as impressive, if not more so just on the visuals. The only noticeable adavantage I've seen is the superior speakers on the IPAD. It's not really close. BUT, I use headphones a lot especially in public, and i'm sure most people would as well. I have to recommend getting the docking station. It is really what takes this tablet to the next level. The increased battery life is incredible. I ordered one from amazon for $95 and it has worked flawlessly. I'm so glad i knew that and didn't pay the extra money for something I didn't need.

In sum, this tablet is awesome. And there are some really nice browsers that give you great flash support. (Jelly bean doesnt support Adobe Flash) I am so happy with my purchase. This is a ridiculously awesome product that is sure to stay relevant for a long time.

The Asus Transformer Pad Infinity TF700T is an amazing tablet.  You can tell the device is all quality the second you open the box and hold it in your hands.  This is our first tablet, and we love it.  Here is a list of some of the device's pros and cons.

Pros:
-The screen is amazing.  You can read it in outside during the day while wearing sunglasses.  Needless to say it works just as well indoors.
-The battery life is great.  It can easy go all day.
-The Android OS is great.  It's easy to use, fast, and reliable.  The upgrade from Android 4.0 (Ice Cream Sandwich) to 4.1.1 (Jelly Bean) was a breeze.
-The device is very stable.  Over a month, it has only frozen 2 times.  In total, I've re-booted it only 3 or 4 times since it arrived.
-The touch screen is great.  Typing, drawing, navigating, it handles all the tasks flawlessly.
-The device plays full scale high quality H.264 videos flawlessly.
-The wifi antenna works great.  I get good reception all over my house (better than my other wifi devices).
-The Micor-HDMI out is awesome.
-The 32 GB of external storage is an awesome addition.  Videos play from it perfectly (we have a class 10 card, not sure if a lower class would have an affect or not).
-The 10' screen is AWESOME.  The size is great for browsing the web, reading books, playing games, or doing just about anything else.
-The device comes with a small set of useful pre-installed apps.  Asus did NOT fill it up with a bunch of useless promotional garbage apps.
-The built in camera works really well.
-The Tegra 3 Quad-core T33@ 1.6GHz processor has easily handled every app I've thrown its way.

Cons:
-The device does not ship with an Micro-HDMI cable.
-The device uses a proprietary cable to charge and connect via USB (it's not the standard Micro-USB connector).  This is actually annoying because the devices ships with a single cable that is used for both charging (via the AC wall adapter) and connecting to a PC.  So you have to tote the cable from room to room or buy a second one.
-The edges are not quite as smooth/beveled as they should be.
-When playing videos, the bottom 20/30 rows of pixels are blacked out (where the home, back, and recent apps icons are located).  This is probably more of an annoying Android "feature", but none the less it's ridiculousness this screen real estate goes to waste.
-The only way to wake the device up is to press the power button.  So far the button works great, but I have a feeling it will be the first thing to wear out.  When it does that will be a big problem.
-The device is kind of heavy (but bear in mind the TF700T is no heavier than other 10' tables).  You only notice it when doing something like reading an e-book.
-No FM tuner (but most tablets don't have them anyways).
-There is no way to store pictures/videos taken with the camera to the SD card.  Again, this is probably more of an OS/App issue, but this really seems like something any device with a camera and removable storage should support straight out of the box.

Conclusion:
Ultimately, the positives far outweigh the negatives.  The TFT700T has all the bells and whistles, and brings them together in an amazing package.  If you want a quality tablet that will exceed your expectations, this is the one for you.

The Asus Transformer Infinity. This tablet is a fun device so far. I got it in the mail super fast. I first setup the device then charged it 100 percent. This is my first very Android Tablet so far so good I think. Getting use to it so far. I used Sonic CD as a games test it is crystal clear and running butter smooth. Currently running ICS( Ice Cream Sandwich) 4.0.3 version the version you will get when first get the device all though I probably won't be on there for long because as soon as I got through setup first use on the Transformer I got a firmware update notification I am assuming it is Jellybean by Asus but it may not be. I have not updated yet but the update is being annoying by popping up every now and then. So will have to update I guess because I cannot swipe an Asus System Update notification away apparently. The Infinity is a good device to own. The camera is pretty decent and it can take decent quality photos.

UPDATE: I am currently running Jelly Bean is good and fast no software bugs yet.

For get the Ipad. This tablet is awesome. It is fast the display is outstanding. I use this daily. It plays the new HD games fast. I would recommend this to anyone. I have had NO heating problems. It does not get warm at all.

I am really enjoying this tablet.  Because it has the latest version of the Android OS, I am waiting for some of the apps to catch up; however, that has not posed a problem for me.  I carry it with me everywhere I go.

I was an ASUS fan, now I am an ASUS addict. Outstanding product.
Super crisp display, super fast performance, super convenient weight and size.
Updates the software/firmware automatically, no hassle at all. My mini sized laptop and travel friend.

My Transformer's screen shut down less than two weeks after receiving it, which was a pain. However, ASUS was willing to replace it for me even though I bought it used on Amazon. The replacement was not the fastest in the world but I didn't have to push too hard to get them to follow through on the warranty.
That inconvenience aside, I love the tablet itself. It runs smooth, looks good, and has a lot of room for customization and fine tuning everything to suit your usage style. Comes with a bit of bloatware but unfortunately that seems to be pretty standard in the smart-device market these days. The one thing that pushed me to get this over any competing products was the optional keyboard dock, and I am so glad I did. The ability to convert between tablet to functioning laptop at the push of a button is really what makes the difference to me. Tablets are fun to play with, but I don't think many people are willing to type out an essay with the on-screen keyboard. When you pair the two together you have all the fun of a tablet without sacrificing productivity. Plus, unlike other options like an iPad plus bluetooth keyboard, it actually increases your battery rather than drain it faster.
On another note, my father just purchased the new Microsoft Surface, which is another keyboard-equipped tablet. It seems pretty nice from the fiddling I've done, so if you're a professional or student looking to use your tablet for both work and fun, I would recommend picking between one of those two.

I just got it for about a month now qnd I am loving the product. what I really like is the speed of the wireless. I use my Xperia Arc as my wireless modem and I have come to realize that my browser (opera mini) is faster on the tab than when I use opera on the Xperia. It is a good buy for the price. I forgot to mention that I also bought one for my wife as her anniversary gift and she always gets admiration from her friends when she uses it.

The power connector broke in the first week.
I took great care to be careful with it but it just
fell apart.

This is my second Transformer, I liked the TF101 so much I decided to upgrade to this one. This does everything that the previous one did and more, the HD screen was just mind blowing. Had it up and running Jelly Bean 10 minutes out of the box with the Asus update, Asus rocks updates like nobody's business! Which is one of the reasons I decided to get another Tablet (now if they would only make an Android phone for the US market I'd be set). The only complaint that I have is probably that the battery for this one lasts nowhere near as long as the TF101, even on the exact same settings, doing nothing differently.

With the TF101 I probably charged it every two days or more what with reading for hours at a time, checking email, shopping, heavy research and journal downloads for school. This one, I've had to charge every night, also, I'm not sure if there is something different about this charger, but the TF101 charger is a 12v and the tablet would fully charge in under an hour from about 14%, this one charges significantly slower, after a half an hour it had only gone to 77% charging from somewhere around 45%. For this reason I'm probably going to purchase the dock because even though I didn't get much use out of the TF101 dock, I have a feeling that I'll get much more use out of this one.

All in all I'm freakishly happy with this purchase, because I also got it for $385 used here on Amazon, but it looked brand new out the book, and even still had all the manufacturer stickers and protective films on it, not a scratch anywhere.

I previously had the ASUS Transformer Prime. I loved it. It was great until the camera failed. I purchased it from Best Buy and had the protection plan so they replaced it for free, but unfortunately it was discontinued at BB so they gave me the latest and not so greatest, Infinity.
The Infinity seems slower, browser crashes often, freezes up a lot, reboots randomly, sometimes, and worst of all, it's not compatible with my Amazon Mobile shopping app. Overall, I don't like it. I wish I still had my Prime, I didn't use the camera much anyways. I'm really disappointed.
Very light weight,great 1080p,fast and smooth,what isn't there to like about this tablet...I strongly advise if you are going to purchase this tablet to spend the extra money on the keyboard dock.

Loved this tablet, screen quality is good plus you have the expansion options. The only thing that really bothers me is the its response to touch inputs. Its kinda herky-jerky at times. Scrolling is not smooth and finger inputs, there is a delay. This is something Android tablet makers really need to refine. In terms of the user experience, the Ipad is just way more refined. Asus may need to tweak the driver for the Tegra as it seems like it doesn't like the 1080p resolution (or is not optimized for it).
It protects the tablet fine. The way in which it stands up seems like it could damage the case over time, but other than that, it's fine.

I cant say enough good about this thing.! An awesome toy, stunningly beautiful display and extremely lightweight and probably more powerful than my current home PC. I also prefer the control i have over the ASUS.  I can be browsing or reading and without closing the screen change screen brightness and Wi-Fi controls.  Fixing typos and editing on the browser i far superior than the iPad also.  You can tap in the middle of a word and it blows up the view to change between letters and delete.

I gave my iPad to my 2 year old and a buying another ASUS for my wife....

This tablet is extraordinarily fast.  Given it has 4 cores, that is not too much of a surprise.  In terms of aesthetics, the tablet is very beautiful, slim, and elegant.  I love that they used gorilla glass for the touch screen interface, because every couple days you can just wipe it completely clean and have the front looking as new as the day you bought it.

Connectivity on the tablet itself is limited to a headphone jack, the proprietary charging connector, and a micro HDMI port.  The micro-HDMI port, however, does give the tablet a great amount of added features (as even if your not fortunate enough to have wireless television, you can still stream movies, youtube, and more to a televsion effortlessly).  Its not merely a gimmick either, as on normally the gpu is powering a 1920x1200 resolution screen, so its actually easier to power 1080p!

If you buy the docking stating, this device goes from great to near perfect!  A full sized usb port and sd card slot, along with the capacity of a full keyboard (which allowed me to type this review easily) are excellent features and in my opinion make the tablet very unique in its realm of competition.  Lastly, the expanded battery life; whenever the table goes below 70% and the docking station has battery life, it charges it back to around 90%.  Quite ingenious if you ask me.

Software is also excellent; recently updated to Jellybean, Asus has a program which syncs all of the files, searches, and google play with your phone or PC, and I think also with mac but I think those users would prefer the significantly inferior Ipad 3...

The only con I could think of is that it has only a single speaker on the right side of the tablet when facing the user.  It is pretty loud, but it is easily covered as a result.  Not worth taking a star off, because I've been thoroughly impressed in every other aspect.

I purchased this tablet 3 months ago and have been exceptionally impressed.

This was a replacement for a first-generation iPad. I wanted something that could sync with my Android phone. It does that and I was able to download the games I had purchased for my phone. I also wanted an HDMI output (without an adapter) and expandable memory. Thus, I purchased a 32gb mini SD card and voila, I have a 64gb tablet.

The screen is very bright and crisp. It handles everything I throw at it with ease. I have mainly used it to look at photos, navigate, watch movies, and read books.

photos: Beautiful screen with excellent color reproduction.

navigation: I used this to navigate the difficult streets of Osaka, Japan on vacation and it was a godsend. Does not require a data plan or WiFi to navigate.

Movies: It handles all sorts of formats and HD looks gorgeous.

Books: Not as good as a dedicated reader, but it works very well, especially dimmed in a dark room.

If you want a solid tablet that beats the iPad in several key areas, this is a great choice.

Im an electrical engineer and mid level geek who loves new technology.

I use an Ipad 2 regularly (Ipad 1 earlier), and this is every bit as good. I compared it to an Ipad 3 in the store, and I could not see any major differences, except price. After a charge, I turned my new TF700 on, found the Wi-Fi screen and quickly set up my system.  I was asked if I wanted to download Flash. I said yes, and it installed within a minute or so. So far so good.

I played with some of the more obvious features and all worked well. I copied some music from my PC onto a micro SD card, plugged it into the tablet, and it was detected and useable immediately. I grew so confident that I then set up my 3 mailboxes (2 ISP and 1 Gmail). The email front end is very nice, since it permits incoming mail to be displayed from individual accounts, or as one combined view. On outgoing mail, (even via my ISP), it picked up and used my Gmail contact list. That encouraged me to combine several email contact lists, including my wife's, into one master contact list on Gmail. (Gmail tools for doing this are easy to use.) Then, even the ISP mail can use the master contact list. It also found the apps I had downloaded from Android Market (now renamed) onto my Android phone, and downloaded those to the tablet as well. I downloaded Skype and was video conferencing in minutes. Wow! I was getting more pleased by the minute.

Then, since the tablet was delivered with Android Ice Cream Sandwich (4.0.3), I checked to download the expected Jelly Bean (4.1.1) update. Nothing there. I tried that for 4 more days, also posting questions on the ASUS site and Amazon BB. Everyone else seemed to be getting JB within a few hours of trying. Why was my Infinity a wallflower?  Then finally, after 5 days of hitting the "check for updates button", a large download arrived.  Hooray, I had Android 4.1.1!  Frankly, I could not tell much difference, but this was definitely not a scientific test. I wish the ASUS FAQ had said that it could take several days before the download of the update might happen. That would have prevented a lot of anxiety. My guess is that they are rationing capacity on their download servers.

I also bought an ASUS USB adapter; a very small device that adapts the TF700's multiport to accept a USB device. Wanting to experiment, I plugged a 16 GB cheap generic USB stick from my car into the adapter, and within about 15 minutes had copied about 8.7 GB of my music from the stick to the tablet's internal 32 GB memory. I clicked on the music player icon on the screen (it's the orange headphone icon, third from the bottom right on the picture), and immediately got to play choices from my almost 3000 pieces of (mp3 and wma) music. The tablet allows me to sort the music in many ways - actually its better in displaying - sorting music choices than the (Clarion/Bose) system in my car. I also tried other media experiments including YouTube, emails with video attachments, and streaming PBS shows. All have worked well. So has the superb amazing Google voice recognition.

I bought this unit because I wanted a large high end tablet to use as a "couch-pad" and to replace
My old Acer 8.9" XP netbook for email when I travel. I wanted the unit to include a GPS, have the ability to easily do file transfers from memory sticks and cards, and not break the bank. (If possible, I also did not want to be dependent on the Apple universe, but my Ipad 1 and 2 experiences were so positive that I was willing to relax that restriction, if needed.) So far the TF700 fills the bill perfectly, at lower than Ipad cost.

BUT, there is one key thing this unit does not do. It does not wirelessly mirror its screen to my TV like Apple Airplay/Apple TV and Intel WI-Di do. (I recently saw a great demo of this at our local computer club.) That is a big shortfall that I know is being worked on via methods such as Miracast. I tested a temporary solution via a 15' cheap HDMI cable to my TV, and the TF700 performed perfectly - streaming a PBS Upstairs Downstairs to my 65" screen. I'm really hoping that the Android industry gets its act together quickly to provide wireless streaming like an ipad with Apple TV!

Except for that, thus far, the TF700 has done everything I have asked it to do, perfectly. It has the solid build and feel of a Lexus. It is definitely an outstanding product, especially at this price!

After having my owned my Asus Infinity TF700 for one month, I just got the Jelly Bean OTA update -- no rooting required.  This is a solid update, to a excellent tablet.  I usually like to wait a bit before posting my technology reviews, so here's my review:

Pros:
+Firstly, Amazing screen.  While it might not have the pixel density of Apple's Retina display, it offers Super IPS+ screen is very nice OUTSIDE in direct sunlight.  (Apple can't say that.)  It also features 16:9 resolution which is perfectly suited to widescreen movies.  Others who have seen my screen agree, it's nothing short of spectacular.  And in my everyday use, the Gorilla2 glass has kept my screen scratch free.

+Secondly, the Android install is clean.  It comes with ICS (Android 4.0), but an update to Jelly Bean is available over the air, with no fuss.  The few Asus apps installed were actually useful -- like a file explorer, an excellent backup utility, and some cloud storage.  I prefer this to the bloatware, and modified operating system that other vendors offer.  (Asus' partnership with Google on the Nexus 7, is evidence of Asus' expertise with Android OS.)

+Thirdly, an excellent camera that rivals my Point and Shoot camera.  It features a  F.2.2 lens with a 28-mm equivalent focal length.  Okay, I'll admit a tablet is a bit large for everyday photography.  But if you have with you, this device camera will outperform your smartphone.

+Micro-MDHI port allows me to natively export the screen image to my LCD widescreen.  I use both direct-HDMI and HDMI to adapter for screen outputs.  (I had a problem with 1 older VGA projector, that couldn't handle the 1920 x 1200 screen resolution.) Overall, this feature is one more step toward using this as a laptop replacement.

+Battery: I set my WiFi to turn off when the device is in sleep mode, and go DAYS (not hours) of casual use.  Even with non stop use, I still get over 9 hours of battery.

Negatives:
No device is perfect.  And while these are shortcomings, these are minor and don't deter me from giving the device a full 5 stars.

-Speaker: good quality, but it's not loud enough for anything more than personal use.  I compensate with a good Bluetooth wireless speaker.

-Wifi: Although it works at 802.11n speeds, I still have some dead spots in my house...in the same places where my laptop works fine.

-Android App EcoSystem is not large for tablets.  There are some fine apps out there, and I was surprised that a lot of business productivity apps are there (like WebEx, Citrix Goto Meeting, Juniper and Cisco SSL clients, etc...).  But as an example, Disney has ignored Android apps, so you'll see apps available for iPad that aren't available for Android.  Google knows this is a weak spot, and I see more tablet apps showing up.

I'll wrap up by saying this has been a very addictive device -- quickly replacing my laptop for day to day use.  The default browser supports Flash, which allows me to view most web sites natively.  I've had no quality issues reported by other reviewers.  I purchased mine from BestBuy (sorry Amazon).  And I would have no problem recommending this for anyone looking for a top-of-the-line, Android based powerhouse.

Update: after accepting all three OS updates from Asus, since buying this, my device has become painfully slow....like, "I can't possibly use this for anything" slow.  I'm beginning to wish I had gone with an iOS device.  With keyboard, cases, and unit, there was a lot of money invested into this purchase.  Now it's functionally useless.  I'm going to try doing a factory reset -- but the point is I shouldn't have to do that.

I'm going to start by saying that I really don't get the people that complain about light bleed! So far, I have owned this tablet for only a week but I have owned previous tablets longer than that. I have to say that my Toshiba tablet had NO light bleed to speak of. The sound on that one wasn't real great though. It also had no LED flash for the rear camera. The TF300T is a nice tablet by ASUS but, still no flash for the rear camera and the "stereo" speakers are placed far to the right of the back of the tablet as is the same with the TF700T which I am now using. It, however, does have an LED flash, a very bright one I might add. The folks that said the flash wasn't very bright, I don't know whom you were trying to kid. Now, the sound on this tablet isn't as good and rich sounding as the speakers for the TF300T, even though the placement is the same...to the far right in the back. That bothers me a little but not enough to send it back yet.

As far as that darn light bleed. Well, this one has one spot towards the bottom that is very noticeable and then a few areas towards the right of the screen that show up also. But you know what people, it is my experience that once that tablet is fully booted up and you have all the images on the screen and the auto brightness has adjusted itself to a mid level, the "bleed" is no longer noticeable. I don't understand the people that have huge complaints about it enough to say they returned their tablets because of it. The screen is very nice and very responsive. Even in IPS mode for outside viewing, I can barely tell of any light bleed and it surely isn't enough to project across my screen. If you are out in the bright sun with the IPS mode on and the bightness at full, the sun's rays still block out what you think one could detect as "light bleed" so again, I don't understand what all the fuss is about! It's still not bothering me enought to return the tablet. The one I really wanted actually was the Toshiba Excite but the reviews were much lower than this one. I still feel in some way I should've got the Toshiba instead (thus the 4 stars of this tablet). At least it places its "stereo" speakers as right and left side speakers and not just all the way on the right side. It also has an LED flash.

I'm not really going to comment on what bloat software it comes with becaue I didn't feel it actually has all that much extra apps installed to worry about. I'm also not going to comment on how well it runs all that software. I have found that from tablet to tablet, they all pretty much do the same thing with just a little bit difference in the design. That part is just to each one's own preferance. I've done the system update to the newest android version. The tablet as a whole seems to function well. I would recommend it to my friends but I also would suggest that they might want to research more and and maybe check out the Toshiba Excite or other brands and come to their own conclusions.

I really wanted to like this tablet.  After about a week, I realized that it's just a big version of my Android phone and it's being returned.  If you are a casual web user that just surfs the web and uses Facebook and Twitter, this would likely suit you just fine. Read on for more...

My wife got an iPad and after playing around with it I decided I'd like to have a tablet too.  She loves the iPad and I felt that this device was pretty comparable in terms of performance and usability.  It is actually much lighter as well.  We recently had a 5 day vacation with 6 hours of flying on the first and last day.  It was nice having this device while flying, although I just used it as a big e-reader.  When we were staying at our friends' apartment the Asus was great in terms of having something compact and light to use for Facebook and replying to a couple of work emails. I used Skype too, although it crashed on me 3 times during a 20 minute conversation and required a reboot of the device.

Once I returned to work, I realized that there are still some limitations. Specifically, I tried taking notes during a couple of meetings and was tapping the screen really loudly trying to get spaces and was annoyed with having to select a separate button to get a tab (I do a lot of formatting in my notes).  I also tried Swype, which I'm ok with, but still was about 40% of the speed of me typing on a real keyboard.  Note that I did not buy the physical keyboard, which certainly could have helped.  However, I would then be spending $650 to have a device that doesn't do as much as my laptop.  The battery life would of course be longer with the Asus, but that's not a huge selling point for me.

To repeat, this technology is at the point where it can be really useful for casual users but I still like my physical keyboard (still have a phone with one), and cannot justify the $650 for a large version of my phone.

Shipping was very quick. I received the item expecting something similar to the tablet I had misplaced. Surprisingly I was wrong. This unit is so much more responsive. I will say that I had it freeze up on me once but I assume is was because of the amount of programs I ha active and I was trying to close them in a hurry. Let's hope this doesn't happen again.

I will never buy an Asus product again from my experience in desktop builds. Their products are shoddy, and their warranty is a joke. Their customer service is incompetent and useless at best or all together none existent. What was Google thinking to have Asus build the Nexus, what a disaster!!!

At the moment, this is the best tablet available. It has plenty of storage space and supports up to a 32GB microSD card. It is light, thin, and comfortable to hold.

== Jelly Bean ==
Asus has recently released the update that will upgrade this tablet from ICS to Jelly Bean. Jelly Bean runs even better than ICS.

== Battery ==
The battery will last up to 9 hours of constant use if you have it on eco-mode, otherwise the normal mode will give you 7-8 hours and power-mode with give you about 5-6 hours. If you also buy the keyboard add-on, you can expect to get about 4 more hours of life out of the battery.

== Graphics ==
The video quality is nothing short of beautiful. It is a pleasure to view content on this tablet. Colors are vibrant, light colors are not too light, and dark colors are not too dark. Watching videos (whether through YouTube or Netflix) is great although the quality of the video is dependant on how fast your Internet connection is and whether you're watching high-def or standard-def video. If you have a fast connection and you're watching video in high-def quality, you won't be disappointed. Games like Dead Trigger which rely on a powerful GPU, look amazing and run without a hitch.

== Sound ==
The speaker on this tablet is nothing to write home about, but it is decent. For me, it's ok for videos, but lacks oomph when listening to music. Most of the time I have headphones on.

== Inputs ==
MicroSD, micro HDMI, microphone, 2-in-1 headphone/microphone jack. Purchasing the dock will give you a full size USB port and full size SD card reader.

== Camera ==
The camera is 8 MP and takes very nice, sharp looking photos. Although, if you use the digital zoom more than a few clicks the quality will degrade quickly. The front facing camera is a passable 1.5 MP, and I wish that it was of higher quality.

== Last Word ==
When tablets first came out I was skeptical about how useful they would really be, but after waiting, and making this my first tablet, I must say that I love this tablet. I use this it more than I use my desktop PC. Switching between apps is fast and simple. Surfing the Internet is easy and playing games on it is fun. I would recommend this to anyone looking to buy an Android tablet. It is simply the best one out there right now. Only a couple of other tablets even come close. I gaurantee you will be impressed and have no regrets.

I don't think I am going to really bother repeating stuff that has already been said in some other reviews. There are some reviews in here that do a really good job going into depth about this device.

Basically, I have been using this for about 2 months now... have had the iPad (1 and 2) as well as several other tablets such as the Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1 as well as the Toshiba Excite 13. I have to say this is my most favorite table to use, the docking station that you have to buy is really worth it, because the functionality of the device improves overall. W/ the docking station you are prettying much running a tegra 3 quad processor netbook...

this thing is damn fast and for a tegra 3 device, the back doesn't get crazy hot when you put the device through some serious performance. I would highly reccomend this product, great screen, very clear and crisp (defenitely still not as good as the iPad's retina display) but you won't be disappointed. I would buy this again

I researched this tablet purchase for a while, and ended up postponing my decision because I didn't really see much of a need for it in my life.  Then we had a baby, and the times we get to actually sit at a computer for an extended period became much more scarce, so the need for a tablet providing internet access and is always on, and easy to use while rocking the baby and sitting on the sofa became more important.

I was deciding between this model, the TF300, and the Apple iPad.  I hate how Apple has a strangle-hold on what you do with your equipment, and really hated the limited memory and storage, so I didn't spend long looking at the iPad.  I mainly compared other tablets to the iPad to see if they were at least competitive.

So I was down to the TF700 and the TF300.  I wasn't sure how stuff would look on the higher resolution screen.  I didn't care about the extra $100 so much.  I also really liked the nice perks which come along on the TF700 (brighter screen, nicer glass, flash on the camera, metallic covering, etc), so I got the TF700.

I've used it now for several weeks, and I'm loving it!  I'm happy to say videos look awesome on this screen.  Even the standard definition videos look awesome.  I was afraid only high-def would look nice on it.  The battery life seems good, but I haven't timed it.

The biggest issues I have are with the Android OS, which is fairly clunky.  Many things are just poorly designed, and the user interface is a bit clumsy.  For instance, I can't believe how annoying they build the standard email program.  Nothing works quite right, but it's good enough I guess.  I know I can probably find a replacement email program, but they really should get this right from the beginning and not depend on the user to replace it with another one.

I remember the first time I used the email client on the iPod touch, and I never quibbled with it.  Everything just worked like I expected it to.  I guess that's the final polish that Apple puts on all their products.

Anyway, I love the tablet, and how it's performed.  I highly recommend it.  I can't compare it to the TF300, because I don't have a TF300.

Hope this helps someone.

*********Update November 5th, 2012***********
As promised at the end of my original review that follows, I said I would keep the tf700 if Asus fixed things.  Well, they came through.
Following the latest firmware update, I followed the guide on TransformerFormus (dot) com and did a factory reset and cold boot (power off and hold the power and volume down button down for 10 seconds after the factory reset) and ALL of my issues were solved.  The lag has all been fixed.  The stock browser runs perfectly.  Amazingly, now the screen seems sharper.  I now prefer this over my iPad 3.

Well done Asus, better late than never, I guess!
****************************

(Original 3 star review)
First of all, I'm a big android fan.  I got the Galaxy Nexus phone on release day.  On the Nexus, Jelly Bean works great.

I got the tf700 when it had ICS.  It now has Jelly Bean and despite cold booting etc as described on TransformerForums and the xda forums, it is no faster than it was on ICS.  I also have an iPad 3 (I hate Apple and refuse to call it the "new" iPad) because it had/has the best screen.  IMO it is still the best tablet as far as performance, but I hate the iOS ecosystem as I'm a geek and frigging hate the Apple playpin.  I also have a Kindle Fire HD... though the processor is not faster, the overall experience is less laggy and web browsing is faster than the Infinity.

Cons:

"Would you like to wait or close your browser."  I specifically waited until the Jelly Bean update to post the review because I heard this would be resolved.  It is not.  If I had a nickel for every time I got this message I would be rich.

Speed.  Over all it is slow.  It is the slowest responding device I have, including the Fire HD, Galaxy Nexus phone, and iPad 3.er

Top Heavy:  falls over.  They should have put a bigger battery in the keyboard or something so it would not topple off the couch/bed etc.  This is a minor complaint.

Google Play Magazines: Text is fuzzy and not optimized for an HD display.  Zinio puts google play magazines to shame.  Performance of these magazines really, really, sucks on the Infinity.

Speakers:  Arguably the world's worst speaker, edging out the iPads speaker on suckiness.  The Fire HD speakes put them both to shame.

Wifi:  The iPad and Fire HD have a 5 ghz antenna so the microwave does not cause the browser to crash every time I turn it on, as it does on the Infinity.

The screen is nice.

The transformer concept is nice, though Windows Surface is going to strip that advantage out.  I do like the option of using the trackpad or tablet.

Overall, I would not recommend this to others.  I will sell it as soon as I get a 8.9 Fire HD.  While the Amazon ecosystem is limited, I just sideload google play apps, overcoming any restrictions.  The new Windows Surface tablets have low ppi screens, so I'll wait on those.

If Asus fixes the sluggishness and glitchiness that should not be associated with this processor or OS before I sell it, I may keep it and will update.  ********Edit 11-5-2012 I now recommend this unit without reservation.  Probably really a 4.5 / 5 stars just because they don't have dual band like the Fire HD,  iPad 4, and Nexus 10 but everything after the latest update, cold reboot, factory reset, is fixed.  Wow!***************

I have had this tablet for about three weeks.  When it arrived, it came loaded with ICS.  Soon thereafter, Asus pushed Jelly Bean and I am now running Jelly Bean.

Let me start with the positive points: fast; powerful; clear high quality screen; good graphics; great optimization potential; and moderately OK battery life.  I selected this device over the iPad since it has a micro HDMI port, I can add memory cards, I own an Android phone, PCs, etc. . . For me, an iPad made little sense since I have no apple products.  What I sought was a quality product that could do what I need without having to purchase an iPad.  I loaded a graphic heavy Tegra THD application (ahem, game) and the graphics are fantastic and it runs well.  For the most part, it does everything well, but there are some downsides.  The downsides have nothing to do with the quality of the product, but with the application market as noted below.

Negatives:  it has WiFi but no 4g/3g (but I didn't want that anyway), and the only glaring negative relates to applications, or better yet, the lack of applications that are available and optimized for this or any Android tablet.  For example, there is no Amazaon.com application available for this device.  Ironic considering where I purchased the product.  That is not the only missing application.  My cell phone has a number of applications that do not exist for tablets or are not optimized for an android tablet.  It is rather frustrating to try to load an application that is on my phone, but unavailable for my tablet.  It is less frustrating, but somewhat annoying that some applications that work on my phone work on my tablet but are not optimized for the tablet; therefore, the graphics on the application appear fuzzy and "old-school".  The best example is the Safeway application.  It looks and works great on my phone, but on the tablet, it looks like I took the application with great graphics, blew it up in size about five times, and then pasted it onto the tablet.  It looks horrible.  The GUIs are fuzzy, it does not rotate when I rotate the screen, etc. . .

Conclusion:
Overall, it is a great product EXCEPT the application market is weak.

There are prior updates about quality control.  My device has no issues.  QC issues may be limited.  Finally, Asus was very quick to push Jelly Bean onto this device. I applaud Asus for not sitting on their laurels and pushing Jelly Bean out quickly.

I bought one a few days ago on the recommendation of the Best Buy employees who said it was the best non-apple pad.  Since bringing it home I have grown increasingly frustrated with it.  I first opened the internet browser, and found it to be pretty slow.  Netflix is very sluggish on it.  The screen response is...horrible. You have to push something sometimes several times for the pad to acknowledge a click, either that or the browser is so clunky and slow it seems like you have to reclick because it isn't responding.  The facebook function on the pad is highly frustrating.  If you are typing a message on facebook and want to click back somewhere to edit something, you tap and a little magnified viewer will pop up to show you where the cursor will drop when you let go.  When you let go, it plops the cursor anywhere but where it said it was going to put it.  It doesn't have photoshop like the Samsung note, no swype, you have to download some knockoff of swype to use it that annoyingly puts a space after the . in any internet address.  The device just doesn't seem well polished.  It has great specs on paper, but functionally it's not really all that in my mind.  I can type facebook messages faster and with less hair pulling on my old Samsung Galaxy phone!  The camera is nice, but the software interface with it is non-intuitive. The glare on the screen is pretty intense too if there is any other light in the room at all.  I think I'm going to take it back and either get the Samsung note or wait and see if the new Kindle HD coming out Nov 20 turns out to be worth while.  I've also heard these pads develop screen issues, black lines on the screen and light bleed.

I was originally inclined to get the Samsung Galaxy Note 10.1, but after reading its specifications and comparing them to this tablet, it was a no-brainer. It is quite an amazing piece of technology. It is fast, the display resolution is great to read PDFs and magazines, and the colors are bright. It is very responsive to the touch and very smooth with Android's graphics and screen animations. I have to add though, I was very impressed with the WiFi antenna of this Asus tablet. It picks wireless signals stronger and faster than other tablets I have had in the past including the iPad. I also own a Google Nexus 7 (which is made by Asus as well) and it is exactly the same with the WiFi antenna. When using it at home, other tablets were showing poor signal quality if I was outdoors, but this one shows a strong signal and it proves it by being able to browse the Internet fast.

Finally, I got myself a pen for taking handwritten notes with the SuperNote app, and I am in pen heaven! No more fingerprints on my tablet screen!

Highly recommended device!

How do you make the best Android tablet on the market even better? Give it Jellybean. I've had this tablet for about 3 months now and it has certainly lived up to it's anticipation. Just recently however I downloaded the Jellybean OS update and I must say my great tablet is now even better. It's quicker, smoother, more responsive and handles multitasking even better. I was hesitant at first because I thought Flash would no longer work, but to my delight it indeed does. The ASUS Transformer Pad Infinity is by far the best Android tablet on the market, and after being a strong advocate for Apple in the past I'd even say it's the best tablet on the market hands down (sorry iPad fans). If you have any doubts then try one yourself. If you truly want the best tablet then look no further. ASUS has arrived!

After watching several reviews about this tab on YouTube I felt it was the closest rival to the iPad 3 (which I'm not a huge fan of, I just want the very best tablet for my needs and my money). I picked it up at Office Depot this past Saturday and was really excited to plug it in and start testing it out because I was sure this would be the keeper and I'd return the iPad 3 buuuut, that's not the case.

LIKES:
Sharp display. Colors are crisp and the general layout of the tablet is just beautiful.

DISLIKES:
1. Length. It felt really long in my hand and looks quite weird when being held in portrait mode. It's like a big fan :-)
2. Jumpy cursor was a nuisance when I was editing some material. It also refused to open my Amazon account to allow me to sign in
3. Some websites don't load as they should, freeze or the browser will just crash
4.  Flash is no longer available on this tablet even though it's listed as being  supported. (My way around that was to download the free version of Puffin, but it's slow and crashes quite often. Photon Flash works better. I think I paid $5 to download it and it's been working really well).

Even though I'll be returning this tab, I'm open to purchasing from Asus in the future. They just need to pay attention to our concerns and fix the glitches. Hope you all enjoy your tablets!

***Quick Update***
I returned the tab today (Mon. 10/15) and got hit with a 15% i.e., $75 restocking fee from Office Depot. I had no idea they did that. I guess I really need to start reading the back of my receipts before I open products. Next time, I'm taking my money to Best Buy or Walmart. As far as I know, neither charges a restocking fee and they allow you 30 days to return defective goods.

Let me start by saying that I waited about a year to get the latest and greatest Android tablet I could buy and REALLY didn't want to get sucked into the iWorld of tables.  I was sold that the Asus Infinity was the iPad killer.  However. . .

The unit I had (now returned) was functionally fine, and had no hardware issues that I could identify.  Got a day + of battery with modest use.  Lots of features and options.  Lots of apps BUT: Sporadicly sluggish and crashy when web browsing and using apps like Facebook. Doing very simple things like commenting on a Facebook post or, just scrolling a webpage.  I tried 5 different browsers to find the right one, and while each had its pluses and drawbacks, none would work as smoothly as expected.  Scrolling was snaggy sometimes where the page would just lock up and the browser would want to force close.  The other big issue is the typing interface is inconsistently sluggish. Sometimes reacting as fast as I can type, other times (randomly) lagging so badly that I would have to type a few characters, wait a few seconds to see what was recognized, then type some more. . . .  I also tried 4 different keyboards in addition to the standard one that ships with the device and none gave me the smooth and consistant input I expected.  My Droid Razr Maxx works more smoothly when typing than this $500 tablet does.  I had the tablet for about 3 weeks but was ready to return it after a few days but decided to wait for the Jelly Bean update hoping that it would fix the sluggish issues.  After the update, while I would say that it was somewhat improved, it was still not where it should be.

I really didn't want to go to the iPad (for all of the reasons you'd expect) but, after spending quite a bit of time (hours in total) literally A/B ing the Infinity with the iPad at an Apple store and again at a Best Buy, I came to the reluctant realization that like it or not, the Infinity (or maybe the Android Tablet OS itself?) is just not up to the same level of refinement and functionality that the iPad is.

I went to look for a tablet/computer for school. I purchase this Asus TF700, once I got home and  turned that baby on I was impress. I really like the thin, light and HD screen.  When I hooked up my hot spot the connection shot through the roof in fast motion. Once I place it on the mobile dock I forget that this is a tablet because it feel like a computer. I even got the amazon kindle app for ebooks so I can finish reading my books. As far as school is concern this convertible tablet pc will be just fine. I have not found any glitches yet even though its too early in the game and I hope not. I really enjoy this device and Im happy that I purchase it.

A wonderful product that meets the needs of the user Mtzawr and useful features practical and excellent user of the Internet, sophisticated colors beautiful programs all programs are working on lightweight

I've had this tablet for about six weeksnow, and I'm really pleased with it.  It's fast, sturdy, stable, and reliable.  It would be really nice if the battery lasted longer, but you do hwve three different power options: power saver, balanced, or performance (you can probably guess which modes do what).  The optional keyboard ( bought separately) really expands what you can do with the tablet.  It has a full keyboard (pretty easy to use) and increases the battery life of the device -- although the odd part is that the battery in the keyboard works by apparently charging the battery in the tablet.  I have very little complaints to make about it.  The screen resolution is fantastic, and with all the android apps out there, you can get everything you need to easily rivsl any product by Apple.  I take it with me everywhere and use it all the time -- even now!

I highly recommend this tablet for those looking for a competetive alternative to Apple's product line.

I have had my TF700 for 3 mos. and have had a chance to really use.  First, of all the tablet.  The tablet has wonderful features and everything works without a hitch!  The cameras are wonderful as well as the screen.  I do not have any problems with acquiring my WI-FI signal anywhere.  I have moved aroung the house and never loss the signal. The tablet is fast.  I enjoy playing games and find it to be wonderful.  The apps that come with it are excellent for work.  I do prefer to use Documents-To-Go and it work!
