The new ASUS has three features that I appreciate (compared to the earlier model):
1. The HD quality of the screen.
2. The LED flash that comes with the camera on the back.
3. The faster processor.

+'s: + Beaultiful Display
+ HD Resolution (1920 x 1200)
+ Quad Core Processor
+ 1GB of DDR3
+ 4.0 ICS
+ Cornering Gorilla Glass 2
+ 8 MP Front Camera / 2 MP Face Camera
+ Expandable Memory
+ Dock makes it a Netbook essentially
+ Decent Battery Life (Great when you get the Dock)

-'s: - Unlocking Voids Warranty
- Less Battery than the Prime
- A bit expensive (Especially with the Dock)
- Sound could be better
- Finger Print Magnet

Other Thoughts: I bought this along with the dock about a week ago. I was interested in ASUS's Transformer series tablets and was planning on getting the Prime, but luckily I waited on a rumor of a new one. A month or two later the Infinity was announced and I patiently waited it for it.

Anyway the tablet is everything I expected; beautiful and fluid like when using. Now I do get hick-ups every now and then, but they're not deal breaking.

The sound is alright, not the best. Personally believed the dual speaker hole would've been better, but the single does provide decent sound if not blocked or muffled. (Recommend Earbuds). Space is not an issue since the memory is expandable, and 32 Gb is a lot of space to fill. The improved resolution is very nice, makes reading books and PDF's very easy with the text easy to make out. Videos also look nice but some problems are there with 1080p. In the end I love

This is an amazing product. Highly recommended over the Apple Ipad or any other tablet. Games run smoothly, tablet battery life is excellent, all features work great as expected... Delivery was prompt and packaging was spot-on... Thank you Amazon! :)

I waited a long time (ordered it on July 11, 2012) for this tablet. Now that I have it and used it for a couple of weeks I can say it was all worth it. Great quick opperation, smooth navigation and BEAUTIFUL display. Very well built and solid feel.

I have really been enjoying this tablet! It is fast and smooth, I just with the jelly bean update was out already for this! There are a few nice custom roms out there if you want to root and unlock this device to enhance the interface. Combined with the docking station, this is like a little laptop, but with touch screen! The only issue  have with any lag is when I plug into my tv through hdmi and run netflix. The videos are perfect, very clear and no buffer time (I have fast internet), it is just the app itself loading up the que on my tv.
I'm really pleased by my Asus. It's moving fast in every program or game that you run. The battery keeps the tablet running as in the presentation. I encourage you to buy such a good product.
ASUS has outperformed this time in the 10" tablet market. Great screen and resolution! Great sensitive touch screen, it makes the changing of the applications fluent and smooth. Love this unit!

This is a good item that has many capable uses.  One thing that I saw that was helpful was that it can switch from one Internet source to another without having to set it.  It does it for you if the Internet source is known already.  The tablet is quick and responsive to the touch.  It is light and slender enough to hold for long periods.  My suggestion for users is not to get this item confused with it being an ultrabook or laptop.  The keyboard does help with the battery life too, allowing the unit to last over 10 hours on a single charge.  The USB and SD ports on the keyboard provides more storage space if needed.  The operating system is very helpful but I only wished that Asus would have worked on the keyboard a bit more.  The keyboard is NOT for papers or long document creations. I bought this item to act as a replacement for doing work online but as I said, the keyboard is cramped and creates more typos.  Deciding on getting the keyboard is a toss up. It gives you more battery life and ports needed to provide more storage space, but doesn't give you much typing space leaving your hands cramped up.  The touchpad is slightly helpful but not very.  I normally turn it off because it does interfere with typing, moving the cursor around.  I'm glad Asus saw this as a problem because they also designed a button to turn the touchpad off, if needed.  It is a good product with a few quirks on the keyboard but the tablet, itself, is sound.

Secondly, now we started to see some few apps that are showing the real value of high definition screen but hopefully there will be more. Compared with iPad i would say this is far beyond imagination and i was real loyal to Apple products but not after this device. Screw Apple such greedy company. My only hope is if Google market would ve category of its own for tablets apps. Those who were commenting on sound im with u and I'm still wondering why the speakers are always on the back of the device and at one side. They should be more creative and practical, but still better than iPad speakers.
Thats my review after experiencing the device for a month now.

I'm really happy with the purchase of my Asus tf700. I'm sure I'm a lot like everyone else who's read reviews and then pulled the trigger and purchased this ... then held their breaths hoping everything would work like it's supposed to. Well I've had this tablet for a little over one month and have absolutely no problems with the function of the tablet. It's pretty quick and totally responsive. The screen in the super ips mode is really quite good for outdoor use and otherwise the display is outstanding. I've had no issues of any kind with the wifi. It found my router and connected without issue and I get a strong signal.
I didn't purchase the keyboard and I might still do that but at present I only do a few emails so it's not that critical. I guess depending on what you're going to do with this tablet that would be a consideration. I do mostly browsing, reading and emails and such. I usually get a good day of battery life. The biggest downside is something that most have already mentioned. The app department is still lacking. Many of the apps are better used on a phone and not a tablet but if you know that going in then you're not going to be surprised by it. The apps function fine and there are many to choose from, they just don't look that great all the time. It's not been a big deal to me though.
All in all I'm happy with my purchase and have had zero negative issues. Whew!

I got my first one last week on Thursday. I noticed it only after a couple of hours. It was really minute, very difficult to make out, as it is noticeable only when looking straight right above it, only on a complete white background. It almost got blended with the white background at certain brightness levels. Well, I'm very particular about my screens. I applied for replacement in the night and by the amazing super-fast service of both Amazon and Asus, I got my replacement next day! Really happy with the service. And yes! my new infinity is perfectly defect free and awesome !

Talking of review of the product itself:
1. Fantastic performance - The four cores fired up and Nvidia tegra 3 kicked into play when in turned on Horn - butter smooth gameplay, great textures, rich world detail, smooth edges. can run songs on youtube/ music from library while surfing on net, or even minimizing that to change screen to supernate/polaris for taking notes. No slowdowns noticed.

2. Brilliant screen: Anyways the human eye cannot process iPad's resolution n ppi - screen would need to be 40inch+, neither can it process the infinity's reso and ppi on a 10.1" screen. Great clarity and color contrast. IPS + ROCKS!

3. Camera - The 8mp on the back with flash, surpasses my expectations! though the front camera is really important for me as I would rarely/never use a back cam on a tab. The front cam amazed me to with pretty decent clarity - it being 2mp. Works great for Skyping!

4. Body and design - Haha! I fell in love with it when I saw it online for the first time. Great design, very thin and light, sturdy, well-built, elegant... all 9 yards...

5. Battery backup (without dock) - After charging it to full, I used it with heavy applications running simultaneously on full performance n IPS+mode for 2 hrs, and heavy gaming (Horn, Batman, Nova 3) for 2hrs - I still had 22% battery left. Its good enough for me.

I also bought the dock. You can find my review on the item page.

The ones that work, work well and the tablet is  pretty responsive -- no lags, etc. My problem is that normal apps (Words with Friends) and web pages (NFL.com) don't work. You have to install the app, find out it doesn't work and then uninstall. For me, the fact that neither the NFL Fantasy app nor NFL.com/Fantasy works is a deal killer. The Wi-Fi signal is not strong enough. My router is in the family room, but if I go into the kitchen I lose half of the signal strength -- not acceptable.

The Pros -- I love the screen display, speed, storage capacity, and weight.

I just want all of the apps and web pages to work.

As an iPad and GS3 user, my expectations for this tablet were/are sky high.  I was looking forward to burying my iPad and continuing in the excitement that the GS3 offers; only in a tablet format.  An added bonus is/was it offered "pure" google experience. The specs for the tablet are stellar.  The ergonomics, size and weight are perfect.  The screen is amazing.  Absolutely incredible.  But...  Ice Cream Sandwich is unpredictable.  Gmail app crashes, apps are unresponsive for periods of time and simple operations sometimes feel laggy.  Even with the settings turned to performance mode, if you start rattling through different apps, I am sure the laggy/choppiness can be recreated.  My only hope is that the butter smoothness of Jelly Bean addresses the OS issues.  I am hesitant to tell someone to wait for Jelly Bean before purchasing but... wait for Jelly Bean before purchasing.  Especially if you are used to a smoother experience, found on the GS3 or iPad.

Yes, I've never had a smart phone or tablet or anything other than a Macbook laptop, so this is my first smart device.  I received it as a bonus at work; I would never spend this much $ on a non-computer device.  I work in the computer industry, I'm a luddite and I like command line tools.  No terminal with ssh and I'm lost.  I don't have a smart phone because I don't see how anyone can read text that small.  I have to admit, though, I'm liking this tablet.  Co-workers have helped me figure out how the UI works.  I have only downloaded a few apps (mostly games).

The screen is very bright and crisp!  The colors are great!  Looking at photos on picasa is a pleasure because of the rich colors.  The sound comes out of the small screen area on the underside of the table.  Volume is OK, but don't expect Bose quality sound.  The UI is pretty snappy; when you scroll back and forth the hardware responds with just a very brief lag.  It's plenty fast by my standards.  Be aware that the screen is a fingerprint magnet.  The smudges are only noticeable when the screen is black.  There is nothing about the Android OS or UI that irritates me, and I'm picky.  I really like the feature where you give a fast swipe and the screen keeps scrolling; just like if you were pushing a ball along the floor, it keeps going!  Very nice UI feature.

I am not pleased, however, that almost every app I download wants access to a lot of information.  I'm hoping that over time this will change and the OS will prevent apps from accessing information.  No problem, though, I just create another dummy account that I don't use.

I received the matching dock.  I provides additional battery life, but it seems to have issues.  I'm not sure if the dock is defective or if I don't know how to use it in concert with the tablet.

Overall, I find the hardware and Android OS to be really fast on this device.  It has only crashed once in almost a month of ownership.  If you want to spend the money on a 10 inch tablet, this is pretty nice.  Since I have never used any other tablet devices to compare against, I don't feel qualified to give 5 stars.  It earns a score of 4 stars because of the great screen, fast hardware and overall positive experience using the tablet.

I have tried all transformer tabs trying to replace my iPad.  Every transformer I've tried has had bad wifi.  I was hoping this one would be different.  The wifi speed on the transformer was one third the speed of my laptop and iPad.  Refund again.

I felt obligated to write a review after reading so many other ones and having for the tablet for a week.

1st off before you purchase this tablet you have to consider the following: Android and iOS are two very different operating systems and are suited for different target markets... I can't stand when people compare Android to iOS because imo they are to very different operating systems (Similar to how people compare macs to pcs). I would say that I have a high level of technical experience (8-10) so my view point is not one of a casual user, after spending a week with this product I can say I'm very impressed with it and consider it the best tablet on the market (for my needs).

If you do your research you will notice that unfortunately the TF700 has some CQ issues so it's important to buy form a reputable retailer in case you have to return or exchange the tablet.

People have complained about slow down or performance issues and while I do not doubt them I myself have not had any...I've rooted it, installed apps, played emulators, watched 1080p videos, used gps, bluetooh and have not had any performance issues again this is just my experience. If you do in fact notice performance issues I would exchange it (there's no explanation why some users reviews say it runs perfect and some say it slows down)

Pros:

* Screen: the screen is very nice, it's sharp, clear and bright...Yes the iPad screen is a bit sharper or clearer but unless you hold them side by side I don't think your going to notice a difference. The TF700 screen is brighter and has an outdoor mode, which depending on how much you use it outdoors maybe an important factor.

*Memory: This was a major priority for my in choosing this tablet over lets say the Nexus 7 or iPad, being that an entry level iPad had 16gb and costs the same I knew that 16 gbs wasn't going to be enough, the TF700 comes with 32 gbs as well as allows use of up to a 64 gb MicroSD card which you can find around $50-$60. You can also get the dock (which I highly recommend) which allows you to add another $64 gb full sd card or connect a usb flash drive or external hard drive. All in all lack of memory or not enough space will not be an issue with the TF700.

*Battery Life: I get around 6-7 hrs of battery life with normal usage, browsing the web, playing apps ect overall its what I expect just realize that it's going to be shorter depending on what you do. A major battery drain is browsing the web and I've read that users get around 5 hrs of battery life w/ only web browsing. Note if you add the keyboard dock it will roughly add another 4 hrs of battery life to your tablet.

*Keyboard Dock: This was another determining factor for me was the keyboard dock, I originally wanted a laptop with a nice screen and excellent battery life (7-8 hrs) and that I could use for typing notes at school...when I saw the TF700 thought it fit my needs well in terms of screen and battery life but a major draw back was not having MS Office...Well good news because MS Office will be released for iOS and Android by the end of the yr (reports are saying Nov), after reading that I had no reservations.

Connectivity: The mini HDMI port was also another big plus in my book, adding a lot of media on my tablet it's nice to be able to watch movies or tv shows you have on your tablet your TV. It's also really nice to be able hook it up to the tv to play games or emulators (PS3 and Xbox controllers work w/android). It also has a optional usb port on either the keyboard dock or adapter, the usb can read drives, game controllers (xbox, ps3 and wii classic) as well as power portable hard drives.

Cons:

*Performace / QC issues: While I have not had any issues, reading reviews and going on XDA I know that many others have, some have exchanged it multiple times in order to get a perfect tablet and while it's not an issue for me to do this it may be for some. Overall just make sure you purchase it form a reputable easy to work with retailer (also make sure you call and ask if it is indeed defective if you pay the out of pocket return shipping costs or if they send you a prepaid label).

*Support: Right now there just isn't very much tablet app support for Android, while that is slowly changing if you plan on purchasing this just for apps then I would recommend the iPad over this easily.

*Connector: Asus uses their own connector similar to apple, while I understand the need for it when attaching the keyboard dock I wish they could have included a micro usb port somewhere as the majority of devices use it.

Overall this is an amazing tablet... I consider it very similar to a laptop with the flexibility of Android and MS Office being released on a mobile platform. I would highly recommend this for someone who is looking wants something different but has similar functionality to a laptop or already has one (cough me cough). As far as performance issues go Jellybean should be released very soon hopefully within the next few weeks and that should greatly improve the user experience and fix many of the performance issues and while there's no way to tell until its released Jellybean's main focus is fix many of the UI issues that have been plaguing Android tablets so no matter what it should help quite a bit.

VS the iPad: As much as I don't like comparisons it's going to happen the main differences between the two products is the OS...it's really important to determine which OS suites you better:

Android: Android will require a learning curve and for you to play around, and set up your OS to suite your personal needs. It gives you freedom to do pretty much whatever you want with the OS and lets you customize like crazy. But once again there is a learning curve I've been using Android for about 2 yrs and its taken me a lof of time and research to learn and utilize the OS even now I'm still learning how to do stuff XDA and youtube are great resources, but once again I'm the type of person that loves doing research and customizing and fidgeting with my toys so it really depends on the type of person you are.

iOS (Apple): The biggest draw to iOS is the simplicity of the operating system and it's app support. The iPad is something that anyone can pick up and use (including my 5 yr old nephew). If you want something where you don't really have to mess around with too much and just want to play with apps then I would hands down recommend the iPad over the TF700.

Hopefully that helps a little! Sorry if I got off topic but I got really tired of reviews complaining that it's too big (uhh why did you buy a 10" tablet in the 1st place) or other issues. That would be like someone complaining that the iPad doesn't have enough memory....Also make sure you check you mobiletechreview they do a great comparison and have really great and useful videos.

Alright, before I begin my review I want to point out that if you want the champagne color, there IS a way to get it. As Amazon is - at the time of me writing this review - only "pre-selling" the 64 GB version of the Champagne version, you CAN find it for sale from BestBuy.com. DO NOT GO TO THE BEST BUY STORE SEEKING THE CHAMPAGNE COLORED TABLET. You will only be met with disappointment, as I was told by a sales rep that the stores only carry the gray color. Now then, moving along.

The tablet is fantastic. I am a junior college student with a weakness for technology and video games. First off, the battery life is amazing. I bought it with the keyboard dock, but I only use it for taking notes in class. Otherwise, I just use the tablet as what it is: a tablet. I play Grand Theft Auto III and Mass Effect Infiltrator on this beast and it can handle it all at max graphics settings. Other people have noted how wonderful the screen looks and yes, it is truly HD. Even with full brightness and graphics cranked up playing a high-end android game, the battery has held up for two hours of constant use, and had about half battery left.

I love using it to watch Hulu and Netflix. The video just pops on the HD screen and it is a truly wonderful experience.

The screen itself is built in such a way that the tablet is not rendered useless outside. I'm not sure how Asus did it, but they have managed to defeat the sun. Normally, as most of you probably know, using a laptop or a tablet outside is next to impossible. The glare from the sun makes it so that you have to strain your eyes to even make out large text.

This is not true for the Infinity.

I was outside today in the middle of a bright August day on campus reading an eBook with no problem at all. There was no eye strain, no squinting, nothing. Just turn the IPS up a bit, and you're good to go! I read a full chapter of fiction before class with no problems from eye strain.

Every Android tablet I've seen can run flash, yet this one is the first one I've seen that can truly run it as smoothly as your PC or laptop can. There is none of the jittery, bumpy lag during flash animations. They play out smoothly and naturally on this tablet.

Durability:

I'm sad to say that I have performed a unintentional drop test on my Asus. I was walking down the sidewalk reading a book on my way to class and was bumped into by a careless student on a skateboard (in college? Really?). Much to my dismay, my slim Infinity fell in slow motion to the concrete down below, landing face down.

I scooped up my precious, which I had only had for less than a day at the time, fully expecting I would have to send it in to Asus for repairs and discovered that, remarkably, the screen was unharmed. There were no scratches, no cracks, nothing! Just a bit of dust! I wiped it off and it was as good as new! Well, with the exception of a minor ding on the corner of the metal, but everything still appeared to be in working order. Headphone jack still worked and played wonderfully, machine still as snappy and responsive as ever. Whew!

Truly, the tablet is everything I could want and more. It's got style, durability, and portability. My only complaint, and it is a minor one, is that there is no stereo audio. There is only one speaker on the device and, while the sound is very clear and high quality, with only one speaker on the side it feels a bit.. off to my ears.

But this is only a minor problem for me as I usually have a pair of headphones on me at all times anyway. But for some people it may be a larger concern.

All in all, a great product with great engineering that I'm sure will last me for years to come. If you're looking for a solid, well-built tablet to finally stick it to those snooty iPad owners, this is the one for you!

----EDIT----

I took a bit more time and compared the New iPad to the specs of the Infinity, in case anyone was considering buying one or the other. So, how does the Infinity compare to the iPad? I took the specs directly from Amazon. As I do not personally own an iPad, I cannot test the Infinity against it for things such as battery life and other hands-on trials. But there are still some other technical details that need to be considered to make the smartest purchase...

Screen:

The Apple iPad has a screen size of 9.7 inches, versus the Infinity's screen size of 10.1. I personally prefer the larger tablets. I mean, if you're going to get a large tablet, bigger is better, right? Otherwise there are smaller, 7 inch tablets. The iPad does beat the Asus here in terms of screen resolution (The iPad's res is a whopping 2048 x 1536 versus the Infinity's 2048 x 1536), however I have compared my Infinity to my friend's new iPad, both of us watching Transformers. There is a difference yes, and the iPad does appear slightly more crisp. However, I did not test the iPad for outdoors entertainment so I cannot say how well it handles under the sun.

Processor:

iPad: 1 GHz
Infinity: 1.6 GHz

That's a huge difference there. That means for more multi tasking and a faster device overall. Both devices run on quad core.

RAM:

iPad: 1 GB DDR2
Infinity: 1 GB DDR3

The Infinity is using a newer, more powerful DDR chip.

Hard Drive:

While the iPad is available in a number of sizes, the 16 GB size is already over $500, compared to the Infinity's 32 GB size being right at $500 (slightly cheaper on Amazon). So, you are basically getting twice as much memory for cheaper. Of course, the Infinity is available in a 64 GB size for $100 more to match the larger iPad sizes that run well above $700.

Item size:

This is not largely significant, as the iPad weights in at 1.4 pounds and the Infinity beats it at a whopping 1.3. Still, if we are getting into the nitty and gritty, the Infinity is still lighter and slimmer. The iPad used to love to brag about being the slimmest tablet. No longer can that be said. The iPad has a width of .37 inches, while the Infinity has a width of .33. Again, this is not significant and will likely not impact anyone's buying decision, but it's a fun fact!

Rear Webcam Resolution:

iPad: 5 MP
Infinity: 8 MP

This is no contest. 3 megapixels is a significant change in picture quality. While I don't suspect anyone is going to replace their digital camera with their tablet any time soon, the Infinity has nevertheless beat the iPad once again.

So there you have it. That is the specs as I see and understand them. Feel free to contradict me. I'm not pretending to be a computer engineer. I'm just a nerd. But from where I'm standing, as far as the specs are concerned, while the iPad does have a higher resolution screen, it would not be able to out perform an Infinity in terms of processing power, memory, and price.

And of course the Infinity has something the iPad could never have: PORTS. Let's not forget the mini USB and mini HDMI ports that they have managed to squeeze on this ultra-slim device. But wait, where is Apple's on their beloved iPad? That's right. They don't have them, because they don't want anyone else gaining access to THEIR device.

And just because I have to: Apple is seriously still not providing Flash support on their devices? Get with the times, Apple. Flash is no longer a problem on tablets.

Update 8/29/2012
I was told about an app on Google play called volume+ which I installed last night. The volume is excellent now, even on YouTube where some of the videos do not have the greatest sound quality. I don't have to hold the tablet close to me to hear movies on Netflix anymore either. I can set the tablet in the dock on a table and still hear it from across the room. I can even watch a movie with another person now and we can both hear it.

Asus Transformer Infinity Review from new Android user - 3 stars

I'm a new Android user and I got this (but not from Amazon) for a few reasons:
1) 6+ yo fruit company computer is thernuclear overheating
2) Inf is super small, tidy, sleek. As a frequent flying professional, I need small thin light computing which does NOT break my neck lugging through the airport, and fits on a tray.
3) Heard about Ubuntu for Android, which requires a quad core (Tegra) to run. I use Linux for work because I'm a scientist and, well, frankly it is better is so many thousands of ways. So Ubuntu on Android is a win for me.
4) Runs Android (which interests me more than iOS as a mobile computing OS)
5) supposedly comes with Jelly Bean
6) supposedly getting PlayStation games

Summary:
As a first time user of Android, I can say I love it. It looks great on this little machine. It is very fluid, and on this computer I have had few hangups which others speak of. No application freezes really, although there are a few apps which will not quit. The tablet experience, at least as a 10 in tablet, is NOT for me. I have no patience with the ridicuouls on screen keyboards. Surprisingly, on a smaller screen, using my thumbs, I have NO problems. But on this huge on screen keyboard, no, too clumsy. I have used the device almost solely as a netbook. For a tablet, the Kindle is the right size for me. The surprising LACK of one of integration of one of Google's key features, Google Voice, is more irritating than I can express. Google Talk is there, why doesn't it handle Google Voice calls? Google phone number, Google OS, Google browser, why do I need a third party software like GrooveIP or somesuch to make a dang call (which would, on a computer, be implemented through a browser plug-in)?! No streaming radio service built in? Macs have it, even Symbian has it. Google? Just too many third party software to set up to do basic things I pretty much expect from other OS's. As a heavy user of keyboard shortcuts and hotkeys on the various desktop OS's (Mac, MSW, Linuxes) I find the use of the keyboard crippled. Typing is not the same as on a laptop. Sometimes unexpected things happen like when I backspace and it goes to the top of the third paragraph ABOVE where I am typing. Weird.

Verdict:
Though it came with Ice Cream Sandwich, I love Android. It has its shortcomings, but, overall, I like it. The learning curve and setting thigns up is tiresome, but, it is just a learning curve so I can handle that. However, I am too frustrated with the unreliable keyboard, frustrating trackpad, and sometimes unresponsive screen. The Infinity is going back tomorrow. Perhaps I'll get a smaller Android tablet like the Google 7. Or wait for a system I'm more familiar with like the Linux Vivaldi tablet. Or an ultrabook. But not a tablet kludged into being a netbook. Great idea, good college try, but for me, nah. Not sure if I'll ever convert to the tablet religion.

-* Details *-

Good:
1) Android!
2) luscious screen, very bright
3) Nice sleek form factor, solid build
4) Google Drive kicks A
6) "function" keys, and home row keys are simplistically designed and intuitively understood. This concept is like a perfected page from Apple's own design book, which it did not itself perfect. I love the function keys on this thing.
7) Notifications are great. Love them.
8) incredible battery life
9) File manager. I guess Android does not normally come with a File manager, but, the Infinity does, and it feels like various Linux file managers, ie, for the most part I like it (and it looks fairly nice too).

Bad:
1) Comes with Ice Cream Sandwich, not with Jellly Bean.
2) No flash. Ie - no Amazon video, very little youtube, loading even Google pages is difficult since they use flash heavily. Poor corporate decisions.
3) Lots of configuring to do
4) No built in phone solution
5) no Chrome apps/extensions (like Google Voice etc)
6) lack of keyboard shortcuts
7) whole thing is too big as a tablet, unweildy, and hard to interact with, but as a laptop/netbook it is too small
8) keyboard is sometimes laggy, or doesn't input
9) sometimes tablet and dock do not, well, dock
10) trackpad is sooooo irritating. seriously, I thought trackpad issues came from the hideous driver implementation MSW (terrible trackpad on MSW? install Linux and turn the trackpad into a Mac quality trackpad, so strange). This little bugger enjoys not working as a trackpad.
11) oh and sometimes the screen itself doesn't like touch inputs to browsing. Fail.
12) No terminal. And there's no Google terminal. I am a little too security conscious to install a nonstandard terminal which I am unfamiliar with.

Notes:

Essential changes for my ATI:
1} Chrome for Android / History
Some comment about not being able to view Chrome for Android's history. Here's how:
chrome://history
I bookmarked it.

2) Chrome for Android / erase History
I went to Settings > Advanced > Privacy.
I could not find an option among the group for delete history. In regular Chrome, and Android Browser, this is where you find this item.
I did a search for the information on the internet.
Jeje it was right there all along. For some reason it is up in the top right of the window bar.

Update 2012-0910:

The Worst part of the whole thing is that I keep getting Hostile Comments from (obviously) Asus Employees; who would waste time writing negative responses to a user review? I have bought this tablet to be my first Android tablet and am very surprised at the low quality control of Asus.  The materials are really nice (Metals > Plastics) but the loose touchscreen issue is very apparent.  The first unit made clicking sounds when you press softly on the left side of the touchscreen where it's slightly lifted up, very annoying.  So I requested an exchange with Amazon, got the new 2nd unit and looked it over.  Immediately noticed three small dents on the back metal housing.  This unit screen also have excessive and annoying light bleed that the 1st Infinity didn't have.  The touchscreen is loose in one corner but didn't make clicking noises.  My brother in law bought one couple of days ago and right out of the box the metal backing has a scratch and the screen is loose and clicked in two places when pressed.  I am very disappointed in your quality control Asus.  I really want this tablet as it's the best in specs at the moment but for what I paid I want a quality tablet.  What I and my brother in law got are tablets put together carelessly.  Please fix your QC as it put a very bad taste in my mouth.  Doing a google search for the loose screen issue comes up with many others having the same issue.  I have used and loved Asus products over the years (videocards, motherboards, etc) but just comes to show QC isn't important anymore.  I've returned both Infinities I got and my brother in law returned his as well.

Specifically Words with Friends, Draw Something and the Onstar app. My wife has an iPad3 and we compared videos. Both looked equivalent and excellent. The tablet does what it should, is fast, screen is great, but the GPS reception is still disappointing. I am using it for replacement of paper instrument approaches, VFR Sectionals and IFR Low Enroute charts which it does a great job with... but the GPS will not locate satellites when flying north at all (I live in Florida) and will just hook up to a few if I place the tablet on the glareshield where I cannot see it when flying south.

I am going to return it and get a different one to see if it is a GPS problem for this unit or they are all the same but it maybe be a while 3-4 weeks before I can test it in the plane.

I have been running Garmin Pilot and Aviation Tools Free, downloading the maps at home WIFI and then flying it without WiFi in the plane... No weather and that would cost $800 for the GDL 39 from Garmin... Maybe if Garmin Pilot and the Tablet start working better I will invest in the GDL 39

PS to make the tablet work on WiFi even in the plane, I use my T-Mobile Android phone (HTC Sensation), turn on WiFi Hot Spot on the phone and I then have WiFi in the plane (some times) and the Tablet will hook up to my phone's WiFi and update the weather... but... cell phone reception in the plane is pretty bad.

This is my first android based device, and after owning an iPhone for 4 years now, I gotta say, I really am glad I went with this android based tablet instead of the iPad. Don't get me wrong. I love apple products and own a MacPro, Macbook, iPhone 4S, iPhone 3GS, Airport Extreme, Airport Express, Keyboard and Magic Mouse. But it is nice to get away from the iOS. Though unflawed, it has become a bit boring. I couldn't imagine just having a larger iPhone to play on after playing on my iPhone all day....na mean? The battery life is AMAZING! I charged it for the first time on a Monday night, and normal use (not constantly using it all day long, but all throughout the day) with the keyboard attached for the most part, and it lasted until Thursday night! One of the main reasons I held off on buying a tablet is because I figured that with its bigger screen, in comparison to the iPhone, and considering how much I have to charge my iPhone (about 2-3 times a day), that I would be charging a tablet all day long. Not the case with this tablet. Its a powerhouse! And the brightness is so AMAZING that I barely have to turn it up much. But when you do turn up the brightness...WOW! Overall, I probably keep mine set around the 30% area. This is probably why my battery life lasted for so many days. And as they say with all electronics, the battery life gets better as you go, so I can only imagine! If you plan on buying this tablet I recommend getting the keyboard attachment as well. Not just because of the extended battery life, which it does so well, but also because it doubles as a screen protector when it is closed and a nice stand to hold your tablet up, (although, it is a bit top heavy, so just be careful it doesnt fall over). I winded up buying the Dark Grey colored tablet, but I decided I wanted to get the light gray keyboard instead of the matching color keyboard. I'm glad I did. Not only was the price $50 less, but I think the keys are more visible with the lighter gray background than they would be with the dark color background and dark colored keys. I was afraid it would look stupid at first, but it looks Really good with the contrast of both colors. So even if they were priced the same, I would still go for the lighter gray in the end. I opted for the older 'Prime' keyboard (Asus Transformer Prime TF201 Mobile Docking - Champagne (TF201-DOCK-CG) used...works good as new) after reading reviews that it works with the Infinity despite the claims of Asus that it will not work. I can confirm that it does work and it fits perfectly. I don't feel like I am forcing anything into place. As for the touch responsiveness, some things can be annoying at times, like when surfing the web and clicking links. It seems to press the wrong link a lot. My smaller screened iPhone knows what I am trying to press better than this bigger tablet does at times. Ive been saying this since day one, and it still holds true that nothing compares to the touch sensitivity of Apple's line of touch products. But this isn't too far off. Hopefully I will see even better improvements when Jellybean is released for the Infinity. Fingers crossed. The sound, as others have said, is not that good. I am not a very picky person, but I could barely hear some videos I was watching at times. Especially if there's a YouTube video that was recorded low. I am overall impressed with the app selections. I like that I have an iPhone and an Android Tablet. It makes my world of app selections that much bigger. I recommend this tablet, especially to anyone who owns an iPhone and is in the market for a tablet. Its a nice escape from the usual and it opens up your arsenal to both Apple Apps and Android App worlds. Hope this helped! Enjoy! ***UPDATE Another thing I want to mention that I've haven't seen mentioned much is that this tablet comes with a cloth to wipe down your screen. This is the best finger print removing cloth I have ever owned. I barely even rub it across the screen and its perfectly clear. I also updated my memory with a Samsung 32GB Class 10 MicroSDHC High Speed Memory Card with Komputerbay SD Adapter and SanDisk MobileMate USB Reader. It works great and the price was great too!
This is really a nice tablet.  I have not had a single issue yet.  The display is very nice, it works very quickly and I am happy I went with Anroid and chose an ASUS tablet.

This tablet is way better than the new iPad! Faster, better camera, more customization, and it is much more productive! Comes pre loaded with polaris office, has an SD card slot, and you can attatch a keyboard to it? Hard to beat that

I definitely have always thought that Asus tablets were the most appealing Android tablets available.  They look nice, have the latest features, great specs, and reasonable pricing.  Unfortunately, I have had problems with eight over three different models that were defective.  For the purposes of this review, I'll stick to the TF700.  After setting the tablet up, I noticed two dead pixels rather quickly.  Not good when the display is one of the major items marketed...strike one.  The sound would stop working.  It required a reboot to bring it back each time...strike two.  Performance was poor.  The tablet was very unresponsive when performing simple tasks such as loading web pages...strike three.

On the plus side, it felt nice in the hand and the display was rather bright and looked nice, but ultimately, the display experience was ruined with the dead pixels.

Admittedly, I didn't try a replacement TF700, so perhaps this is an exception rather than the rule, but it matched my experience with their other tablet products, so defects have become my expectation for them.

I can safely say that I won't be supporting Asus any more.

We have had the Infinity for 10 days.  I bought this for my wife but we both use it. This review will have a follow up down the road, new stuff does not weigh in heavily.  I won't bother with all the tech specs, benchmarks and stuff like that because there is enough of it already posted.  I hesitated for two weeks due to the reviews about the glass / frame fit.  Non existent here.

This tablet arrived in perfect condition and appeared to be well constructed.  Right out of the box it was a joy to behold and the software/hardware experience was excellent.  My wife and I both have used this tablet a lot everyday and I have really tried to stress it.  I am very familiar with the ipad3/ios.  My kids have them and they are nice but I really like this baby.  Smooth, fast and responsive.

HD vids look great and I don't experience lag.  I converted a HD video to MP4 and it was flawless.  The resolution is stunning and the ipad is the only thing that can beat this screen but my eyes can't tell the difference between the two.  The Infinity has so much more going for it in regard to upgradable memory on the tablet and the dock.

GPS is excellent and I get a good signal indoors too.  Wifi = excellent.  I have used PDAnet / Foxfi to have wireless ( 3G ) connection via my cellphone when I am away from a Wifi connection.  Works good as long as you have a good 3G/4G phone connections.

Apps.... well they are coming and there are some good ones out there.  I like the stock book reader and the Kindle app does just fine with mobie files.  I like reading books on the Infinity better than our Kindle Fire because you have more page / text.  But we still like the Fire too.  The tapered edges take getting used to for book reading.  The Fire handles like a small heavy book and this feels like a tapered glass slate.

This is great for email, IM, talk apps and video calling much better than any phone.  The cameras are the best of any tablet I've seen.  I have been waiting on the Windows tablets and phones for over a year now and I think I might just get another Infinity since it will be the end of the year before they debut and I never buy anything that is new to the market.  I always give it some upgrade time as I did with this.  The first transformers were crap but this Infinity is just great right now.  I will give this tab some more abuse time and tell all. By then I will have two Infinity tablets to compare and give everyone our findings.

Most everything ASUS says about this tablet is true.  I've got 3 ASUS laptops (new to 3 yrs old) and now this.  So far I've had very good luck with my ASUS technology. I had one bump with an early EeePC.  The screen pixilated and to my surprise ASUS fixed and returned it fast.  I had read where ASUS support was lacking at times.

My gripes so far:  You have to use a usb dock adapter on the tablet specific to ASUS.
Speakers are sort of lacking.  You can hear fine as long as you cup your right hand behind the right side where the speaker is.  You need externals or a good set of ear-buds if you are watching a movie.

Alive time is great.  I've pulled 7 busy hours with a 1.5 hr HD movie mixed in and still had plenty of time left for emails and general browser stuff.  I would like to know about how long the LI battery will last and how much of a hassle it will be to have another one put in.

I say if you want a good tablet and you want to chance it on a 10 day simple review then get this thing.  I am very happy with it and I am rather critical about equipment. This thing rocks, holds its own to the ipad3, AND you get much more versatility with this Infinity.

My first tablet was a Motorola Zoom. This new Asus TF700 blows it away on every point. With the keyboard attached the onboard memory capacity is unsurpassed by anything out there. The screen is crisp, bright and useable in sunlight. Touch is fast, accurate and responsive. Wifi connects fast and has decent range. GPS is off by 10 feet but plenty good enough for navigating. My Zoom was scary accurate. Battery is on par with most other tablets and the keyboard dock does add half again as much life. I must recommend getting the keyboard with the tablet. It will allow you to use thumbdrives, larger SD cards and pocket drives. This is definitely the best android tablet out there.

I am a previous owner of the Prime now used by my wife instead of her Fire, and current owner of the Infinity.  The tablet is great and has almost replaced my laptop.  At work I use both the tablet and the laptop, preferring a multiple display workstation that the laptop supports.  At home I can do just about everything on just the tablet.  The differences between the Prime and Infinity are subtle.  Higher resolution, and much better GPS performance.  For most applications, you don't notice the resolution difference between the models.  The keyboard dock for the Prime also fits the Infinity.  I made the mistake of buying the new dock thinking it was different, but the factory box clearly showed both tablets use the dock.  I rarely use the dock unless travelling without a laptop.  The display is bright enough to use in direct sunlight, and automatically adjusts to light conditions if using the auto mode.  My Prime cases also fit the Infinity.  I saw other reviews suggesting they were different and couldn't be interchanged.

I am very happy with both tablets.
This tablet is great with everything because it supports Full HD and has gorilla glass 2. All it need is to update to android 4.1 jelly bean.

So everyone has a lot to say about the best Android tablet (currently) on the market.  I'm not going to bore you with the technical details of the tablet.  I waited to purchase a tablet for a long time.  This would have been the perfect tablet except it only has one speaker which is covered by your right hand when holding it (in landscape mode).  Very few tablets have the speakers on the front (like the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2) where they belong.  I loved everything about this tablet (the speed and especially the screen) but since I was shelling out top dollar, the single speaker was not acceptable to me so it was returned.  Sure, I could wear headphones but I'm not 15 anymore.  If Asus would only listen and learn, they would have had a real winner here!

Well let say it is better than Apple iPad .....only in the things that iPad can't do... for example downloading torrents or playing materials in a dope flash....other than these things it not a match for the perfection of the iPad... it crashes alot ...and it has poor  gesture sensitivity....thou  it good for watching movies thanks to it wide screen.

I have used iphone3G, iphone4 and new ipad ...even though apple's build quality is great, i am not a fan of itunes, sync and usual apple tricks to keep your hands tied.

Decided to make a move to android...wanted to buy a tablet for myself...waited for prime in dec11-jan12 timeframe, reviews are not so great, then came the anouncement for the new HD tablet, so decided to wait, after infinity release waited for a while, this time not so many negative reviews...more on the positive side, so placed the order and got the tablet delivered by amazon on 8/8.

Rushed home...opened the package, my first impressions are not so great. Finish on the back of the product had some minor scratches..plastic strip with camera also had some finishing issues...glass on the top shows bend in places where camera, micro sdcard slot and charge port exist, also glass not set properly on the lower left corner...not something you would expect on the 500$ price tag product.

Decided to overlook the cosmetic issues and started the tablet...charged fully as recommended. Played with it for a while..display is very good...speed is very good...installed the microsd card and it got recognized with no issues...able to read/write stuff into sd card. Configured emails...facebook etc...etc...all good, for issues list: had lag when moving between pages/screens...weather widget failed to refresh all the time...even outdoors...except that everything else was good, until yesterday morning...wokeup and started checking emails on the device..suddenly screen started showing black thick link in the middle of the device running from left to right in the landscape mode...initially thought it to be some software issue or screen refresh issue, moved across applications, still line is seen, rebooted the tablet, still seeing the line...rebooted multiple times after waiting few mins between shutdown and startup...still no luck...frustrated with this experience on the brand new tablet, chatted with amazon representative...got return labels for the tablet and the cover, dropped them in UPS during lunch...keeping the sdcard..so that i can use it for my next tablet...

Exactly after 8 days of usage...screen issues...who will expect this...along with the other cosmetic issues i mentioned above on the brand new product...ASUS have to come a long way in the quality department...with that said... I am not going to try another asus product again...and pass on my experience to all my friends who put quality on top of the list...

In one way, I am glad it broke sooner...than later. I am travelling overseas for a month and it would have been a hell lot of problems returning this piece of crap, if it had broke during my travel...bye bye to ASUS...

Now I am wondering about all the happy positive reviews...either people got a really good piece (or) they have never owned/tried a real quality product...

Now I have no tablet...i don't want to go back to ipad...checked the new samsung note 10.1 with no HD screen and all plastic build...not sure what to do....for now I am not very happy....

I love this tablet!

A smartphone is extraneous to my needs, so I had no prior experience with this type of device.

I got the tablet on July 23, and learn something new about it daily.  I have downloaded books and games mostly, but some other apps as well.  This device has exceeded my expectations.

Before purchasing, I did extensive research and came to the conclusion that this is the BEST Android device on the market.  I have no complaints about its operation and function and versatility.

I have had to contact customer care with app questions, and have received prompt, courteous replies.

My desktop PC is 8 years old.  When I get a new PC, it will most likely be an ASUS.

Overall a great tablet, I was moving from a 1st Gen IPad, as I have most of my purchased apps on Google Play was a no brainier, I admit is not for everyone as you have to buy on the platform as much as on the tablet. But I think that right now this is the best android tablet around.

The Screen es beautiful and the big internal memory (32GB in the one I bought) plus the microsd card is the way to go, that was the deal killer with the nexus 7. has a nice felling and I could handle it for long period of time.

the downsides this tablet as apparently other tegra 3 tablets overheats a bit. not to the extreme to be uncomfortable, but is noticeable. also as the sides are curved the custom connection don't have a way to set solidly, because this the metal around the connector can get bent and the connection may brake if forced.

The placement of the speaker also is a problem as that is the location that your hand usually goes when you are holding it on landscape mode. and being on the back of the tablet the sound goes away from you. making the headphones a necessity.

I read more reviews than I can count regarding this tablet, the good and the bad.  Before I go any further, I am the IT Director for my company, just to set the stage.  At $500 purchasing this was a major decision.  I don't mind laying out the cash, especially if it will assist me in my job duties.  First, as far as the negative reviews of this item are concerned, I'm not sure what was expected.  Due to complaints about the screen flexing on the edges when squeezed, I decided to purchase locally.  I have seen what shipping companies can due to a package regardless of how careful the sellers may package the product.  In any case, the TF700 was rock solid out of the box, no give, and no flex.  Bleeding at the bottom edge has also been a concern, and I did notice some, but nothing more than some light reflection, and no real issue.  I only noticed this at boot up on a totally black screen, and don't consider it an issue.  Battery life, most report about 7 hours give or take.  I have a lap top that cost 6 times this TF700 and would love to see 7 hours of battery life out of it.  That said, I turned on everything that I could find, Performance Mode, Highest Screen Resolution, Blue Tooth, etc.  With these setting you will get no where near 7 hours, but then again I didn't see any real need for these, maybe in special circumstances or occasionally, but not consistently at least for me.  Unexpected shutdowns have also been reported.  I wonder about this.  Out of the box, the unit is set to go to sleep after 1 minute of inactivity.  I suspect that like most computers, this tablet measures activity by touch.  In other words, a computer measures activity by keyboard stroke or mouse movement.  Downloading or video streaming is not seen as activity on the part of the computer.  I suspect the TF700 measures activity by screen touch or keyboard activity if you have one.  The sleep setting can be increased or turned off completely.  On the plus side, the TF700 is everything that the positive reviews claim.  Enough said!  So why did I take it back.  As I said, I work IT, and I don't play games either on my computer or my tablet.  I do read a book or sometimes watch a movie.  The TF700 is flawless for these purposes, and I suspect it is just as good at playing games.  The display resolution is great.  For business related IT issues however, there were some problems.  Some if not all of these were not actually related to the TF700.  Cisco provides a free AnyConnect app on Google Play.  I use this application on my computers all the time.  What Cisco doesn't tell you is that while the app is free connecting to an ASA is not.  For some reason, "PURE GREED", Cisco wants you to purchase a license for each firewall you wish to connect to.  Ten firewalls means ten licenses.  Why this need for a license is completely confusing.  You can get Cisco AnyConnect all day long and attach to your ASA for free using a computer.  Why they think they should charge for tablet access is as I said, "PURE GREED".  The workaround for this would have been to get a VPN Client, which there are many out there.  Unfortunately, I couldn't get any of them to work successfully, we use a IPsec/UPD configuration and maybe this is the reason.  Finally, the TF700 consistently gets compared with the IPad.  At least in my area there is a significant difference in price.  People who love Apple will undoubtedly say that there is a reason for this.  I looked at the new IPad as well as the TF700 and didn't really see anything that justified the extra expense.  Don't get me wrong, Apple makes a fine product, but the Brand Name comes with a cost.  For the average user the TF700 is a solid 5 as far as my rating.  I gave it a 4 due to business related concerns.  If you want a tablet for general use, this is a great product.  If you want it for business related items, be cautious and check exactly what you are expecting it to do, as well as app availability.

For me, this tablet acts as a glorified pdf reader; which is probably a bit of overkill considering the specs. In terms of hardware, the device is well built:
(Pros)
- It's fast; pretty smooth for playing games
- GPS and WiFi function well
- The super IPS display allows me to read in most bright locations
- Lasts 6-8 hours on average
- The android platform is a much nicer system to deal with in terms of transferring files.
- Asus provides its own jailbreaker for the device.

(Cons)
I have a few minor complaints, but it wouldn't stop me from picking up this tablet.
- The gorilla glass display is not flush with the casing; for me, this is still a non-issue.
- The top corner under the ASUS logo heats up when playing games; I'm guessing this is where the harddrive is. It's a little uncomfortable, but a thin leather case mitigates that.
- It's not easy to mount the tablet on a Linux computer even though Android is based on Linux...
- It's not easy to mount the device in debug/developer mode.

For me, the pros outweigh the cons, and it's still one of the top 3 tablets out there.

This is the tablet that I have been waiting for... literally and figuratively!  It has the power, the speed and the durability that a tablet should have.  What a great item!  Its about time Asus, Great Job!

I got this tablet for work to kill two birds with one stone- getting a laptop replacement and an android test device for the price of a low end laptop.
The primary use is email and rdp support (applications support and even software development by rdp on a remote PC).
The secondary use being for testing mobile web and application software.

So far I have been very impressed with the Tablet. It works smoothly and has few lags, in spite of using an active desktop (I am not one for frills usually, but the floating ice cubes one shows battery status by the water level on screen, which I thought both cool and useful).

Sure, there is the odd thing that is not perfect- stability when using in the docking station, a very slight sponginess on the screen at one point on one edge (very minor and causes absolutely no problems, but just noticeable).

I am using the Infinity as primarily a work machine, so I have not delved deep into things like video support and playback. What I can say is that it does what I need it to, and what I bought it for very well. The screen resolution is great- I can rdp into my desktop PC at full resolution and work in a visual studio like environment. It is obviously not as good as being in front of the PC, but the ability to pinch and zoom the view means that it is actually more productive than the wide screen Laptop it replaces. I am using the Jump rdp software, and have worked 3 rdp sessions deep (rdp to pc to server to VM) with no problems.

Another thing I have found surprisingly good is the Supernote software that came pre-installed. When combined with a stylus pen this has made taking handwritten notes viable. (I had tried earlier versions of tablets and found them to be insufficiently responsive to properly write on).

Battery life has been everything promised. I was caught at home having run down to about 10% battery only to find I had left the charger at work, then had two overnight support calls which took somewhere between 30 min and an hour in total to resolve. The Infinity coped with this and still had some charge left to check email in the morning.

On its own, I don't know if I would have gone for the tablet- for what I am doing, but when combined with the keyboard dock it is a real winner. The keyboard is not fantastic, but is about what I would expect given the size- more than adequate for what I use it for. Having USB is great, as being able to use a mouse for fine RDP work is a bonus.

All in all, if the rating system allowed I would give a 4 1/2 star to the product.

Its already fast given some time for development this thing is going to fly..

I was fortunate to be able to compare the Prime and Infinity tablets side-by-side at Office Depot before purchase. The Infinity's display is much brighter and clearer than the Prime's--the increased pixel density gives the Infinity a greatly improved display. The Infinity continues the Prime's thin, strong, lightweight design but adds a small plastic strip along the back to improve antenna action for wifi and GPS. This doesn't detract from the tablet's appearance IMO.

So far I've encountered no issues (as described by some others) with wifi connections to either my home network (even at over 50 feet from the modem) or to my HTC mobile phone hotspot. I've seen only one Internet glitch in a couple of days' testing: The New York Times website froze with a partly blank screen and had to be closed and reopened for browsing. Other than that, Internet access and downloads seem fast and smooth.

The Infinity's GPS/Google Location services work flawlessly with Google Maps. Coupled with the high-resolution display, this is why I bought this tablet, and I'm looking forward to taking it with me on the road.

One sour note, though: the so-called 8MP camera on the Infinity is nowhere near the quality it should be, as compared to my HTC Thunderbolt's 8MP camera. (It's not just the larger tablet display: I've uploaded pictures from both devices to my desktop computer for comparison.) Seriously, this tablet's camera pictures resemble those of the earliest flip camera phones...were those VGA? I exchanged the tablet after one day because of this issue, but both Infinity tablets I've tested have poor camera quality. Admittedly, the camera is not why I bought this tablet. But the best camera is (or should be) the one in your hand when you need it, and it's too bad the Infinity's camera has such poor resolution--particular if you try to zoom in at all. Also, when you record video, the sound drops out to zero rather than recording continuously during low sound levels. The panorama feature works smoothly, but again is impaired by the overall poor picture quality.

Actually, I'll add another sour note: pictures load low-resolution and then reload stripe by stripe into high resolution--even the pictures that are preloaded in the Infinity's memory. I'm hoping I don't encounter this when I try reviewing my DSLR camera pictures in the field on this tablet, but I think I probably will see it there also. If I were interested in gaming or watching movies on the Infinity, I'd be concerned about this slow graphics rendering. However, HD YouTube videos seem to stream smoothly.

About the docking keyboard: on the advice of many reviewers, and because Office Depot had only Prime keyboards in stock, I tried pairing the Infinity with the Prime docking station. It fit, but very tightly (tight enough to scratch the screen protector I'd put on the tablet). So I've ordered the docking station designed for the Infinity from Amazon. Its extra battery power will be welcome because the Infinity tablet does indeed, as others have noted, have a short battery life (not in standby but in actual use).

I'm pleased with the lack of bloatware on the Infinity tablet.

Yes, as other reviewers have noted, the speaker sound quality is poor. That's why the tablet has a headset jack and Bluetooth. One should not expect fine sound quality from a tiny little speaker.

One thing to note: I was able to install Flash on my Infinity. However, it appears that Flash will no longer be available for download to devices that don't already have it after August 15, 2012, and will not be available for download to Android devices with OS versions higher than 4.0.x (translation: Jelly Bean and later). We'll see how this battle between Adobe and Google plays out.

Overall, I recommend this tablet for its excellent, clear, bright, and smooth display of Internet content and maps, but don't count on getting nice pictures with its camera.

Update 8/14/12: I received the Infinity docking keyboard today. As others have noted, it's clearly labeled as a TF201T or TF700T dock, and the internal model number is TF201. However, it does fit my tablet better than the Prime-labeled dock. What's interesting is that I tested the dock's USB connection to my precious DSLR camera, and that works fine: I can review my photography results on the Infinity's high-quality display, with only a tiny, almost imperceptible graphics rendering delay for 16MB picture files. But I also ordered the ASUS "dongle" to attach a USB device directly to the tablet, and that does NOT work to connect my DSLR camera to the tablet. So I'm very glad to have that dock.

UPDATE: I've had my Infinity a few weeks now, so I can offer a better impression of the tablet.

Overall, this is a very good tablet, but it still has some of the same issues that have plagued Android tablets since the beginning.

First the good:

- The screen resolution is outstanding.
- Video playback is excellent.
- The processor is snappy and responsive.
- It has more than enough on-board storage memory for most tasks, making an SD card almost redundant unless you plan to store large amounts of large files.
- The interface is good.
- ASUS is very good about pushing updates.
- The speaker is adequate for its size and positioning.

And then the bad:

- The battery life is average--which is to say mediocre--under regular use. (This problem is solved using the docking station)
- Like most Android tablets, it does not have enough RAM and gets bogged down under heavier use (though, interestingly, not during video playback)
- The WiFi antenna is terrible as with most tablets.
- Most of the bundled software is useless.
- The Android task manager is useless. (This is not really an Infinity problem but it is really annoying)

Overall, I would recommend this tablet to anyone looking for a higher end device, especially if you're going to use it for video playback or gaming.

-----

ORIGINAL: I've had my Infinity for a few days now, so this review is a first impression.

The tablet is solid and, as a result, a little heavy compared to the Galaxy Tab 10.1 that I am comparing it to. The screen resolution is outstanding and, so far, things like video playback live up to the hype this tablet got when it was released. This tablet is much, much faster that the previous generation and is able to handle complex tasks like running remote desktop sessions without too much trouble.

The battery suffers a little under heavy usage, but it charges quickly and seems to hold up well under average daily use.

My only complaints so far are with the bloatware Asus (and most manufacturers) feel the need to heap on their products and with the docking station mechanism.

So far, so good.
