My wife bought the ASUS Transformer Infinity for my birthday.  I opened it tonight and it was dented next to the left dock latch point.  This caused the glass to bow out in this part of the screen.  The packaging was fine and the box was perfect so I think this happened during manufacture but shipped from ASUS anyway.  I'd read about some quality issues from ASUS and bad support but figured that was a small percentage of customers with a big voice.  Now I'm not so sure.  It shipped from Circuit City (via Amazon order) and looks like we'll be paying for shipping back to CC as well.  You may want to buy local so you can take it back if you have quality issues too.

UPDATE:
I received my second TF700.  This unit doesn't have a dented frame but the glass is separated just as bad (in about the same location).  I can pinch the unit and the glass bends back into place and bows back out when I let go (it doesn't creak like some do).  Gregg, I turned this unit on and it has very bad light bleed (especially where the glass is separated).  Check out the pictures I'll include in the 32G TF700 item photos.  Forums say both of these are common problems.  This one shipped from Amazon rather than CC.  I don't want to hassle with returning the new mobile dock, micro SD card and 3 cases my wife bought me so I'll keep this unit.  Based on my experiences, ASUS is not capable of shipping a tablet with build quality to match other tablet/pad manufacturers.  Again, if you want a unit with decent fit/finish, buy at a brick and mortar store and open it before you leave.

UPDATE2:
Today (9/14 - a month and a day after taking delivery) I noticed the glass is separating on the right side of the screen too and makes a popping sound when I pinch and let go of it there.  I also hate where they put the headphone jack because it's on the lower left corner (right where you hold the tablet).  I can't patch this flaw with either of my Bluetooth devices because video lags audio from the TF700 over Bluetooth only.  Both devices work perfectly with my phone and PC.  I also, can't copy files to the TF700's microSD card because it freezes and reboots itself every time (after the update that should have fixed this).  Again, these are all common problems when I visit forums.

I waited many months for this tablet to come out and the wait was definitely worth it. Those of you who are sensitive to the price, it's worth every penny of it. The docking station gives you so many other options, about 4-5 hours of extended run time, USB port, etc. An excellent case of the tablet/keyboard combination is made by minisuit available here.
I love this tablet, personally i think it has the appeal of an IPAD but better because it is android.... love it

I have no complaints, cant put it down. I love stuff. I have been waiting for this tablet. Glad I choose it over the apple. Great buy, worth the money. Light weight, 2nd day owning it, battery still good with out charging. I have been listening to music, blue tooth and reg downloads . Since I got it. Kids also playing games. Long battery life. Great choice

I was deciding between the Nexus 7 and the Transformer Infinity for my first tablet purchase. The iPad was out because of the closed ecosystem, and I have already paid for android apps on my phone that will scale up well once installed on the tablet. The Nexus 7 was almost a no brainer for me, it has a great price, quad-core processor, amazing screen and great software support from Google except for the lack of

1. MicroSD expandability (gameloft games on average take up at least 2 gigs of internal memory)
2. HDMI-out (with apps like Netflix, Hulu plus, and HBO go not to mention flash support, being able to output that to a TV screen is a huge plus)

For about twice as much as the Nexus 7, the Infinity offers a higher resolution screen that's also brighter powered by a top of the line quad core processor. It also includes a microSD slot, 8 mp camera, microHDMI out and the ability to expand via a mobile docking station that adds additional battery life, full sized USB OTG support and a SD slot. I have to say that all the additional features are worth the extra premium. I don't have to worry about storage space and the tablet functions much like a laptop replacement for me. If you're on the fence between the two, I'd say go for the Infinity.

So I read all the expert reviews, and I have to agree that this is the best android device I've used. it's my first tablet (have android phone), but I am impressed with what it had out of the box wrt apps, and there is abrely any lag at all! This is by no means an expert review but a quick summary of my user experience after 24 hrs

Pros
- GREAT display - watching videos or browsing the web or pics is a pleasure on this (and I can use flash still!)
- very fast performance with little to no lag in switching apps 9with up to 6 or 7 multitasking)
- apps all behave smoothly
- light weight, even with the dock
- great battery life esp with the dock basically charging your tablet!
- camera is good (though I haven't really tested it)
- convenient flexibility - I've been able to use microSDHC cards, SD cards, USB flash drives (via the dock) and this has allowed me to sideload content far easier than any syncing!

Cons

- none so far except maybe the dearth of apps. Personally this doesn't bother me as I use few apps on my phone - I've never been one to have hundreds. A few dozen fulfill my needs, but I can understand where it may frustrate others especially to find tablet-optimized HD apps

Neutrals

- the sound is so-so. Personally I don't expect a device this small to have great sound anyway, but it is a bit muffled and just about acceptable volume for you an another few persons close by, but don't plan to sue this for any talks! I think a suggestion would be to add another speaker or include speakers in the dock. The sound is great via earphones though

I don't write many reviews, but I have to say this.  I got home from work today and my brand new $600 Asus TF700 was sitting on the porch.  I'm not sure who to blame, Amazon or Prestige shipping.  I just think that's kind of an expensive device to leave sitting on someones porch.  But, I do have to say the tablet is nice.  Setup was easy and took about 10 minutes.  Now I'm just letting it charge a bit before I really start to play.

So, this being my fourth Android device in a little over two years and having relatively high expectations given the mostly glowing reviews here, I was definitely looking forward to receiving this new tablet.

However, having used an HTC Flyer for nearly a year (that was ruined by the incompatible Honeycomb "upgrade"), I find it annoying having a speaker only on the right side of the ASUS TF700T.  Unless you put the tablet into portrait position or hold your hand on the right side in landscape to deflect the sound more to the middle, it sounds like the (non-existent) left speaker is broken.  I don't usually listen to my music with the left channel shut off or with only the right ear bud in my right ear, so this is especially frustrating on this tablet model given that the screen itself is quite nice visually.  If I do return it, it will probably be due to the inexplicably poor speaker placement, limited volume output, and less than stellar audio quality even with expensive headphones and equalizer apps.  At this price point (I bought the 64GB), as an audiophile and music lover, I am not satisfied with the disappointing sound features.  The overall build quality is also taken down a couple notches by the cheap feeling plastic volume and power buttons, and the proprietary and flimsy power adapter connector (no direct USB without the dock??).  Yes, the full HD screen is really nice, especially for viewing high resolution photos, but the other downsides may be a deal breaker.

Even my old HTC Flyer has the stereo speakers in the center, but with enough of a raise in the rear profile of the case so that the sound is nearly evenly distributed in landscape mode even when lying flat.  While I do have the nice Bose portable bluetooth speaker, it's not practical to carry it around everywhere all the time to compensate for the TF700T's lousy sound.  What was ASUS thinking?

I've read the XDA discussion about this tablet's DAC, so I'm not the only one who hoped for more from this tablet.  It would be nice to know if there is a better Android tablet choice available in terms of sound quality that still has a decent display, whether 7" or 10".

File this one in the "so very close but so very far" category.  How this can arguably be the best Android tablet on the market for this kind of money is just sad.

*** UPDATE - 08/04/12 - Item returned due mainly to poor quality sound design.  Will wait until something better is released for this kind of crazy money for a tablet.  Manufacturers are you listening?  Please, offer a device with a good DAC and decent stereo speakers with this kind of a gorgeous display and I and others will gladly buy it.

I sold my Toshiba Thrive 10.1-Inch 32 GB Android Tablet AT105-T1032 Black recently and upgraded to the Transformer Infinity 64GB. Why? I'm writing a novel, and needed to be able to create portions of the narrative on a tablet with a keyboard. I am in an environment where I cannot risk my Macbook Pro while out and about, so I write snippets of my story on the Infinity and then transfer them back into the laptop later. For that purpose, the Infinity is excellent. It is also thinner, lighter and better designed than the Thrive. It is peppier, and Asus, unlike Toshiba, is excellent about releasing operating system updates. My only complaint about the unit is that the screen does not look good when displaying solid black - some of the corners are grayish instead. There are no dead pixels. With the Asus Transformer Infinity TF700T Mobile Docking - Amethyst Gray (TF700T-DOCK-GR), this little tablet is a marvelous wonder of productivity enhancing excellence. I use it for writing, reading and music and it serves excellently for all three. I also use it as a white noise generator with this app:White Noise. I've unlocked and rooted the tablet, which is relatively easy compared to some others on the market. May void your warranty - I am not responsible for anything that goes wrong. Amazon apparently doesn't want me linking to rooting and unlocking sites (they removed my links) so I'll give the following hints: Google "unlock Transformer Infinity" and you'll get a link to an .apk file on the Asus web site. To root the Infinity, Google [ROOT][TOOL]Debugfs automated root and you should find the top hit at XDA developers. If you don't know what unlocking and rooting are, you should probably do some research before trying either, as you can end up with a very expensive paper weight if you are not careful. The apps Asus ships with the Infinity are mostly very useful. In particular, I found Polaris Office to be quite handy for opening Word and Excel documents and editing them from the tablet using the keyboard. I highly recommend the Apex Launcher app as well, as it is a bit more elegant than the stock ICS launcher. EDIT: A few other thoughts. I also purchased the ASUS Transformer Prime TF201-B1-CG 10.1-Inch 32GB Tablet (Champagne) at the same time I purchased the Transformer Infinity. There are some minor design differences, but for all intents and purposes, the Prime is identical to the Infinity. The differences I noticed before I sold the Prime to a very happy buyer were that wireless range is slightly shorter on the Prime (there is a plastic antenna strip on the Infinity because the all metal case on the Prime caused wireless problems for some users). The screen on the Prime is lower resolution, but the picture actually looked identical to my eye. The Prime did not have the lighter areas in the corners - I believe this has to do with the bonding process used to attach the LED screen to the Corning Gorilla Glass. The Infinity has a slightly tapered back. The keyboard docking station for the Prime and Infinity are interchangeable. If budget is a concern, there is no compelling reason to spend more for the Infinity, unless you are particularly concerned about the range of the Wifi. I got about 30% more range with the Infinity. EDIT 2: Here are the other items that I bought to go with the tablet: Asus Transformer Infinity TF700T Mobile Docking - Amethyst Gray (TF700T-DOCK-GR) Poetic Asus Transformer Pad Infinity TF700 Leather Keyboard Portfolio Stand Case Cover for TF700 Brown SanDisk 32GB microSDHC Memory Card (Bulk Package) EDIT 3: The Infinity tablet and docking station/keyboard comes in two color schemes. Champagne is actually sort of silvery-yellow, and is sometimes described as gold. Gray is actually slightly purplish and dark. Neither color description reminds me of the actual tablet/keyboard color. Make sure you match them up if you are buying both parts, and remember - champagne is light and gray is dark. Some vendors do not describe the colors accurately, so make sure you know which you are getting if color matters to you. Docking station/keyboard review is here: http://www.amazon.com/review/R6UTZZWNHAG7Q/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm

I ordered this the day it became available and Amazon shipped two days later. I am writing this review after using my tablet for two weeks. This is a great tablet.  The brightness level lets you read outside in almost direct sunlight, although the glass is a bit too reflective and shiny when outside.  Indoors is no problem.  The TF700 finds and locks onto WiFi connections with ease and the GPS locks onto multiple satellites quickly even indoors. The tablet is fast and the only lagging I have found was due to the software I used to borrow books from my local library. The touch screen is very responsive.  The battery drains a bit fast when on-line or playing games (though much more slowly than my wife's Kindle Fire) but lasts at least nine hours when offline. It charges quickly.  The tablet is light and easy to hold and it looks good. The high resolution display is fantastic. I noticed the only time the case became hot was when I was charging and surfing the web simultaneously.  If you do one or the other, the tablet stays cool. A number of useful apps and widgets are included. Internal storage is 32GB and you can add another 32GB micro SD card.  I use my card for backups.  You also get Asus cloud storage and can connect a USB flash drive or connect to an external PC through the dock/power supply connector (cable included).  The manual included with the tablet is sparse and basically useless, but you can download the full manual from Asus Support and, while not perfect, it provides much more information, especially for the included apps.

This is my first exposure to Android (and my first tablet) and I have found ICS to be intuitive and easy to use.  We all know that the Android app store is small in comparison with Apple, but I found all of the apps I wanted at the Google Play Store and Tablified Market.  The selection may be small, but you probably can find what you want there.

My only complaints are trivial: - the small plastic connector cover for the dock/power connector falls off easily and the screen is a fingerprint magnet (Asus includes a cleaning cloth).  Using a stylus helps.

I choose the Asus over an iPad for several reasons, including (for the TF700): 32 GB on board storage, DDR3 RAM, a fast clocked Tegra 3, SD card slot, USB port (inexpensive USB f/f adaptor needed for some interfaces), Adobe Flash, cool operating temperature, and screen customization capability with ICS, all at a lower cost than a 32GB iPad without these features.  I did a side to side visual comparison with the iPad retina display and the TF700 and honestly could not see any difference.

If you want a fast, well executed tablet I highly recommend considering the TF700 before you make your decision.

I love this near perfect tablet. The full HD screen is awesome and it's a joy to view videos on it. The build quality is great. Its light in weight although I never really concern myself with that when it comes to tablets. The speaker sound is nice but two speakers should have been put onto the Infinity. One is unacceptable in my eyes. I am an amateur photographer so I'd rather draw a picture of a subject than take a photo of it with a tablet. How rediculous is it to snap photos with a tablet?? Very, I must say. However, for those of you who don't mind using the Infinity to take pics, it does take decent photos.

The update that was released recently has fixed the SD issue with 64gb cards. They now work flawlessly in the Infinity. The recent update also made the Infinity a bit more responsive as well. As some users have noted, the browser crashes or becomes non responsive from time to time which is aggravating to me. This should get fixed with a future update or when the Infinity gets Jelly Bean.

all i have to say is thanks amazon!  this asus tablet is the ultimate out there so far loving it. it has and does what other reviews on here said can do, lots of pros n a few cons. nothig else to say about it. but i suggest people just buy it its worth the price.
This is my first Tablet. I wanted one that was as bright as possible for use out doors when I needed it. So far everything has run with out any problems at all.

I've been dreaming of this device for 10+ years.  I've been running android phones, starting with the Droid about 3 years ago.  Android has improved greatly, as well as the ecosystem, to make this device perfect.  This device blows my Samsung Nexus Prime out of the water in terms of performance.

Physically - build quality is 99% of Apple (the buttons are ever so slightly less refined than apple's).  In terms of subjective usability it is completely on par with the new iPad.

What is really unique are the apps that this device enables.  Offline, moving map and imagery for off-road navigation; works great.  Music library control that's easy to operate as you drive; check.

One final note - Google Earth is ABSOLUTELY AWESOME on this device.  In terms of performance and appearance, this is how GE was meant to be enjoyed.  Even on my Samsung Nexus Prime, it is not nearly as responsive.

Brief review after owning it for a week and 1/2.

Pros: Convenience and portability (smaller than an average folder). Battery lasted about 7 hrs and 20 mins (for the first week). Heat is not as hot compared to a laptop. There are plenty of free apps to use. After a firmware update, I noticed a slight improvement in app response. It has an external microSD slot and 8 mp back facing camera. I enjoy the keyboard swipe feature.

Cons: Too many open browsers tabs will slow down responses. I've had the occasional freezing/crashing/lagging/random shutdown and muted sound while using it. The touch screen sensitivity can be too sensitive or have no/delayed response. Videoclips can take long too load. Playing games may cause the back of the top left corner to heat up uncomfortably. The edges of the Gorilla corning glass is not glued down properly, so it will creak when pressed down. The battery life has sharply decreased down to just 4 hrs and 10 mins (even though I have the power saving mode and auto brightness on).

Other thoughts: I take great care with my electronic toys, so maybe I got a defective ASUS product... Perhaps getting a stylus will improve the touch sensitivity. I may wait for further firmware updates and Jellybean To determine the value of this product. Overall, I like using this Android tablet when it works. But when it shows problems, I question whether I should have spent my hard earn 500 dollars on it was worth it.

I really love this product, its only the 2nd day i have had it but it runs smoothly, the real reason i got this tablet was for supernote, so i woouldnt have to lugg my computer to classes or around on campus, this is worth the buy. A few of my fraternity brothers have ipads, Specs to specs this tablets blows the ipad out of the water, and they're about that. Get this tablet!! Just wait until jellybean 4.1 hits the market!!!

Great looking tablet and works well. The only downside is that the response is occasionally sluggish. I think these issues are being addressed in the Android 4.1 release. Looking forward to that. Other than that this tablet is (IMO) as good or better than the iPad.

One other minor issue the relative absence of good cases/cover for this tablet. I did put an order for one though there was hardly any choice.

Pros:
The screen resolution is amazing.
Front and back cameras for photos and video chatting.
HDMI out is nice.

Cons:
Non standard USB plug for charging (I need to find a way to extend it... my usb extension cable when attached with the ASUS power cable does not charge the tablet)
Not running Jelly Bean... yet.
Buy the T201 keyboard, since the TF700T keyboard is the same exact keyboard, just repackaged and sold at a higher price (lame).

Honestly, the first couple of days was a little disappointing due to the i/o issue. Asus just released .26 update that solved it!!! I was about to return it until the update was received ota.

Overall, very snappy and fast, no lags anymore, gorgeous screen, great gaming experience, and the dock is just brilliant.
Im using mine for school mainly (taking summer school atm) i record all my teachers lectures. Great quality camera, not a single issue. 1080p recordings are beautiful. I use 720p mostly since is a lecture. Also, it doesnt get too hot, not even gaming, very important

Highly recommended.

I'd been waiting for this tablet to come out for several months, and am not the least bit disappointed. I had a few issues with the micro SD card, but they have already been solved with a new firmware release. If you're looking for a powerful Android tablet this is a great pick, and the optional keyboard dock is really appreciated by my wife who hates typing on virtual keyboards (I don't mind them, but hate losing the screen real estate). This will serve as an excellent laptop replacement for me on shorter trips.

I really like the tablet and haven't had any of the build quality issues mentioned in other reviews.  It feels solidly built and the performance has been fantastic.  That being said I am having 2 issues.  The first is that some apps are not working properly or at all on the tablet (WWF & DirecTV app for instance).  And the ASUS MyLibrary crashes, locks up, and rus slowly sometimes.  Also, hyperlinks in EPUB documents aren't functioning in MyLibrary.  I am working with ASUS on this and will provide updates on the outcome.

So how many of us purchased the Prime in 2011 and then in January the Pad Infinity TF700T was introduced and suddenly the Prime looked less compared to this? Well I was one of them and decided to return that item for that reason and others as well. I returned the Prime because the 1280by800 resolution looked bad compared to the Pad's 1920by1200 monster resolution, the WiFi and the GPS had so many problems. I'll admit I could live w/o the GPS not functioning correctly but the WiFi needed to be fixed as there was no excuse for that not working 100%.

Here 7 months later we have the Pad Infinity. Full HD screen with super IPS+ mode, fastest quad core processor available right now, 1GB of DDR3 ram, and a slim design that rivals the iPad's. So is this the best Android Tablet on the market right now? In my opinion, yes it is. The Nexus 7 is the best 7inch tablet, and this is the best 10.1 inch one. Acer has their Full HD Android on the market right now, but that processor is clocked at 1.3GHZ and to be honest I have heard many people say that device is sluggish for a quad core device. Granted that does cost $50 less but for an extra $50 for the Infinity it is worth it. I am not going to get into the specifics of the Infinity as Amazon has them listed, but this device really sets the bar for Android Tablets. The screen is fantastic and when you see it in hand, you will be in awe. The slimness feels great in the hand and it is light like the Prime so that area is covered. The WiFi and GPS work 110%. Do not worry about that at all. MY unit does not have any light bleed like others have had, and yes the browser does crash from time to time, but that can be fixed with an update or Jellybean when that comes out. If you are looking for an Android Tablet to buy in 2012, than this is it. Do not hesitate. It is a fantastic device and is worth every penny.

I own both the a700 and the tf700t, having upgraded from two a500's (which I was happy with).  I have owned the a700 since June 16th and used it up until passing it on to my girlfriend last week.  I have owned the tf700t since the 20th of July.  These are my observations:  Both tablets have touch screen issues.  The tf700t seems to have improved after a recent update.  Both displays are beautiful, both have great viewing angles, however the Asus is brighter. I do not play high graphic games on either tablet, that said, the tf700t dissipates heat better (not that I am bothered or worried about the a700's heat).  In the sound department the advantage by far goes to the a700.  Two speakers, Dolby, and slightly better placement wins out.  Both tablets exhibit lag in the browser.  I would give build quality to the a700.  It just feels better to me.  It is slightly heavier but that does not bother me.  I don't use the camera or video on either tablet; on paper the Asus has the advantage.  The Acer has the better battery life.  The Acer also came with the micro to full-size USB adapter, I had to pay $17 for the Asus adapter.  I like that the a700 has a cover for the micro SD, the tf700t does not.  I like that the a700 does not use proprietary ports.  Charge port is of the micro USB variety, the tf700t's charging port is proprietary.

Overall, I like the Acer a700 a little bit more than the Asus tf700t.  I have had no major issues with it.  I have had issues with the Asus tf700t.  Freezing, wifi connectivity (slow to connect), and the dreaded white screen off death.  Recent update did not fix those problems...happened to me before and after the update (except for White screen).  If only the Acer a700 had the higher clock speed and ddr3 RAM, it would be the better tablet for sure.  For now, I hope Asus gets on their horse and fix the issues with their tablet.

I've had my TF700 about a week now and am definitely in love with it.  The quality of the screen makes things like Google Earth an absolute dream to play with.  I do a lot of traveling, so the ability to just go to a city, look around and mark where I want to go is pretty nice.  Yes, I can do this on a computer, or my first edition Motorola Xoom, but the screen and speed of the processer flat out shines.  Its had some glitches with smoothness and so forth, but I've already gotten two updates from ASUS pushed to me.  For the most part this is as smooth as an Ipad (My Xoom never was).

Games: I really never got into android games on my Xoom, but again, the quality of the screen and processing speed makes gaming fun, even compared to XBox 360 hooked up to a home theater. One complaint, I wasn't able to get any external controllers to work on this, which was apparently possible with previous Transformers.

Movies/Pictures/Videos: This tablet true shines when playing media.  I have lots of high megapixel nature and travel pictures - this tablet allows you to see the quality of the shot.  Literally the images seem to jump off the screen.  I haven't used the camera yet, so no comment there.

Wifi: Works great, no problems, same with GPS and Bluetooth.

Cons:
Apps Unavailable: Many of the apps in the android store will not work with this.  I believe it has to do with pixel density, but for instance, I wanted to buy the NBC olympics app to see live events on my infinity.  I couldn't download that or even the score updater from NBC.  So expect many apps to flat out not be available for you.

Battery: The battery seems to die quicker than advertised.  Not sure why, I haven't been playing around with it.

Sound: The sound is OK strength, but wonder why they put both speakers together.  If I was going to knock a star off, it would be for this reason.

Bottom line, there's not a lot to complain about.

I absolutely love this, fast, thin, great screen. I love the purple color, its not outrageous, but definitely sets it apart from the sea of black and grey tablets. I got the keyboard dock and it is most definitely a great replacement for a netbook, even better than some "ultra-books"

I suggest saving some money and getting the 32GB version though, since this tablet has a micro SD card slot built in, and if you get the keyboard dock you get another full size SD card slot plus a full size USB port, so storage is not an issue at all!

I'm passing on the review of the Infinity+ from the person who wrote it.

The good:

Screen is gorgeous.  Resolution is high enough that you can hold the device in either orientation and still easily read text and navigate thru documents.

Light weight enough so you can easily hold it for extended periods.  Balance is good so you can hold in either orientation with one hand easily.

Responsive and powerful, able to chew thru the most complicated word, excel, and power point slides easily.  Plays Blu-ray movies at the original data rate.  Even plays my finished edited HD videos.

64 gigs onboard is a big jump over the previous capacities.  Micro SD slot gives the ability to interchange data easily with other devices.

USB support has finally come of age.  Can use it to mount large NTFS external hard drives for easy file transfer.  Also supports mice and keyboards for easier editing and surfing.  I've read where it also supports Xbox and PS3 controllers.

I've ran 6  hours on battery and still had 53% battery left and that was with using both Bluetooth and Wi-Fi.

The bad:

Manufacturers, pay attention, we need real functional USB ports!  They don't have to be full size but putting them in a 40-pin connector and forcing us to hang cables and dongles off is asinine because they will get broken!  Need to move the charge cable to one of the other sides or the top so it doesn't interfere with charging and using the tablet.

Need either the USB dongle or the dock to use USB devices, should have been builtin.  If I wanted a dock, I would've bought a tablet.

We need a way to connect to USB devices and charge the device at the same time!

If the device is plugged in, and you hold it by one hand, you smear fingerprints over the camera.  It helps you to point when you use the camera where's it at, but you really need to offset this.  Same thing for why you charge or hook it to the computer, you have that flimsy cable dangling down just waiting to get broken.

Price!  Can get laptops that are more powerful, more storage, and can just do more.  They are not as easy to hold or as light.

The strange:

Who is going to pull out a tablet this big in a social event and start taking pictures and video?

Android doesn't allow mounting of network drives (that I've found).  Only one external drive can be mounted at the same time.  Both work if you root the device which can void your warranty.

No AES support?  Haven't found a way to support this newer and more secure wireless connection.  Wake up manufacturers, most equipment phased TKIP out and only support AES.

Had problems on several computers and laptops running different versions of Windows and even some Linux.  Mounting the drive as a MTP will cause other external media to not be seen.  Something I've done?

I have been researching tablets since my G-tab dies 6 months ago.  I have read alot of reviews on most of the tablets out there and it always seemed that something seperated them from being great.  For example Acer's heat problems, Toshiba's light bleed, Samsung lack of a Tegra 3 processor.  Finally Asus put out the Ifinity prime that had the promise of having no wifi or gps issues and had a screen that rivaled that of the Ipad.  I pulled the trigger last week and have been using it for 5 days and on the 6th day took it back.  First off the screen is incredible but that is the only thing that seems to seperate it from other tablets out there.  The touch aspect seemed to be unresponsive at time and the web borwsing was surprisingly slow.  I updated the firmware and did a full reboot many times to see it helped but it did not.  I can not justify spedning 5 hundy for something that is just ok.  Maybe Asus will work out the kinks but for now I recommend going wiht something more affordable.

After receiving a non-functioning unit on my first try, the replacement unit is great!

Overall this is one of the best large Android tablets on the market with top-end specs, a high resolution screen, and a great design using high quality materials (metals instead of plastics). Asus also does very little to alter the stock Android experience and adds just a few helpful changes like settings and control widgets in the notification panel. Because ASUS has done little to muck up the experience, Android flies on this tablet. Very quick and smooth transitions and easy app switching with little lag, even before the promised Jelly Bean upgrade. Overall this is probably the Android to get and I think it's an amazing value.

Pros:
Very bright high res display
Impressive hardware specs highlighted by the 1.6ghz Tegra 3 Quad Core CPU.
Great design and materials (mostly glass and metal)
Lightweight relative to other large tablets
Comfortable to hold with rounded edges
Close-to stock Android experience
Keyboard dock option makes this a legitimate laptop replacement
Excellent 8MP camera with 1080P video + LED flash
Micro SD storage expansion

Cons:
Noticeable screen light-bleed
Runs warmer than its predecessor (Prime)
One rear-firing speaker vs dual stereo speakers on other tablets
Buttons are hard to feel and operate
Stock Android experience means less features and customization like you get on the Galaxy Note 10.1

I received the 64GB Amethyst Grey unit and was so excited to open the box and turn on the device. That was the end of my excitement.

After the initial set-up the Wi-Fi radio would not turn on. I turned the unit off & on several times with no success. They should have upped the ram by a gb ( NO QUESTIONS ASKED )! They put in superior hardware but leave out what needs to POWER that BEAUTIFUL screen!??? Ok, for starters, I'm not some blind fan-boy trying to boost the hype behind this thing. I'm more the type to tear it down if it wasn't worth every penny I paid for it. I have been using Android for several years and am very familiar with it's pros and cons.

I have to say, honestly, I haven't touched my laptop or netbook and have barely used my phone (for anything other than calls) since I got my Infinity (and dock.) Truth be told, I'm using it to write this review.

Display: The display on this thing is nothing short of beautiful. I've always loved the idea of watching movies on my back patio.  Unfortunately, it's been a headache-producing, eye-squinting nightmare on every tablet, computer, phone and portable DVD player I've owned...until now. I intentionally loaded it up with Resident Evil: Apocalypse (because of the many dark scenes in it) and headed for the back yard. After being thoroughly impressed with how well I could see the movie, I decided to walk around the yard with it, in the midday sun. Only then did I have to turn on IPS+ to see the darker scenes and it worked perfectly. This display renders colors very true (not over-saturated or washed out) and blacks and whites are BLACK and WHITE. Text is crisp far smaller than I'd ever be willing to spend any time reading.

Speed: I don't know what else to say but it's very VERY fast. I've loaded over 225 apps of many different varieties on it, so I'd say I've put it through its paces. Now, I'm not saying that you won't have a sluggish moment here or there. What I AM saying is that if you do, it's probably the app you're using that's to blame. A poorly written app can cause a plague of problems on any device. I have a couple of apps that I'm willing to forgive shortcomings for because of functionality they offer but I can say that their shortcomings aren't nearly as apparent on this tablet as they have been on any of my other Android devices.

Battery: If I beat it REALLY hard, I can kill the battery (tablet only) in about 6 hours. My version of beating it really hard is multi-tab web browsing with Flash turned on, switching back and forth between several other apps, installing apps, downloading from my Box.net account, playing some games, using a remote desktop client, etc. All the while running either native movies or YouTube streams in Stick It Player (resize-able, floating, video player window that renders on top of whatever app you have open.) If I use it like most people would normally use a tablet, I can easily break the 10 hour mark (tablet only.) With the dock (I'm using the Prime dock,) I get anywhere between 9 and 16 hours of use out of it.

Dock: I'm using a Transformer Prime TF201 dock because A) It has a bigger battery than the Infinity dock and B) it was about $50 cheaper than the Infinity dock. It works perfectly. All of the ports, the keys, the charging, etc. work exactly as they should. One thing is, it's a little bit tighter of a fit but all that really means is that there's less play and you have to manually slide the lock over to secure it.

Cameras: Front-facing is great for video chat (tested with Google+ Hangouts and Skype) and the rear-facing takes absolutely beautiful pictures. I'm almost willing to consider being "that guy" who uses his tablet instead of a camera.

Bottom Line: I haven't found a single thing I dislike about this tablet. It really is everything they say it is, which is rare in this day and age. I would happily buy this tablet again.

Edit: Now that I've had it long enough for the newness to wear off enough that I'm actually willing to put it down once in a while, I'm getting 12-13 hours of battery life on the tablet alone and 17-18 with the dock. Again, results may vary but I'm still at the heavy end of the usage spectrum, so I don't foresee anyone having to worry about finding an outlet in the middle of the day.

EDIT #2:For Christmas, my wife bought me a Sandisk Ultra 64 GB micro SDXC card. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009QZH6JS/ref=oh_details_o04_s01_i03
I have tested it in both SD slots and the USB port (via USB card reader) and it works in all three. Apparently there are some SDXC cards that aren't working properly with the Infinity, so I thought I should post a link to one that does. DO NOT reformat this card. It works perfectly right out of the box with the standard exFAT format it comes with.

Just got this in a few days ago and I'm loving it. The pad feels super sturdy and is very lightweight. The super IPS mode makes the screen visible even in direct sunlight, it's fantastic. One thing I noticed was how hot the pad got while I was using outside. Yes it was very hot out, but the all metal backing did not help. I'm a tinkerer. I like android, and I'd never buy an apple product for all the BS lawsuits they've done to android phone tablet OEMs. As such, I can handle roadblocks and problems with ease. Unfortunately, most can't. So here is my gripes and observances so far with the device; some annoy me, and some will just cause it to be returned for most people:

HARDWARE

1. Some complain about the top right hand corner, being able to push the glass in. I can, but very little, so that's really nothing to me.

2. The bottom left of the screen has a little light bleed. Visible when the screen is all black.

3. It doesn't seem to register finger taps as well as my HTC Sensation does.

4. The wifi keeps sleeping or something. So it keeps throwing a "No connection error" while the wifi comes back. Never had an issue like this with my phone.

SOFTWARE.

1. I go to use Netflix, and it just closes. I try to update the app, but it doesn't offer an update. Wait, the description at the play store says if I can't update it, click here to install it. It downloads an apk for me to install, thus requiring the install of 3rd party sources. Now it opens.

2. The "My Library" has a serious flaw. I can't tap on any links in epubs (same issue with the Transformer 300). That's a big show stopper. And the page animations are very choppy. So I installed FBReader instead. Then I associate any epubs I download with that.

Here's the weird part: I can't disable it to just get rid of it. And this obviously is ICS. Even on my phone previously preinstalled apps you couldn't remove can at least be stopped and removed from the app list (I know that from people who upgraded from 2.3 to 4. I don't run carrier crap and thus was in control via a 3rd party ROM since day one). Not here. Now I realize there might be a reason for it, but still.

3. Using Hotmail. The email app has no built in settings for it, nor did it work for me doing it the exchange server route. Ended up using the app. Why it isn't a non-issue like my dad's 2+ year old ipod touch is beyond me.

4. Has a newspaper app. Activated the free trial, then tries to load a newspaper. After waiting about a minute, it disappears.

There are good things about this device. Problem is, I know the average person could care less. Some of it is Asus' fault, and some of it is Google. But I have a feeling that most people (read: people who shouldn't own electronics, apple or otherwise) will get frustrated and return it.

I know that with my know how I can get it to work much better than any ipad ever will, so I like it.

UPDATE: The dock gives it a nice touch, so I upped it a star.

I owned an original Ipad, gave it to my mother and bought a Motorola Xoom, and now upgraded to an Asus Transformer Infinity.  I love it.

I have had 0 issues with build quality, it's solid, crisp, and I love the look and feel of it.

The screen is drastically better than my original Xoom.  Putting them side by side makes me wonder how I felt the Xoom had a nice screen.  The colors are vibrant and much deeper than the Xooms.

The sound isn't as good as I had hoped.  It's ok, but having the speaker on the back side leaves some to be desired.

Some of the included software is nice.  I was using Quick Office HD, but I find Polaris Office that came with it to be superior so far.  I have yet to install Quick Office HD thought to see how it'd perform on my Infinity.  Haven't really tried the Asus Cloud Storage, but I assume it works like many other cloud storage apps.

Overall though, I love it.  I am just waiting for my case to get delivered so that I can use it more often without the need of holding it.

I always think it's important to see where someone is coming from when they review an item.  My background in tablets goes as follows: GTablet --> Nook Color --> Kindle Fire --> Transformer Prime (TF201) --> Transformer Infinity (TF700).  While I haven't personally owned one, I have used each of the iPads (primarily the iPad 2).  I'm quite technologically savvy and I am pretty up to date on technology trends.

I gave the TF700 five stars after having it for five days and using it a fair amount.  I don't spend all my waking hours on the tablet, but I do like to look at it while lying in bed and periodically through the day.  While I don't believe that it is anywhere near a perfect tablet, I do feel that it is the best one, yet.  Also, rather than running through the specs that are found in other reviews, I'll focus on some of the things that I like about it and compare it to the TF201.

I had the TF201 for about two weeks.  As has been mentioned here and elsewhere, the gorilla glass isn't always properly seated on these tablets.  It bothered me enough that I eventually returned that tablet and then just decided to wait for the TF700 to come out.  When I got my TF700 I scrutinized it for problems and I have not found any so far: the gorilla glass is securely in place, there are no dead pixels and no noticeable light bleed.  When running a few apps designed for phones I do occasionally see some funny lines on the screen, but I'm not sure if that's a hardware upscaling issue or a software issue.  They are only noticeable if I look for them and they don't appear often.

The most important features of the TF700 are the speed and the screen - both are wonderful.  I'm not much of a tablet gamer (if I am going to game, I want a real gaming system), though I do enjoy casual games and I have had no issues with any games or apps slowing it down.  Even with multiple apps running in the background everything is consistently snappy and fast.  Video playback is excellent and I can easily stream full HD videos from my NAS.  In the time I have used it, I have not experienced any problems with app compatibility.  One surprising feature is how much I like the stock browser - it is very reliable and I actually prefer it over the after-market ones I've tried.

The screen is beautiful.  You have to see it to appreciate it and the viewing angle and IPS+ modes are incredible.  It definitely beats any other tablet (including the new iPad) in terms of screen.  In fact, I don't know that I really expect a better screen to come along any time soon - the resolution is more than enough for a 10" screen and everything simply looks good.

There are several physical improvements over the TF201 that I do want to point out.  The first is that the positioning of the volume buttons and the power button are better and the buttons themselves are better.  The plastic portion on the back of the TF700 has been well discussed elsewhere, but I will point out that I never notice it while holding or using the TF700 in any position.  I think the improved reception (and I get quite good wifi - much better than the TF201) is worth the trade from the all metal back of the TF201.  In general the TF700 is very comfortable to hold and handle.

One other design change that I haven't seen mentioned elsewhere has to do with the microSd card slot.  The slot itself is slightly more recessed so that the card slips completely into the device.  With the TF201 the microSD card stuck out a fraction of a millimeter which I noticed as I slid my hand along that side.  This, by the way, was with the exact same microSD card.

One thing I don't like is that the serial number is stuck on with a sticker and is not engraved/etched/embossed onto the metal.  I took a picture of it and now I'm okay if it just falls off (or I may pull it off).

A brief comment has to do with moving from the TF201 to the TF700: the app backup worked flawlessly. I put my TF201 apps on my microSD card and then was able to reinstall them without a problem on the TF700.

What I really like about the Transformer series which makes it the best tablet, yet, is the dock.  I am using the TF201 dock and it has worked great.  The colors (both grey) may be slightly different, but, depending on the light, I'm not sure I would bet the house on it (but YMMV).  What I like about the dock is that it allows me to actually do some productive things with the TF700.  Unlike other tablets, this keyboard really lets it act like a netbook and its great for getting through some email (I use the tablet edition of TouchDown).  It's great to have the extra battery life if I ever need it (which is doubtful as this is not my primary means of consuming electronic media) but what I really like is that the tablet becomes functional for doing real things and then I can simply pop off the dock and switch to media consumption mode.  I also really like the full size SD card slot and full size USB port on the dock.  Too bad they had to choose the proprietary charging port as it would be great if you could just charge/connect to the dock with a traditional USB port.  If you don't have any need to ever use the dock to do anything productive (like write emails or take notes), then there may be other tablets which are more or less comparable to the TF700 (such as the new iPad) and the differences will boil down to personal preference.  If you're looking for the best of the best in tableting, though, get the TF700 with a dock.

Finally, to put things in perspective relating to the user experience, I'm generally one to root and customize my android gadgets.  My phones and tablets over the time I've been on Android have almost always had a customized ROM on them.  So far, though, I've felt no need to do that with the TF700.  That's because it has simply worked and worked well.  Time will tell just how well the TF700holds up and I will update this if anything important changes.  For now, if you are looking for the best tablet out there, this is the one to go with. It will surely lose its position as "best, yet", but for now, Asus is crowned the winner.

***UPDATE***
After charging and discharging the battery several times, I found the typical charge duration to be close to advertised, around 9 hours without the dock and close to 14 with.
***UPDATE 2: JELLY BEAN***
Installed Jelly Bean on this tablet yesterday (10/1/12), and I am quite pleased with the performance improvement. Everything seems smoother, and I haven't had any hangs that I occasionally experienced previously. After doing some research as to why there were hangs in the first place, I came across a chart of internal memory/storage I/O speed comparisons across many android devices. I was surprised to see that all the Asus transformers were at the very bottom of these speed tests. This would also explain the slower app launch time compared to my Galaxy Nexus phone, even after the Jelly Bean update. It pretty disappointing that Asus would cheap out on this aspect of the system, and it does seem like this is the root cause for all of the pauses and hangs in the system. A user over at XDA Developers created a modded kernel that mounts /data/ and /cache/ on an external SD card, and when using a high quality SD card (class 10), it seems to get rid of all of the problems completely. I am curious to see how this mod applied to the Jelly Bean kernel would perform. If I am successfully able to do this, I will post the results.
********

I've been wanting to purchase a tablet for a while now, but I held off on the iPads because I personally don't like iOS all that much. After playing around with a friend's original version Transformer, I did some research and decided to wait for this tablet to come out. It was definitely worth the wait.

When used with a keyboard dock, the tablet essentially replaces my laptop. I still use my desktop for any intensive applications, but this tablet is able to provide all of the mobile productivity that I need. I can easily SSH and connect to my Linux server for any programming that I need to do. Functionality wise, it's everything that I needed.

***PROS***
The build quality is superb; the tablet feels very solid in my hands. It's also surprisingly thin and light, which makes it easy to hold the tablet in one hand and read in portrait mode. The screen is excellent as well. Although it has a slightly lower pixel density when compared to the new iPad's screen, I still prefer this screen. My friend owns the latest generation iPad, so I did a side-by-side comparison to see which screen was better. The brightness on this tablet beats that of the iPad screen by quite a bit, and the 16:10 aspect ratio makes it much better for watching HD movies than the iPad's 4:3 ratio. Overall, there's plenty of real estate which many of the tablet-optimized apps make use of. Android also seems to do a pretty good job of scaling the non-tablet apps as well, so there's not shortage of apps for the device.

The performance in general is pretty snappy as well. I've been using Android 4.1 Jelly Bean on my Nexus phone for nearly two weeks now, and I remember that there was a noticeable difference when I switched over from ICS. I think the same can be said about ICS running on this tablet. There are a few places where it may seem to stutter or drop frames, but it's uncommon and doesn't seem to detract from the experience. ASUS did announce that they have plans to release Jelly Bean to their Transformer lineup in a few months, so I'm sure that the smoothness will improve dramatically with the update.

Several reviewers have noted that since the speakers are located on the backside of the tablet, it may output a muffled sound when the tablet is placed on its back. Honestly, this isn't a deal for me. When laid on a flat surface like my desk, the sound is still rather clear. If I put the tablet on my bed, however, I start to notice some muffling. It's really not too bad, and I don't see where else they could have put the speakers without more people complaining.

***CONS***
Update: Jelly Bean now installed on the Transformer Infinity. Performance is great, but I/O speed still a slight bottleneck.

The only real downside to me is that the performance isn't what it would be with Jelly Bean installed. It's still great - apps don't hang and it's generally very responsive - but I expect Jelly Bean to really showcase the speed of the Tegra 3. After playing around with a Nexus 7 which also uses a Tegra 3, I can see how amazingly fast the OS runs. Considering that this tablet uses a Tegra 3 with a higher clock speed, the device will be at least as fluid, most likely better. Asus has already announced that they plan to roll out Jelly Bean to this tablet within a couple of months, so it should be seeing an update pretty soon.

As others have said, it seems that there is no 5GHz wireless support, which is a shame. The proprietary charger that this tablet requires is also a bit of a downer for me. I would have much preferred a micro-USB charger so that I don't need to use two different charges for my devices.

Lastly, the decision to keep the amount of RAM at 1GB is a bit disappointing. I feel that doubling it to 2GB would have helped future-proof the device for a couple more years to come, but I'm pretty sure that this tablet will manage fine for the next few years.

My 8th tablet. Had original iPad, Moto Xoom, Asus Transformer, Transformer Prime, Acer, Samsung, iPad 2.

But hands down the Infinity is the best combination of lightness, thinness, performance, screen, features. Asus has out innovated Apple and the speed at which they develop new devices is stunning.

The screen is amazing! Games are beautiful and super fluid and responsive. This thing is fast!
I do not have any issue with glass being slightly out of place like others have mentioned. And as far as some of the negatives mentioned about this tablet, well I think some people are just being a little picky. Yes it is a tablet, what do you expect for speakers? Only thing I would list as a con (and really it is kind of hard to say it is a con in actuality) is that you can not charge it up on a laptop. Maybe you can on a desktop if you have more powerful usb ports, but this tablet requires to much power to charge through normal usb ports, and that is why you can not charge it as such.

I am pretty tech savvy, am also pretty picky about my gadgets. I am also kind of lazy about writing bench mark reviews and such. But I like to help my fellow potential buyers make good decisions on products when I can, because I also pretty much go by user reviews before purchasing any new toys...

Here's the bottom line, if you want a tablet, if you need a tablet, this is the one to get! If you don't have it yet, well I feel sorry for you :) If you are contemplating purchasing it, just buy it already, you won't regret it one bit, you will have the best tablet out right now.

It was worth the wait! I received this tablet a few days ago and it is simply amazing. Really sharp display (better resolution than my monitor!), great battery life, solid and attractive build, smooth interface, and fun to use. Makes my iPad friends jealous (I can tell :)).

I got the keyboard yesterday and it makes it even more practical to use. I had previously been using a BlueTooth keyboard with another Android tablet I had and it was time-consuming to set up each time I wanted to use it. With the Transformer Pad Infinity, I can just dock it and the keyboard works, and it adds hours of battery life when connected to boot! It also works well to support the tablet and tilt it at my desired angle.

Very good tablet. Light and thin. Fantastic display. Good audio. Does not get hot. Excellent readability outside. No hangs or random reboots so far.
One problem seen with wifi. I have a hidden network. One time I connected to a public network. On coming back home the tablet would not detect my hidden network. I had to delete the network configuration from the tablet, reboot and add the network again.
The tablet is mostly used for viewing movies and learning apps for children. No games. Very good for these, especially the AppLock.
Skype video calls do not work. I cannot see video from the other side. Nor can the other side see my video.

Update: (Aug 21 2012)
W.r.t Skype the person on the other side had an outdated version of Skype. After updating everything works.

Update 2 (Oct 9 2012)

This is why I keep buying from Amazon. The original tablet was a pre-order one and started showing erratic behavior - wifi dropping intermittently, no audio on waking up from sleep etc. ASUS Support was not able to help and asked that the item be sent in at my own expense for attempt at repairing it. One short conversation with an Amazon rep and in two days' time I had a new tablet. It works like a champ.
Thank you, Amazon! First time I am returning anything that was bought from Amazon. Painless, easy process and understanding support folks.

I received my brand new asus transformer tf700t ($499). Got it out of the box try to click the power on button but nothing happens. I thought may be the battery need to be charged for 8 hrs as per the manual. Charged it for an hour, while its still connected to the charge tried to start it again but nope it won't start. Called asus customer service, they said to wait till 8 hrs charge complete and call back. Now its more then 3hrs charged, the orange charge light has turned green, but still its not starting. I will wait for 5 more hrs before calling the customer service again / returning it (for now giving a 1 star)

But does anyone else had this problem? I will update later more.

UPDATE (after 8 hrs)>>>>>> After 8 hrs charging also, no luck. Asus support could not help much with soft/hard reset. Amazon was very helpful in promptly sending my a replacement. I am getting a new tf700 by friday. This one seems to be arrived dead. 5 stars for Amazon. I will update more after I get the new one.

UPDATE (after 3 days) >>>>> After 3 days, got a new tf700 tab from Amazon. This one is good. Charged it for 8 continuous hrs as recommended. This one starts up nicely. The IPS+ mode is superb. But the power saving modes are not bad either for in home use. While I am outside I use full brightness and that does work. I liked every bit of this tablet.

PROS:
1. Lightweight, very bright, smooth tablet.
2. Operation & setup is easy.
3. Do not find any lag, delay once got used to use a tablet.
4. GPS does work outside where no WiFi (used the inbuilt GPS app -Maps provided with it). Shows the turn by turn directions.
5. The photos with the camera outside / in daylight are good. I will be using this camera occasionally (or when I forget to carry my SLR).

CONS:
1. Battery life could be a con for some. Initially I got only 4 or 5hrs max battery. Then I stopped the gps, location service, and a task manager app to close the unwanted tasks. If playing a game, switch of wifi and while in sleep switch off wifi. With all these settings, now I get a good around 8 hrs of battery life. so generally charging it daily for few hrs it enough.

So I am quite happy with this product and will change the star ratings to (5 from 2).

Received my TF700 yesterday. I ordered it and treated myself to express delivery from Best Buy! Worth every penny! I have many friends who have the IPads and I once owned an IPhone. I got so tired of being so limited with IPhone products and switched to an Android phone and have been an Android fan since. That said this is my first tablet. Husband has an older Acer tablet and likesit but I wanted something as sleek as the IPad. The Infinity TF700 is a beauty and easy to use though I am still learning it. Picking up a dock today and looking into a case for it. So far I love everything.
If I had to have a complaint it would be the Owners manual which is pretty worthless :(. The other complaint would be outside in the sun like others have stated you cannot see the screen it becomes a mirror. I am wondering how one can resolve this problem if it is at all possible to do.
That said I am glad I waited for this tablet to come out it really rocks.

I'm absolutely enjoying this tablet so far! It's very thin, sleek, and fast. No complaints now thus far. There are some I/O issues, but ASUS has already recognized this and will be resolving it in a future firmware upgrade. Nothing negative to report right now after a week with this beauty! Get this tablet!

I was so impatient waiting for this tablet to come out that the very first place that had it on sale, I bought.  Needless to say, it was not Amazon.  I love Amazon for their return policy and I wish it had been them.

Thank goodness though that I finally have an Android tablet that I did not want to return within a very short period of time.  This TF700 does have its glitches, but most of it is due to Android as I have seen the same problems on every other brand.

The first thing you will notice is the beautiful screen.  What makes it more beautiful is that so far, everything is responsive.  I finally was able to swipe the screen and it changed without stuttering.  No dead pixels and the one irk is that yes, there is some very little light bleeding going on.  Very little though compared to the other tablets I have owned or tried.  Frustrating, but not enough to return it.

This TF700 is very light weight.  Much lighter than most I have ever help in my hands.  Makes my iPad 3 feel very heavy.  The weight makes it feel fragile indeed, but only time can tell how well it holds up.  My case is still on back order, so I have been treating this like a baby.

Many of the apps I use or want to use unfortunately are made for Android phones and not for tablets.  So many of them look bad.  A nicer tablet means nothing without updated apps.  Hopefully more of the apps I like to use will become tablet apps as well.  Most of those same apps are made for the iPad and look wonderful on it.

Another device with a proprietary plug for it.  Need I say more?

My volume control seems to click funny and I hope that does not become a problem some day.  I am hoping that is just the way it is, but it does not feel quite right.

With my one processor intensive game I have played for a couple of years now on Android, I get about 4.5 hours of battery life.  Which is a lot compared to other tablets i have tried.  Without playing that game and just doing other things, I got about 9 hours twice.

The TF700 is a great device. Whether or not is it worth this much is completely for you to decide.  I think it is a little on the high side, but doable.  The biggest issues are what most tablets experience: ICS.  Though ICS is a big improvement, it has some issues and hopefully Asus publishes updates in a timely manner.
Amazing product. Its the ever best tablet I've used. I assume Jelly bean will make it more spectacular. I loved the hardware specifications very much.

Take this review for what it is, just my experience, which has been quite disappointing.

This is my very first tablet, so to spend $500 when there are so many tablet options out there was not a straight-forward decision for me. After doing tons of research and reading many reviews on the TF700 I was expecting to be blown away by this tablet. Well, I was not at all.
I'm not gonna write a review on the pros of this device, you've probably read too many of them. Here's what sucked about my experience, which ended with me returning the device and ordering a new one, same model.

SCREEN BLEEDING: I noticed as soon as I turned this device on a bright spot almost in the center of my screen, about 3mm wide. It was mainly visible with bright colors, and it became too annoying. Looking for other similar spots in my screen I found two more, quite larger each (5-6mm) but not as bright. They never went away, even after reboots and factory resets. It just became too annoying.

FREEZES AND REBOOTS: Some of the first things I've done with the 2-3 android phones I've owned is run benchmarsk test to compare them with other devices. I was quite unpleasantly surprised when I saw my tablet freezing in the middle of it, and then rebooting itself, taking about 4-5 minutes to be ready to be used. Figured it was a one-off, but I tried to run test a total of about 10 times, and they always ended in reboots. Then tried to play games (frontline commando and a pinball game) and they both ended in reboots, as if there was an issue with my tablet not being to handle any graphic intensive apps.

UNRESPONSIVE BROWSING: Once I found out about the spots on my screen and the reboots, I figured I'd do some research on the internet using my tablet. Another disappointment. Scrolling down, opening new tabs, and typing in the search bar were all sluggish, to the point I wasn't sure if screen had frozen or it was just a little delay. It became impossible to do anything. Gave up and did the research on my laptop.
This all happened in one night, after updating firmware, and fully charging tablet. I also did 2 factory resets and nothing improved. I returned to Best Buy this morning without any issues. Even the guy helping me out was surprised by how long it took the tablet to startup (2-3 minutes). He didn't have to ask any questions about what the issue was.

Hopefully this is a 1/1,000,000 case, but just beware of some of the issues. Again, first tablet I owned, nothing else to compare it with, but expectations were high and not met at all by the device I received. Too bad. Just order my second device, which I hope confirms this is not the norm. Will update post as soon as device arrives.

First, let me say that this is my first tablet.  My wife owns the Samsung 8.9" tab, and I've certainly used it.  I really like hers, and I really like this one.  Honestly, I like the size of hers a little better.  That 9" size really fits well in my hands.  I am 6' tall, and have typical large hands for someone this size.  Yes, I can hold this one, but it is a little more awkward.  That is certainly not the fault of the tablet.  Just thought I'd mention it.  As it turns out, she likes the bigger size of the display on mine.

If you're looking at this tablet, you already know that it is the most feature packed, high powered android tablet now available.  It is awesome.  Everything really works as well as you'd hope and expect.  All the apps I have that indicate "HD" or "tablet ready" work very well on the TF700.  Some apps won't run, and it appears to be graphics related issues.  Again, I cannot fault the tablet for this.  The screen is beautiful, it is extremely fast, the operating system is super smooth, the fit and finish are superb.  I detect no light bleed at all, and the sound is fine.

The only things I wish were different are the speaker and the volume control.  The speaker is in the back, which I really don't like.  I prefer the speakers to be in the front, like the new Samsung tablets.  The volume control is just a little too short.  You depress the left side of this button to lower the volume, and the right side to raise the volume.  Simple enough.  However, the tactile feedback is not distinctive enough, and the two ends are close enough together to not be intuitive.  I'm sure I'll get used to it, but it could be better.

I really recommend this tablet.  It works so well.

Just a side note here, if you are looking for a case for it, do NOT purchase the "MoKo Slim Fit Folio Cover" that is supposedly compatible with both the TF201 and this TF700.  It does sort of fit, but is less than ideal.  The bottom corners of the case do not fit around the bottom corners of the tablet.  Instead it just sort of hugs the edge instead of clipping around the corners.  The two tablets are not identical, and this case was not designed for this new tablet.  Just FYI.

I bought mine from B&H since Amazon didn't have it in stock. It came 2 days ago and I heard cracking noice when held the left lower corner, as if the front & back panels were not fit together completely. Asus support said I'd have to ship to them for service, instead of a replacement. That's disappointing, first for the build quality, then the service - considering it's a brand new line and I have had it for only 2 days, I'd expect this to be a replacement.

Other than that, it's good looking thing. I wanted to love it.

Update (7/23): from comments and posts on Web, it appears this (creaking around the edges) is a known issue and has been around since earlier models. According to these, it doesn't further develop into bigger problems. I'm still a bit unsure that it would not worsen over time, since that's the spot I hold the most. Right now it creaks pretty much every time pressure changes.

7/24: regarding the TF700 tab and TF201 dock combo. While I'm waiting for B&H to restock (btw that's the reason I contacted Asus hoping for a quick replacement) TF700 for an exchange, I picked up a TF201 dock at a local BB so I could try it right there. There are active discussions on this combo. Here is my take based on my pair. (Please note, Asus website as of now states TF201 dock is not forward compatible with TF700.)

On the question of how they fit - the tab slides into the top of the keyboard, lock clicks, snug & smooth. I'd say that's pretty much perfect.

Color difference - Mine are gray. The keyboard is slightly darker. However, I think they complement rather nicely - think of it as a subtle 2-tone scheme. I probably like this better than an identical color, although I haven't seen a TF700 dock.

Whether the tab tilts back, maybe due to weight mismatch - the max open angle is about 110 deg from keyboard to tab, which is the least stable case. I can use touch screen functions gently at this angle. In addition, since I'm using the keyboard and find my other hand naturally resting on the keyboard. So I don't find this a problem either. And I don't know whether a TF700 dock would make a significant difference.

Firmware update - I updated the tab's when I turned it on initially, prior to getting the keyboard.

Cost - can't complain about the $50 savings from a TF700 dock, let alone there are questions as to what genuine differences there really are.

*** Update 11/3/13: So I decided to do an update to my review since there are still people buying this tablet.  Just my two cents.  I do like this tablet, but it has a major I/O bottleneck issue.  You can research this yourself to find out what it really means, but what it comes down to is that the device will slow down and even become choppy.  There are workarounds for it but from what I see it is only minimal performance increase.  As I stated below, when you pay over $500.00 for something, you should be able to install as many apps that you want from the PlayStore and it shouldn't slow things down.  I hear using different browsers helps and uninstalling some apps, but once again, why have a tablet if you can't have all these apps installed, especially when you get a 64 GB model like I did.  I have not rooted, and have not unlocked.  I'm over my year warranty but I'm not one to delve into modifying a device and risk bricking it.  It is still usable, and games run smoothly.  It just isn't up to par with my standards for being really slick.  It started out smooth, but moved on to being jittery and unpredictable at times.  I don't have any screen issues like others have reported.  I have moved my star rating down yet another notch because of these consistent I/O bottleneck issues that haven't been fixed and not sure they can be fixed by OTA updates.  I still like most of the things about this tablet, but I feel that today, there are probably better devices out there.  Maybe they don't have the keyboard dock with the SD card slot, or the Micro SD card slot on the tablet,  HDMI output and USB port that we all love to have, but when it comes down to it, I want a stable smooth product and this just isn't quite living up to my expectations and I am clearly not the only one who loved it at first then became disappointed after a while.

*** Update 4/5/13:  Jellybean 4.2 came out the other day, I updated and it works fine.  Please note that Photosphere is not included, apparently this is only on Certain tablets like Nexus 10.  I was hoping for it, but it isn't there.  Also, my tablet is slowing down a good bit and hiccups more than I would like.  I'm considering doing a clean slate format to see if that clears things up a bit.  Overall I'm still happy, but for the specs and money we pay, you would think it would be consistently smooth and it just isn't.  I'm dropping my rating by one star for this.  Keep in mind this is just my experience.  I hear other people say they have no problems at all.  Maybe I have just too many apps installed, but isn't that the purpose of having a tablet?  I have also installed some apps from Amazon's free app of the day, so those can slow it down too I suppose.  I may just format it and only install the stuff I regularly use and see if there is a performance boost.  If I get around to it, I will update to advise how the factory reset worked.  At times there are no issues at all, so who knows what I will do.  PS, mine is not rooted.  I've only done the push notification updates from Asus.

*** Update 1/21/13:  Thought I would update to say that I still love my non-rooted Infinity.  There have been a few updates since the Jellybean 4.1.1 came around, and so far everything is going pretty good.  I still notice some hangups here and there when using certain websites on the stock browser.  Many people prefer other browsers so you might want to try those out if the stock it sluggish for you.  The current build number on mine is 10.4.4.25 which is supposed to improve MicroSD card compatibility, guarantees that the music played in the background will no longer have lag if the user is switching between tabs in the browser, and also fixes an issue where some exported videos cannot be played to the end, a few bugs for the camera, Mio map, and movie studio app are fixed.  I have seen a few apps in the store that were not compatible with this tablet.  At this time I don't recall which ones they were, games, or Live wallpapers, or what, but I was surprised.  Most games run silky smooth, but there are some that have glitches.  Facebook is horrible on this tablet, and I'm not sure why.  Pictures are HUGE in your regular news feed.  I wish those were reduced in size unless you click on it, but that is most likely the app, not the tablet.  The latest Youtube app is no longer able to play full screen since it is missing that button, but I hear they may be working on that.  Workaround is to uninstall the updates.
Photos have been really smooth in transitions since the latest updates, so now when flipping thru, it is really snappy.  I currently have about 349 apps installed overall.  I'm sure things would run more smoothly if I uninstall some, but where is the fun in that.  I have stuff there for me and other people.  My TF201 keyboard dock works great.  It used to be a tight fit, but now it works perfectly.  I don't notice any other problems with the dock.  GPS locks on lightning fast.  I get over 31 Mbps on Speedtest.net's app.  I do notice significant decrease in Wifi thru just a few walls, but it still works well.  Mt favorite wallpaper, which I chose to buy the full version, is called GyroSpace 3D.  But Planets Pack is great too.  Battery life is great alone, and even better with the keyboard dock.  I still highly recommend this table if you like customizable options.  If you are a stickler for stability, then you may prefer the Apple line of products, but I am very content with my Infinity.
Still waiting on the official Jellybean 4.2.  Hope this helps everyone.

****Update 10/1/12:  I just received my Jellybean update to version 4.1.1 and so far so smooth.  I do notice a smoother experience while scrolling on the homescreen and in the default browser.  There are a few enhancements to the lock screen and when you press the power button in for a few second you get a few different options.  The upgrade did not delete any apps for those concerned about it.  But it is usually recommended that you backup anything you are concerned about losing.  The Gallery scrolls much more smoothly now.  Very nice.  They added Asus MyFrame in the Live Wallpaper.  Just an overall improvement so far.  And Adobe Flash seems to be working fine on mine.  I will test out more of it tonight and report any odd findings or any cool features.  I'm sure they will be posted somewhere though.  Have fun everyone!!!

****Update 8/29/12:  Sorry for the constant updates, but I forgot to include in yesterday's update that I have been experiencing an odd behavior with my Infinity.  I usually use the keyboard-docked Infinity and when done, I just close it to put it to sleep, then when I open it later, all is fine... I may do this a few times, then suddently, here and there when I open it, I get a blank black screen and I have to press and hold the power button for about 10 seconds and it restarts.  This is a little annoying when you want to open it quickly to do something, so I have no idea why it does this.  I always have it docked to the keyboard, so I don't know if that is the underlying problem or if it is something else.  Thought it was worth noting, but not enough to cause me to drop a star rating.

****Update 8/28/12:  Time for a much needed update.  So first I'd like to start by saying that I'm very satisfied with the tablet.  It isn't perfect, but it suits my needs.  I have no regrets getting the Infinity.
  I will let you know that a new problem that I have noticed is sometimes, during some web browsing, the default browser will freeze up and then just close by itself.  The good thing is that when I reopen it, it takes me right back to where I was.  Some sites that I use with a login have quirks that make it annoying, but not enough to make me mad.
  Another thing I noticed is when playing videos that are at 720p, I notice a little stutter now and then, as if it pauses for a millisecond, but the audio stays in sync.  Doesn't happen all the time, but still happens even when on the Performance mode setting.  I haven't read anything about anyone else having this issue, so maybe I have to adjust something or turn off other apps running in the background.  I thought it was worth mentioning.
  Games run smoothly, most web browsing is smooth, Youtube plays nicely.  I'm Still happy.

****Update 7/27/12:  First off there was an firmare update over the weekend.  For those that don't know, Asus is very good at pushing out updates. This seems like a big one and it only stated that it was to improve performance, but I found an online comment of the changelog, and it was a lot of stuff.  For info, look it up.  firmware v9.4.5.26 should help you find the info.
